summary: In the early 20th century, some convicts while on a road gang escape and one of the convicts is Zach Provo, a half Indian, who was sent to prison during the latter part of the 19th century. He escapes with 6 others to exact vengeance on Sam Burgade the lawman who not only captured him but was also responsible for the death of Provo's wife, at least in Provo's mind. Part of his plan is to kidnap Burgade's daughter, which prompts him to strap on his guns and go after him on horseback. Can Burgade who has been retired for sometime still have what it takes to track Provo down?
translation:
This came out during the last breath of the Western genre; Unfortunately, it turns out that it is a very small and overall unsatisfactory effort - even if it is done by veterans and on the field! At the beginning, the storyline offers nothing new: James Coburn escapes a chain gang who wants to kill the man (now retired) who brought him there - Charlton Heston. While the latter is trapping him, Coburn outwits Heston by kidnapping his daughter (Barbara Hershey). Of course, the former lawman - accompanied by Hershey's Greenhorn fiancee (Chris Mitchum) - goes hunting for Coburn and his followers, who all collapsed with him in jail.

Instead of negotiating in his case In the usual sub-Fordian style, McLaglen goes for a Sam Peckinpah approach - which he never feels comfortable with: disgusting characters, violence and sexual tension created by Hershey's presence in Coburn's lustful bunch. By the way, Heston and Coburn had previously performed together in a Sam Peckinpah Western - the troubled MAJOR DUNDEE (1965; I really have to record the restored edition of this on DVD, though I've recently taken the theatrical version in pan-and-scan format TCM UK ). However, the film is too generic to achieve the elegiac mood it clearly aspires to (also indicated by the title): both stars had the most American of all genres - WILL PENNY (1968) for Heston and Coburn with PAT GARRETT & BILLY THE KID (1973)! summary: In 2210, mankind has explored the space and found a vampiric menace, declaring war against different breeds of vampires some of them inclusive human flesh cannibals. Man was to the very ends of the earth and now he is traveling to new worlds. But with new worlds come ancient evil ... the vampires of space. And not just a handful, but whole tribes. In this movie (which I have seen as "Bloodsuckers", but I also believe as "Vampires Wars") we see what happens when the imperialist earthlings hit the imperialist vampires.

I will make this review very short because it does not deserve a good rating. The best I can say for this movie is a good cast of B-lists and upcoming stars. Natassia Malthe was Quintana and was much more attractive here than in "Bloodrayne 2". Michael Ironside is Muco and is always a fan favorite (as I say he is Jack Nicholson the poor man). And we even get Carrie-Ann Fleming as "Damian's Wife", who will now recognize horror fans as the eponymous Jenifer from Dario Argento's "Jenifer". So this movie, bad as it is, is not without a name ... but the same goes for Uwe Boll's work.

The concept of the military tracking and killing vampires in space is not necessarily a bad idea, but it's easy to go into the "cheese" section and this movie is hard to come by. Acting, especially of the vampires, is exaggerated and I found the explanations of their existence simply unconvincing. Worst of all, the vampire tribes have the names "Voorhess" and "Leatherfaces". I understand that this should be a smart reference for the horror fans, but it was not smart at all. It just sounded stupid and out of place (as opposed to the much more subtle references in James Gunn's "Slither", such as the naming of stores for lesser-known horror directors).

That's all I want to say. If you can endure a lot of cheese (that day I could not and I'm from Wisconsin) and I want to see average actors with bad costumes fight vampires in space (though "space" looks a lot like any other forest in the world) This if you can find it. Personally, I do not recommend it if you can see other cheesy vampire movies (Jon Carpenter's "Vampires") or other cheesy space movies. Or maybe some good ones. But, hey, do your thing.

summary: It's the Florida party season for heiresses, with both Oklahoma oil heiress Hortense Burke-Meyers and New York face cream heiress Daisy Appleby in the state. While nouveau riche, uncouth Hortense courts the attention, the excitement and the European bachelors clamoring after her, Daisy is more reclusive, wanting to stay out of the party scene and limelight by hiding aboard her yacht. Daisy desperately wants to marry for love, and not marry because it makes good print (and thus sell more face cream for her father), especially as she knows those European men are only after her money. So Daisy offers a proposition to Johnny Jones, a Florida Star newspaper reporter she befriends: marry her out of convenience. translation: This is an excellent example of Bette Davis' early talent. Production is above average for 1936. I can not understand why the owners of the rights to this movie did not put it on DVD. summary: A meltdown at a nuclear power plant turns a bunch of folks into lethal shambling flesh-eating zombies who go on a gory rampage.
translation:
I collect horror movies from all over and have seen the good and the bad - Zombie Bloodbath is a low budget video. Sure, the acting is bad, the story is basically a mix of all zombie movies thrown together and the quality is low on some points. What you seemingly misses is that it's still entertaining and really fun. The effects range from, as someone here has said, pasty-faced zombies that like KISS refuse to really good ones with some amazing latex works. But the reason you buy a movie with a title like this is for the blood, and this movie is fantastic in this area. The effects are very good for such a small movie. Someone called it a party movie and it is. 100% funny party movie. I've heard from various websites that this is actually a "rough cut" of the movie that was released in general, but the actual "Director's Cut" comes on DVD and it's very nice quality. I will buy it and judge for myself.

Story is basically a nuclear power plant goes bad and makes zombies. The government shuts it down, hides the story and sanctions houses to be built over it. Part of the plant is still underground and these undead come up and attack the area. A few actors are doing a great job, there are some pretty straightforward social comments that are enlightening and true, good music, great lighting, some effective tension and tons of blood and sick blood. A guy is attacked and torn from the bottom, if you know what I mean. Then his guts are pushed out of his mouth. Another guy split in half like in Day Of The Dead and they did a great job. There are a million gore gags and it's almost ALL action. I say, stop being prudish, enjoy life and get more movies like Zombie Bloodbath and Meat Market. Two great undead epics.

OK - UPDATE !!! I just set the DVD and here's what I thought:

MUCH better picture quality and for once I could see the actual director cut of the movie, and it's a much better movie. I liked it before, but now I can see what Todd Sheets actually tried with this one. And the commentary also helps by talking about sheets in detail about the film. He knows it's a trashy zombie movie, but he shows respect to everyone involved. Sheets also has a great sense of humor and modest integrity that others can learn in the film industry. The behind-the-scenes Zombie Bloodbath is also pretty funny. I found it almost as entertaining as the movie it was made for. There are some great interviews and behind the scenes footage, mixed with news about the movie from some major venues like CNN, FOX and MTV. All in all, a funny little movie that is VERY rough around the edges but still made me laugh and enjoy the ride! I've seen a lot of DV movies and some video footage, and many are pretty boring, but it really was not. While newer DV movies are technically superior, they just are not that much fun.

PS - I've heard that they are now recovering on a big budget ???

summary: Set before the events of the previous films. As group of strangers awaken with no memory to find they have been involuntarily placed in a maze containing deadly traps, a young man whose job is to watch over the Cube endeavors to rescue a woman trapped within.
translation:
I did not really like the first "Cube" movie. It was a good idea, but the annoying acting and the characters always kept me from liking it too much. I did not really feel the need to see its sequel, but when I heard that they were making a third film that would rather be a pre-history of the original. I was intrigued, thinking that maybe they would fix some of the original's problems and give us a memorable cast of characters. Well, I thought wrong.

"Cube Zero" starts well enough by introducing us to the two characters who are responsible for observing and preserving the endless maze of traps that plague people in the cube. The filmmakers manage to give the establishment of the everyday life of the two men a mysterious feeling. This raises several questions, the reason why people are sent there and the true nature of those who lead the entire operation. All of these are completely up to the viewer. Acting was a bit weak, but overall, the first half of the film moved relatively well.

As the story progresses, one of the two "watchers" begins to doubt seriously what he is doing. And later decides to help a group of people in the trap. Everything quickly dissolves into boring cheese.

Sent by the people who run the Cube program, we are introduced to the character "Jax". Together with his two subordinates play a major reason why this movie has failed. At the beginning of "Jax" he looks and speaks more like a third-rate villain straight out of a James Bond movie complete with the ever-popular "Glass Eye" that alone ruins any atmosphere created by the relatively nice tempo of the first half. What's more, it feels more like a comedy rather than a serious movie. With some unbelievably cheesy lines, the scriptwriter might get bored and he did not care. The action itself continues to deteriorate when the former "observer" hits the group in the dice. The entire interaction is painful to watch, as well as everything else that follows.

Once again, it's a waste of time for all those looking for a good horror movie.

summary: Charlie Silvercould III carries around a family curse passed down from his grandfather; death by a milk truck on his 25th birthday. With eight days left, Charlie accepts his fate and starts taking care of his unfinished business, like watering his plants and returning his library books and so on. translation: Honestly, I was disappointed with the "expiration date". Super clever title and interesting premise, but I do not think it was delivered. What was it about? The desire of the main character to reconnect with his roots? Or, more likely, it was his need to overcome his fear of death. But he was not put up as someone who lived his life in fear - it seems his life was going well, but since the doomsday approached, he should now be worried. I did not buy it. The secondary characters of the film seem to have no needs that fit into an overarching story. They all did their thing and ran parallel to the main character. Even what was treated as a "curse" looked more like a coincidence. Who cursed the family? Why? When? After all, why was not he planning to stay in his flat all day on his birthday? These are my reviews, but I liked the shots from Seattle, the camera was beautiful, the acting was good in those times when it was not outstanding.

Carl Panzram lived an amazing life scribbling his memoirs on scraps of paper for possibly the only person who ever did anything selfless for him. The book "Panzram: A Journal of Murder" by Thomas E. When Panzram grew big and strong, he tried to take revenge for the wrongs he had done in South America, Europe, and Africa, and it did not matter which people he raped, robbed, or murdered because we were all worthless.

summary: When the villagers of Klineschloss start dying of blood loss, the town fathers suspect a resurgence of vampirism. translation:
Mysterious murders in a European village seem to be the result of THE VAMPIRE BAT horde plaguing the frightened community.

This surprisingly effective little thriller was created by Majestic Pictures, one of Hollywood's Poverty Row studios. Even though the possible explanation for the heinous crimes is quite ridiculous and is not. With proper land development, the movie can boast of a good cast. Grave Lionel Atwill gives another of his typical accomplishments, this time as a doctor conducting scientific research in an old castle. Beautiful Fay Wray plays his assistant in a role that requires her to do little more than look lovable and alarmed. Dour Melvyn Douglas appears as the stunned police inspector who happens to be Miss Wray's friend.

Maude Eburne, who could be extremely funny given the right situation, steals most of her scenes as Miss Wray's hypochondriacal aunt. Senior Lionel Belmore plays the frightened mayor of the village. And the little Dwight Frye, who will always be remembered for his weird roles in the FRANKENSTEIN and Dracula movies, is most effective as a batsman.

summary: Meg and Charles Wallace are aided by Calvin and three interesting women, Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit, and Mrs. Who in the search for their father who disappeared during an experiment he was working on for the government. Their travels take them around the universe to a place unlike any other. They must learn to trust each other and to understand that everyone is different.
translation:
I have loved this book since my 5th grade teacher read it in our class many years ago. And I have read it in each of my grades 3 and 5 for the last 18 years of my teaching. Allegedly, a movie had been made in the past, but I could never find it. Well, my students and I were all so excited when we heard that Disney had brought Madeline L'Engles excellent book to the screen.

When I saw the movie, I had the greatest hopes. As the movie progressed I became increasingly discouraged. They had botched it badly! I have never been so disappointed with a favorite book-to-film adaptation. I understand that movies can not stick to a book, but they do not have to change things for their own sake! Most, if not all, deviations from the book were completely unnecessary!

At first, I kept my opinion to myself and have just listened to my students discussing the film. Well, it was not just me. Almost everyone felt the same - cheated out of the great story Madeline L'Engle had skilfully created!

Why, they wondered, did Aunt Beast look like Chewbacca from the Star Wars movie? Why could not Calvin's hair be red? Why did not woman have the right "witch-like" outfit that was such a smart game on her name? Basically we all wondered - why did almost every detail have to be changed?

I've always dreamed of how wonderful a movie would make this book. I'm still waiting for this movie. This was only a time fold in the widest senses. I write to Peter Jackson and try to convince him to take over!

translation:
For the knowledgeable Beatles fan, the main value in this film is simply to sit back and seek out the mistakes, inaccuracies, combined events, omitted events, wildly exaggerated events, exuberant people, timeline errors, false quotes, wrong attire of field songs, and ( Shame) false instruments and other boners that I can not think of right now. summary: Heading home late one night after a party, Kate falls asleep while waiting for her train. She awakens to find herself trapped in the London underground, with all the doors locked for the evening. While being attacked by a co-worker who has followed her, a mysterious unseen creature drags him away and kills him. This begins a terrifying ordeal, as Kate and a young homeless couple are stalked through the dark tunnels by something dangerous with payback on its mind.
translation:
That's a good little shocker; not perfect from any part of the imagination, but tight, competent and disturbing. An excellent example of a simple idea that has been developed into a compelling 90-minute script.

The setup requires no frills, no lengthy presentation or wordy backstory; Kate (Franka Pontente), a young German businesswoman living in London, is drifting while waiting for the last subway. She awakens to feel the place as deserted, but quickly realizes that she is not alone. Someone or something is down there with her and her intentions are completely vicious. In fact, she meets several other characters in her quest for survival, including a lustful work colleague, a homeless couple, and a caged sewage worker who all add speed and substance to the plot. Somewhere in the middle of the movie, when the suspense thriller mutates into a Gore feast, it's a bit embarrassing, but nothing so cumbersome to slow down the hustle and bustle. For those of you who have weak dispositions, this will probably be a devastating ride; For those of you who enjoy a bit of well-executed carnal chaos, this should push the right buttons.

The climax of the film may be less successful than the main part of the movie, but it is interrupted with a beautiful moment of unexpected social commentary that provides a satisfying conclusion.

Some may feel a bit cheated about a clear explanation of the nature and history of the threat Kate and her allies face, but for me that was not the case. A horror movie author should not have the feeling of crossing and crossing every single point, just as an author of political thrillers would expect. There is enough evidence to give you a very clear idea of ‚Äã‚Äãwhat this evil has produced, making a detailed and conclusive solution superfluous. Preserving a certain secret is to be welcomed and reminds us that in this film the journey was always more important than the exact destination.

My understanding is the budget for this film That was minimal, to say the least, and in this case, our applause for this British horror should be louder, because at no time does one have the impression of corners cut off or effects are not delivered.

If that sounds like your kind of movie, it probably is. Buy a ticket and get on board.

summary: Four best friends, with four different personalities, have issues of their own. Deidre is fascinated by her sexuality and has many boyfriend problems. Madge is unhappily overweight and has overprotective parents. Annie boozes and does drugs, and runs away from her abusive father, a policeman. Jeanie has to take care of them and is fighting with her divorced mother. The only way to loosen up, and forget all the bad things happening in their lives, is to party and have fun. Jeanie is ready to grow up and wants to stop acting like a child. Annie is the worst of them all and Jeanie is worried about her the most. She risks her neck more than once trying to keep Annie clean and free from trouble. However, Annie's unstable behavior and flare ups keeps everyone on edge.
translation:
"Foxes" is a serious look at the consequences of too rapid growth in the 1980s. And unlike the teenage sex comedies that overshadowed it (Porky's, Fast Times at Ridgemont High), the movie stays well against time.

His topic of teenage fear is just as relevant today as it was 25 years ago, and Jodie Foster and sk8er boi Scott Baio (do you remember him?) lead a beautiful young cast that's worth watching.

The film follows four Southern California girls who move through a rootless existence of sex and drugs without parents. Teenagers spend their days in and out of school and their nights at parties, concerts or out in the street. Rarely are they at home because instant gratification is a pill, a party, or a boy.

But rather than condemning them, the film is sympathetic and accuses absent, indifferent adults forcing teens to grow up by themselves. And the charismatic cast is impossible to like.

The opening of the movie ?? a long and loving pan - sets the tone for the following. We see the girls sleeping at daybreak amidst the objects that define teenage girls, from twinkies to a picture of a young John Travola, while Donna Summer's "On the Radio" stands underneath.

From there the movie picks up speed as the girls go to school and to life. Annie (Runaway Rocker Cherie Currie) is the wild kid who lives for the next party or pill. Deirdre (Kandice Straw) is the young crazy drama queen. Madge (Marlilyn Straw) is the shy girl in her head. And Foster is the one with the plan. It's her job to keep this crew together long enough to finish high school while at the same time chasing her divorced and desperate husband in line (Sally Kellerman).

It's an almost impossible job and one that Foster ultimately fails to accomplish.

Despite his age, "Foxes" is a pleasure to behold. Dated hair, clothing and references to the Olympic skater Dorothy Hamill did not hurt the movie.

The cinematography is simply breathtaking, with breathtaking, filtered footage of the L.A. basin at dawn, dusk and at night. Giorgio Moroder adds a soundtrack from the 80's with greats like Donna Summer and Janis Ian.

Perhaps the biggest disappointment of the movie is that the young stars around Foster never broke out, like the "St. Elmo's Fire" (1985) or "Empire Records" (1995). "Foxes" shows why they should have. But maybe, like bowling for Soup's song "1985", they just hit a wall.

summary: A hip, very erotic twist on the werewolf thriller, this atmospheric horror film adds a a wickedly sexy appetite to the bloodthirsty cravings of its monster. A vicious werewolf stalks the streets of Los Angeles. Between killings, its desperate goal is to mate with unsuspecting Josie, who is unaware of her special power attracting the beast. Forced to take over an investigation involving werewolves after his partner is killed, an LAPD Detective is led to the trail of this ravenously deadly hybrid werewolf. The story of was interesting, although the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãthe bloodline in werewolves is nothing new. The subplot of a "book of the werewolf line," which had spelled some of the other characters for a while, was effective, but could have better explained what had happened in the past.

Bring in a better script and direction and I'll come back.
