But anyway ... yes the story in this movie is great, I love historical movies and Queen Victoria is very fascinating! I love all the historical stuff. Like the guy who tried to manipulate her mother. And when she ran away and met her future husband, he showed her the "new dance type" waltz. When waltz was new, it was considered a bit scandalous because the couples dance so close. Yes, her governess was like oh my god!

And also the clothes, I love the clothes. The styles are great, hoop skirts are awesome. And of course Romy always looks very pretty.

summary: Jennifer Baichwal's cameras follow Edward Burtynsky (1955- ) as he visits what he calls manufactured landscapes: slag heaps, e-waste dumps, huge factories in the Fujian and Zhejiang provinces of China, and a place in Bangladesh where ships are taken apart for recycling. In China, workers gather outside the factory, exhorted by their team leader to produce more and make fewer errors. A woman assembles a circuit breaker, and women and children are seen picking through debris or playing in it. Burtynsky concludes with a visit to Shanghai, the world's fastest growing city, where wealth and poverty, high-rises and old neighborhoods are side by side.
translation:
Edward Burtynsky is a Canadian photographer who makes art out of the few "artful" objects. Everyday items, such as boxes, boxes, metal containers, etc., which most of us at best perceive as utilitarian and dismiss as utterly aesthetically objectionable, are instead transformed into glorious works of art by Burtynsky's camera. He achieves this result by focusing on the recurring colors and geometrical patterns that seem to be ever present in the industrialized world - for those who see them perceiving enough to recognize them. Even heaps of compressed garbage can become objects of beauty through Burtynsky's lens (but did not we already know about Wall-E?). He is especially interested in photographing areas like mines and shipyards where man has already invaded nature - which might explain why sometimes even people in his paintings (ie the workers in those places) become uniformed and robotic Part of the industrial landscape.

"Manufactured Landscapes," a documentary on Burtynsky's work, has much of the feel of a "Koyaanisqatsi" because it astounds us with its colorful kaleidoscope of images and patterns. Director Jennifer Baichwal and cameraman Peter Mettler capture the essence of the original photos purely cinematographically, because Burtynsky and his assistant photograph a camera in a factory in China, a shipyard in Bangladesh and the construction site in the massive Three Rivers Gorge Damprojekt in China. With their fluid camera work, the filmmakers hit the beauty of Burtynsky's paintings point by point. In fact, the film begins with a stunning eight-minute camera shot of a Chinese factory, where hundreds of similarly dressed workers toil in perfectly symmetrical and color-coordinated rows.

The film does less Well now that Burtynsky articulates the "themes" of his work that, frankly, sound confusing, contradictory and decidedly only half-baked. But it is a purely aesthetic experience that emphasizes image and form that "Manufactured Landscapes" matters most. In the case of Burtynsky, perhaps a picture is worth a thousand words.

summary: Dr. Peter Houseman is a brilliant geneticist who is working on a serum which will stop human aging, but his colleagues don't believe in his work. When his university funding is threatened by his skeptical benefactors, the doctor takes a desperate measure to justify his work. He administers the serum to himself, but the results are unexpected and horrendous.
translation:
Ha. No doubt, Tommy the Evil is here. I do not know why, but for some reason, little children in horror movies tend to stumble as little butts. and since they are children, they will not die. because they are annoying ... well ... except asylum for terror. but these are few and far between.

At least on the movie. Can not I find this movie on DVD? surely you can! All you have to do is buy the Chilling classics DVD package! Not only will you get a $ 15 metamorphosis on DVD, but you'll also get 49 OTHER FILMS! What a bargain! pff. OK. I advertise these cheesy films. Let's just say, this movie is not worth the $ 15.

So we have a chemist. Yes. Because all chemists look as good as this guy who plays Peter. He tries to develop a serum to stop the deterioration of the body. The college he works on wants to unplug his project, so he tries it out himself. but because this is a horror movie, he sucks it up and starts and an incredibly long transformation sequence that takes almost 3/4 of the movie.

To unpack the film, he gets into a relationship with a woman. Who has a son? and she was never married! scandalous! But of course Tommy is one of the most annoying characters .... no. I take it back. He is the most irritating character. Much worse than the old crippled guy who wants to take over Peter's job and be happy about him while he's in the hospital. That's right, even as an old cripple you can still be the bad guy.

So we see Peter start killing some people in visions until he realizes that he is the one who does it and just decides to kill everyone on his way to get back to normal. In the end, however, he develops into a lizard. Yes, I do not ask. The end really does not make sense. And if you hope for a really good payout, you will not get it.

This is not a horrible movie .... it's just frustrating because of the lack of a good one. If you already own the 50s movie pack and it's next on your list, you're not for a Snoozer, but you're not in a big movie either. Just sit back, relax and eat a lot of snacks. Because this movie will not let you jump out of your skin soon.

Metamorphosis gets 4 plastic-headed heads, out of 10.

summary: Dr. Bill Cortner has been performing experimental surgery on human guinea pigs without authorization and against the advice of his father, also a surgeon. When Bill's fianc√©e Jan Compton is decapitated in an automobile accident, he manages to keep her brain alive. He now needs to find a new body for his bride-to-be and settles on Doris Powell, a glamor model with a facial disfigurement. Jan meanwhile doesn't want to continue her body-less existence and calls upon the creature hidden in the basement, one of Bill Cortner's unsuccessful experiments, to break loose.
translation:
The brain (or head) that would not die is one of the more elaborate low-budget exploitation films of the early 1960s. It is very hard to imagine how a script of this repulsive sexist could be written without the intention of self-parody. And the issues repeatedly expressed by the female lead, Ginny Leith - a detached mind kept alive by machines, I-Vs and braces - seem to confirm that the film should exploit and criticize gender stereotypes simultaneously. Shades of undervalued Boxing Helena.

The genderisms are numerous and as irritating as an army of angry ants. The dialogue is hyperbolic, overdramatic and unbelievable, and action is only OK (but not consistent). Why did I give this movie a 4? Because some thoughts have gone in clearly. I'm really not sure which point the movie actually wanted to do, but it seems clear that it's aiming for an uncommonly edgy and raw horror (without the blood and guts that today's audiences expect).

Another unique and interesting aspect of the brain is that there are really no heroes in this movie and none of the characters is particularly personable. All in all, this is a rather painful and disturbing look at early 1960s American pop sexuality, from the perspective of a woman who, despite her missing body, was kept alive after a fatal car crash. Her lover threatens to sew a fresh, high-quality body to her and force her to continue living with him. She is understandably not permeated by all this and forced to befriend a creature almost as monstrous as her friend. Oh, there are some vague references to the clich√© of the 1950s / 60s about the evil of amok, which is operated by science.

Recommended for B-science fiction fans and doctoral students in gender studies. O / W not recommended.

summary: On 24 October 1955, the hard-work geologist of the Hadley Oil Company Mitch Wayne meets the executive secretary Lucy Moore in the office of her boss Bill Ryan in New York and invites her to go to a conference with the alcoholic playboy and son of a tycoon Kyle Hadley. On the way of the meeting, he confesses that they had traveled from Houston to New York to satisfy the wish of the reckless Kyle, who is his best friend since their childhood, of eating a sandwich from club 21 and the meeting was just a pretext to Kyle's father Jasper Hadley. Mitch and Kyle immediately fall in love for Lucy, and Kyle unsuccessfully uses his money to impress Lucy; then he opens his heart and proposes Lucy. They get married and travel to Acapulco and the insecure Kyle stops drinking. Meanwhile, Kyle's sister Marylee is an easy woman and has a non-corresponded crush on Mitch that sees her as a sister. One year later, Kyle discovers that he has a problem and might be sterile and starts drinking again. The ...
translation:
WRITTEN ON THE WIND, directed by Douglas Sirk and released in 1956, is, like all of Sirk's films in the '50s, pure melodrama. Yet it is a captivating, richly-developed melodrama, and Sirk's trademark, colorful expressionism, throbbing, barely repressed emotions, symbolism, and juxtaposition of classes make this film a desirable movie.

The film opens brilliantly, with the four central characters and the plot being introduced as the credits are still rolling. Sirk uses a clever flashback to bring us into his world ... Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone are great as the two Hadley "Kids", Kyle and Marylee. He drinks and sleeps with women. She drinks and sleeps with men. Both are worth millions thanks to the Hadley oil business. Hunky but poor, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is Kyle's lifelong friend and Marylee's dream friend. Enter this dirty mess Lucy Moore (Lauren Bacall), a slender, attractive young woman who falls under Kyle's charm after taking a phone and flying over the landscape one evening. Mitch loves her too, but Kyle wins her. They marry quickly and Kyle stops drinking. But fate seems to be in the wind, and it does not take long for a sneaky Marylee (who will have "Mitch", marriage or no marriage), a stealthy Mitch, the bewildered Lucy and the sad drunken Kyle to the ground go. ...

Malone is just as wonderful as Marylee Hadley and deserves her Oscar for Best Supporting Actress. She steals every scene she's in. Stack is almost as good, amplifying the melodrama, while still maintaining subtle and quiet desperation. Hudson and Bacall are much more restrained than these two, but it's consistent with the characters they play.

So, what is all the melodrama really about? Well, many things. Stack's powerful portrait of male inadequacy and anxiety, on the one hand. Sirk surrounds Stack with phallic symbols throughout the movie - note his tiny little weapon, the oil derricks and the ultimate phallic symbol, Kyle's apparent inability to father children. Stack seems to be suffering from a massive male superiority complex compounded by his father's preference for Hudson, his sister's desire for Hudson, and his suspicion that his wife continues with Hudson. With all the wealth, Kyle Hadley still lands at the wrong end of town and buys cheap corn liqueur like a "bum."

It's about impossible dreams and letting go of them. The river where Kyle, Marylee and Mitch played when they were children is constantly mentioned throughout the movie, symbolizing Kyle and (above all) Marylee's desire for the innocence and simplicity of youth. In an excellent melodramatic scene, perfectly supported by Malone, Marylee stands by the river and introduces herself as a child, with a voice-over from Mitch telling Marylee that she will always be his girl. Here Sirk meets a big emotional accent in the viewer. Who did not dream of returning to this special place in childhood? Who has not lived on a precious memory before? Who did not want something? And Hudson's last line of the movie (yes, he gets no dialogue in the last 10 minutes, just close-ups) remembers how far "we came from the river, Marylee." Amazing.

summary: Ned Trumpet, the chief pilot of a Navy blimp, is given to weaving accounts of the fighting prowess of his non-existent son. His friendship with widow Maude Weaver and her son Jess in effect sets him up with a real family.
translation: Bunny Comes Home 'This Man's Navy' deserves more recognition than it deserves, a clever script by Borden Chase, directed by 'Wild Bill' Wellman, the movie has just the right feel for early euphoria and goodwill after the 11th World War and none of the Blind Terror that came into play a few years later. The following year, Jan opened on Broadway in 'Carousel'. Wally Beery, a bit sleepy, prides herself on becoming an ever-disbelieving Jimmy Gleason? his memories are an improvement on reality, and give Beery a Ulysses-like shadow to play against. The images of the Navy LTA (Lighter Than Air) are authentic, photographed in Tustin and Lakehurst, and the P-38 squadron is from the AFB in March. Lot 3 doubles for India, and Bunny U-Turn ?? Hare is coming home ?? is Beery giving back an authentic piece of his past, something he wanted to believe was true? Then is the future into which we turn again fantastic? Now on a larger scale, a redesigned Navy LTA with launch capabilities for a reconnaissance aircraft? how expensive, blissfully optimistic? still, "You have to believe that, that's the way you make things come true?"

summary: The paranoid registrant administrator of the Department of Public Safety Erroll Babbage is forced to an early retirement due to his abusive behavior against the sex offenders that he should monitor, and shall spend his last eighteen days training his replacement Allison Lowry. When the seventeen years old Harriet Wells is considered missing in his area of work, Errol is convinced that her disappearance is related to one of his parole sex offenders. However, his superiors do not believe on his investigations and he convinces Allison to follow him in the sick underworld of pornography and perversions trying to find the missing girl.
translation: After Chicago I gradually lost respect for Richard Gere and then came The Flock.
