summary: In 1965, Ernesto 'Che' Guevara resigns from his Cuban government posts to secretly make his latest attempt to spread the revolution in Bolivia. After arriving in La Paz, Bolivia late in 1966, by 1967, Che with several Cuban volunteers, have raised a small guerrilla army to take on the militarist Bolivian movement. However, Che must face grim realities about his few troops and supplies, his failing health, and a local population who largely does not share the idealistic aspirations of a foreign troublemaker. As the US supported Bolivian army prepares to defeat him, Che and his beleaguered force struggle against the increasingly hopeless odds.
translation:
I sat through both parts of Che last night, back to back with a short bathroom break, and I can not remember when 4 hours passed so fast. I had to psychologically pre-test for a week in advance because I have a real "thing" about directors, producers and editors who keep putting up with long quasi-epics, and by and large, I feel like 2 to 2.5 Hours is about right for a movie. So 4 hours seemed to exceed the limits of my tolerance, and I was very uncertain about the whole company. But I will say in advance that this is a beautiful one? Could I say affectionately ?? Made a movie and I'm really glad I saw it. Director Steven Soderbergh is to be congratulated for the clarity of his vision. The fight scenes are like dodging the bullets themselves.

If there is one person on the planet who does not know, Ernesto 'Che' Guevara was the Argentine physician who helped Fidel Castro overthrow Fulgencio's 1959 Cuban Revolution When I was a kid in the 1960s, Che's picture was everywhere; on blackboards, on t-shirts, on front pages. Che's image has to be one of the most overused of all times. If one relied on the famous pictures, then Che was a very handsome type, the epitome of revolutionary romanticism. Would he have been ugly, I would have wondered if he had ever been so popular in the public performance? Of course, dying boy helps.

There have already been films about Che (especially the excellent "Motorcycle Diaries" of 2004, in which the unbearably sweet Gael Garcia Bernal went on tour as a young Che through South America and saw endemic poverty formed his own Marxist politics), but I do not think anyone has ever tackled the entire story from start to finish, and this two-parter is an ambitious project. I hope it pays off for Soderbergh, but I can only imagine that immediate commercial success was not top priority.

The first film (The Agentine) shows Che Castro in Mexico and follows her journey to Cuba to start the revolution, and then the trip to New York in 1964 to join the UN turn. Cleverly shot black and white images look like contemporary films, but they are not. The second film (guerilla) returns in 1966 when Che arrives in Bolivia to launch a new revolutionary movement. The second movie is almost exclusively in the woods. As far as I can see, it was mainly filmed in Spain, but I still think it must have been pretty grueling to film. Benicio Del Toro is excellent as Che, a part of whom he seems born to play. Personally, I felt that "The Argentine" (Part 1) was much easier to watch and more entertaining in the movie sense because it is optimistic. You win; The revolution will succeed. Che is a leader in his element, a disparate gang of peasants, workers, and intellectuals in the revolutionary cause. The second part is much harder to observe due to the inevitability of his defeat. Just as the youngest Valkyrie - although a good movie - was an exercise in witnessing heroic failure, so did I feel in the second part of Che (guerrilla). We know from the beginning that he is dying, we know he is failing. It is frustrating because the manner in which the story is told is quite early obvious that the revolt of the revolution in Bolivia is doomed to failure; Che is considered a foreign invader and does not associate with the indigenous peoples, as he did with the Cubans. He persistently insists on what is frustrating to observe because I felt he should have known when to give up and move on to other, perhaps more successful companies. The movie does not romanticize him too much. He kills people, he executes, he struggles with his asthma and follows a lost cause long after he should have given up, and moves on, leaving a woman alone to raise five fatherless children.

But overall, an excellent exercise in classic filmmaking. A note; As I watched the US-trained Bolivian soldiers arrive en masse to pick up Che and his little warband one by one, it reminded me of Butch Cassidy's final. I almost turned to my husband and said it, but hesitated, thinking he would find such thoughts banal and out of place. When we left the theater, he turned to me and said, "Did not you think the end was like Butch Cassidy?"

summary: A famous psychologist, Margaret Ford, decides to try to help one of her patients get out of a gambling debt. She visits the bar where Mike, to whom the debt is owed, runs poker games. He convinces her to help him in a game: her assignment is to look for "tells", or give-away body language. What seems easy to her becomes much more complex.
translation: In the spirit of the classic "The Sting" this film meets where it really hurts ... in the heart! A primitive, proper female psychiatrist, hungry for adventure, meets the dirtiest and most cursed villains. The vulnerable doctor falls in love with the career badman and asks to be involved in his surgery. While the movie somehow moves "slowly", the climax and the end is breathtaking! You will especially enjoy how the doctor "forgives" you!

summary: Eva has just gotten married to an older gentleman, but discovers that he is obsessed with order in his life and doesn't have much room for passion. She becomes despondent and leaves him, returning to her father's house. One day while bathing in the lake she meets a young man and they fall in love. The husband has become grief stricken at the loss of his young bride, and fate brings him together with the young lover that has taken Eva from him.
translation: Famous for launching the world in Hedy Lamarr and full of frontal nudity, but it's so much more. In fact, this is one of the highlights of cinematic poetry, with some of the seminal works of 1930s art cinema, in the same prestigious group as Under the Roofs of Paris, Taboo, Olympia and even L'Atalante. It is almost silent, relies largely on his wondrous images, and also on his fantastic, symphonic score by Giuseppe Becce. It is a masterpiece of cinematography and music, yes, and also of editing, directing, writing and acting. A good 90% of the film moves perfectly. Machat√Ω seems to be an expert in the use of motifs. Maybe not as subtle as it could be, and maybe a bit overused, but the look of things like insects, lights, and horses makes the story wonderful. Fortunately, the small dialogues of the dialogue are not intrusive. They do not crawl as you would imagine. The last bit is weird, to say the least. Reminiscent of Russian silent films, we have a montage of workers. This makes little sense in the story, but it's so great that I refuse to listen too much to that mistake. Ecstasy is a film that needs urgent rediscovery. It is one of the best films of all time.

summary: Bourne is once again brought out of hiding, this time inadvertently by London-based reporter Simon Ross who is trying to unveil Operation Blackbriar--an upgrade to Project Treadstone--in a series of newspaper columns. Bourne sets up a meeting with Ross and realizes instantly they're being scanned. Information from the reporter stirs a new set of memories, and Bourne must finally, ultimately, uncover his dark past whilst dodging The Company's best efforts in trying to eradicate him.
translation:
This is the first 10 out of 10 I have given to any movie. What made this movie so good for me? Constant action - there are no slow parts, good action, clever writing. I also liked the style of shooting, where the shaking and the different angles just made me feel part of the scene. I liked the first two Bourne movies, but I loved them.

Attention - after watching this movie, you'll be full of adrenaline and you might want to calm down before driving your car!

summary: Dublin, 1920. Gypo Nolan, strong but none too bright, has been ousted from the rebel organization and is starving. When he finds that his equally destitute sweetheart Katie has been reduced to prostitution, he succumbs to temptation and betrays his former comrade Frankie to the British authorities for a 20 pound reward. In the course of one gloomy, foggy night, guilt and retribution inexorably close in...
translation: I only saw this movie last night on Turner Classic Movies and was overwhelmed by Victor McLaglen's idea: a "tour de force" in every sense. The atmosphere of Dublin in 1922, which was evoked by film and production design, was a foretaste of techniques used in the best film noirs of the 1940s and early 1950s. summary: nan

summary: In the future, humanity has constructed several space colonies. But the corrupt Treize and his organization Oz have manipulated the United Earth Sphere Alliance into controlling earth and its colonies with an iron fist. To counteract this extreme measure, rebel colonies launch Operation: Meteor; an attempt to smuggle Mobile Suits made of Gundanium alloy to earth to combat the corruption and free earth and the colonies from Oz's control. One of these "Gundams" is piloted by Heero Yuy, who is shot down and is forced to blend in to enemy society. Now up against social issues with a girl named Relena and Oz and its puppets, Heero must unite with other rebels and save his people.
translation:
How I got this: When I watched this series on Cartoon Network, I have to say that I've never seen anything like that, and it was the best. It had a lot of exploding action that will knock you out of the game. And of course the title songs "Just Communication" and "Rhythm Emotions" were the best.

Characters and Gundams: My favorite characters in the series were: Heero, Duo, Relena, Treize, Lady Und, Noin and Zechs. My favorite Gundams in the show I liked the most are Wing Zero and Epyon, and of course the Altron and Deathscythe I and II.

Show: Whatever this series tells us In real life wars are very hard and we can sometimes win or lose. But peace can be hard to come by, and I believe the Gundam pilots are doing the right thing and trying to achieve world peace.

But this show is really the best of the best. If you come to this review after seeing this show, watch the movie Endless Waltz.

summary: THE PERVERT'S GUIDE TO CINEMA takes the viewer on an exhilarating ride through some of the greatest movies ever made. Serving as presenter and guide is the charismatic Slavoj Zizek, acclaimed philosopher and psychoanalyst. With his engaging and passionate approach to thinking, Zizek delves into the hidden language of cinema, uncovering what movies can tell us about ourselves. Whether he is untangling the famously baffling films of David Lynch, or overturning everything you thought you knew about Hitchcock, Zizek illuminates the screen with his passion, intellect, and unfailing sense of humour. THE PERVERT'S GUIDE TO CINEMA cuts its cloth from the very world of the movies it discusses; by shooting at original locations and from replica sets it creates the uncanny illusion that Zizek is speaking from 'within' the films themselves. Together the three parts construct a compelling dialectic of ideas. Described by The Times in London as 'the woman helming this Freudian inquest,' director ...

Zizek is a powerful writer with his work, and brings it with a clarity that reminds you why we watch movies first to be entertained safely, but also to have that real experience of sitting and having something up there, as he put it, looking into a toilet true one of the greatest films about cinema, and in such a gorgeous close analysis of how Freud works into films about desire, the ego / super ego / ego and the supernatural in the imagination that you may never see. ..our distribution is finally coming, if only on the smallest levels.

summary: A German spy carrying information that will reveal the target of Operation Overlord becomes involved with the wife of a crippled man on an isolated island off the Scottish coast while he waits to be picked up.
translation:
To make a good movie, you need either excellent actors or an excellent director. You need at least one of them. In this bottleneck we have none.

I do not even remember the name of the director. He did not have to do much in his career. I like Donald Sutherland a lot, but he can not be the lead actor in a movie. He falls short. summary: A group of childhood friends, now in their thirties, reunite at Camp Tamakwa. Only a few of the original campers show up, but they still have a good time reminiscing. The people share experiences and grow while at the camp. They are dismayed to discover that the camp's owner, Unca Lou, is going to close the camp down.
translation: This movie is by far one of my favorites. summary: Tax collector Lorenzo Charlton comes to the Larkins' farm to ask why Pop Larkins hasn't paid his back taxes. Charlton has to stay for a day to try to estimate the income from the farm, but it isn't easy to calculate when the farmer has such a lovely daughter, Mariette...
translation: A well-groomed comedy by I. R. S.
