If someone offers to see it, you need your rest

summary: Ten years in the life of Abraham Lincoln, before he became known to his nation and the world. He moves from a Kentucky cabin to Springfield, Illinois, to begin his law practice. He defends two men accused of murder in a political brawl, suffers the death of his girlfriend Ann, courts his future wife Mary Todd, and agrees to go into politics.
translation: It is noteworthy that for "Young Mr. Lincoln" supportive players Ford lesser known, other than star actors occupied. This not only enhances the film's focus on Lincoln's central role, but also gives the audience a refreshing glimpse of Lincoln as a man of his time and place, a man who, like each of us inexorably, immerses himself in the themes and feelings his time and sought his way to solve it. It's not so much through Fonda Lincoln's words and deeds, but in the faces, the reactions of the supporting players, that Ford tells the story of the formation of Lincoln's world view, the sense of place in society and community, and how people insist on it Mr. Lincoln's words and deeds responded and trusted this man, whom they had respected and respected. Give it a try: Instead of focusing on Henry Fonda, next time you see, Young 'Mr. Lincoln shifts the focus to the supporting characters - they'll be rewarded, I think, with a deeper appreciation from Lincoln and Ford. I suspect that Ford's narrative was appeased by the supporters 'reactions to Fondas Lincoln's David Lean when he staged Omar Sharif in "Doctor Zhivago", in which the supporters' responses to Zhivago report on Zhivago.

summary: An adaptation of nine stories from Bocaccio's "Decameron": **** Segment 1: A young man from Perugia is swindled twice in Naples, but ends up rich; **** Segment 2: A man poses as a deaf-mute in a convent of curious nuns; **** Segment 3: A woman must hide her lover when her husband comes home early; **** Segment 4: A scoundrel fools a priest on his deathbed; **** Segment 5: Three brothers take revenge on their sister's lover; **** Segment 6: A young girl sleeps on the roof to meet her boyfriend at night; **** Segment 7: A group of painters wait for inspiration; **** Segment 8: A crafty priest attempts to seduce his friend's wife; **** Segment 9: Two friends make a pact to find out what happens after death.
translation:
Yes, I "care" for Pasolini and his milieu, but at the same time I feel that his "decameron" is largely overrated and more than a little disconcerting. Overrated because the supposed "realism" he introduces (grinding crowds, crumbling architecture, etc.) is thrown up by the absurd and downright silly way the characters behave. In search of realism, Pasolini used many non-actors, but their glances at the deer in the spotlight and the painfully awkward line deliveries give the whole thing a terribly out of balance and contradictory feeling. And frankly, many of the toothless, misshapen people are painful to look at.

And Pasolini's "Decameron" is troubling (at least for me) because of the casual and prevalent homosexual content. Not because I am prude or homophobic (neither am I), but because the emphasis Pasolini places on homoerotic images and situations contradicts the neo-realism that he otherwise advocates, and therefore seems superfluous and forced. You can almost hear him say "Ooh - I have to put a sweet, naked boy in this scene!" It sometimes seems that Pasolini is trying to play the homosexual angle in order to nip the critics, and sometimes because he enjoys this aspect himself, regardless of what his viewers prefer.

The incoherence of the 9 or 10 different stories in Pasolini's "Decameron" seemed to me a Pasolini storyteller failure rather than an aspect of neorealism. He seems bored with every story and so he packs them with little conviction and with little conviction. Even the last dialogues of Pasolini in the film, which some people seem to find succinctly ("Why create a work of art when you dream about it is so much sweeter?") - that just makes me wonder why Pasolini would do it Movie, if he felt like that? In my opinion, Fellini's "Satyricon" is a much better movie (and with MORE homosexual content). It is also full of bizarre-looking people and absurd situations, but it succeeds because of its tempo, direction, and strong narrative style, while "Decameron" fails on the same elements.

summary: A high school outcast who lives in a trailer with his mother finally meets a friend. He wants to ask her if they can go the next step, but then sees her kissing another boy at a party. He runs home only to find his mother having sex with a drunk. He starts yelling, but is countered by the drunk when he suffocates him and makes him look like he hung himself. The scarecrow comes in when the boy's soul is pushed into it. He goes out for revenge.
translation:
The spirit of a murdered high school geek animates a scarecrow, which then takes its revenge.

This movie really annoyed me. It has a great-looking monster, some good low-budget effects, some atmosphere, but it does manage to bridge the goodies with bad. Halfway I started to fast forward and then go through the chapters on the DVD.

The problems with this film are manifold. At first, the cast looks about thirty and yet they are supposed to be in high school. They do not believe in the result as a result. The scarecrow looks good, but not much beyond that. He says silly liners and moves in a way that's weird rather than scary. Is this a comedy or a horror movie? It's a problem that goes beyond the individual liners and builds much of the dialogue. It seems to send more of every clich√© than a heartfelt horror movie. I expect the movie is meant for a very close audience, horror fans who want to mock the genre instead of embracing it.

Despite the good-looking monster, this is a movie to avoid. Even if you get it for less than five dollars in the special items, you pay too much.

Me.

summary: An American of German descent arrives in post-war Germany 1945. His uncle gets him a job on the Zentropa train line as a sleeping car conductor. The American's wish is to be neutral to the ongoing purges of loyalists by the Allied forces and do what he can to help a hurting country, but he finds himself being used by both the Americans and the influential family that owns the railroad. After falling in love with the railroad magnate's daughter, he finds that he can't remain neutral and must make some difficult choices.
translation: Zentropa is the most original movie I've seen in years. If you like unique thrillers influenced by Film Noir, then this is just the cure for all the Hollywood summer blockbusters that are clogging the movie theaters these days. Trier's follow-ups like Breaking the Waves have gained more recognition, but that's really his best work. It is striking without being distracting and offers the perfect combination of excitement and dark humor. It is a pity that he has decided that handheld cameras are the wave of the future. It is difficult to say who has distracted him from the style he exhibits here, but it is everyone's loss that he instead went in his hard theoretical dogma direction.

summary: The warrior Deathstalker is tasked by an old witch to obtain and unite the three powers of creation - a chalice, an amulet, and a sword - lest the evil magician Munkar get them and use them for nefarious purposes. After obtaining the sword, Deathstalker joins with other travelers going to the Big Tournament to determine the strongest warrior. The false king holds the true princess in captivity, and plots to have Deathstalker killed, and Deathstalker must fight to free the princess.
translation: This is probably one of the worst movies I've ever seen, everything about it is weak and incoherent. Acting is absurd, the costumes are even more crumpled and the story is nonexistent. This "Army Row" sword and adventure movie should catch some of the success that "Beastmaster" and "Conan" had, but it gives us no reason to follow. The main character is lukewarm and dull, he can not even fight with a sword and the sword comes from the 16th century. All the action sequences are so slow and unrealistic, not to mention the castle and the terribly old-fashioned music when riding a horse. Do not even worry about this crap.

summary: Tetsuro Hoshino, orphaned by the Cyborgs, lives in a slum in the shadow of their megapolis. He steals a pass for Galaxy Express 999, and is saved by a mysterious woman called Maitre, a living image of his mother who had been killed by the Cyborgs. Wearing a special pendant, he sets out for Andromeda where he can obtain eternal life and avenge his parents' death. On his odyssey, he meets a gallery of fantastic characters that help him exterminate the evil Star of Andromeda which had been giving mechanical bodies to rich human beings.
translation: This early anime movie was a pretty good movie I once caught on the sci-fi channel when anime was actually popular here in America and not the quota disaster that adult swimming claims is in the animated network. To be honest, it has less to do with the fact that it is less popular and more with the fact that people would rather buy DVDs now to see the episodes uncut on the internet. This movie probably did not have that many cuts and the voice was okay for a dubbed movie, though I'd rather see the original Japanese version. Americans tend to use some pretty annoying voices for kids in anything that gets dubbed. This movie shows a young boy climbing a train called Galaxy Express, hoping to make it into a planet that has the technology to turn it into a robot. He wants to become a robot to avenge his mother, who was brutally murdered by a robot chasing people for fun. In the course of his adventures, he meets friends with the various workers aboard the train, as well as a woman who resembles his late mother, a beautiful woman named Matel, who, like most women in anime films, has a secret that either really could be good for our young hero or really bad. He also goes from planet to planet as the train makes various stops and he encounters a space pirate named Captain Harlock, who appeared to be seen in his own animated series, so basically the Galaxy Express takes place in this universe. All in all a very good trip with a rather strange and unexpected ending. There would be a sequel to this, but it was not quite as good as this, but the end was a bit more final than it was here.

summary: A military machine carrying untested lethal chemicals crashes into a forest, a dead patient comes back to life in the operation room and mutilated bodies are being found all over the country. A new epidemic has broken out, the "Extreme Pestilence". Two doctors discover the epidemic and take on the hopeless fight against the living dead. The only way to kill the zombies is to destroy the brain or seperate the brain from the rest of the body.
translation: This review is based on the Shock-o-Rama video released in 2002 on an unworthy world. How bad is it? It's terrible, which is a "1" on the IMDb scale - but it's a lot worse. It's nice to imagine that original German-language printing could improve things - the English-language comedic dubbing is not funny at all - but truthfully, this is one of the worst amateur movies of all genres you'll likely see. The zombies in the movie are as slow and awkward as ever, and they do not seem to have the ability to talk or think about their next meal. But they are also smart enough to chain-saw and malicious enough to know that Western taboos on genitals will undoubtedly liven up their table talk. George Romero's Land of the Dead set a zombie nation that maintained a sense of social coherence; Here, zombies are nothing but a blank canvas for the perverted ideas of director Andreas Schnaas. With no social value and, worse, nothing but entertainment, Zombie '90 is a bad joke to anyone who wastes money on it.

summary: A group of guys capture a young girl with the intent of hurting her. They torture her in many ways, from beating her to putting a sharp piece of needle-like metal through her eye which pierces across her retina.
translation:
Many people like this series unfairly, but some of Guinea Pig's videos are pretty entertaining. Devil's experiment, in particular, has some truly fantastic effects - not just the infamous eyeball scene, but also a very realistic skin on the foot and a hand slamming with a sledgehammer are very realistic - especially for the vintage and low budget of the videos.

Let me start now for those who do not know: This film is an "extreme" torture / counterfeiting snuff movie that appeared in Japan in the mid-1980s. The story is simple: a young girl is being held by a few men and forced to brutally torture herself to see where her break point lies. This brings with it brutal violence - all realistic effects including those mentioned in the last paragraph, as well as a painful-looking application of hot oil to the trapped girl's arm and the insertion of maggots into the subsequent flaky wound.

The least effective sequences are at the very beginning of the video and consist of an unconvincing slap session, in which three men take turns banging their heads and a second sequence in which the three Men take turns kicking the girl and pushing her to the floor. These two scenes are obviously staged and diminish the realism of the rest of the process.

The actress who plays the victim of the "experiment" is quite convincing in having pain and takes a lot of it with abuse and gross things in front of the camera. Her reactions, how she strapped headphones to her head and loud noises for hours are played, are frightening. Some of the other maltreatments she takes are suspended in a net from a tree during the only time they rest. There is also a disturbing scene in which the giggling kidnappers go through their bowels and another nasty greasy scene where they spin in an office chair and are forced to drink a bottle of Jack Daniels until they puke.

If you have not seen this series. I hope I helped you decide if you want to give this episode a chance or not. 8.5 / 10 for Devil's experiment.

summary: Jerry decides he needs a vacation from the county and Tom so he leaves Tom a note and heads for New York City for some peace and quiet. However, Jerry has a number of unpleasant experiences in New York (being chased by cars and cats among other things) and it isn't long before he changes his mind and heads back home to the country.
translation:
There is a lot of good that can be said for this cartoon; The backgrounds are rich, lusciously colored and full of beautifully made art deco details. The animation complies with the usual studio standards of the time, which are undeniably higher than today's. However, I find it tiresome for a number of reasons.

The Music: It's definitely not the usual standards of Scott Bradley. Although it probably recalls a "Great Gatsby" situation, it becomes bleak, drowsy, monotone, and monotonous (repetition and monotony are not the same as Beethoven's 5th Symphony testifies). Since most people (including myself) tend to close their eyes when they yawn, there is a lot of the visual part of the cartoon that is overlooked by an average viewer.

The storyline: I'm not revealing any secrets that are not already included in the summary of the plot - land well, town bad. This is a common theme in movies, both animated and live, from that time. It is a misplaced nostalgia for a nonexistent rural idyll that today mirrors a similar nostalgia for "values" that never existed.

summary: Life couldn't get much worse for News Producer Tim O'Hara. He humiliates the one he loves, Brace Channing and ends up getting fired by her father. Then, a Martian from Mars arrives in his home. The Martian adopts the name 'Uncle Martin' and becomes friends with Tim, whilst he fixes his ship. Unaware to Martin, Tim actually wants to reveal him to the world, but can he actually do that to his new friend and 'Uncle'?
translation: I grew up watching the original TV series in the sixties and one thing I can tell you right away is that there is NO comparison. This movie was totally ridiculous with a flying suit that was alive. A Martian who has taken different forms. Special effects that looked like something a little kid would create. On the other hand, characters were developed in the original and the audience developed a feeling for Tim and Uncle Martin. The only highlight in this movie, yes, actually it was one that occurred when Ray Walston finally appeared at the end. He wore dark glasses and referred to life on this planet for 30 years as a kind of tribute to the TV series. But even the real uncle Martin could not save this turkey.

summary: For the last six years, has continued the ongoing missions of Starfleet after the journeys of Star Trek: The Next Generation, Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, and Star Trek: Voyager. More than "just a fan film", has made an improving production using spectacular special effects.
translation:
I regard myself as the # 1 fan of Hidden Frontier, as I count to a rather small group of fans who have met most of these people - well, of course not with conventions. I've seen Hidden Frontier since 2001 and I have to say that I'm still impressed by what these guys came up with.

Hidden Frontier is the brainchild of Rob Caves and his self-made studio, Areakt Pictures, operating out of the back room of his home. Not as "fancy" as the TOS-based series New Voyages (which sometimes features some of the original series actors / writers like Walter Koenig, aka Mr. Chekov), Rob and the cast and crew of HF manage to create a series that deserves to replace the gruesome experiment we called "Enterprise." The most controversial and successful story arc was the launch of Star Trek's first openly gay character, Corey Aster (who was introduced in the second season), and his search for a soulmate. Somewhere later in the series, he meets Jorian Zen, the Excelsior Trill helm officer. In the final storylines with these two characters (CAUTION: MAJOR SPOILER! Do not read if you have not seen the show yet!), Zen is linked to a symbiote in exile, causing great changes and conflicts in his relationship with Aster. Although the future is uncertain - since the last episode "Beachhead" was shown to the fans in the chatroom last night - I think this relationship will last, but only time will tell.

Gene Roddenberry has created Star Trek with the intention that the story is more about his characters than flashy space battles. For the same reason, Rob Caves created Hidden Frontier - and that has made this series as popular as it is. As the previous comment said, I wish I could give it a rating of more than 10, but it will have to suffice. Although the next season will be the last - in the tradition of the seven seasons of Star Trek: The Next Generation - I'm sure we'll hear a lot about Hidden Frontier after this final episode.

summary: A group of martial arts students are en route to an island that supposedly is home to the ghosts of martial artists who have lost their honor. A Hitler lookalike and his gang are running a female slavery operation on the island as well. Soon, the two groups meet and all sorts of crazy things happen which include cannibal monks, piranhas, zombies, and more!
translation: "Raw Force" is like an ultra-sleazy and perverted version of Love Boat, with extra kung fu fights, insane cannibal monks, white slave traders, energetic zombies and a whole lot of lousy acting. No wonder this movie was included in the recently released "Grindhouse Experience 20 Filmbox". It has everything the fanatics are looking for, blending a totally incoherent and seemingly improvised script! The production values ‚Äã‚Äãare extremely poor and the technical aspects are pitiful, but the amounts of unnecessary violence and sex can hardly be described. The film opens in a tropical sunny place called Warriors Island, where a group of sneering monks resurrect the dead for no apparent reason, turning them into kung fu fighters. The monks also buy sexy slaves from a greasy Hitler-like businessman, ostensibly because the woman meat provides them with the necessary powers to increase their zombie army. Tourists on a passing cruise ship, including three martial arts fighters, a female LA policeman, and a slew of gorgeous but dark ladies, are being attacked by Hitler's thugs for planning a trip to Warriors Island. Their lifeboat washes on the island anyway, and the monks challenge the survivors to a fight test with their zombies. Okay, how does that sound for a crazy midnight horror movie? It's not over yet, as "Raw Force" also has piranhas, wild boating orgy, Cameron Mitchell in another embarrassing lead role, and Camille Keaton from the '70s, "I spit on your grave" in a completely minor cameo. There are loads of badly realized gore, including ax massacres and beheadings, hammy jokes and bad taste romance. The trash value of this movie will leave you speechless. Of course, the background of the evil monks remains unclear and they are not even punished for their questionable hobbies. Maybe that's why the movie ends with "Continuation" and not "The End". The sequel never came, unless it's so obscure that IMDb does not even list it.

summary: A mysterious man is sent deep into the forest to investigate the bizarre behavior of the notorious Dr. Tarr. What he stumbles upon is the doctor's torture dungeon, a hellish asylum completely cut off from civilization and presided over by the ultimate madman. Innocent people have been savagely chained, tortured and stuck in glass cages, then forced to take part in gruesome games of ritual slaughter.
translation:
I read reviews on this movie and decided to give it a try. After all, I'm an open-minded guy and I've given good reviews on some pretty bad movies. When the credits ran over this one credits, I searched for meaning and something nice to say. Here it goes: "This film was graciously short." That's all I have.

Okay, okay. The sets and visuals were well done and the music helped to match the mood of asylum life, but the film was painful to watch and the endless dialogue departed from the good pieces. I laughed at this movie, but at the way you laugh at your best friend, who has just been embarrassed by a large crowd.

At the time of the "chicken dance" at the finals I had decided I just decided to stow and roll the film and drop the bodies where they fall. I do not know what could have saved this movie. The acting was not bad and it looked like it had a budget, but there was no way to make it worth seeing; not even the presence of beautiful bare breasts. Maybe I should have triggered a doobie or had to drink a lot of beer to get the full experience of the movie. Anyway, I'm not watching this movie unless I'm really depressed. Then I can tell myself, "At least I was not in Dr. Tarr's torture dungeon." I'm better than these guys. "

summary: After witnessing his mate and child's death from Nolan's hands, Orca, the killer whale, goes on a rampage in the fishermen's harbor. Under the villagers' pressure, Nolan, Rachel and an Indian sail after the great beast, who will bring them on his own turf.
translation:
Is it a coincidence that Orca was made two years after the Jaws? Orca is not exactly a "Jaws rip-off", but it's obvious he's been trying to capitalize on Jaw's success. Above all, Orca was in my opinion a bad movie, not terrible, but definitely not good, on average at most.

The plot is basically a male killer whale (Orca), having seen his buddy and his unborn calf killed by a fisherman seeking revenge. I could not bear to see this movie again. The direction of this film is bad and compared to Jaws it looks like the director, the producers and the authors are almost without talent.

As far as acting is concerned, it was very average and believable, but the actual characters are not the least bit sympathetic. The effects were fine for his time and the killer whale shots looked pretty good.

The violence is confusing, bloody and not recommended for sensitive people. The music is exaggerated and very loud, drowning the sound effects and sometimes irritating. I hated the way they exaggerated the killer whale's intelligence (killer whales do not mate with just one buddy, as depicted in Orca). Overall, this movie was in my opinion bad / bad because of the reasons mentioned above. Some people may appreciate this movie more because of the concept of revenge among animals and humans, so I will not beat this movie and I can understand why some people like it.

My rating: 3.5 / 10 (but maybe 5/10 for his concept)

summary: An Italian high school student becomes infatuated with a woman he sees outside his class window. Her fianc√©e is in jail for being involved in a radical movement, and she spends much time in court providing moral support. At first she resists the student's advances, but eventually begins an affair with him. Their situation is condemned by her family and his father, who is the woman's psychologist.

summary: When an unemployed Detroit man is arrested for a crime he didn't commit, his three children are determined to get him out of jail in time for Christmas and they decide to enlist the help of "the most powerful man in the world" - President Hoover. En route to the White House, they meet an array of colorful characters.

In the end, there are no details about how the president helped the family, and I think that's another downpoint to the movie. The movie finally brings tears, but it takes too long to come to that. The movie should not have been an original TV movie (according to IMDb), but it has the obvious fades that make it look like this? That's why I'm not sure if their information is correct. All in all, this is a simple movie (which could have been more complicated) with a happy Christmas story, but mild and without much substance.

summary: An American of German descent arrives in post-war Germany 1945. His uncle gets him a job on the Zentropa train line as a sleeping car conductor. The American's wish is to be neutral to the ongoing purges of loyalists by the Allied forces and do what he can to help a hurting country, but he finds himself being used by both the Americans and the influential family that owns the railroad. After falling in love with the railroad magnate's daughter, he finds that he can't remain neutral and must make some difficult choices.
translation: Lars von Trier's Europe is an extremely good movie. How is that? Von Trier has a very stylized way of telling a story, at least he had with Europe. For me, the whole movie was like an experience, even though I saw it on a small TV screen. The last scene is one of the most horrible scenes ever.

summary: Junior high in a time of rotary phones. Cougars have been spotted in the area. Logan is 13, the odd kid, with an active imagination and few friends. His young, single mother seems stressed. Latency is giving way to puberty, and Logan, who keeps a tube of lipstick in his dresser, may be gay or, more mysterious, transgender. He stares at himself in the mirror. translation: Wow, I hated this movie. This is less a movie than a random slideshow that leads nowhere. I'd say it's not going anywhere fast except that it's actually the longest 81 minutes you've ever been through. A second touch will render the person dead again, unable to be revived. Through his connections with PI Emerson Cod, Ned revives his childhood sweetheart, Chuck. summary: Reda, summoned to accompany his father on a pilgrimage to Mecca, complies reluctantly - as he preparing for his baccalaureat and, even more important, has a secret love relationship. The trip across Europe in a broken-down car is also the departure of his father: upon arrival in Mecca, both Reda and his father are not the characters they were at the start of the movie. Avoiding the hackneyed theme of the return to the homeland, the film uses the departure to renew a connection between two generation.
translation:
LE GRAND VOYAGE is a gentle wonder of a movie, a work deepened by the simple script of author and director Isma√´l Ferroukhi, which allows the natural scenery of this road trip story and the sophisticated spectacle of stars Nicolas Cazal√© and Mohamed Majd, to carry the emotional impact of the movie. Ferroukhis' vision is through the cinematography of Katell Djian (a sensitive mix of travelogues of horizons and densely photographed duets between characters) and the music of Fowzi Guerdjou, who manages to preserve some beautiful themes during the film while pays homage to the film proves, very cleverly expanded many local musical variations from the numerous countries of the film surveys.

Reda (Nicolas Cazal√©) lives with his Muslim family in southern France, a young student with a western girlfriend who does not seem to follow the religious direction of his heritage. His older father (Mohamed Majd) has decided that his time has come to bring his hajj to Mecca. Since he can not drive, he asks the reluctant Reda to neglect his personal needs to do him his religious duty. The two set off in a fragile automobile to travel to Saudi Arabia through France, Italy, Bulgaria, Croatia, Slovenia and Turkey. During the trip, Reda asks his father to visit some of the interesting sites, but his father remains focused on the purpose of the trip and Reda is tempted to fight his father's demands. On their pilgrimage, they meet an old woman (Ghina Ognianova) who ties to the two men and eventually has to be abandoned by Reda, a Turks Mustapha (Jacky Nercessian), who promises to lead the father-son duo, but instead causing a schism by drunk Reda in a pub and make her disappear, and countless frontier guards and customs agents delaying their progress for a variety of reasons. The tensions between father and son are rising: Reda can not understand the significance of this pilgrimage, which is so full of trials and mishaps, and the Father can not understand the insensibility of Reda to the religious beliefs and needs of the Father. At last they reach Mecca, where they are surrounded by pilgrims from all over the world and the importance of travel for Reda is overwhelming. The way the story approaches is touching and meaningful. It has undertaken a religious pilgrimage to restore the gap between youth and old age, between son and father, and between defiance and acceptance of religious values.

The visual impact of this film is extraordinary - all the more so as it feels like the camera simply "passes through" to capture the beauty of the many stops along the way, without having to upgrade them with special effects. Nicolas Cazal√© is a great actor (watch his latest movie "The Grocer's Son") and it's his carefully nuanced role that gives this film magic. Another beautiful movie from The Movie Movement, that's a tender story that's brilliantly narrated. Highly recommended.

Grady harp

summary: Chester Kent produces musical comedies on the stage. With the beginning of the talkies era he changes to producing short musical prologues for movies. This is stressful to him, because he always needs new units and his rival is stealing his ideas. He can get an contract with a producer if he is able to stage in three days three new prologues. In spite of great problems, he does it.
translation:
"Footlight Parade" fascinates on so many levels. The allegedly staged "theater prologue" could of course not be produced in any theater in the world. Take, for example, the huge pools and three-storey fountains of By A Waterfall. (Berkeley staged John Garfield six years later in "They Made Me a Criminal" and let the Dead End Kids sing "By a Waterfall" as they showered.) "Shanghai Lil" is the best Production number in the picture. It's a catalog of Warner Bros. sensibilities of the 30s. Note that the African guys were mixed with white and Asian prostitutes in the scene. In other films of that time, you would never see blacks integrated into a social scene, unless they were carriers in the train or maid in a big house. Here the blacks sit at the bar and sing with the others. I find it exciting, too, when the military dancer Roosevelt perform a "card section". There is also the NRA Eagle - the logo of the controversial National Recovery Administration's New Deal. FDR was the new president and hopes were so high that he would pull the nation out of depression. You would never see anything so worker-oriented that comes naturally from MGM. Warner Bros. wholeheartedly supported the F.D.R. Administration.

Dear little Miss Ruby Keeler has never been better when she plays the Chinese hooker "Lil". She barely watches her feet as she dances, which was one of her typical mistakes.

The pre-code stuff is fun. The "By a Waterfall" number is wonderful in this regard. The girls dress in their bathing suits in the crowded bus that races through Times Square with all the lights. The eagle eye girls hovering above the camera offer the kind of step shots that have not been seen for 35 years. In a few months, the production code would eliminate such sassy pleasures.

summary: The Cahulawassee River valley in Northern Georgia is one of the last natural pristine areas of the state, which will soon change with the imminent building of a dam on the river, which in turn will flood much of the surrounding land. As such, four Atlanta city slickers, alpha male Lewis Medlock, generally even-keeled Ed Gentry, slightly condescending Bobby Trippe, and wide-eyed Drew Ballinger, decide to take a multi-day canoe trip on the river, with only Lewis and Ed having experience in outdoor life. They know going in that the area is ethno-culturally homogeneous and isolated, but don't understand the full extent of such until they arrive and see what they believe is the result of generations of inbreeding. Their relatively peaceful trip takes a turn for the worse when half way through they encounter a couple of hillbilly moonshiners. That encounter not only makes the four battle their way out of the valley intact and alive, but threatens the relationships of the four as they do, ...
translation: James Dickey is a wonderfully descriptive author. When you read "Liberation", you are immediately transported to the lush forests of the deep South. When you look at John Boorman's film version of the book, you notice how he captures the essence of the book. The camera is as descriptive as the narrative. The characters are fully realized and the depictions are fantastic. I saw this movie for the first time in 1992, after my first year of college. I was in a phase where I saw movies that were all released within a few years of my birth in 1973. Among them were "Patton", "Papillon" and "All the President's Men"; fine films, all of them. This was easily the class of the group. That says a lot.

summary: Fanfan is a young handsome peasant. He joins the army to escape marriage and because a gipsy girl predicted he will get glory and the king's daughter as a wife. But the gipsy girl was in fact Adeline, the daughter of the recruiting officer. Once he has discovered the stratagem, Fanfan refuses to forget this dream and decides to fulfill the destiny of the fake prediction. Fantastic swashbuckling adventures in a 18th century setting, with a light criticism of the war and the mighty.
translation:
"Fanfan la tulipe" is still the most popular part of Gerard Philippe and it started the Swashbuckler enthusiasm that prevailed in French cinema in the years 1955-1965. She made Gina Lollobrigida a star (Lollobrigida and Philippe would reunite in Ren√© Clair's "Belles de nuit" in the same year.

"Fanfan la tulipe" is totally crazy, sometimes almost absurd, Henri Jeansons witty lines - full of dark irony - were probably influenced by Voltaire and "Candide." Antimilitarism often comes to the fore: "These conscripts radiate joy of life and vitality when it is necessary (joy of life and zest for life)" "It becomes necessary, men recruiting when the number of victims surpasses the survivors Fighting without the thousands of deaths you promised me, King Louis XV complains, but no matter, we'll wait for the next time. "

A voice-over annotates the story at the beginning and at the end and the story is given a rough ride: height of irony, it's a true historian who speaks!

Remake 2003 with Vincent Perez and Penelope Cruz. I have not seen it, but I do not think it had to be done in the first place.

summary: Arthur Sailes must have the courage to marry his beloved Ben Sheets and stand against the obstacles that face him. His brother, Victor, a devout Christian, plans to get himself reinstated into the church after they throw him out because his brother, Arthur, is gay.
translation:
As an actor I like independent movies, but this one is amateur at best.

The guys go to Vermont for a public service, but when the plane lands, it flies over a palm tree - that's what the directors knew Palm trees are not in Vermont? Pines yes - palms no. And the same for the wedding service - again beautiful palm grove.

Apparently, when the guys left VT, they could not get a plane ticket from a major airline, as the filmed plane is Federal Express. Did they load themselves overnight in a box? Come on people small details like these separate an indi movie from totally amateur.

The Christian brother is much more gay than Arthur with his bleached hair and tribal ribbon tattoo. The two should have changed roles.

The minor characters are ridiculous and exaggerate something terrible.

Appeal to the directors to do a gay movie, but pay attention to your locations and pour them next time

summary: Santos attempts to lead a people's revolt in Colombia to overthrow the oppressive El Presidente. When his revolt fails and he is killed, his sister Christina goes to New York to find McBain, a lieutenant Santos rescued during the Vietnam War. McBain agrees to avenge Santos' death, calls up his old war buddies, raises the necessary funds by killing a few drug dealers and threatening the mafia, then leads an attack to topple the corrupt government.
translation:
I do not have to add much to my summary, this movie is one of the funniest movies ever made with Top Gun without trying. For my part, I do not think that it should be taken seriously, if it is observed, since it is very pleasant.

I do not think it brings Christopher Walken's reputation down as his reputation was on the decline. It took Pulp Fiction to wake him from the slumber he had been in. As for Michael Ironside, he was funny in some of the big ones while he was not trying to be serious movies. Total recall, Top Gun. What I find amazing is the budget of this film. The scenes and actors and explosions etc. are pretty amazing, so obviously someone liked it a lot and was willing to risk a lot of money. Whoever he was, I like her because I love this movie!

If someone is reading, looking for information about McBain (and I seriously doubt there will be too many), then know that it's a funny movie and looked at with a smile on the face should!

summary: Jack Saunders and Bob Corby are two boxers in love with Nellie. Jack and Nellie are married but their marriage is flat so she starts to look to Bob for comfort.
translation: Hitchcock shows his already developed understanding of visuals in this early silent movie. The plot of the film, in which two boxers argue about a girl, is a straightforward drama without much to recommend. However, Hitchcock's talent can be found in his stunning use of images. Almost every shot is filled with visual symbols. Especially noteworthy is the jewelry a boxer gives the girl just before she marries the other boxer. He puts it on her arm in a clearly sexual way and with a simple movement, Hitch has shown us everything we need to know. The boxing scenes are well-handled with some interesting point-of-view shots, once again proving how far Hitchcock was ahead of his time. The film also gives insight into his later treatment of women. The object of the wishes of the boxers is driven by money and lust, not by reason or love. The only other women in the movie are either pretty party girls offering open sex offerings or old women helping to break up happy relationships. All in all, the ring is a must for anyone interested in Hitchcock's early work and his development as a visual storyteller.

summary: nan
translation: This movie has a lot of great adult stars, but it does not get you interested in an adult movie. Under all the stars you could not get your kicks from any of the scenes. The film is shot in a dream-like medieval set, which is embarrassingly cheesy. Acting is worse than Keanu Reeves, the sex scenes are as exciting as listening to your neighbor talk about his kid in college, and dialogue is the worst thing I've seen in a movie. The plot was ten times worse. I stay with the amateur route. The audio commentary was useless as it's a skin-patch, but even then that was bad. Unless you are a diehard Jenna Jameson fan, there is not much here. 4.10

summary: The infamous Zodiac Killer returns through string of copycat murders in this thriller. In modern day Los Angeles, a young man is obsessed with recreating the killings of the Zodiac Killer, a gruesome serial killer who was never caught or even identified and remains one of the most mesmerizing killers in American history.
translation:
Well, I start with the good points. The movie was only 86 minutes long, and some of them were so bad that it was funny. Now for the low points. My first warning sign came with an actual "warning" on the movie. When it started, the following "warning" message was displayed: "The movie you are going to see contains graphic and disturbing images, because contrary to popular belief, killing is neither funny nor pretty or romantic." I should have saved the 86 minutes and then switched off. The first words of the film were: "I'm in the glue factory." It was a guy talking on his phone and he was referring to a nursing home as a glue factory. I do not know why. The basis of the film is that a child is obsessed with the Zodiac killer and begins to imitate him. The budget for this movie was at least $ 50 and they must have used the cheapest cameras they could find. The acting was worse than reading directly from a script. That's what they looked like. The script was awful, and the big "twist" was that this guy who wrote a biography of the Zodiac killer was actually the Zodiac killer. Of course, they tried to show this subtly, but made it completely obvious within the first 10 minutes. Without further painful details of the plot, here were some horrible highlights of the movie. They try to compare the Zodiac killer with an "army of one" because soldiers are really just killers. Then they tried to try "Satanic Worship" by showing some guys in black hoods in a meeting. The big "computer hacker" could get that kid's address if someone gave him the kid's name and phone number. For some reason, he had to hack into the FBI to have someone talk to him. I'm not sure why he did not just look up the phone book or used whitepages.com. There was also a random allusion to 9/11 for no reason. I also learned that no matter where you are shot, blood comes out of your mouth in seconds.

So, if you like really bad acting, below-average scripts, bad camerawork and an obvious plot, you'll love Zodiac Killer!

summary: Hard drinking, burnt out ex CIA operative John Creasy has given up on life until he's hired as a bodyguard to protect nine year old Pita Ramos. Bit by bit, Creasy begins to reclaim some of his soul, but when pita is kidnapped, Creasy's fiery rage is finally released and he will stop at nothing to save her as he sets out on a dangerous, revenge fuelled rescue mission.
translation:
Basically, the film could be one of the most intriguing titles made by the two Scotts (Ridley and Tony). Let's just say it, the movie deserves its hype as one of the most stylish action / thriller of all time.

When it comes to the angry tragic heroes, Denzel Washington and Tony Scott really make a perfect duo. Both this movie and Deja Vu are better thrillers to expect. Washington felt very comfortable in the shaky cameras and in all the film's executive scenes. One would easily be connected to the feelings of his character and therefore enjoy all killing on the street. It is a success that they have created a super-dark city in Mexico with a lot of shit. One would easily be convinced of the extent of corruption in Man On Fire. I do not know what the Mexicans would think if they saw this ......

Well, let's face it again. It's one of the best in the Death Wish genre, but it also suffered from extreme violence. It is a bit annoying that they justify the actions of a vigilante by making the movie very realistic and let Denzel Washington play the "missing sheep" sort of tragic hero. In the end, they even shot the kidnapper like a documentary in his own swimming pool. I was checking on IMDb if the movie is based on real events ...... So that's for your attention, if you also find the theme of the movie is a bit spurious.

In the end I hope you would not really take this movie.

8/10 for Art Direction / Editing / Cinematographic / Denzel Washington.

summary: A young man with a talent for music has begun a career with much promise. He meets an aspiring singer, Apollonia, and finds that talent alone isn't all that he needs. A complicated tale of his repeating his father's self destructive behavior, losing Apollonia to another singer (Morris Day), and his coming to grips with his own connection to other people ensues.
translation: The movie is fine, it has moments, the music scenes are the best of them all! The soundtrack is a true classic. It's a perfect album, starting with Let's Go Crazy (which is a great party song and very fast tempo at the beginning), Take Me With U (a funny pop song ...), The Beautiful Ones (a happy ballad R & B is probably closest to R & B on this entire album), Computer Blue (a somewhat angry hymn on Appolonia), Darling Nikki (one of the funniest songs of all time making fun of Appolonia), When Doves Cry (the climax 4) U, baby, I'm a star, and of course Purple Rain (a real classic, a very decent ending to this classic album) The movie and the album are both very good. I highly recommend her!

summary: Born in Dehra Dun, temperamental and ambitious Kamna changes her name to Kamini, hires Babu as her Manager and becomes one of the most sought-after heroines in Bollywood. As a publicity stunt and to get the attention of film-maker Karan Johar, she recruits Rahul to pose as her childhood sweetheart and future husband - which result in nothing but insecurities for both - as Rahul reveals his true character and starts to blackmail her; Gia Bakshi lives with her dad, Col. Bakshi and is in love with Shiven Dungarpur, both are to get married shortly, but Shiven starts to get cold feet and decides to disappear from her life, leaving Col. Bakshi no alternative but to arrange Gia's marriage with Rohit Chhada; Gia's sister, Seema, lives in Britain, has been married to Vinay Malhotra for 15 years, & they have two children. While preparing to travel to India for Gia's marriage, Seema finds out that Vinay is having an affair with a gorgeous woman named Anjali - leaving her with nothing but ...
translation:
This is a sad movie for sad people. I sat in theaters and tore my hair apart because I wanted to break the chairs in front of me as the movie spit out one shrill scene after another. And there were people roaring with laughter, making me wonder what kind of movies these people need to see to enjoy this horse.

Nikkhil Advani has six storyless stories and no interesting characters. The script is boring, probably he was drunk when he wrote this movie. These stories have no firm hold. Nothing new, nothing to hold the audience and filled with dialogues that would have been heard millions of times. One of the stories is that this couple is unable to have sex because a series of disasters happen every time they want to. I seriously, is this story really necessary? It's not funny, not creative, it just proves that Advani has no sense of humor. Another of the stories (which was probably the only story I was interested in) is based on the infidelity of a man and also ends in a lame, ancient sati-savitri pati-parmeshwar crap. I have no idea what the Salmaan Priyanka plot was about. There was no problem in the plot because it was a conspiracy. Can not take Karan Johar's film because she has to marry Salmaan? Why can not she marry him and still take the movie? Or do Advani and Priyanaka only want to prove to the world that it is indeed true that female actors can not be successful if they are married or are not to play in films after marriage? Of course, with six actors in the movie Advani can not produce the film alone. So he uses sponsors like the Times group, who shamelessly promote their Filmfare magazines. And also a jewelery brand, which the women in the movie seem to love! I come to IMDb to give him the worst rating, and I'm shocked to see contributions that praise the movie. It just shows the sad state of Bollywood and how the star hit the fans. With fans like these, films like Salaam E Ishq will continue to be made and worse ones will probably be a hit.

summary: Wong Kar-Wai's movie about two love-struck cops is filmed in impressionistic splashes of motion and color. The first half deals with Cop 223, who has broken up with his girlfriend of five years. He purchases a tin of pineapples with an expiration date of May 1 each day for a month. By the end of that time, he feels that he will either be rejoined with his love or that it too will have expired forever. The second half shows Cop 663 dealing with his breakup with his flight attendant girlfriend. He talks to his apartment furnishings until he meets a new girl at a local lunch counter.
translation:
For those who decide whether to watch this movie or not, and read these comments for glimpse, I offer these four words first: do not waste your time! "Chungking Express" was filthy filmed, quickly beaten up and seems as if it had been designed in its entirety by someone standing in line at a Hong Kong Burger King. I can not remember ever seeing a movie with a selection of such one-dimensional characters trying to work through such a common script! It is an absurd effort with philosophically ridiculous dialogue (a man wanders into his flooded flat and offers the stunning revelation that "tears can be dried with a handkerchief, but water needs time to mop up"). The same character is also seen bearing a deep, meaningful relationship with his towels, soap, stuffed animals, dirty linen and so on. The trembling, wandering, hand-held camera work was another annoying feature that I could do without. And if that's not enough to make you puke in your popcorn, we hear the ode of the 60s "California Dreaming" from moms and dads in a very long sequence over and over the soundtrack.

Quentin Tarantino was responsible for bringing this loser through his company Rolling Thunder Productions to America, although for my life I can not figure out why a man with his talent would bother. He was known to say, "I'm so happy to love a movie so much." However, many of us hope that he will focus on satisfying his audience with more rewarding discoveries in the future.

summary: It's death-by-fear (aka scared-to-death) in this deceptively psychological thriller. The hero, Mike brings his friends to his grandparents' house for a Halloween party wherein they will all dress up as their innermost fears. Mike's fear is that he's inherited a homicidal legacy from his father. Mike's father was a serial killer who murdered his mother right in front of him when Mike was five before committing suicide. Mike's fear manifests itself in his inability to commit to his girlfriend of 4 1/2 years, Peg for fear that he will kill her too. Everything gets rolling when an ancient Indian totem wooden figure named Morty comes to life and starts killing off Mike's friends by making their worst fears come true. The ultimate confrontation comes when Mike has to face his greatest fear - his own father.
translation:
I did not see the first movie and if it does not have that, I do not feel like it.

After watching it a few hours ago, I have trouble remembering something.

From what I remember, the main plot seems to be a group of very annoying people who are sitting in a house with this dodgy old woman from Friday, the 13th, being chased by wooden board people ,

Some people die, the movie ends, I start a lawsuit against the person who sold me this movie as I want compensation for the missing time in my life.

I'll pay you ¬£ 1 to take this movie off my hands ... oh wait, I've already given it to a "friend".

summary: Incarcerated and charged with murder, David Aames Jr. is telling the story of how he got to where he is to McCabe, the police psychologist. That story includes: being the 51% shareholder of a major publishing firm, which he inherited from his long deceased parents; the firm's board, appointed by David Aames Sr., being the 49% shareholders who would probably like to see him gone as they see him as being too irresponsible and immature to run the company; his best bro friendship with author, Brian Shelby; his "friends with benefits" relationship with Julie Gianni, who saw their relationship in a slightly different light; his budding romance with Sofia Serrano, who Brian brought to David's party as his own date and who Brian saw as his own possible life mate; and being in an accident which disfigured his face and killed the person who caused the accident. But as the story proceeds, David isn't sure what is real and what is a dream/nightmare as many facets of the story are incompatible to ...
translation: This movie is another one on the list that I did not want to see. I was talked into and dragged to the theater, but I'm glad about it. I thought it was just another love story, but SOOO is much more than that. Definitely an intellectual movie, one of those movies to watch out for.

summary: A Sydney lawyer has more to worry about than higher-than-average rainfall when he is called upon to defend five Aboriginals in court. Determined to break their silence and discover the truth behind the hidden society he suspects lives in his city, the Lawyer is drawn further, and more intimately, into a prophesy that threatens a new Armageddon, wherein all the continent shall drown.
translation:
This film has a steady, insistent tempo, backed by great acting (one of Chamberlain's finest achievements) and a story revealed to us over time.

In addition, the music determines the mood and helps to maintain a restless, cautious and sombre tone.

Weir's story is enhanced by the use of aborigines, their stories and their tensions with the prevailing white population to deliver a fantastic story that is ominous.

Although they are unrelated to both the story and the genre, it retained the same feeling in me as Ursula Le Guin's "Lathe of Heaven" (1980).

"The Last Wave" is a dramatic thriller with some shocking moments. Remember, hoeing and cutting does not turn a movie into a horror movie, but is the psychological element of fear and anxiety that rests in all of us.

summary: Sexual satire about a young farmer who has had many bad experiences with women. He showers love and affection upon his pet pig, Amanda, saying she alone is worthy to be his wife. His "marriage" to Amanda causes a scandal in the community, almost mass hysteria.
translation:
"The whole world is a stage and their people are in it" - or something like that. Who the hell said the theater stopped at the orchestra pit - or even in front of the theater door? Why is the audience not part of the theater experience, including the story itself?

This movie was a great experiment that said, "Hey, the story is you and it needs more than your attention, it needs your active participation". "Sometimes we bring you the story, sometimes you have to go to the story."

Alas, no one has been listening, but that does not mean it should not be said.

summary: Brian Kessler, a journalist researching serial killers, and his photographer girlfriend Carrie set out on a cross-country tour of the sites of the killings. Sharing the ride and their expenses are Early Grayce, a paroled white trash criminal, and his girlfriend Adele. As the trip progresses, Early begins to appear more and more unstable, and Brian and Carrie begin to fear that they may have a real-life killer in the back seat of their car.
translation:
If this is to be a representation of the American serial killer, it appears as average.

A journalist [Duchovny] travels through country to California to document America's most famous murderers, unaware that one of his white-bellied Trash travel companions [Pitt] is a serial killer himself.
Rather predictable, this has its moments of action and Pitt and Lewis portray their roles well, but I would not bother to see it again.

summary: A group of childhood friends, now in their thirties, reunite at Camp Tamakwa. Only a few of the original campers show up, but they still have a good time reminiscing. The people share experiences and grow while at the camp. They are dismayed to discover that the camp's owner, Unca Lou, is going to close the camp down.
translation: A silent, sweet and beautifully nostalgic film about what it's like to be confronted with your old friends and the environment of your youth with all these memories and the problems and worries of the present with you. A movie that makes you feel good. All the ingredients are here: old jelly, rivalry, friendship and loyalty. Mischief, nocturnal fridge raids and all the other funny stuff we all know from our summer camps. All characters have the opportunity to relive this for a week, as the old camp senior retires and wants to meet the children from the golden years of the camp. They are all in their thirties right now and in the middle of their careers.

summary: Abandoning artistic ambitions, sensitive and club-footed Philip Carey enrolls in medical school and falls in love with a waitress Mildred Rogers. She rejects him, runs off with a salesman and returns unmarried and pregnant. Philip gets her an apartment and they become engaged. Mildred runs off with another medical student. Philip takes her back again when she returns with her baby. She wrecks his apartment and burns the securities he needs to pay tuition. He gets a job as a salesman, has surgery on his foot, receives an inheritance, and returns to school where he learns Mildred is dying.
translation:
When I saw that this movie was only 80 minutes long, I thought we were in trouble. Shutting down the gigantic W. Somerset Maugham novel to a movie that can be seen in less than an hour and a half seemed like a catastrophe waiting to happen. But you know, the movie is not half bad, and it even manages to withhold much of what makes the book resonate so much with its readers.

I've heard many movie freaks complain that Leslie Howard was an actor's wet noodle, and he was, but I can not think of a more appropriate one to play the role of Philip Carey could be considered a wet noodle, because Carey is quite sure. Howard plays him well, which means you want to shake him and hit him repeatedly, then get him out and buy him a spine.

Ah, and then there's Bette, as the girl with The Carey is obsessed and who's bringing his world down around him. I did not know what the charm of Mildred was in the book all over the world, and the film remains true to that detail. But as played by Davis, she becomes the most intriguing character in the story, and when she's evil and unlikable, she's the most dynamic person on the screen at all times. Davis's appearance here is associated with the change in the drama, as Brando's would have done almost 20 years later when he starred "Stella !!" playing in this little-known Tennesee Williams, and it's not hard to see why. Davis is intense to scare. She does not try to elicit sympathy from the audience, and she looks ugly and unglamorous. Her appearance, when Carey arrives too late in the movie to find her dead or nearly dead of an unnamed illness (though not much care is taken to hide the fact that it is an STD) is shocking. Of course it helps that the film squealed just before the production code came into effect; if it had been done a year later, you could bet things would have been a little different.

Yes, much of the novel and many of its most interesting parts have stayed on the floor of the cutting room and the story is really about Carey and Mildred and not much else. I found this to be the least interesting and boring part of Maugham's novel, but it is the part that gives the novel its title, and seems to be the part that readers are still attracted to as part of the filmmakers, that they have decided to adapt the novel as they did.

Note: B +

summary: Anna Zador is a secretary who's been working for 6 years at Count Willie Palaffi's bank. Every day, she rides to work on her bike and places flowers on Willie's desk, but Willie (the Budapest playboy) doesn't know that she exists. "Whiskers", noticing Anna to be a sweet and beautiful woman, believes she would be the perfect wife for Willie. He insists that Marika (Willie's personal secretary) invite Anna to Willie's costume birthday party - she does so reluctantly for she wants to marry Willie. Marika, knowing Anna is low on cash, offers to help her get a costume. At the party, everyone is dressed elegantly, while Anna is in a simple Angel's outfit. Willie, feeling sorry for her, asks her to dance, but when he sees the guests laughing at them, he makes an excuse and goes upstairs. Upstairs, Willie falls asleep and dreams that an Angel named Brigitta comes to earth to marry him. On their wedding night, Brigitta loses her wings to Willie's delight. He is less delighted when her ...
translation:
I just read a book about Anita Loos' work and the photo in MacDonald's TCM Magazine in her angelic costume looked great (impressive wings), so I thought I was going to watch this movie. I had never heard of the movie before, so I had no preconceived notions about it. I thought it would have made a nice start with Eddy as a playboy and MacDonald as a secretary he does not know exists. The scene in which she shows up at the costume party in her simple angel costume with an uncooperative halo and wings that do not stay was really adorable. I even went to the movie when Eddy went to sleep and imagine her as a real angel. But after a while, it started to crumble for me. Eddy stays "asleep" for the rest of the movie, so it's all a dream. Whatever happens from then on does not matter because he just dreams. The rest was pretty plain and pointless. I had to force myself to stick to it. And the last number, in which MacDonald changes in a crazy hallucination of the music number to the music number, was simply crazy.

Did Eddy "wake up" earlier and the original story went on, or did he really marry an angel? I think it would have been a lot more interesting. I wanted to see more of her true character.

There were not really enough musical numbers to call it a musical. The first few songs were good, but the jitterbug that MacDonald plays was like nails on a blackboard. Totally wrong for her opera voice. Nevertheless, Eddy and MacDonald still shine and show what true stars are.

summary: While working in a greenhouse, a man receives an insect bite after touching an exotic plant. Immediately, he falls ill and is taken to an emergency room where the doctors diagnose him as suffering from an unknown bacteria, and a strange parasite which emerges from his mouth as a large slimy wormlike creature. Soon, there are more cases of bacterial infection, but the more immediate problem for the hospital is the wormlike creature which after accidental exposure to a genetic growth stimulant grows to monstrous proportions and starts a reign of terror and bloodshed in the hospitals abandoned wing.
translation:
This movie is a mess, but at least not pretentious. The boxing art for the video markets it as a "fun flashback" to the huge 1950s bug movies. In fact, it is a transparent bargain rip-off of "aliens".

The producers clearly wanted to make an "ALIEN" picture, but they probably did not have much money. In fact, it does not look like they really have any money. I hope everyone who has worked on this thing has been paid.

Maintaining the groundwork - a group of people isolated with a murderous insectoid creature - and an earthbound place being inserted for budgetary reasons, I suppose. Instead of putting the film in the room where nobody can hear you screaming, they put the movie in a hospital where everyone can expose their budget. The amusing thing about "Blue Monkey" (and only one thing is amusing) is that the filmmakers did not abandon the "ALIEN" aesthetic. Although we are in a hospital, we still have an unlikely cavernous appendix where science fiction experiments are performed, in this case the venerable "growth hormone" plumbing device. The appendix also serves as a boiler room (or so), so we can get an explanation for the monster that seeks the heat. The boiler room is so large that it is clad with multi-level steel walkways, perfect to let slime drip between the slats.

The idea is that a man who works in a greenhouse is being attacked by a hanging flower from a rare imported plant that grows in an exotic location. He touches it and says "Ow," so we know he was hurt. The cut on his finger causes him to sink into unconsciousness within a few minutes, and in the hospital he gives birth to a white worm through his mouth (I assume that in an "ALIEN" image, this would be called the "oral lover"? ). The worm is isolated, but some naughty little children (leukemia patients) sneak up on it and "randomly" give an experimental growth hormone. They know that everyone is in trouble when some unsportsmanlike hospital workers are attacked by a camera on a crane, and pretty soon a maintenance man finds some compulsory cocoons just before being grabbed by a pair of semi-convincing insectoid arms. The rest of the movie is dominated by the half-offscreen monster, half hidden in the semi-darkness.

What brings us back to "ALIEN". How can you ask if a movie in a hospital can record all the flashing strobe lights that are always in the "ALIEN" movies? No problem ... a power outage (or something else) causes the electrical system to go awry, which obviously causes flashing lights in every room in the hospital and flickering throughout the movie. This also serves as a comfortable coat for the less than special effects (though the bugs look pretty neat, they do not move so well, and the baby bug looks charming like a cootie toy).

OK, so what "ALIEN" bases we did not cover ... OH, water was dripping on the walls! Check ... we'll divide the huge hospital into two and then send some of the characters through the dank, drippy basement to get to the other side. Problem solved, we now have the option of numerous "Sham Tunnel" shots. And do not forget the fog ... well, in horror movies you never need an excuse, right? OK, maybe in a hospital you do, so we'll smoke by lighting and burning a lot of things.

I have not said anything about the negligible spectacle, not that the actors are given any kind of script to follow. I suppose "Blue Monkey" should be carefree and fun, and if so, then it's a nice try, but the pieces do not come together and the movie becomes a real dilemma. See a movie titled "Return of the Aliens: The Deadly Spawn" if you want to see a movie of this type that does it right, with even less money and even marginal acting skills. This falls flat on his ALIEN.

summary: This is the story of a young boy who moves to a small town after the divorce of his parents. At a local festival, he becomes an unlikely hero when he is chosen as the "Kirin Rider," a protector of all things good. And he must lead Japan's ancient Yokai spirits in their apocalyptic war against the evil bizarre-looking monsters.
translation:
"Yokai Daisenso" is a children's film by Takashi Miike, but as expected, it is probably a bit too dark and scary for the younger ones. However, older children can eat it up, that is, if you play it in English.

The story is that of a little boy who moved in with his mother to live with his grandfather after a divorce. During a village festival, the boy is chosen as the "Kirin Rider", a great honor, but with that honor comes, of course, much danger and adventure.

Meanwhile, evil acts as a woman's hand in a white miniskirt, go-go boots and a hive hairstyle, team with a wicked yokai to counter the resentment and discarded objects of humans against her turn. And this evil has manifested itself as a flying city in the form of a monster moving toward the City of Fury itself, Tokyo. A pretty funny scene has two traitors watching the monster fly over the city ... one says, "Oh, it's just Gamera".

The young boy has become friends with Yokai, who are monsters of a kind, mostly benign, who have isolated themselves from humans, and all Yokai in Japan band together to fight against evil.

In many ways, Miike & Crew have made the Yokai movies of the late 60s and early 70s into a modern action adventure movie for (older) kids, which also combines some weird mechanical monsters that appealed to me "Transformers" reminded. The look and feel of the movie is great, the effects are entertaining, and some of the humor will just sail over kids' heads, but still older people will like it. As for adults, there is not much to like here, if you are a fan of Japanese monster movies, enjoy hell.

Cool & funny stuff, sometimes a bit dark, but maybe that's just Miike ... and what a wild ride. 8 out of 10 points.

summary: As a young girl in Japan, Nagiko's father paints characters on her face, and her aunt reads to her from "The Pillow Book", the diary of a 10th-century lady-in-waiting. Nagiko grows up, obsessed with books, papers, and writing on bodies, and her sexual odyssey (and the creation of her own Pillow Book) is a "parfait m√©lange" of classical Japanese, modern Chinese, and Western film images.
translation:
This film is about a Japanese woman who has an obsession with calligraphy on her skin.

The plot is absolutely bizarre. I do not see any "sensual" or "erotic" undertones. The plot transforms an ancient art form into fetish pornography. The scenes filmed in Hong Kong certainly portray bad parts of Hong Kong, such as the airport in the middle of the city, poor living conditions and noise pollution. Throughout the film, I keep thinking that "The Pillow Book" insults Japanese culture and the Hong Kong environment.

"The Pillow Book" is a perverted but boring movie. Stay seriously away from it.

summary: Sick of her life, housewife Nancy just wants it to be over and done with, but rather than kill herself, she hires a stranger from the Internet to do the job for her. But fate takes a strange turn when she meets her killer and the two fall in love. Of course, Nancy realizes that love and murder do not naturally go hand in hand.
translation:
As is often the case, films about self-deprecating characters usually do not provide good drama. "Download Nancy" is no exception. It is supposedly based on a true story about a woman being murdered at her own request by someone she encounters over the Internet.

The protagonist is Nancy (Maria Bello), who is married to Albert (Rufus Sewell). Albert is a successful software developer who has developed a golf game that has successfully marketed his business to various bars and bars / restaurants. Unlike most people, Albert has virtually no positive qualities (apart from his ability to succeed in the business world). Throughout the film, Albert has a grim and sullen expression on his face. He has no sympathy for his wife with all her emotional problems and resorts to upcoming prostitutes. When his wife asks about sex, he punishes her by masturbating in her presence instead.

Nancy is as much a character as a person. Not only did she have a loveless 15-year marriage, but she was also sexually abused by her uncle when she grew up (fortunately, there are no flashbacks from this back story in the movie). Her self-loathing takes the form of self-mutilation and causes her to be forced into therapy. However, she has such contempt for her therapist that no progress can be made.

Finally Nancy is so depressed that she contacts Louis via the internet. He is a kind of sadomasochistic gigolo who has sex with women to earn money while causing large amounts of pain. It turns out that Louis has two children, but he does not see them anymore (the children's mother does not want to have anything to do with him anymore).

Nancy's plan is to have painful sex with Louis first and then have him killed. There is a particularly unpleasant scene in which Louis has sex with Nancy while she cuts her vaginal area with a broken piece of glass. These scenes are shown as flashbacks after Louis visits Albert, who captivates him and hits him with a golf club. It seems Louis has a twofold plan to see Albert: 1) berate him for his treatment of Nancy and 2) enjoy the blows he receives. It takes a while for Louis to reveal Nancy's fate. First, he forces Albert to do him the favor of bringing his dog to a relative for someone to take care of in the future. Of course, Nancy's fate is that Louis eventually suffocated her to death (but he did not hesitate until he made it clear that he had some "feelings" for her). We soon learn that Louis is imprisoned for life for Nancy's murder.

What exactly do we have to take away from a movie like Downloading Nancy? Should we regret victims of sexual abuse and domestic violence? Is that the main point of the movie? Is sympathy for Nancy actually justified? I do not think so. The authors of the film create a straw man in the guise of Albert - someone so cut off from his feelings that he is the one to blame for Nancy's decay. But are people so one-dimensional in real life? I do not think so. You've come across the repugnant Louis, a man who is making a living from causing pain, and accusing Albert of neglecting Nancy. In addition, his love for Nancy (before he kills her) should show his "sensitive side".

In the end it does not matter if the filmmakers have defined where their sympathies lie the different characters in the movie. They are so anxious to tickle their audience with scenes of unnecessary violence that Downloading Nancy is nothing but an exercise in bad taste and gentle pornography.

summary: After Matt Kane leaves his wife Lara after seven years of marriage for the single, fast life that he wanted all his life after getting a promotion at work, she plots revenge against him by hiring an female ex-con and grifter, named Tuesday, to romance and bring him down in a series of encounters and plots while loyalties begin to be tested as to who is ploting against who.
translation:
A good movie, with a fine lead actress, but a terrible lead actor. Stephan Jenkins, who plays the husband, is a really bad actor. Joyce Hyser, on the other hand, is saving the movie. She is the best actor in the group.

NOTE * The first comment by the colleague who praised the movie (and wrote only ONE review according to their IMDB.com account - and guess what movie?) is obviously a plant. While the film is filmed nicely, it is by no means subtle or grand or what the reviewer used for other hypobolic descriptions.

"Art of Revenge" is a fair movie, but it's a big tease. It offers all sorts of sexual situations, but never gets away with it. Like a skin patch on Cinemax, but with all the "naughty bits" cut out.

The movie as a whole is a bit unfocused and the end and much of the third act is really a big mess. Of course, there is a twist-end, because nowadays every film needs a twist-end.

A 4 out of 10.

summary: A young American and a young English woman are kidnapped by a tribe in Africa. They manage to escape but the leader of the tribe is killed in the process. There's a whole jungle between them and civilization and chief's son wants revenge.
translation: I had seen this movie when it was released, and when I was 12 years old :) And I still vividly remember the wonderful scenes of how the heroine / heroine escaped dangers each time :) And the best feature of the movie was the representation of the villain! I think many so-called action movies have copied many "escape scenes" from this movie !! And it not only impresses me when I see such copies, it always enhances my appreciation for this masterpiece! :) The main actors did a wonderful job. The slow and realistic development of the chemistry of the heroine and heroine was extremely natural and wonderfully portrayed. As children, we felt that the love they developed b / w was very natural. The way they coped with all their trials and tribulations together was something that even made children realize the value of true love, sacrifice, and care. I recommend everyone to watch this movie if he gets a chance !! --Vijay.

summary: In the background of the rise of the International Hare Krishna movement in the 1970s, is a Montreal-based family of the Jaiswals, consisting of mom, dad, son, Prashant, and daughter, Jasbir. Due to irreconciable differences between Mr and Mrs Jaiswal, they separate, leaving Jasbir with dad, and Prashant with his mom. Eventually Prashant and his mom travel to India, leaving father and daughter behind in Montreal. Mr. Jaiswal re-marries, and brings his new wife to live in his home. Years later, Prashant has grown up to be a pilot. He has received a letter from his dad that Jasbir, who had rebelled and left home, is now located in Kathmandu, Nepal, with a group of hippies. Prashant undertakes to find his sister and hopefully get her back to the family. When Prashant lands in Kathmandu he does not find Jasbir, but instead finds Janice, who is indeed his sister with a new name. Janice has no recollection of her childhood, and is always in the company of fellow-hippies. Prashant now needs ...
translation:
Hare Rama Hare Krishna was the biggest feature film from 1971. The film was filmed almost entirely in Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal, and shows not only the theme of a broken family, but also a relationship between a brother and a sister drug and the hippie movement that made many people think that it was about the ISKON - the Krishna Consciousness Movement.

The film begins with drug scenes and informs that the dancing woman's narrator is sister. Back in time, the brother and sister happily play around the house just to hear their parents quarrel. This soon leads to a split in the family. The brother goes with the mother and the sister with the father.

Over the years, the brother goes in search of his sister and learns that she no longer lives with the father and that she has moved to him Nepal. Here, Prashant, the brother not only finds love, but also finds his sister Janice. But he finds out that she is not only in the wrong company of friends but also on drugs because she wants to block all memories of her past. With the help of Shanti, his love, the brother tries to get his sister away from all this, but has to overcome many obstacles, including humans, who dwell on all possible levels to stop him. This is a multi-cast film directed and directed by the producer himself, Dev Anand and also stars Zeenat Aman (her first film), Mumtaz, Rajendranath, Prem Chopra, Jnr Mehmood, AK Hangal and Achala Sachdev.
