summary: Herbie is a very special boy. He has the ability to predict the near future. During the taping of a show where he advises the public of his predictions, he repeatedly insists he must go home. The studio heads talk him out of leaving, but Herbie remains uneasy. He tells his audience that tomorrow is going to be the beginning of a new and different world. Human beings are going to live as they were meant to live. Has he told the truth, or is he sparing mankind from the awful reality?
translation: This was a very short episode that appeared on a 1971 Night Gallery show. The episode starred Sue Lyon (by Lolita Movie Fame) and Joseph Campanella, who play a babysitter and a vampire respectively. The vampire hires a babysitter to watch his child (which seems to be a kind of werewolf or monster) while he goes out to get blood at night. The babysitter is totally ignorant of the vampire's appearance when she sees him for the first time, and only begins to put two and two together when she notices that he has no reflection in the mirror, a curious collection of books in the library on the library Occult has and hears strange sounds while the vampire is talking to the child. She realizes that the man who hired her is not what she originally thought was him. She shoots out the door, the vampire seems confused and the episode is over. I do not know what purpose it was to make such a shortened episode, which lasted only 5 minutes. You should have simply extended the earlier episode by the same 5 minutes and skipped it. A total wasted effort.

summary: Based on the true story of Lindy Chamberlain. During a camping trip to Ayers Rock in outback Australia, she claimed that she witnessed a dingo stealing her baby daughter, Azaria, from the family tent. Azaria's body was never found. Police noted some apparent inconsistencies in her story, and she was charged with murder. The case attracted a lot of attention, turning an investigation into a media circus, with the public divided in their opinions.
translation: Fascinating film based on a true story about an Australian woman, Lindy Chamberlain (Meryl Streep), who is accused of killing her baby daughter. She insists that a dingo has taken her baby, but the story is highly suspicious. The film is actually about the media circus that took place around the case, the way Australians interpreted what was presented in the media, and the lynch mob mentality that ultimately resulted, based on barely any hard evidence of the woman's condemnation , I like films that challenge the media, and films that look closely at how people are hounded by the judiciary. I've always thought Jury's 12 Angry Men should be shown before they perform their duties. It is not, as has often been said, a liberal film, but a clinical look at how we as human beings interpret events that are based so much on our prejudices and desire for revenge. A cry in the dark is also clinical. Schepisi takes care not to make the film melodramatic. Some may find the movie boring or dry, but I found it interesting.

summary: Limo driver John Bourgignon is engaged to Nancy Reese. Her father, Congressman Ed Reese, is running for president and crusading against cult leader Sun Yi. Misadventure and intrigue stalk John and Nancy's path to the altar.
translation: One of John's funniest, Eugene Levy, is great in this one, too. I just wish the studio would find out that this one needs to be on DVD, I have it on videotape, but feel that this movie deserves DVD (and extras would be awesome) the Kung Fu Uuniversity (Kung Fu U) sketch is so much funny, like the entire movie, even the scenes he has with his girlfriend and her family are spectacular, this movie never seems to be on TV, but he loses most of his joy when edited for broadcast TV, If you find the video, I would suggest that you buy it (ebay is a good place to find a copy) I will keep my VHS until one day we see it on DVD. There are so many great films that have not yet been released on DVD, and that's one of them.

summary: A multi-volumed documentary mini-series, "The World at War" covers the entire history of World War II from the causes of the 1920s to the aftermath of the Cold War in the 1950s. Emphasis is also placed on several inside story episodes, where events are covered which occurred inside Germany and Japan such as resistance to Hitler, life in general under a dictatorial regime, and particular emphasis is focused on the Jewish Holocaust.
translation: Although told from a British perspective, this is the best WWII documentary ever produced. Presented in digestible (as digestible as war can be) episodes as the serious voice of Laurence Olivier unites the multitude of eyewitnesses who were forced to live the events of this horrific time. Longing for his appearance on DVD in the US The Europeans had their chance with a release on DVD earlier this year.

summary: In 1931, a young soldier (Fernando) deserts from the army and falls into a country farm, where he is welcomed by the owner (Manolo) due to his political ideas. Manolo has four daughters (Rocio, Violeta, Clara and Luz). Fernando likes all of them and they like him, so he has to decide which one to love.
translation: I've recently seen Belle Epoque and thought it could be wonderful as it won an Oscar for the Best Foreign Language Film. I was a little unimpressed by the predictability and simplicity of the film. Maybe the conflict I had was that from the moment the movie was made, the story of a man who falls in love with beautiful women and eventually falls into the good girl has been done so many times. Aside from the predictability of the plot, some scenes in the movie really felt out of place with the plot (eg, a particular event at the wedding). At times, the film was a bit preachy in his ideas and in relation to the Franco era, the film was put in and the church. The only thing the movie had in mind was the cute moments, the scenery, and the character of Violeta, who was a strong, independent woman in times when women were not really attached to those qualities.

summary: Shenzhen businessman, Da Ming, goes home to Beijing when he thinks his father has died. He finds his father hard at work at the family's bathhouse (the false message was a ruse of Da's mentally-handicapped, exuberant brother, Er Ming, to get Da home). Da stays a couple days, observing his father being social director, marriage counselor, and dispute mediator for his customers and a boon companion to Er. Da is caught between worlds: the decaying district of his childhood and the booming south where he now lives with a wife who's not met his family. When Da realizes his father's health is failing and the district is slated for razing, he must take stock of family and future.
translation: That was a very nice movie. A humorous but engaging look at the family and its commitments. The story of a man who comes home from his life in the city to his bath house in a small Chinese village. There he learns to appreciate, even appreciates the things from which he left home. The movie is as beautiful as it is emotionally beautiful.

summary: In New York, Alvin Sanders is a small-time thief who's just been hauled in for stealing a bunch of prawns (shrimp) from a local restaurant. He ends up in a cell with John Jaster, one half of a high-tech criminal team that's just stolen $42,000,000 worth of gold from the Federal Reserve. Realizing that he could die at any moment from his worsening heart condition, Jaster tells Alvin to relay a cryptic message to his wife about the whereabouts of the hidden gold. Alvin doesn't know exactly what the message means, and Edgar Clenteen, the U.S. Treasury investigator working the case, hopes it will lead to the gold or Jaster's partner Bristol, but it does neither. Eighteen months later, Jaster is dead, and both Clenteen and Bristol are still looking for that gold. Clenteen decides to secretly plant a tracking device in Alvin's jaw, release him from prison, and then let the word out that he knows where the gold is hidden. Knowing that Bristol is probably watching their every move, Clenteen ...
translation:
A slightly witty action thriller in which Jamie Foxx is a hapless, fast-talking crook sent by an overburdened US Treasury agent (David Morse) onto the streets of New York to find a picky computer thief. Hacker (Doug Hutchinson), who stole forty-two million dollars from the treasury and shot two guards.

"Bait" marks the sophomore feature for Antoine Fuqua ("The Replacement Killers") and does the job pretty well, though it does not surpass his first movie. What the two films have in common are the action sequences that are superb.

Foxx is pretty good here, although his character is annoying at first, but during the whole movie I started to catch up. Hutchinson is wonderful as the mastermind, who can be reckless as John Malkovich and patient as the late Laurence Olivier was in "Marathon Man". Morse is fine as the agent who has the ingenious plan to get anyone who has done it at any cost.

summary: Sgt. Bilko is in charge of the Motor Pool at an Army base. He's also a good-natured con man, providing gambling facilities for the soldiers on base. When an old enemy from his past shows up to inspect his records and steal away his fiance√©, Sgt. Bilko has to put his skills to creative use...
translation: OK, I'm not an American, but in my humble Scottish mind Steve Martin is not, never was, and will never be a jolly man as long as our offspring point in a southerly direction. Sergeant Bilko's Phil Silvers was a jolly man, no doubt because of the capable writers and directors and all the other talented team characters in the series who contributed perfectly to one of the funniest and timeless sitcoms America has ever produced. How anyone would have the audacity to repeat the character of Phil Silvers is a mystery to me. To sum things up, the exercise was repeated in Martin's clumsy attempt to be Peter Sellers Inspector Clouseau, which, in my opinion, was another failed attempt to rekindle a proven unimportant career. Some of your contributors say, "Steve Martin gives the character its own stamp," to which I would say "Balderdash," his depictions will long be forgotten when the generations of Silvers and Sellars are appreciated

summary: Toots and May's marriage is one of Toots being dependent on his wife. Shortly after Toots and May arrive in London to visit with their grown children Bobby and Paula and their respective children, Toots falls ill and dies. Toots' death brings to the surface the underlying strain that has always existed between May and both of her two children, and the unhappy lives they have all led. Now specifically with Paula, May is disapproving of her relationship with a construction worker named Darren. Not only does May think his occupation makes him beneath Paula, he's also a married man. Darren is in an unsatisfying marriage but doesn't want to leave it if only because of his son. Even after May gets to know and like Darren, she still encourages Paula to break up with him. The issue is that May herself has fallen in love with Darren, the two who begin a sexual relationship. What will ultimately happen between May and Darren also depends on Darren, who is floundering in his own life and doesn't...
translation:
Mai (Anne Reid) and Toots (Peter Vaughan) apparently visit their son Bobby (Steven Mackintosh) and his family rarely in London. Even as the visit begins, Toots suffers a fatal heart attack that drives Mai, uncertain and questioning her life and her future. As she feels attracted to the friend of her daughter Darren (Daniel Craig), her actions lead to inevitable consequences.

Beautifully filmed, but with all the anticipated realism and applause, the mother offers a collection of mostly unpleasant, even repugnant characters and asks the viewer to engage with them. Reid seems like May, and it's her skill and dedication as a wonderfully underrated actor who saves the film from a completely depressing swamp, but Michell and Kureishi have allowed Craig, Mackintosh, and Cathryn Bradshaw to create such thoroughly disgusting characters that it It's becoming increasingly difficult to take care of what's going on with May. As written, the characters played by Mackintosh and Bradshaw are actually so selfish and cold-hearted that one begins to wonder what exactly Kureishi wanted to say. As I said, they are either unwilling or unable to lift Bobby and Paula over the two-dimensional in their horrible selfishness.

Interesting for Reid's performance, but little else. A crying shame ...

summary: "The Straight Story" chronicles a trip made by 73-year-old Alvin Straight from Laurens, Iowa, to Mt. Zion, Wis., in 1994 while riding a lawn mower. The man undertook his strange journey to mend his relationship with his ill, estranged, 75-year-old brother Lyle.
translation:
I went to The Straight Story and expected a sad / happy type drama with a nice direction and some good acting. I have them. What I did not expect was an allegory for the trials of human existence. Leave it to Lynch to make a simple story about a 300-mile trip on a lawnmower and turn it into a microcosm for the human condition.

If you did not notice it, look at it again and watch out for the age of the people Alvin meets, the terrain he drives through, the reactions people give him , the kind of discussions he leads (one of the first is about pregnancy and children, one of the last is outside a graveyard). The last way he goes down is particularly insistent in this context, as he narrows and increases his anxiety and nervousness. The last mechanical failure could be considered a death, and the miraculous rebirth of his motor in terms of a life after death, in which he achieved the desired reunion.

I just hope some of the people who have branded this as A slow, melancholy melodrama takes the time to watch with a more holistic approach.

summary: Vada Sultenfuss has a holiday coming up, and an assignment: to do an essay on someone she admires and has never met. She decides she wants to do an assignment on her mother, but quickly realizes she knows very little about her. She manages to get her father to agree to let her go to LA to stay with her Uncle Phil and do some research on her mother. Once in LA, she finds herself under the protection of Nick, the son of Phil's girlfriend, who at first is very annoyed at losing his holidays to escort a hick *girl* around town. However, he soon becomes more involved in the difficult search.
translation:
If you want to know what kind of music white people heard in 1974, this is the movie for you. But you will also have to hear many flutes and violins (see my comments on "My Girl 1" for reference).

Indirect admission: I have met My Girl 2 with cynicism and anger, have just seen his predecessor. But as an adopted child, preparing to search for my birth mother, My Girl 2 let me search for his mother's topic.

In other words, all I liked about My Girl 2 had nothing to do with My Girl 2, but with a protagonist who, like so many adoptees, asks, "Who is my mom?" And if there are home videos of my mother in a drama group, I'm sure to make my own film about it.

Humans are listless. Films should not be listless. My Girl 2 (like My Girl 1) is just ... listless.

Avoid it if you're not a complete sap consoling yourself with a series of little annoyances.

summary: Crime novelist Catherine Tramell is living in London, and becomes the center of police investigation (yet again) when her football player boyfriend drowns in a car accident and it is revealed that he was already dead because of a drug overdose before Tramell drove the car into water. Police psychoanalyst Dr. Michael Glass is called for examining Tramell, and is intrigued by the seductive and manipulative woman. On the other hand , his friend Det. Roy Washburn is sure Tramell is guilty. Tramell asks Glass to treat her for her 'risk addiction' problem, and with each therapy session , Glass gets more and more suspicious about her intentions. As more and more murders are committed, including that of Glass's ex-wife, Glass becomes obsessed with proving Tramell's guilt even though the evidence is contradictory .
translation: I do not understand why the reviews of this movie are so bad in general, unless I'm just from my rocker. I found it sick, brilliant, twisted and psychologically demanding. You will not go deeper into the head of a criminal psychopath in a Hollywood movie than this. It has levels within levels, nuanced by Stone, and an action that will keep you guessing after the end. People have to get over the fact that Sharon Stone is 48 and Michael Douglas is not in it. I predict that this movie will be a big hit on DVD as soon as people see it for themselves and stop paying attention to the driving professional reviewers. Try it, you might be glad you did!

summary: Eddie Hall and his partner Slim are a pair of nickel-and-dime con men on the hustle. Nearly caught by the police, Eddie ducks into Ruby Adams's apartment and convinces her to hide him. Ruby isn't averse to taking advantage of the gullible herself and has even tried to manipulate money out of Al, the square shooter from Cincinnati who adores her. Ruby and Eddie hit it off, but when Eddie accidentally kills a drunk who was pawing Ruby, he takes off and she ends up in a women's reformatory, where she discovers she is pregnant. Devastated at the thought that Eddie has deserted her, she doesn't realize that Eddie has undergone a great change--one that will have a powerful impact on her.
translation: This movie returns from 4th to 1st place without worrying about 3rd or 2nd gear, to the juicy B-Movie finish line. The Con at the beginning is easily the best and smartest part of the movie. That is worth seeing. The scene with Harlow in the bathtub is so fast that you might miss her. Definitely not worth the allusions that Robert Osborne made in his TCM intro for this poor to mediocre confusion. There is no real conflict, and all the characters in this supposedly marginalized society turn out to be saints - especially the incredible character of Al. I wonder if he has a job for me in Cincinnati?

summary: Set in New York, 'Whipped' is about a group of three single men, buddies from college, whom meet every Sunday at their local diner hangout to discuss their favorite sport: scoring with women. Their conversations (always revealing, sometimes revolting, and occasionally riotous) revolve around the weekend past and the girls that these three egotistical and narcissistic swingers were able or unable to "scam." However, when all three single guys unknowingly go after the same "perfect" woman, Mia (Amanda Peet), they begin to question their skirt-chasing ways. Squabbling breaks out amongst the group as they compete for her attention and suddenly, the fate of their ritual and their friendships, becomes uncertain. Who will win the morning round table bragging rights? You'll be surprised.
translation: I just watched this movie last night and had to send a warning to everyone else who wants to watch this movie. In a word - not. I feel like this is something a scriptwriter would have written in a Quentin Tarantino / Eddie Murphy phase, d. H. Every second word would be a dirty word. I have no problem with profuse swearing, as in "Good Will Hunting," provided it helps to dive more into the characters. In this case, it was just hollow bantering in an attempt to get an occasional gasp or laughter from the audience. The three main characters are all their own unique stereotypes, the Wall Street idiot, the coffeehouse idiot, and the "I'm not gay just-in-touch with my-female side," a little less of a jerk. You do not care which of them! They are all superficial, irretrievable losers who want to see you lose. For those who dare, this movie has some fun moments, at the very beginning and the end. The toilet / vibrator scene is funny in a sick "Uh, yeah" way. Really, I would recommend this movie only to my worst enemies.

summary: Actress Patty Duke portrays herself in this autobiographical film that details her long-time struggle with mental illness.
translation: Actress Patty Duke wrote a revealing, witty and highly competitive book about her acting career, her crazy love life and her manic depressive episodes and suicide attempts that made her disappear almost forever. With this rich material to draw on (and Patty playing in the final act), one might think that a Crack TV director like Gilbert Cates could film everything together, but "Call Me Anna" is a pale shadow from Duke's autobiography. For those who have not read the book, the sketchy narrative (moving forward in time) is not receptive, we must never identify with what is happening right now, and production seems to be constrained by a low budget. The cast is misfired, and the value of making Duke appear at last does not pay off - the film's fake reality is so big at the time that Patty can not bring stability to the scenario. It seems that the producers are sincere enough (and mindful) to anxiously direct the film to Duke's ultimate diagnosis and mental freedom, but they have left out many dramatic opportunities.

summary: Jerry Springer stars as more or less himself, the host of a raunchy, controversial and popular Los Angeles talk show which features everyday people with problems and who frequently vent their problems on the air. A new group of guests are flown in for one show who include white trailer trash from Sarasota FL; Connie, whose current husband has cheated on her with her nymphomaniac teenage daughter, Angel, for which Connie has gotten revenge by having sex with Angel's fiance; and from Detroit, black trash Starletta, whose boyfriend, Damone, has slept with all of her girlfriends. Soon the paths of all of these parties cross which leads to more sex, arguments, physical violence, and Jerry sweating out just another day.
translation: Please avoid this movie at all costs. This is without doubt the worst movie I have ever seen. Most movies have at least one redeemable value. That has none. Totally awful!

summary: Ricky is a promising young scientist whose experimental formula regenerates dying cells. Ever since his parents died, Ricky's been trying hard to balance work while taking care of his younger brother Jermaine. When Jermaine is killed in a violent drive-by shooting, Ricky does the unthinkable to bring him back to life. His brother is now a blood-thirsty zombie wreaking carnage all over the hood. Now it's up to Ricky's colleague Scott and the boys in the hood to stop Jermaine from killing and turning the entire hood into zombies.
translation:
I discovered this strip on the shelf under "New Releases" and found the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãa hip-hop zombie strip too interesting to discard. So it was calculated on the box, and I thought, What a great idea! There is also a "Welcome to Oakland" sign on the cover. How could I resist? Unfortunately, the hip-hop part lasted only as long as the opening theme. Neither hip-hop music nor hip-hop culture played a major role in the film. Having lived in Oakland myself, I know there are many aspiring hip-hop artists there, so the low budget of this strip was no excuse for not having the right soundtrack. A number of artists who struggled had taken the opportunity to contribute to this film. Why the Quiroz Brothers did not take advantage of that is a mystery to me.

Once the movie started rolling, it was a typical zombie movie with a cast that happened to be all black and latino. You'd think that would take the movie in an unusual direction ... but it did not. Somehow, the vision of the Quiroz Brothers of Urban Culture comes down to drive-by shootings and dropping an F-bomb on every line of the movie. The quick use of the word "Fuck" is probably the most characteristic feature of this film; there were single lines that contained the word three or four times, and no line contained it at least once. I'm not squeamish in a movie at all, but the feeling here was that it was the result of a lack of ideas from the writers (including the Quiroz brothers), and the script was generally very poor. Br />
The movie was generally a disappointment. It would have been interesting to see a real "Urban Culture" zombie strip, but "Hood of the Living Dead" does not stick to it. The characters in the movie could just as easily have been white or eskimo or anything else. There was no pronounced taste for the movie. It's just another ordinary low budget movie with bad acting, bad lyrics, amateurish directing, bland cinematography, cheap soundtrack and nothing to recommend.

summary: A photographer and his model are on a photo shoot in a forest when they get the feeling they are being watched. The feeling becomes so strong that they decide to cut their session short and leave. Later, when they develop the photos they took, they discover what looks like alien creatures in the background.
translation: For some reason, in the late '70s and early' 80s, the local CBS affiliate station in New York played the late night movie every Friday or Saturday night for several years, usually at two o'clock or so. It's a fitting movie for this timeline, as it's really hard to follow and pretty weird (see the other reviews for specific story info). Anyway, after intercepting it several times just before cable TV at the time (and even after it had landed, but before they had been programming all night), I kept catching up with that little curiosity. After not seeing it for many years, I decided to see if I could find it on DVD. Well, it's only available (from any search I've done anyway) in a pretty lousy grainy print on the budget label called "Brentwood Video" as part of a 4-pack of movies (4 movies on 2 double-sided discs) " Alien Worlds "if anyone is interested. It's usually available for about $ 10 - but much less when you shop. The other 3 movies on this set are available in numerous other collections of public domain movies, so they do not need to be commented here. But I have not seen "Eyes" anywhere else. Although hardly a "recovered" version in any way, this print runs exactly 92 minutes, so for once IMDb specified runtime of 90 minutes is not correct. Even with a running time of 92 minutes, it's not uncommon for a movie that has been dubbed from another language to be in English to trim some of its duration. It seems to be a common practice to save money by not copying some scenes if they are not considered important to the story. Would a longer version be less confusing? Who really knows - unless you've seen it in his mother tongue ... Incidentally, my attempts to see it during the day do not work and I just turn it off. There's something to see in the middle of the night that fits in with this movie ... or maybe it's just from my previous experiences, who knows?

summary: In April 1994, after the airplane of the Hutu President of Rwanda is shot down, the Hutu militias slaughter the Tutsi population. In the Ecole Technique Officielle, the Catholic priest Christopher and the idealistic English teacher Joe Connor lodge two thousand five hundred Rwandans refugees, under the protection of the Belgian U.N. force, and under siege by Hutu militia. When the Tutsi refugees are abandoned by the U.N., they are murdered by the extremist militia.
translation:
This film is told through the eyes of a young teacher at a Catholic school and observes how the RAWANDAN genocide dissolves around him.

The film begins with a brief explanation of Rawanda's past and rivalry. Then it jumps to the story as told by a young idealistic "NEW COMMERCIAL", a young teacher who does not take the life or the situation too seriously. As he and the driver approach a roadblock, he plays ID with his drivers. Not realizing that this is a serious moment and that if the driver can not identify himself as the right tribe for the soldiers, they will be killed. And so he treats the unfolding history of chaos and unfolds around it. Suddenly it becomes clear that every Rawandan (including his driver) is involved and that European soldiers and tourists can not and will not help. The media cameras can not stop machetes, and there are too many machetes shooting down militiamen. The title comes from the army captain who says he will shoot the dogs eating the bodies around his facility, but he will not shoot the militia men who kill the surrounding people. Especially because they have not fired on the soldiers yet. Eventually he realizes the hopelessness of the situation and the guy who tells the evacuation team that he wants to leave his place for one of the intended victims flees with his tail between his legs instead of dying with the schoolchildren in imminent death he promised not to leave behind.

It's more of character study, and come to Jesus moment for a character, than a story about the genocide in "RAWANDA". This film did not have to be in RAWANDA, it could have been one of the genocidal hellholes at any time.

summary: Hamilton High is no place for a teacher who cares. Teacher Sam Decker doesn't care anymore. He's quitting. Sam marks his last day in the battleground of public education by getting saddled with the detention class after hours, playing warden to a pack of rebellious students, the worst troublemakers in school. But Hamilton High is about to become an all too real battleground when a well-organized group of killers armed with automatic weapons and explosives invade the supposedly deserted school after hours to use it as an operating base for meticulously planned armored car robbery. Led by the brilliant and sadistic Chester Lamb, the invaders are surprised to discover Sam and the kids from the detention room are still inside the school. The hunt is on as the killers ruthlessly stalk the teacher and students through the school's halls and classrooms, while Lamb tracks them on the surveillance cameras, turning the school's security system against his prey. Sam and the kids band together ...
translation: Cheezy action movie with Dolph Lungren. Lungren is a former military man who has retired to a teaching job. But the changes in the neighborhood and the student body have frustrated him and he decides he'll hang it up. It gets dicey when a few robbers take over the school as a base for a tank raid while they are detained over a group of students. His dolph against the bad guys in a fight to the death. Jaw Drop throw back to the exploitation films of the late Grindhouse era, where bad guys dressed up as punks and some of the bad women had day glow hair. What a stupid movie. I can not believe that people did that. This is an action movie that was probably doomed to failure from the beginning, before the low budget, the bad breakaway sets and the bad action direction were even a wink. See how late in the movie the cars drive through the school (do not ask), they crash into the security turrets (do not ask because it looks more like a jail than a high school) and smash their barely constructed form looks in earlier ones Recordings are not so. What did the gods do to bad movies? Actually, I'm perplexed, since it was directed by Sydney J Furie, a really good director who filmed films like The Boys in Company C. Has his ability failed him or was he hopeless from the start and did not bother him at all? It is a turkey. A worth seeing but a turkey nonetheless.

summary: An innovative look at the life of fictional Mafia Capo Tony Soprano, this serial is presented largely first person, but additional perspective is conveyed by the intimate conversations Tony has with his psychotherapist. We see Tony at work, at home, and in therapy. Moments of black comedy intersperse this aggressive, adult drama, with adult language, and extreme violence.
translation:
The Sopranos is probably the biggest show in the history of dramatic television.

It's hard to think of another series that offers so much intelligence, sublime writing or first-rate performances.

Everywhere epic it produces fresh and iconic characters and a consistent quality. The focus is on the life of a Tony Soprano, a man who lives in two families. One is the conventional wife and two children, the other a huge New Jersey mafia group, of which he is the boss of both. James Gandolfini plays True Romance and The Mexican, and Tony is a fascinating, scary but also likable guy. Gandolfini must be fully praised for turning a proliferating and cruelly aggressive blank into a truly identifiable and perfect leader. Contemporary American drama has never had such a captivating and iconic character as Tony.

The occupation of hundreds never offers a flat performance and such outstanding characters as Paulie Walnuts and Ralph Cifaretto will be remembered forever.

The true genius of this story, however, is that the Creator and the writers bravery and revolution take over a conventional drama series. Twenty-minute dream sequences, powerful and original use of symbolism and metaphorical images and truly shocking scenes of violence. But all of this applies to truly moving themes such as love, honor, and family respect. The series never gets cold-hearted or groundless.

Now competitive with TV and often poor The Sopranos stands high above the rest as America's most original and compelling drama. Forget the family redefined. This is Television Redifined.

summary: A group of popular students play a cruel prank on a shy nerd resulting in a terrible accident. Years later a reunion is held where each of the students face a stalker killer who may be the same nerd out for revenge.
translation:
The film begins with a review of Doddsville County High School on April Fool's Day. A group of students play a joke on class nerd Marty. If they are punished for playing this prank, they will follow a bigger prank that goes ridiculously (as with Slasher movies with pranks on class nerds) and Marty is simultaneously burned by the fire and acidified by acid to thoroughly his . Nearly five years later, when we meet members of the student body who meet in the now deserted high school for their five-year class reunion. We note that it is no coincidence that everyone at the reunion has listened to the clique of jokes from the flashback as all participants are being persecuted and killed by a mysterious masked murderer in ever more complicated and absent-minded cases. It does not take Sherlock Holmes to solve the mystery of the murderer's identity, since it's a scarred Marty, who seems to have used his nerdousness and high intellect to bend the laws of physics and engineering to rig the school for himself revenge scenario. The movie takes a turn for the bizarre as Marty ends his revenge on his former tormentors just to be haunted by their ghosts. Marty is finally pushed over the edge and takes his own life. Eventually, the film explodes in a crescendo of incoherent weirdness as the whole revenge scenario turns out to be a dream as Marty wakes up in a hospital bed, freeing himself from his shackles, stabbing a nurse and finally disfiguring his own face.

The script is tired and suffers from horror movie logic. The only originality comes from the amazingly intricate ways in which the victims are sent. The absurd "all-for-a-dream ending" feels pinned. It's almost as if someone pointed out the disconnected nature of the film, and the author decided then and there that it was a dream.

Technically, the movie is horrible. Some scenes were filmed so dark that I had to stop the movie and play with the color on my TV. The drama is below average, even for Slasher movies. I can not help but think that casting was part of the problem, as all actors are at least five years older than the characters they portray, making the flashback scene even more unintentionally ridiculous. Their lack of commitment to the film becomes apparent as half of them do not bother to keep their accents straight through the movie.

All this said, if you like bad horror movies, you might like this one too. It's not the worst movie in the genre, but it's far from the best.

summary: To make Sidney's slump all the more painful, Clifford Anderson, a student of one of Sidney's writing seminars, has recently sent his mentor a copy of his first attempt at playwrighting for Sidney's review and advice. The play, "Deathtrap," is a five character, two act thriller so perfect in its construction that, as Sidney says, "A gifted director couldn't even hurt it." Using his penchant for plot, and out of his desperate desire to once again be the toast of Broadway, Sidney, along with Myra, cook up an almost unthinkable scheme: They'll lure the would-be playwright to the Bruhl home, kill him, and market the sure-fire script as Sidney's own. But shortly after Clifford arrives, it's clear that things are not what they seem! Indeed, even Helga Ten Dorp, a nosey psychic from next door, and Porter Milgram, Sidney's observant attorney, can only speculate where the line between truth and deception lies.
translation:
Unlike Tinseltown's version of HELLO, DOLLY !, Jay Presson Allen's screen adaptation of Ira Levin's Broadway thriller hit could not wait for the stage to be embodied before he put it on the screen, and the producers opted for the best make it out white way! The opening and closing scenes of the film will be shot at the New York Music Box Theater, where DEATHTRAP played for almost five years. Even the final fade out of the film on the theater tent is a version of the famous logo of the stage play. (Although the marketing people have decided to use a funnier Rubik's Cube icon for the movie.) Now, on a budget DVD release, DEATHTRAP is just as fresh and inventive as ever. The cast is just right (better than their stage counterparts) and location scouts should be applauded to find a fittingly spooky house for our "one-bedroom, two-act thriller". Opened in a surprisingly simple and innovative way, director Sidney Lumet marks every "new" material wisely at the beginning and at the end of the film, leaving Levin's malevolent center alone.

The final scene of the movie is a big Hollywood run off the boards and undermines some of Levin's plot shows from earlier in the movie [Helga (via a dagger): "Being used by another woman, BECAUSE it's game. "]. Like Robert Altman's THE PLAYER, our new finale will help us refold the film and blur the boundaries between stage, screen, and (could it?) True life!

summary: Boom, pregnant from an affair, is told by her lover to leave him and his family alone. Enraged, she goes to a witch doctor and has him use black magic against her ex-lover and his family. They all die in suspicious manners. Just when Boom thinks everything is over, a woman claiming to be her lover's secret mistress claims his inheritance and moves in to his house with her 4 children. Not long after that, unexplainable things happen to the family and, one by one, they begin to die.
translation:
Ever heard of a Taiwanese horror movie? Or any Taiwanese movie? Probably for a reason. This one was really boring even though it has black magic, including weathered baby corpses and people exploding inside with thousands of eels.

After reading other people's thoughts, I was looking forward to some violence and blood, but there is not much. Puking some blood and other lame things, if you're waiting for graphics gore or any gruesome effects, you'll be disappointed. They exploded the eel and did not use other things to their maximum potential.

Pretty much nothing good about this movie; a single character who was not completely boring and some good black spells like the eel. The plot was confusing and boring. The characters were thin and annoying, including the main character. The horror aspect did not work at all, the most frightening thing was an albino girl (not really scary). This is the worst Asian horror movie I have ever seen.

summary: Richard Haywood, a Californian high school's coolest kid, secretly teams up with another rich kid in his class, brilliant nerd Justin 'Bonaparte' Pendleton, whose erudition, specially in forensic matters, allows them to plan elaborately perfect murders, just for the kick, for which they set up Richard's marijuana supplier, their school's janitor Ray Feathers, as a psychotic serial killer. The case is assigned to detectives Cassie 'the hyena' Mayweather, who carries a sequoia-size chip on the shoulder from her previous life, and her brilliant new partner, Sam Kennedy, who just transferred from the vice squad; they can work together very well, and even fit romantically, but fall out over different professional attitudes towards the investigation, which Captain Rod Cody and her understandably vindictive abused ex, Assistant D.A. Al Swanson, soon ban her from when she disobeys instructions and hand to him. When the plotting boys both dig class-mate Lisa Mills, their unnatural bond comes ...
translation: From director Barbet Schr√∂der (Reversal of Fortune), I think I've seen a bit of it in my Media Studies course, and I've recognized the lead actress, so I've tried, despite the critics' rating. Cool kid Richard Haywood (Half Nelsons Ryan Gosling) and Justin Pendleton (Bully's Michael Pitt) work together to murder a random girl to challenge herself and see if they can get away with it without the police finding her. The murder case is the murder detective Cassie "The Hyena" Mayweather (Sandra Bullock) with new partner Sam Kennedy (Ben Chaplin), who is evidenced by the evidence found in the scene, e.g. unrelated hair. The plan does not seem to be going very well, because Cassie and Sam are quick to spot Richard or Justin as suspects, it's just a matter of throwing them away. Also with Agnes Bruckner as Lisa Mills, Chris Penn as Ray Feathers, R.D. Call as Captain Rod Cody and Tom Verica as Asst. THERE. Al Swanson. I now see the same concept as Sir Alfred Hitchcock's Rope in murdering a challenge, but this film does it in a very silly way and not even a reasonably good Bullock can keep it from being boring and predictable. Appropriate!

summary: Seemingly in constant trouble at school, 14-year-old Antoine Doinel returns at the end of every day to a drab, unhappy home life. His parents have little money and he sleeps on a couch that's been pushed into the kitchen. His parents bicker constantly and he knows his mother is having an affair. He decides to skip school and begins a downward spiral of lies and theft. His parents are at their wits' end, and after he's stopped by the police, they decide the best thing would be to let Antoine face the consequences. He's sent to a juvenile detention facility where he doesn't do much better. He does manage to escape however.
translation: This movie aka "The Four Hundred Beats" is a mistranslation. Faire Les 400 Coups "means" to live a wild life. As a Frenchman, I am stunned when I see the popularity of this good but by no means outstanding film. 1. It is not the first film of the "nouvelle vague" movie, see Agnes Varda's "la pointe courte", (1956) Alain Resnai's "Hiroshima mon amour" (1958), Claude Chabrol's "le beau serge" (1958) anterior Historically, "Les 400 Coups" comes afterwards. 2. The "nouvelle vague" was sometimes cumbersome and hard on its predecessors: overnight, Julien Duvivier, Henri-George Clouzot, Claude Autant-Lara, Yves all√©gret and many others were condemned to oblivion. This selfishness and contempt is typically "nouvelle vague". You have never heard (or read) the great generation of thirties (Renoir, Carn√©, Gr√©millon, Duvivier, Feyder), say, Maurice Tourneur or Max Linder. So, thanks to Truffaut and Co Some people will never discover the jewels of the French fifties or forties (Duvuvier's "Sous le Ciel de Paris", Autant-Lara's "Douce", Yves All√©gret's "une si jolie petite plage" and "man√®ges") so much to say that William Wyler, Georges Stevens and Fred Zinemann were worthless! 3. "Les 400 Coups" is technically rather disappointing: it's very academic, the story is as linear as it can be, the teachers are caricatures, and the mother Claire Maurier delivers such memorable lines as (you have to be a Frenchman) 1960, to understand how ridiculous it is): Well, your father has only his Brevet and, like me, I only have my high school diploma, you have to know that in 1960 barely 10% of students had HSD in France! Antoine Doinel should finally have been proud of his mother! She wants him to have diplomas, who can blame her? 4. In contrast to the innovations of "Hiroshima mon amour", which have a completely new form and a new "fragmented" content, "les 400 coups" become meaningful. The Truffaut will master a new form only with the supremely superior "Jules" and Jim, "supported by the incomparable Jeanne Moreau. 5. The interpretation is rather stiff, Jean-Pierre L√©aud, who is probably heard when dubbing in English will still be decent, but he will soon degenerate to the most affected of his generation 6. The theme = stolen childhood had better days before (Julien Duvivier's "Poil de Carotte", Luis Bunuel's "los olvidados") and afterwards (Maurice Pialats "l'enfance nue", Kenneth Loach's "Kes") I did not want to humiliate Truffaut, his film is not bad, but, frankly, French film fans, "Jules and Jim" prefer "enfant sauvage" ( a movie honest, true and commercially uncompromising to a debt) "l'argent de poche" (as academic as "400 coups" but much funnier) or his nice hitchcock pastiche "vivement dimanche".

summary: The Herlihys are a working class family from Chicago whose three children take wildly divergent paths: Brian joins the Marines right out of High School and goes to Vietnam, Michael becomes involved in the civil rights movement and after campaigning for Bobby Kennedy and Eugene McCarthy becomes involved in radical politics, and Katie gets pregnant, moves to San Francisco and joins a hippie commune. Meanwhile, the Taylors are an African-American family living in the deep South. When Willie Taylor, a minister and civil rights organizer, is shot to death, his son Emmet moves to the city and eventually joins the Black Panthers, serving as a bodyguard for Fred Hampton.
translation: I was no longer alive in the 60s, so I can not guarantee that this film was a perfectly accurate representation of the times, but it is certainly a moving and fulfilling experience. There are some outstanding performances, most notably by Josh Hamilton (of With Honors), Jerry O'Connell (Sliders), who played brothers divided by the war. Bill Smitrovich, a character actor who has long been ignored by many, gives a heartfelt performance when his stern father, compelled to question his own beliefs and values ‚Äã‚Äãas one of his sons, proudly goes to Vietnam but returns empty-handed inside, while the other is just the opposite. All in all, this is a powerful and heartwarming movie that I hope everyone has a chance to experience.

summary: At an annual pace, a huge colony of ants is forced to collect every piece of food that grows on their island for a group of menacing grasshoppers. But that all changes when a misfit inventor ant named Flik accidentally knocks over the offering pile thus forcing the grasshoppers' devious leader Hopper to force the ants to redo their gathering of food. Despite the fact that his friends don't believe him and desperate to help save the colony, Flik volunteers to go out into the world and search for a group of 'warrior' bugs. Instead, what he got was a talented group of circus performers. But when the grasshoppers return and take control of the island, Flik must prove himself a true hero before it's too late.
translation:
For starters, it's a very funny movie with some crazy characters running around and laughing (look at the two Russian beetles).

A Bug's Life has a classic Disney story, but that's one of the good things about the movie. Family values ‚Äã‚Äãare praised and the main characters of the film will evolve to end up against the grasshoppers. And there are some great voice-overs by Dave Foley, Julia-Louise Dreyfus, Kevin Spacey (of course), ... But actually, the most amazing thing about this movie is the animation. It's just wonderful. Every detail, great color, every ant looks different, beautiful backgrounds ... And the guys and girls from Pixar have made everything look so realistic. All in all a very nice piece of work. This is the best animation of Disney since Aladdin.

summary: Nestled in the mountains of Germany, a grim and secluded castle stands - the haunted legacy of the beautiful medieval vampire Baroness Varga. Put to death for her ravenous hunger for female blood, the Baroness uttered a curse that she would one day return to forever satisfy her unnatural lust...and that day has finally come! Four women have gathered at the castle unaware that its darkly seductive housekeeper is a satanic high priestess presiding over a coven of delectable servants who each night perform sensual rituals and profane acts to keep the Baroness' spirit alive. As the women are drawn deeper into the ultra erotic nightmare, it will be the most uninhibited among them who shall serve as the vessel into which the Baroness passes...to continue her unholy reign of terror!
translation: Well, if you are looking for a great mind control movie then this is it. No movie has so many beautiful women under thought control and naked. Marie Forsa, as the busty Helga, is almost always there when she falls asleep and a few times when she is not asleep. One wishes that they made more films like these.

summary: Johnathan Cabot is a champion gymnast. In the tiny, yet savage, country of Parmistan, there is a perfect spot for a "star wars" site. For the US to get this site, they must compete in the brutal "Game". The government calls on Cabot, the son of a former operative, to win the game. Cabot must combine his gymnastics skills of the west with fighting secrets of the east and form GYMKATA!
translation: This movie is hilarious. The problem is that it's not a comedy. A classic scene is that Kurt Thomas is currently finding a pommel horse in the middle of a village square (with which he beats the bad guys). Another is the way to the "village of the crazy". Too bad that this movie was not made a farce or got better ratings.

summary: From a bland tract house on the outskirts of Los Angeles, Simon Geist (with occasional help from his platonic girlfriend Darla) wages war against all of modern American popular culture. Geist starts up a magazine called "The Next Big Thing", which he uses to confront and insult upcoming actors, comics, models and rock bands. As Geist's mysterious Underground Agenda escalates, will he become the "last big thing", or be co-opted by the very forces he is railing against?
translation:
"The Last Big Thing" is a wonderful satirical film that sardonically brings pop culture to the point of humorous self-destruction. The characters are so interesting and it's fun to laugh / sympathize with them. That brings me to an introduction to the characters I liked the most.

Simon Geist is a man of his late 30s / early 40s who creates a pop culture-driven editorial magazine called "The Next Big Thing." The point is, this magazine does not exist really, and it's just an excuse for Simon to get close to the actors by interviewing them just to make them silly by offending their way of shopping into pop culture, and his live-in girlfriend Darla also writes one Magazine (which is real), which mainly has to do with her and Simon, as well as with her and her dad, Darla is a genuinely amiable (or repulsible) character, depending on how you see her muted neurotic behavior. "Magda is a prostitute Brent is a shallow character with not much for him, like Tedra, the music video queen for a bunch of B-rated rock bands, yet these characters weave together a very interesting network. And this film questions all the motivations people have for what they do and why they do it. It's a wonderful movie and I suggest you watch it when you're in the indie / art house crowd. Mark my words!

summary: The year is 2010. Teenager Alan Tracy, sent off to a distant boarding school, is the youngest of the sons of Jeff Tracy, a retired American astronaut. Jeff, a widower, has formed International Rescue, and raised his sons to act as a secret, volunteer organization which uses highly advanced technology to save lives worldwide. Jeff and his older sons John, Virgil, Scott, and Gordon, who like Alan were named after the Mercury Seven astronauts are joined in this effort by Lady Penelope and her butler/chauffeur Parker. Their futuristic hardware is largely developed by a genius scientist known as Brains, who lives at the International Rescue base on Tracy Island, somewhere in the Pacific.
translation:
I still have not seen everything; It's just on the cable, and I always seem to intervene. My main reason is that I'm a fan of Bill Paxton; He is a pretty good actor, and has been doing consistently well throughout his career.

The other thing that's turned on is that, while never really a fan of the old series, I kinda want Thunder for the ships and effects work. Derek Meddings was probably the best in the industry in the sixties and seventies, and his designs for the International Lifeboat are wonderful. The current team has done a good job transferring their work to the big screen.

BUT ...

This is a lame story. The kids are asked to drive it, and while doing an okay job, it's hard to dispel the disbelief, especially if you have Brains' eight-year-old son flies T2, a massive multi-ton transport with all the aerodynamics a Buick. Everywhere you look you will see a Ford logo. Product placement is overkill here, and it's annoying. Ben Kingsley does a good job as The Hood, but he can only do so much with a one-dimensional role. If you can accept the movie on its very low merits, Thunderbirds is a fun, entertaining ride. Do not look too closely at the machines that propel them.

ADDENDUM: I've finally seen it all and it's worse than I thought. The drama is pretty equally bad, and while the effects are pretty good, the story has become cheesier on several considerations. The exaggerated product placement for Ford is annoying, and the kids as main characters irritate my nerves. As with The Avengers, it's bearable if you ignore the source material. But not very. Take a look at the original show and you'll see what I mean.

And a word of advice to Jon Frakes. Do a refresher course in the Director's Guild. You can do better than that, old friend.

One more footnote ...

I saw that again. Last night. On Telemundo. Synchronized in Spanish with kitschy comedy sound effects. And yes, I came in about halfway with Ben, Ron and Sophia in their fight scene on Tracy Island.

I did not think it was possible that an already lame movie would get worse, but it was. It was awfully bad.

If this had just been done, no child-to-rescue, no ironic jokes, it might have worked. As it is, it's just another beloved childhood joy that has been ruined.

summary: Ruby, a young woman, arrives in a Florida resort town during the off season to make a fresh start. She gets work as a sales clerk in a souvineer shop run by Mildred Chambers. She dates, and sleeps with, Ricky Chambers, Mildred's conceited son, but breaks off with him when she finds she's just another conquest. She gets involved with Mike, a left-wing greenhouse worker. As the seasons change, Ruby's relationships with others and herself go through metamorphoses as she makes choices and discoveries establishing her own identity. A character study.
translation:
Very slow, but complicated structured and ultimately very touching. A beautiful, very lifelike view of a small beach town in Florida in the middle of winter - I was there, and that's absolutely correct.

It's also the debut feature of actress Ashley Judd, and she makes a big impression here. It's hard to believe this movie is 12 years old - I remember seeing him in cinemas and I recently rented "Ruby" again. Apart from the 80s, it has done very well. Ashely is so radiant and touching here that it's hard to think about her later career without flinching. Boy, talk about not fulfilling your early promise! Anyone who sees Ashley here in "Ruby In Paradise" would think that this elegant, natural beauty leads to all sorts of interesting art films and serious acting - instead, she has become the "go to" girl for stupid action movies and slasher movies! Very disappointing, but at least we have received this beautiful achievement to present their early promises.

As some other commentators say, this is not for everyone as it is very slow. This is not an action movie, nor is it really a romance. The director (Victor Nu√±ez, "Ulees Gold", another excellent character study) treats the life of this ordinary young woman with great respect and lets her story build slowly and with much detail. In that way, I think this is one of the most moving and respectful stories about young women I can remember - it's not about Ruby's sexual awakening or "how she lost her virginity", but about her life choices and her growing maturity.

A nice movie, if you take the time to see it ... I think it would be a really excellent movie to show teenagers and young girls (or boys). and give them a chance to think and discuss it.

Special thanks to director Nunez, who also wrote the screenplay, which is so realistic and beautifully detailed that I have accepted the entire film that it was based on a novel or memoir written by women but in fact it is the original work of Mr. Nunez. Rated 8 out of 10.

summary: Emma Woodhouse is a congenial young lady who delights in meddling in other people's affairs. She is perpetually trying to unite men and women who are utterly wrong for each other. Despite her interest in romance, Emma is clueless about her own feelings, and her relationship with gentle Mr. Knightly.
translation: If you know something about Jane Austen's production, you will now repeat the same in each of her novels: Marriage, Marriage and Marriage! In my opinion, all the movies in her novels are a bit boring, but I like Austen's characters because they all have a certain personality and typical sayings that they like to repeat, as in Emma. What makes Emma good is Gwyneth Paltrow, she is very good in her lead role. Also, the fact that each of the characters in the film is unable to think otherwise than to find a good partner and soon to be married makes the movie hilarious.

summary: American kids go to a space camp during the summer holidays. They learn how to operate the Space Shuttle. A team consisting of a guy who just entered to meet girls, a wanna be astronaut and an instructor who wanted to go on a mission instead of teaching can sit in the Shuttle while testing the engines. Then they're launched by mistake ...
translation:
Space Camp is a pretty decent movie. The plot is predictable, but the actors do a good job, and the special effects are acceptable over time.

This movie was originally released during the shuttle disaster, and that really was a drag on how popular it was.

The scene in which the shuttle doors open in space is simply spectacular ... on the big screen, that's ... on a TV ... just looks average. I remember this scene in the theater. It made you feel that you are really up there.

That would be a good movie to watch on IMAX, but I'm sure that will never happen.

summary: Patrick Galloway is a former soldier turned writer and an authority on occult phenomena. In 1922 he receives a plea for help from his old friend and former comrade in arms Jeremiah Covenant. It seems that something very strange and gruesome is happening at the Covenant estate. Believing his old friend to be exaggerating, Galloway travels to the Covenant estate in Ireland. He soon realizes that Jeremiah Covenant has not been exaggerating at all -- quite the opposite.
translation:
This game was really great and quite a challenge. It has a great, scary story and the graphics are also very good. I would recommend this game to all horror fans and is very gripping from start to finish. The only problem with this game is that I had more weapons, but that's just me.

A really great game for RPG and Shoot'em'up fans.

>

summary: A young inbred loner wandering the back roads of North Carolina comes across an abandoned baby. He immediately starts seeking the baby's parents, but starts developing a bond with the child that explores his own isolated roots. In true bad guy fashion, a traveling salesman appears and truths about the baby's origin start to unravel. But little did they know it was a trap.
translation: I found terrible. If you think anyone in the South is stupid, morally bankrupt, stupid, violent, a religious mother or a child molester, then maybe this movie is for you. Everyone is poor and seemingly ignorant. In one scene, two older men talk in a grocery store and one mentions that he had abused a number of sisters before they could tie their shoes. The man seemed to be proud of his actions, and the other man obviously took it as a normal part of life. Very nice. A young girl is walking in the street after her sister and no one offers her help - despite obvious limping and lack of food or water (no backpack, etc.). Strathairn's character is not only disgusting and slimy through and through, but he also appears as a religious believer who (typical of Hollywood) reflects the wicked nature of the Christians. One scene in the film is reminiscent of the end of Cape Fear (the one with DeNiro) - Bible verses are broadcast by the villain. I'm from the big Northwest, but I found this movie offensive because of the wonderful people I know from NC, WV, AL, MS, KY, TN etc.

summary: Abandoning artistic ambitions, sensitive and club-footed Philip Carey enrolls in medical school and falls in love with a waitress Mildred Rogers. She rejects him, runs off with a salesman and returns unmarried and pregnant. Philip gets her an apartment and they become engaged. Mildred runs off with another medical student. Philip takes her back again when she returns with her baby. She wrecks his apartment and burns the securities he needs to pay tuition. He gets a job as a salesman, has surgery on his foot, receives an inheritance, and returns to school where he learns Mildred is dying.
translation:
Today, actresses gain weight slightly, dye their hair, dress like slobs and lose their luster for a role, and Bette Davis was probably the actress who started the trend. Even as a pretty young woman who occasionally wore designer clothes and Constance Bennett makeup in movies, Davis was ready to devastate herself to create a character both outside and inside.

Her determination shows in her breakout film "Of Human Bondage", starring Leslie Howard as Philip Carey. Davis plays Mildred, a lusty, manipulative, greedy low-life for Howard's masochistic, club-footed Philip. He first meets her when she is a waitress, and she allows him to take her to the food and theater while she plays with a wealthy older man (Alan Hale Sr.). In fact, Mildred is repulsed by Philip's clubfoot. On his part, Philip seems to enjoy the abuse of her open flirtation and her coolness towards him. He allows Mildred to bleed him financially, among the friends who drop her when they get tired while blowing some really lovely women (Kay Johnson and Frances Dee). When he gets the courage to throw her out, Mildred shatters his apartment and robs him, forcing him to retire from the medical school and lose his shelter.

"Human bondage" looks quite stilted today. Although Leslie Howard was a wonderful actor and attractive, his acting style is from a more formal old school, and so he tends to file whatever he is. He shines in material such as his role opposite Davis in "It's Love I'm After" or "The Petrified Forest" that demand its kind of technique. His dated acting is even more obvious here, because Davis was breaking new ground with a gritty, edgy performance that would really make her name. If she seems exaggerated at times, she came off the stage, and the intricacies of filmmaking would later come to her mind. Contrast this achievement with the restraint, warmth, and gentleness of her Henriette in All All, and Heaven Too, or the pathos that brought her to Dark Victory. She was a true actress and a true artist. Davis really does allow himself to look like a holy hell; Mildred's deterioration is absolutely pathetic, as Philip seems to gain strength as her mind fades.

An excellent movie in which to see the puckering of one of the movie's biggest stars.

summary: In the funeral of the famous British journalist Joe Strombel, his colleagues and friends recall how obstinate he was while seeking for a scoop. Meanwhile the deceased Joe discloses the identity of the tarot card serial killer of London. He cheats the Reaper and appears to the American student of journalism Sondra Pransky, who is on the stage in the middle of a magic show of the magician Sidney Waterman in London, and tells her that the murderer is the aristocrat Peter Lyman. Sondra drags Sid in her investigation, seeking for evidences that Peter is the killer. However, she falls in love with him and questions if Joe Strombel is right in his scoop.
translation:
Something happens to Sondra Pransky as she enters the magic box on the stage of a London theater. Little does Sondra know that the ghost of newly-deceased journalist Joe Strombel materializes to ask her to ask the man to investigate someone, on his journey in another dimension, is the infamous tarot killer who is on a binge of crime been in London. The only problem is the man is charged, for all appearances, a respectable upper class man.

When Sondra recounts her experience in the Great Splendini, aka Sid Waterman, the wizard is stunned, but decides to go along. The two would P.I. Invite an invitation to a club where Peter Lyman goes swimming. Sondra, who drowns her fake, catches the attention of this hunk, who wants to see more of her. Needless to say, the two of them get into all sorts of fun situations until the mystery gets revealed at the end of the movie. The real Tarot killer does not think he can fool a resolute Sondra who proves she's more resourceful than he has trusted her.

The result is a perfect summer movie with a lot of laughter what you need to get from the heat to the perfect time in a cool theater. Woody Allen has done better, and yet this sunny comedy will justify him for past failures. In "Scoop", Mr. Allen has said goodbye to the romantic top of his gorgeous lead actress. Gesturing his brand is something this funny man will never get rid of as it seems to be his brand. The film has some funny liners that go overboard for those who are not careful.

Scarlett Johansson, the beautiful star of "Scoop", seems to be the perfect foil for Woody Allen. She plays the straight part while Mr. Allen does his shit, a perfect combination. Both are excellent in their banter during the movie. Ms. Johansson is a knockout beauty in her red bathing suit, though she has dressed her so old-fashioned in most of the costumes she wears on the screen. Hugh Jackman is considered Peter Lyman, a cultured man in the city with the right pedigree. He makes a good showing in the movie as the man who chases Ms. Johansson. Ian McShane plays the dead Fleet Street journalist on his way to eternity.

"Scoop" is thanks to Woody Allen a light film for the hot and humid summer.

summary: An interweaving narrative chronicling the antics of such diverse characters as: a transsexual taxi driver, a family obsessed with hygiene and toads, a fiery reverend, a carnival owner who kidnaps women into marriage, and a xenophobic couple who run a local shop for local people.
translation: One of the best comedy series ever to come from the UK. Mark Gatiss, Reece Shearsmith and Steve Pemberton are terrific actors and performers who are at home with drama and comedy. With the support of their writing partner Jeremy Dyson, they have populated the series with the most memorable characters of recent years. Little Britain fades as a faint imitation of her ideas of insignificance. Consistently original and groundbreaking, I am sure that so many people hate these series as they love, but I'm just as certain that no one could have an opinion on LOG. I have not seen the movie yet, but I have heard good and bad things, so I'll reserve the verdict. The original radio series from which LOG came was as innovative as the TV series. I do not know if the TV series came to the US, but I would be intrigued to see how the American audience found the comic English humor

summary: After a spot of therapy Cruella De Vil is released from prison a changed woman. Devoted to dogs and good causes, she is delighted that Chloe, her parole officer, has a dalmatian family and connections with a dog charity. But the sound of Big Ben can reverse the treatment so it is only a matter of time before Ms De Vil is back to her incredibly ghastly ways, using her new-found connections with Chloe and friends.
translation: After watching the 1996 remake, I thought it would be the funniest way to see Cruella De Vil, who would be punished for torturing animals just for her skin. The whole movie was pretty funny and in my opinion better than the animated one. But there was no need for a second. First of all, when Cruela returns, she does not heal and drives her crazy again. Just let her break out of prison and that's rap. I thought it was not very funny. It's just meant to give back an original puppy. I expected it to be Lucky because he was the most attractive and also had Roger and Anita back. However, they decided to have a complete recast and not really one hundred, not even one hundred and two, but only three puppies and a parrot who thought he was a dog (smart). Gerard Depardieu's role was meaningless. In the end, Cruella suffers too much, too humiliating and too over the top to be true. She is baked in a giant cake. This was a desperate attempt at physical humor, trying to mimic the same effect of the first one. That just did not work. It was too much over the top, and not too funny. I really felt sorry for Cruella.

summary: Sexy, romantic comedy about a girl in her early 20s named Violet Sanford going to NYC to pursue a dream of becoming a songwriter. Violet gets a "day" job as a bar maid at a nightclub called Coyote Ugly. Coyote Ugly is the city's newest hot spot where the employees are a team of sexy, resourceful women that provoke the clientele and press with their mischief.
translation:
What a disappointment! Piper Perabo is adorable, Tyra Banks is beautiful, but pitiful as an actor, and the talented and beautiful Maria Bello is wasted! Bello must have been embarrassed by some lines! The storyline, script and premise is a joke!

I'm not against silly movies, I think something about Mary is a masterpiece, but Coyote Ugly is a waste of 90 minutes ..... ...

summary: On the Franco-Austrian Frontier during WW I, an oriental priest, chaplain of a French colonial regiment, is condemned to life imprisonment because he possesses the power of turning men into zombies. As the priest,in his prison cell, is preparing to burn the parchment containing the location of the secret formula, Colonel Mazovia kills the priest and takes the partially-burned parchment. Fade to after the war to an expedition of representatives from all the Allied countries (only those with colonial interests it appears) being sent to Cambodia to find and destroy forever the Secret of the Zombies. The group includes Colonel Mazovia (somewhat akin to sending the fox to guard the hen house); a student of dead languages, Armand Louque; Englishman Clifford Grayson; and General Duval and his daughter Claire. Armand falls in love with Claire, who accepts his proposal of marriage in order to spite Clifford whom she really loves. Later, when Claire, following an accident, runs to Cliff for ...
translation: Revolt of the Zombies begins with Armand Lou (Dean Jagger) trying to convince General Duval (George Cleveland) that his buddy Tsiang (William Crowell) is a priest who has the power to hypnotize people and turn them into ingenious zombies (a bit like the people I really work with). Anyway, Tsiang is being murdered by Colonel Masovia (Roy D'Arcy), but he does not manage to turn humans into zombies. An expedition was set up by General Duval to seek the secret, since Tsiang will not tell them much anymore. General Duval leads the expedition together with his daughter Claire (Dorothy Stone), who is engaged to Louque, who also comes along. During the expedition, Claire Louque throws for his buddy Clifford Grayson (Robert Noland) on which Louque is not pleased. In a way that can only happen in a movie, Louque finds the secret of turning people into zombies and starts using his newfound power to avenge Claire & Clifford ... co-written by Victor Halperin's revolt of the zombies have a bad name and after seeing them, I can see why. The Halperin, Howard Higgin and Rollo Lloyd script, all uncredited, has a good central idea, but is killed dead as it's boring and so exciting how to paint paint. Not much happens for a long time, and not much happens after that. How Halperin depicts his zombies is different than what most modern audiences would consider a zombie, these zombies are just brainwashing and the audience has to wait more than 30 years for George A. Romero to define what a zombie is now in the Night of the Living Dead (1968). At just about an hour in length, Revolt of the Zombies still feels too long. Technically, the film is OK, considering that it was made 70 years ago, black and white cinematography is appropriate, though some of the scenes look like they were shot against a photograph of the background. The spectacle is wooden and largely unimpressive. Revolt of the zombies may have been hot in 1936, but it did not turn out well and in 2005 it's an absolute must to persevere. I think the movie is now a public domain because it appears on many ultra-cheap DVD compilations and budget labels, but it's still not worth watching, no matter how cheap it gets.

summary: Willful young Jennifer Cassi travels to South America to claim the inheritance of her recently deceased twin sister Johanna's house. While there Jennifer must contend with her eccentric grandmother Mary Ellen Cassi, who has damned the family with an ancient curse. Jennifer immediately starts to suffer from scary visions of a sinister raven every time she goes to sleep.

Ravens have a strange role in it. When the relatives go to sleep, the ravens eat organs there so they can not go to sleep. But they do it. Basically everything is crazy and Mary Ellen will never die and her relatives will be buried, but not dead, b / c they will have to suffer forever so Mary Ellen can stay alive. Yes, I hope that helps. If not, I'm sorry. Love you.

summary: Heading home late one night after a party, Kate falls asleep while waiting for her train. She awakens to find herself trapped in the London underground, with all the doors locked for the evening. While being attacked by a co-worker who has followed her, a mysterious unseen creature drags him away and kills him. This begins a terrifying ordeal, as Kate and a young homeless couple are stalked through the dark tunnels by something dangerous with payback on its mind.
translation:
I saw this movie last night at the Toronto Film Festival where it played under the heading Midnight Madness. However, the story is pretty weak, but then the whole point of the movie was to make the crap out of you, and that was pretty effective. The score of a Bristol band called The Insects was first-rate. That scared me more than anything else.

The director was a really decent kid and was entertaining during the Q & A session. I really hope that he will make better films in the future.

This is for genre fans only, but I would recommend non-fans to try it anyway. It was a fun ride.
