summary: A young couple, Renee and Pierre, take one night a room at the Hotel du Nord, in Paris, near the canal Saint-Martin. They want to die together, but after having shooted at Renee, Pierre lacks of courage and ran away. Another customer, Monsieur Edmond, a procurer, rescues her. When Renee goes out of the hospital, she is hired as a waitress at the hotel. Monsieur Edmond falls in love with her, but Renee is still thinking of Pierre ...
translation: This is an excellent movie and is a kind of treasure that can only be achieved through sporadic movie screenings, as it is not available on video / DVD. The way the movie starts and ends with the two lovers (even though a lot happens in between and they do not stay in one place at the same time), a sense of unity and feeling convey that everything is right with the world. If you get a chance to watch this movie, then do so. I can not wait to see it again and I hope that it could come to the general publication.

summary: An American of German descent arrives in post-war Germany 1945. His uncle gets him a job on the Zentropa train line as a sleeping car conductor. The American's wish is to be neutral to the ongoing purges of loyalists by the Allied forces and do what he can to help a hurting country, but he finds himself being used by both the Americans and the influential family that owns the railroad. After falling in love with the railroad magnate's daughter, he finds that he can't remain neutral and must make some difficult choices.
translation:
Someone is releasing this film on DVD so that he can take his place as one of the greatest films of all time in ten to twenty years, when critics and film historians look back on the so-called films of the 1990s and see how bland they are for the most part and How Lars von Trier tried to revolutionize and revitalize the international film world with this masterpiece. As it stands, "Zentropa" (or "Europe," as it is called outside the US) is one of the most intriguing and artistic views of desolation and almost psychotic uncertainty that erupted after the Second World War, namely the decimated German landscape whose physical horrors were only accompanied by the damage to the psyche of their people. Von Trier paints his vision on the canvas. You'll feel like you're seeing a lost late 1940s spy-noir classic with its perfectly lit black-and-white scenes, while at the same time having the feeling of being a little off the cutting edge, especially in scenes like that Assassination aboard the train. When you see this movie, you literally experience the evolution of an art form.

For this reason Von Trier got into his own dogma movement shortly thereafter. And while "Breaking the Waves" and "Dancer in the Dark" are classics themselves, "Zentropa" has taken the art of filmmaking to new and exciting heights. 10/10, age like a good wine, and asks for a DVD release.

summary: Cinderella, the beautiful and kind-hearted daughter, sees her world turn upside down when her beloved mother dies, and her pained father remarries another woman, the wicked Lady Tremaine, who has two equally cruel daughters, the jealous Anastasia and Drizella. But, once more, things will go from bad to worse, when Cinderella's father, too, dies, leaving her all alone in the Lady's clutches to serve as her maid-of-all-work. Under those circumstances, a shabby and neglected Cinderella doesn't stand much of a chance of attending the King's royal ball--let alone, captivate the handsome Prince--unless she turns to her loving Fairy Godmother who has quite a few tricks up her sleeve. Nevertheless, will the wronged damsel ever find peace--and with it--her own Prince Charming?
translation:
but "Cinderella" gets my vote not only for the worst Disney princess movie, but also for the worst movie the company made during Walt's lifetime. The music is really pretty and history deserves to be called "classic". What fails in this film are the characters, especially the title character, who in the broadest sense of the word can only be called "heroine".

After a short prologue, the audience will be introduced to Cinderella. She wakes up in the morning and sings "A dream is a wish your heart makes." This justifies her as an idealist (and thus deserves our sympathy). Unfortunately, the script gives us no indication of what she's dreaming about. Freedom from her servant role? The respect of her stepfamily? Someone except mice and birds? In a song (excerpt from the film, but in the special features of the latest DVD) Cinderella tells of her wish that there could be many of her to make her work more efficient. You are going girlfriend! In short, Cinderella is a very mild character. She passively accepts the abuse of her stepfamily and escapes into her unspoken dreams. She asserts herself only once, reminding her stepmother that she is still a family member. But she gets permission to play the ball when she does her housework and finds something to wear, a symbolic gesture that is clearly absurd for everyone, except, of course, for Cinderella. Can anyone see that Belle or Jasmine is such a doormat? When Cinderella is bored, her male counterpart is lifeless. The prince in Cinderella gets no dialogue and almost no screen time. We are not given any indication as to whether he is a good man, whether he respects Cinderella or something. All we know is 1) he is a prince and 2) he dances well. Damn, even the Prince of "Snow White" has at least been able to sing a romantic song. This lack of development not only makes Romance less interesting, it also makes Cinderella look like a social mountaineer or an idiot and weakens her already weak appeal.

Perhaps when you realize how boring the main characters were, animators decided to give the comic relief of the movie to Cinderella's friends, the mice, excessive screen time. Granted, these characters are amusing. Still, if the comic relief steals the show from the clients, well, let's just say your story has some problems.

Dinsey loves to proclaim all of his animated features as "masterpieces". While many of them are, there are some who do not deserve this appellation in any way. Cinderella is a prime example of this.

summary: The Forrester family - father Mitch Forrester, mother Helen Forrester, their pre-teen son Billy Forrester and their pre-school son Woody Forrester - have just moved to a new town where Mitch is starting a new job. Both Mitch and Billy are worried about fitting into their new environment. It's worse for Billy as Woody, who is not worried about the move, is at that stage in his life where everything is simple and easy. Billy's first day in the fifth grade at his new school does not go well when he gets into an altercation with the class bullies, led by Joe Guire. The altercation involves worms and Billy stating that he eats worms all the time, which leads to all the bullies calling him "Wormboy". As such, Joe bets Billy that he can't eat ten worms (without vomiting), the bet to take place this upcoming Saturday, with the last worm to be consumed by 7pm. Despite having a notoriously weak stomach, Billy takes him up on the bet. As the bet starts, the only classmate on Billy's side is ...
translation:
I saw the commercials for this movie and was pretty confident that I would detest it. For one, it was one of those "loosely novel-based" movies, which usually means that the author saw the script, hated it, and refused to be associated with the film. Worse, the trailer showed only the most banal slapstick, which is conceivable (eg: child is sprayed with a garden hose in the face ... and falls over). When my little brother put it in his head, this was the must - have movie of the season (of course he was thinking the same thing about "cars", "about the hedge", "the ant swarm", "monster house", etc, etc admittedly, I was less than enthusiastic.

But once in the cinema, the movie convinced me for a variety of reasons. First and foremost, the authors capture the "children's dialogue" better than any other children's film I've ever seen. A good example of this comes right after the headmaster accidentally ate a worm in an egg omelet. The boys make a lame, over the exaggerated impression that the headmaster is teaching them what makes them realistic, since all the little kids (mistakenly) think they are making big mockery of their adult tormentors. Then one of the boys asks, "Why did he say, 'Alley oop'?" Another boy answers, "Maybe he's crazy!" and the whole group laughs loudly. Not a hilarious response, but the kind of thing a young child would devise on the spot, and the kind of remark that other kids of his age would find funny. As if to confirm, my little brother laughed right at the cue when they were spoken on the screen; I could practically hear his voice, which produced exactly the same lines when he got into a similar situation.

Another reason why the movie works is that the authors seem to make problems like bullying, sibling relationships, creating new kid at school, and peer pressure / conformity without making any of them as if they were subplots for any after-school special. For example, the bully (Joe) is not stereotyped; he is definitely bad, but not pure evil, and just enough of his home life reveals that the audience feels sympathy for him and understands his bullying origins. Nor is there a "Cue the dramatic music" moment where Billy ('Worm Boy') realizes what a complete tool he is to his younger brother, Woody, and yet, at the end of the film, a sort of minor transformation has been made. There is some realism here in the way the characters solve situations and the way they relate to each other, and very little of it looks cheesy.

The film's only drawback comes in the form of an absolutely ridiculous dance scene that even the creators of the infamous McDonald's dance party in "Mac and Me" would mock. Why, oh why was it put into the movie? Has Austin Rogers (Adam) pulled a Macaulay Culkin and refused to take the role unless he got a vehicle to show off his oh so impressive dancing skills? The entire sequence definitely did not have to be there and was a little less funny than any given show on "The History Channel". Overall, though, this film was excellent, and the length (about an hour and twenty minutes) was almost perfect. One of the best and most realistic live action children's movies you'll ever see, when you're ever around kids or just remembering what it's like to be a kid.

summary: Between the heaven and the Earth exist the Zu's mountain range, where live the immortals of Omei, the highest mountain of Zu, but the kingdom is in danger by Amnesia, a renegade immortal what want to rule Zu and all the world. White Eyebrows, Zu's leader, call to his most experts fighters for to defeat Amnesia until destroy It, but Amnesia hides in the legendary and almost myth Blood Cavern in order to make stronger his powers. While Red, Eyebrows' servant, watches the enter of Blood Cavern, King Sky and the others warriors will try to find a way of exterminate Amnesia with an ancient and powerful mystical swords, hoping to be free of the Amnesia's threat.
translation: For those of you who love the Lord of the Rings and love special effects, check out this movie! That will surely keep you on the screen. You may even like it, if you like how people fight magic.

summary: Detroit, the early 1960s. Curtis Taylor, Jr., a car salesman, breaks into the music business with big dreams. He signs a trio of young women, the Dreamettes, gets them a job backing an R&B performer, James "Thunder" Early, establishes his own record label and starts wheeling and dealing. When Early flames out, Curtis makes the Dreamettes into headliners as the Dreams, but not before demoting their hefty big-voiced lead singer, Effie White, and putting the softer-voiced looker, Deena Jones, in front. Soon after, he fires Effie, sends her into a life of proud poverty, and takes Deena and the Dreams to the top. How long can Curtis stay there, and will Effie ever get her due?
translation:
Eddie Murphy as Best Supporting Actor What an insult to Alan Arkin and Djimon Hounsou.

Jamie Foxx (who can act) goes through this movie like a zombie.

Beyonce ??? That was action ???

This film fades in comparison to CHICAGO or another recent musical.

If it had not been for the great singing and performance of Jennifer Hudson, I would have given this a ZERO.

And no, I've never seen the play, so I do not do the typical Broadway Vs. Hollywood rap.

summary: At the end of the 19th century a large cylinder falls on the English countryside. A young writer is among those who witnesses the event. But soon the cylinder opens and a group of Martians appear. It soon becomes apparent the Martians intend to attack. The writer soon finds himself fighting for his own survival as the military fights to stop the Martians, society collapses, and as the human race fights to win the war of the worlds.
translation:
I have to admit that I burst into laughter when I saw a reviewer comparing it to LOTR. Well, if you exclude the dwarves, the cast of thousands, the big special effects, the big battles, the strong characterization, the decent action, the good acting, the classical direction and everything else. What lets you go. And boy, is this movie going? If Mr. Piano was going his way, it would probably be an uninterrupted three-hour hardcore walk through the Wisconsin countryside, but every 40 minutes or so, these pesky Martians show up for a few seconds to interrupt him before settling on one another hike starts. You have never seen so much in a movie. If this really had a budget of $ 20 million, most of it would have had to run on Mr. Piano's shoes because he had to endure many couples with all the running he does. This explains why there is no money for decent effects, a decent video camera or real actors. Honestly, it's like a bizarre fetish video for people who want to do something with long walks in period costumes. Even in the forerun, this is a loooonggg walk.

As for the science-fiction stuff, I think it was a mistake to bring Martians into the movie: they only hinder walking, which is clearly more interesting to the director than the story.

I wonder how much Mr. Piano requires dogs to go?

summary: Prosperous California couple Carter and Meghan find the perfect live-in nanny when they hire Abby Reed. But no sooner does she arrive than she begins to arouse suspicion in friends and neighbors who, one by one, start dying. By the time Meghan looks deeper into the past, it's too late. Abby's work has already begun.
translation:
If you have a lot of time to waste ... it's fine. It's moving at a good pace, but to pull that movie off, it would have to be a bit longer, with a bit more background for the actor.

The acting is OK. Mariana Klaveno as an actress does the best job and is the most credible.

William R. Moses played a pretty good role as a husband.

Gail O'Grady, the woman, had a weak part and the reasons for her return to work were not developed.

The end is kinda silly. Like most of these Sitter movies ... there are parts that are interesting ... but overall, it leaves you wondering why you spent the time.

summary: Alex, a sad-eyed mournful man, goes into psychotherapy: he discloses he's a hit man. He also tells the doctor, after a few sessions, that he's attracted to a young woman he's met in the waiting room. She's Sarah, 23, quick, edgy, and perhaps attracted to him as well. But he's married, the dutiful father of a young precocious boy, so Sarah brushes him off. In flashbacks we see him get his start as a killer, at his father's prompting: it's the family business. Dad gives Alex his next assignment: to kill the therapist. Alex keeps returning to Sarah, calling her, stopping by her apartment, as he decides what to do about the hit, his father, his marriage, and his malaise.
translation:
Had that put on my TIVO for a rainy day because of the cast, some really hardworking people in the industry, and when I finally saw, I was not disappointed.

This movie has some Altman-like flavor (it's mentioned in the credits as a "thank you person") that uses seemingly independent, independent storylines that intertwine when the movie reaches its climax. Macy is clean, clean and honest like a man who can not escape his "fate", Sutherland plays and portrays as little as possible, Neve adds Splash to a deliberately weakened environment, adds Tracy Ullman, Barbara Bain Impossible on TV?) Not to mention the steady John Ritter and you have all the ingredients for a good movie. The script is clear, the dialogue is free of clich√©s and thoughtful (especially between Macy and David Dorfman). Suspend faith and enjoy, this is really time spent well.

summary: Kol is an evil guy about to be executed on a distant spaceship. He manages to escape on a shuttle and make his way to some woods in America. The commander of the spaceship decides to send out The Alienator to execute Kol at all costs. Kol meets up with some teens and Ward Armstrong and together they all try not to get killed by the pursuing Woman of Death - The Alienator.
translation: Nothing can prepare you for another lousy Bimbo trip! This time it will be presented to you by the inevitable Fred Olen Ray! As for commercials, this does not click! As science fiction, it's just unoriginal! All we see is an ugly female android wearing a bikini to destroy the earth and show everything that is almost empty! Give me a break !!! If this type of entertainment is your thing, why not just dust off the old SI swimsuit magazines from the attic ?! That would have been much better if it had not set the sleaze factor very high, but that would not make it great anyway. I would like to point out another movie called THE ASSAULT (1996) by Jim Wynorski, which resembles the identity of ALIENATOR. It shows why first-person femme fatale action movies do not work well in America. Sorry, guys!

summary: A ten-years-later continuation of Hal Hartley's "Henry Fool", where Fay Grim (Posey) is coerced by a CIA agent (Goldblum) to try and locate notebooks that belonged to her fugitive ex-husband (Ryan). Published in them is information that could compromises the security of the U.S., causing Fay to first head to Paris to fetch them ...
translation:
Fay Grim is told on his face a story of espionage and intrigue with a nod and a wink. Continuing his extraordinary Henry Fool, Hal Hartley creates a startling mix of film noir and hardened spy thriller that starts with a knowing smile and a big dose of laughter and turns as poignant and warm as any movie I've seen this year is Parkey Posey Fay Grim, an ignorant Mata Hari, caught between the love of her ex-husband Henry Fool and the questionable intentions of a charming CIA agent. As Agent Fulbright, Jeff Goldblum is a master of wit and sarcasm, in a role that seems tailored to his talents. He has never been better. James Urbaniak is Fay's brother Simon, imprisoned but famous for his wildly popular poetry books. His love for his work and his sister brings with it a passion to contrast the sullen nature of the spies that eventually populate Fay's world. And Liam Aiken is Fay's exuberant 14-year-old son. Although that may be superfluous. Aikens restrained style is remarkably "old soul" for someone his age.

The whole movie is Dutch-turned, the off-kilter style famous by Orson Welles and used mostly in horror movies and psycho thrillers convey a sense of foreboding. In Fay Grim, it's fascinating to use the style from the opening credits to the end, in the next one deceptively clever. Because as the viewer falls for the perfectly timed comedic elements and the joke of Hartley's brilliant script, something happens. The film takes a dark but strangely reassuring turn as these characters magically become sympathetic before our eyes. What began as a dark comedy turns into a romantic drama and the transition is masterful. Slow pace is replaced by breathtaking action and we are sucked straight into the whirlpool.

Hartley's keen dialogue combined with the astounding accomplishments of a perfectly matched ensemble ultimately creates a delicious movie cocktail. Said with the luxury of one who is able to write, produce, direct, edit, and even compose the music, Hal Hartley has created a clever, sexy story of spying with tongue just cracked in the cheek , Fay Grim is part of Dashiell Hammett, part Raymond Chandler, and part of Ian Fleming, shaken and perhaps also touched.

summary: American tourist Jesse and French student Celine meet by chance on the train from Budapest to Vienna. Sensing that they are developing a connection, Jesse asks Celine to spend the day with him in Vienna, and she agrees. So they pass the time before his scheduled flight the next morning together. How do two perfect strangers connect so intimately over the course of a single day? What is that special thing that bonds two people so strongly? As their bond turns to love, what will happen to them the next morning when Jesse flies away?
translation:
There are many notable things before Sunrise, almost too many to fit into a review like this, but suffice it to say that it is one of the most observant character studies of the nineties, perhaps even throughout the contemporary cinema, to avoid being attentive about love, per-say, as much as it is about a human connection. How do you fall in love at first sight? Nobody does that, at least that is the consensus that Linklater wants to show with his film. And yet, there is the possibility of such an intense connection, a bond that can be formed into the young, with many ideas that can be articulated and expressed with a breadth of cynicism while at the same time being very tender and true. Linklater tells us the story of Celine and Jessie, a Frenchman and an American boy, getting off the train to Vienna and talking about things on the way, at first arbitrarily, then personally (Jessie sees death for the first time in his life) great-grandfather). Jessie persuades Celine to come with him one night in the 'city' in Vienna, to his plane the next morning.

Before Sunrise gives Jessie and Celine, in the middle of beautiful Vienna, sceneries and locations that deal with topics that are very important, and, to a certain extent, conversations about what it's like to watch people, the one in the other lead. These are often relationships and obligations, as Jessie and Celine tell stories that are sometimes inconsequential or apparent, and others that can say a lot about their essential qualities. We hear confessions of desires for other loved ones, or what is not really love, being part of a family or part of an education that may teach you how you love your life, what it means to believe or not believe in any religious form, or to have any connection to any belief and soul (I loved the tittle of the Quakers in the church), and sometimes laced with cynicism or skepticism. Jessie may be more responsible for this final part, but the fascinating thing about the film is that it's never cynical itself, just commenting on the cynicism that lies in the concerns of men and women at this age of their lives.

Meanwhile, it's always great to see Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy in those roles where they are not incessantly annoying in this 90's Generation X mode, but the people are, if not in the central one Imagination of the film, It's not bad, but necessary, you might think you have to run around in the streets of a city. The imagination is that of an old romantic picture ala Brief Encounter, only here the intimacy is expressed in the main characters, either among each other, where sweet trifles are actually acceptable ("I have to tell you a secret," says Jessie and then leans for a kiss, ho-ho), or in the little moments that appear on the way with other people. I loved the scene with the poet, where it's very cinematic to suddenly find a random romantic bit player in the midst of a romantic picture with such beautiful words, or with the palm reader and the reactions of Jessie and Celine that we could share but really see that they do it first-hand. Hawke and Delpy are intriguing the roles all the time - we can see neuroses already forming for their adult lives - as they can lead into the future ...

With great cinematography and a script with an ear to the natural joke and a true sense of what it means to have a moment of bliss, however, in itself, how it can lead to something more. Who can say that you can not suddenly be attached to someone, if only for less than 24 hours, and so much more connected than a couple? Maybe that's Linklater's thesis, but there's more to it than that. It's a very dense movie, and I'll keep calling it. A scene that is both cheesy and brilliant is that when the two speak in front of each other "on the phone" and mimic their representations, they might come to each other's friend. A +

summary: Mala leads a contented life as the best hunter in his Canadian Arctic tribe, providing meat, fish and birds with his great skill. When another tribe member returns from trading furs with the white men for items such as a gun and an iron needle, Mala's wife, Aba, urges him to make the 500-mile trek across the frozen tundra to do the same. After the long night of winter, Mala does go with his family to the white man's "floating house" in Tjarnak. The friendly captain makes trade for Mala's excellent furs, but upsets Mala when he insists that Aba sleep with him that night. "He didn't even ask me!" Mala complains. Afterwards, the captain suggests that Mala go whale hunting and promises not to touch his wife, so Mala agrees. But news of a successful catch spurs a celebration on board ship, and the captain has Aba forcibly removed from her tent, plied with liquor, and then he rapes her. In the morning, the still-drunk Aba staggers from the ship, but collapses in the snow, where she is ...
translation: I was really surprised how much a movie over 60 years old could impress me. It's almost two hours long, there are absolutely no stars, there are subtitles, but still it's interesting and exciting to see. What impressed me most was the realism of the film. You could almost feel the cold of the ice, because you could see that the storms are real. This is a relief in a CGI world like today. I wondered how much work that had to be for Van Dyke. I read somewhere that it took 17 months to film it. Who wants to talk about Titanic again? It's a great movie with a great message, and I'd recommend it to future directors to see how big and realistic films can be if they're focused on realism rather than visual effects.

summary: A director is casting dancers for a large production. Large numbers of hopefulls audition, hoping to be selected. Throughout the day, more and more people are eliminated, and the competition gets harder. Eventually, approximately a dozen dancers must compete for a few spots, each hoping to impress the director with their dancing skill. But, is this really what the director is looking for?
translation:
I was fortunate enough to see A Chorus Line when it came to my town .. I was younger than .. but it was an excellent game ... so someone would tell me why in heaven name they had to make a movie out do it .. and why Michael Douglas ??? He was not suitable for the role .. this movie really took a lot of time !!!

my advice is NOT to rent this movie .. save your money for something better like "cats" ....

summary: Hindustan (Urdu name for India) used to a vast territory and countries' like Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bangla Desh, and Bhutan were all it's provinces. All this changed when the British established their rule over India, and promoted their policy of hatred, and division - mainly between the Hindus and the Muslims. After their departure in 1947, the celebrations of a independent India were short-lived, and the divisions created by the British stayed on and flourished with extremists from both sides ready to kill anyone from the other side. While the Muslims under Jinnah wanted a separate country, which they would like to call Pakistan, the Hindus wanted the Muslims to leave this country and go to Pakistan. Clashes followed, millions fled, millions more were killed, Very little is known of mankind's heinous behavior in this circumstances, such as looting, raping, and kidnapping. puro was one such woman who was recently married to Ramchand, and then abducted by a man named Rashid, who ...
translation: Pinjar is one of the few films that really leaves its mark and makes you think. This film shows in Partition India the true reality of the division of India. Urmila receives full marks for her beautiful and deeply emotional depiction of a suffering woman who can not walk. Their freedom, their personal identity and their respect for the family were eliminated overnight by a tragic land dispute. Manoj bajpai is just brilliant as her repent kidnapper. There are some moments in the movie where you are moved to tears. The film at points is deeply traumatic. Some of the partition scenes are scary, but Urmila's stamina and survival are remarkable. From a woman deprived of her liberty to a woman who gave women freedom in similar situations. A remarkable movie that should be recognized for smart characters and storytelling.

summary: Detroit, the early 1960s. Curtis Taylor, Jr., a car salesman, breaks into the music business with big dreams. He signs a trio of young women, the Dreamettes, gets them a job backing an R&B performer, James "Thunder" Early, establishes his own record label and starts wheeling and dealing. When Early flames out, Curtis makes the Dreamettes into headliners as the Dreams, but not before demoting their hefty big-voiced lead singer, Effie White, and putting the softer-voiced looker, Deena Jones, in front. Soon after, he fires Effie, sends her into a life of proud poverty, and takes Deena and the Dreams to the top. How long can Curtis stay there, and will Effie ever get her due?
translation:
Yes. I'm pretty sure I saw this movie years ago when it came to the Supremes.

Another recycled story glittered in the Hollywood style and borrowed scripts from better films in the music industry.
Nothing original here.

More make-up, glamor costumes and choreography = more money for the questionably "talented" Beyonce remix.

If you like the fallback style, you should appreciate actual groups who have struggled (digitized without voices and a Hollywood empire).

Beyonce's involvement makes this hypocritical garbage.

summary: USA, summer of 1969. Man is about to walk on the moon, the Vietnam War is breaking out, and there is the great concert in Woodstock. In a holiday camp for Jewish families not far from Woodstock, Alison and her family are on vacation. Pearl, the mother is young and attractive, but defeated by life, having become pregnant on her first loving relationship, forgetting her dreams to devote herself to her children. Marty, the father is absent because he is busily occupied working at a television repair business. One day a charming salesman arrives at the camp, selling clothes and knick-knacks. He lives an intense life of love and passion, culminating in an escape to Woodstock with Pearl, where events have a deep impact.
translation: Why do people who do not know how a certain time has been in the past feel the need to define that time for others? Replace Woodstock with the Civil War and the Apollo Moon Landing with the sinking of the Titanic, and you've got a movie as realistic as this formulaic soap opera, which is completely populated with substandard trash. Are these children who were too young to go to Woodstock and did not pass the school education? "I will show this old mine, I will bring out my own movie and prove that you do not have to know anything about your subject to earn any money!" Yes, we already know that. The only thing that watched this movie was to give me a little insight into subcategory thinking. The next time I see a slut in a bar that looks like Diane Lane, I run in the other direction. It is child maltreatment that parents raise children so worthless. It is public abuse, Woodstock and the moon landing just to put in a strip, as if the ipso facto means that the film 1969 portraits.

summary: This is the retelling of the events of the weekend of April 23rd 2004. Three young, sexy girls go into the woods on a camping trip to a family cabin. The local forest Ranger had warned them about an old Hermit who lives in the woods, so when two young, great looking guys show up, the girls are nervous. Anxiety turns to attraction after they get to know each other. The next day, someone is still watching them. The Hermit shows up and threatens them, telling them to leave or die. That night, the gruesome murders begin and we realize that the victims are little more than food for this √íwatcher in the woods. Snares, long sharp knives, bear traps and branches all make for perfect ways to end the lives of these young adults who are camping on haunted ground. In the end, the line between friendship and terror is blurred when we realize the murderer is an evil spirit who befriends then murders his prey.
translation: HORRENDOUS! Avoid like the plague. I would rate that in the top 10 worst films of all time. Special effects, drama, mood, sound, etc. seem to be done by Kita students ... wait, I've seen programs better than this. Opens like a gentle porn show with a hazy naked woman making a shower scene and getting sick from then on. Good nude scenes, but that's it. Sound and light problems were persistent throughout the movie. Sometimes I swear I could hear the roar of the camera motors. YIKES! I would like to see another movie about this story, but made by different people. This group of actors and crew needs more acting and film lessons. Chosen 1 in 10.

summary: A teen boy grows from playing and fighting with his German-shepherd dog, to playing kids and adult games with two equally young girls, in a dream-like forest which eventually turns eerie, and somber.
translation: Would anyone really see this RUBBIS if it did not contain young kids walking around naked? From a cinematic point of view, it's probably one of the worst movies that I've come across as terrible. Some Perv woke up one day and thought I would make a movie with little girls and call it art, stick it in nature and there is no need for a story or explanation of how they got there or why they did not appear somewhere to live or have parents, because such films do not need anything. I would comment on the rest of the movie, but I did not tick off spoilers, so I'll just say avoid avoiding and find a suitable movie to watch

summary: A revealing movie about the tumultuous life of Little Richard Penniman, whose ground-breaking music revolutionized rock and roll. Growing up a social misfit in poverty, Little Richard's passion, talent and flamboyance catapulted him into the limelight of rock music. His career was rocked by his homosexuality, his fundamental beliefs and the pervasive discrimination within the music industry. We go through his chart-topping years when he lived the quintessential Rock and Roll life, indulging in all-night orgies and the spiritual callings that pulled him in and out of the music industry. But as alcohol and drug addition plagued his career in the late 1960s, Little Richard makes the life-saving decision to return to his family. Through their love and strength, and Little Richard's resolve, he moves on in history to become one of the most memorable performers in rock and roll.
translation: I know that the true story of Little Richard is more exciting than this maudlin and thoroughly average biopic. But producer Little Richard was probably too reluctant to expose any filthy details of his life, and gave us just a forgotten facsimile of his career highlights from the 50s and 60s.

summary: A semiserious, often rollicking, multigenerational insider's look at the origins of surfing, the colorful and subversive birth of surf culture, and the mythology and lure of the big wave. This passionate and fluid film is without question the first authentic history of surfing from its humble Hawaiian beginnings to the big business it became to the still-rebellious universe it inhabits today. Riding Giants is a study in individuality and freedom, the pursuit and techniques of pure kinetic pleasure, and the risk taking and attitudes that characterize its leading figures. For some viewers, this is perhaps more than they ever wanted to know. But Peralta's detailed knowledge of the surfing lifestyle, its icons and locations, its boom and exploitation by the media, and the fascination it has held for young men for more than five decades is unparalleled and fuels this expedition for the expert and initiate alike. Closely chronicling the sometimes-life-and-death drama that big-wave riding ...
translation:
I found out a few days ago that the creators of this movie have made a pun on the title. This film is not primarily about the "giant ride", but especially about the giants of the sport, RINGING gigents, to shift the focus.

In my youth, I lived one block off the wedge, one of the hardest and best bodysurfing spots in the world. I was surfing in 15 to 18 feet, and ridden and was hammered by 10 and 12 foot waves on many occasions. This experience makes me totally excited about the surfers in this movie. The idea that Jeff Clark, apparently a normal mortal, could get away with Mavericks BY HIMSELF for over a decade, is unattainable to me. The first safety rule of any water sport is "Never surf / dive / swim alone". He went where sensible people were not and lived to tell about it. I would not go out there if the water was 75 degrees and the sharks were all gone.

In the world of warm water: the first shot of the waves in the Jaws always makes the skin tingle all over my body. These are not just scary waves, these are uncontrolled intestinal tides. If we see that Laird Hamilton not only survives waves of 40 to 60 feet (I can barely type these numbers), but I actually work faces like a fun day in Rincon, I'm blown away. There is a dedication and concentration in big-wave drivers that is comparable to that of anyone in the world.

This is a great movie. I only gave it a 9 instead of a 10 because it does not mention that there are big big wave riders outside the Hamilton / Kalama crew, and I think they deserve to be mentioned. Splice in Ken Bradshaw outside Log Cabins and a 10's it!

summary: Jennifer Baichwal's cameras follow Edward Burtynsky (1955- ) as he visits what he calls manufactured landscapes: slag heaps, e-waste dumps, huge factories in the Fujian and Zhejiang provinces of China, and a place in Bangladesh where ships are taken apart for recycling. In China, workers gather outside the factory, exhorted by their team leader to produce more and make fewer errors. A woman assembles a circuit breaker, and women and children are seen picking through debris or playing in it. Burtynsky concludes with a visit to Shanghai, the world's fastest growing city, where wealth and poverty, high-rises and old neighborhoods are side by side.
translation:
I was very excited to see this movie and expected a visual digression on the relationship between artistic beauty and nature that contained the wisdom of "Rivers and Tides". I did not get that. Instead, I get a rather uninspired film about how human industry is bad for nature. This is clearly a rather unorthodox statement.

The photographer seems to occasionally populate the images about the aesthetic qualities of his paintings and the supposed "ethical" duty he has towards the workers, along the periphery. And frankly, the pictures were generally not that impressive. And after this "artist" scale is the basis for what makes something beautiful.

A stupid movie in every way. For people who want to feel better in their environmental awareness ... but not for someone who wants to think about the complexity of the problems involved.

summary: Edward Walters, an auto mechanic, falls for the intelligent and beautiful Catherine Boyd. It is love at first sight. There is however a problem, she's engaged to jerk James Moreland. Fortunately, Catherine's uncle likes Ed, and with his friends they scheme to make Catherine fall for Ed. The comedy in this movie stems from the fact that Catherine's uncle is none other than Albert Einstein, who's portrayed as a fun loving genius, as are his mischievous colleagues, Nathan, Kurt and Boris.
translation: Since I am a big fan of the romantic comedy genre and have therefore seen a large number of these films, it is rare that they make me feel unique. Likewise, it is rare for me to gasp through the laughter in several scenes. The love story is a bit thin on the ground, but I would say that's probably the best, because this romantic comedy has the emphasis on "comedy," and in any case, it just pushes the limits of credibility a little more than I like Most rom com's do. The four scientists have provided some of the funniest moments not just in this movie, but in every movie I've seen in a long time. I hesitated for a few moments until I finally chose a "10" over a "9" as a rating, as I believe that too many people use them indiscriminately and therefore lose the maximum rating of effectiveness. I'm also a big Meg Ryan fan who helps, but this is one of the few films I've seen that I would say is in the shade. She and Tim Robbins are the main characters, but for me they play the second fiddle against the antics of the awkward intellectuals. A really laughing loud movie.

summary: A mysterious creature from another planet, resembling a giant blob of jelly, lands on earth. The people of a nearby small town refuse to listen to some teenagers who have witnessed the blob's destructive power. In the meantime, the blob just keeps on getting bigger.
translation: Most of the atomic-age monster monsters I saw on television as a kid - and some of them, THE BLOB, scared me. Films like INVADERS FROM MARS made it all too clear that "toddlers" just should not get used to things like things that invade the homeworld; THE BLOB has just repeated this fact once more. I like to remember the late evenings I spent on the floor watching Body Snatchers and Martian Invaders and Blobs enter an unsuspecting society. There was a summer, in the early 1980s, when a local science museum (in Richmond, Virginia) held every weekend a classic of the nuclear age. These were 16mm movies, and most were black and white (and the projector was loud), and THE BLOB's "color" print had faded to a faint pink - but, man, it was funny. I dragged my mother along, and she enjoyed it as much as I did. There, in this science museum, I really fell in love with THE BLOB. The intention of the filmmaker was, of course, to make money - but it was the sincerity of everyone involved, from the filmmakers to the "talent" (the players) who fell in love with this movie. Cheesy? You bet. Cheesy? They do not become cheesier. But, man, what a movie!

summary: Nice, nerdy Xenia, Ohio senior high school reporter Chris Hughes (18), paperboy and cool quarterback Hudson Reed's cool pack's punching-ball, can't even get girls to attend a free booze-party. When Chris's biological parents, publisher Peter Mack and nude model Honey, die, he inherits a horny teenager's wet dream: Heaven magazine porn empire, a huge Hollywood 'play heaven' villa and $87,000,000 cash, which instantly makes him Mr. Popularity. However his uncle Duncan 'Duncay' Mack plots with lawyer Michael Hunt, the trust administrator, to cover up their embezzlement and steal the firm while the naive heir parties and barely attends school.
translation:
My friends can usually endure many hopeless movies, but this one was too bad for us to even see it through to the end. It was just so boring and unoriginal. Not even the "hot" girls playing in this movie could keep watching me. Everything was just predictable and annoying. The acting was sometimes good ..... but sometimes bad. The most annoying character in the movie you just wanted to die for would be the best friend of the main character. The more I saw him, the more I wanted to smash my screen. (You know what fat ugly kid I'm talking about)

The plot was done so many times before I think they should be sued by other movie companies. OK, it's a good idea, but that's all this movie had.

Overall, this movie can only be seen by yourself to save abuse from your friends. Or, if you have absolutely nothing better to do.

summary: Investigative reporter Jack Parlabane stumbles across the aftermath of a murder scene in Edinburgh, and when he shows little sign of shock at the gruesome killing of a respected doctor, Detective Inspector McGregor suspects that he is the killer and Parlabane must clear his name.
translation:
Did I miss something here? This "adaptation" has everything that Brookmyre's first novel had. Everything but history, laughter, black humor, political intrigues, characterizations, conspiracy and the appearance of meaning.

spoiler;

Godamnawful, from start to finish. They made a conspiracy of plot, they had a romance between Parablane and a policeman, and what was it about, dr. Slaughter was portrayed as a spectator, and who the hell was Annette Crosby?

It looked as if they had made a three-hour adjustment and then cut it down to 90 minutes. (Although the 90 minutes seemed to last forever.) Please, please, do not do this with other Brookmyre's books (especially "Land of the Blind").

summary: On the 28th of February, 1997, two men armed with AK-47 machine guns try to pull a heist at the Bank of America in North Hollywood, but their plan fails and they are kept under siege by the LAPD. During the ensuing forty-four minutes, Los Angeles witnesses live on television one of the greatest shoot-outs in American history.
translation:
Contrary to my principles, let me first draw a conclusion, because I have just seen this piece of "art" and still stand under strong impressions. The reader is asked to excuse my stronger vocabulary.

Well, this movie is absolutely terrible, and I would never bother to write a single word about it, if it were not for "44 minutes" it got me sick, which rarely happens to me. The fact that I paid for it does not make me any better, as does the fact that the film deserves the high user rating here.

So what's up with the movie? It has a fashionable title - "44 minutes". One thinks first of "fifteen minutes," which by the way is a much better movie, but still bad in my book, and in fact the two can be compared to some degree. But as luck would have it, the things they share are their worst qualities. In both plays Mr. Oleg Taktarov, who obviously fulfills the expectations and prejudices of the population with his strong Russian accent. Its purpose is to appeal to the spirit of the Cold War. Ah, we miss the good old days. Well, I do not suppose that he is a bad actor, I still have to judge his true performance, but he's just not a real human here, he's more like an archetype. How one can indulge in such things is completely beyond my comprehension. We can detect here modern American xenophobia. The point in the film in which Taktarov tells his companion that Romanians are not Germans and that they are in America is really ridiculous. Should we assume that the miserable duo's biggest wish is to become "real" Americans?

Then there is the media problem. Yes, it seems that most of what we learn comes from cameras, interviews and reporters. The director should let us feel the rhythm of the alleged 44 minutes. Instead, he bores us throughout the movie with interviews like in a cheap TV show and tries to reinvent the wheel. In 15 minutes, the topic of the media is the central theme. The point is presented as a teacher addressing a blunt student, but that deserves a separate comment, we are now focusing on 44 minutes. So I tried to identify the purpose of this movie. What is it? To give the audience a good time? To glorify weapons? To glorify the police? Violence? Oh yes, the officer gives the underage delinquent the Bible. So it has to promote peace and understanding? I do not think so, but do not ask me. All I know is that I did not like that.

Ah, Michael Madsen. I admit, I'm a big fan. I hoped he was a good point, but I was wrong. It is not his fault though.

As a final comment, the comparison of "firepower" and "willpower" at the end of the film was one of the worst lines I've ever heard.

In summary, on the scale 1-10, I give a pure, unadulterated 1.

summary: The Herlihys are a working class family from Chicago whose three children take wildly divergent paths: Brian joins the Marines right out of High School and goes to Vietnam, Michael becomes involved in the civil rights movement and after campaigning for Bobby Kennedy and Eugene McCarthy becomes involved in radical politics, and Katie gets pregnant, moves to San Francisco and joins a hippie commune. Meanwhile, the Taylors are an African-American family living in the deep South. When Willie Taylor, a minister and civil rights organizer, is shot to death, his son Emmet moves to the city and eventually joins the Black Panthers, serving as a bodyguard for Fred Hampton.
translation:
Do we really need more narcissistic waste in the Baby Boomer generation? Technically, I'm a boomer, even though at the time when all "idealistic youths" of the 1960s read Marx, burnt their draft cards and generally prolonged a war that destroyed tens of thousands of lives; I was still in elementary school. But I remember them well, and 9 out of 10 were just stupid idiots who would believe everything as long as it was destructive.

This is just another exercise in self esteem from the kids who never really grew up on.

summary: One at a time, each by herself, ten women speak directly into the camera and talk about themselves. Talking about a relationship with a man - sometimes a long-term one and more often a brief one - triggers remembrances of a parent lost, of a pet, of childhood. The first woman talks about running into a true love several years later, the second describes her loss of virginity, the third recounts a discomforting blind date; only one woman has experienced a long-term marriage. Dreams figure into several stories. Some ask "Is there only one great love?" "Where am I when I'm in a relationship - even one that ends in a night?," is a question others raise.
translation:
This is a movie about how men think women think about love. No woman describes a sexual encounter with a single night and explains her to a love story.

Of the ten monologues I felt, only three actually felt some sort of truth through them. I've been waiting for the movie to get better, a bit, but never better enough.

This is an interesting concept, and I always wanted it to be good, but it never succeeded. Maybe if they were really love stories, it would have worked.

summary: Dan Katzir's autobiographical film expresses the outcry of his generation, as it struggles to find love and privacy amidst the reality of daily terror and hate. Mr. Katzir, a former officer and paratrooper intimately reveals his loves story with Iris, a charming girl about to begin her army service. A truly poetic film filled with beauty innocence and wisdom. This film is also an important historic document with rare and shocking footage from the era of assasinated prime minister Yitzchak Rabin. Made with much love and humour, this brave film examines Israel's most painful scars. A unique Israeli classic which has garnered over 13 International Awards across the globe.
translation: One of the best records of Israel's response to the murder of Rabin.Extra true and, of course, it captures the spirit of the nation. Of particular importance was the response of young people to the trauma of Israel's loss and the feeling that we will overcome.

summary: A man who has devoted himself to serving the leader of the free world is accused of plotting against him in this thriller. Pete Garrison (Michael Douglas) is a veteran Secret Service agent who has had a long and distinguished career helping protect the president of the United States. David Breckinridge (Kiefer Sutherland) is a fellow Secret Service agent who learned most of what he knows from Garrison and holds him in great respect. When intelligence data suggests that there is a mole within the Secret Service who is part of a plot to assassinate President Ballentine (David Rasche), Garrison launches an investigation to ferret out the rogue agent, and asks Breckinridge to go over the evidence with a fine-toothed comb. Breckinridge is shocked when the clues point to Garrison as the traitor within the Secret Service, but his sense of duty compels him to see that his former mentor is placed under arrest. Garrison eludes his captors and struggles to prove his innocence while tracking down...
translation: SPOILER ALERT! ! ! Personally, I do not understand why Pete did not help save Williams' life, I mean, it would be great to know why William was motivated or forced. I think Secret Service members are every day people, and there is a rumor that the author was a member of the Secret Service, now he motivations clear, well known.But as a rental, this movie will not satisfy you, because the old but used twists, the average acting - these are just things in this movie, just to keep you waiting for the end. Clark Johnson as Director of SWAT I've done a lot better work than this time and I still wonder how the producers (like Michael Douglas, for example) put this movie in the cinemas.

summary: Captain Drummond and his girlfriend want to marry but a hidden treasure in the house in which they want to celebrate their marriage is complicating the situation.
translation:
This Drummond entry lacks continuity. Most of them have their elements of silliness, the postponed wedding and so on. However, this has an endless series of events that take place in the near dark as the characters move from one place to another. The house seems more like a city. There is also Leo G. Carrol, who is such an obvious suspect nobody seems to see. He is a stranger and behaves quite suspicious, but Drummond and the people seem to pick up nothing. Still, it's a pretty good action and a pretty good ending.

I know that Algie is supposed to be a cartoon character, but like Nigel Bruce in the Rathbone Sherlock Holmes flicks, he's so arrogant that it's hard to imagine anyone with taste or intelligence around him. Is there a story behind him that will explain how he and Drummond became associates?

summary: The Maclean brothers, Paul and Norman, live a relatively idyllic life in rural Montana, spending much of their time fly fishing. The sons of a minister, the boys eventually part company when Norman moves east to attend college, leaving his rebellious brother to find trouble back home. When Norman finally returns, the siblings resume their fishing outings, and assess both where they've been and where they're going.
translation:
The combination of reading Novella and watching this movie inspired my wife and me to new levels. Recently, I thought about a statement by artist Thomas Kinkade in one of his inspiring books; He says, "You and I were not designed to breathe the stinking air of five o'clock traffic, nor do I believe that God had banal TV programs, media hype, worthless purchases, and soul pollution in mind when he created the universe. "I had not seen a river flow in a few years," but after thinking about Kinkade's statement, I was made to look at the movie with a spiritual look, I saw it, and a whole new world for myself seen the movie and it inspired me to read the book (a must) I was always frustrated in Southern California but somehow trapped in its materialistic society, the film really puts into perspective the way we should really experience God's creations. A combination of Maclean's story and my desire to move back to the Northwest has made me move to Montana, I want my future kin who are able to tour the countryside, go fly fishing with me, ride horses in nothing but open country and calm lakes in the mountains. A place where you rarely worry about crime. I look around in SoCal, and all I see are shopping malls, rude, growling people in their Mercedez Bens, miles of congested highway vehicles, gangs, race riots on the verge of a violent eruption, and all skeptical of others' intentions. Anyway, the movie is very inspiring with brilliant acting and a deep story about the fragile connections of loved ones. Much thought is made in this film. The landscape alone is worth seeing and actually helps to reduce tensions. You should end this movie relaxed and full of insights on your own life. It takes a compassionate, intelligent and spiritual person to truly grasp the meaning. If you do not understand the art of cinema and how a director achieves his goals through dialogue, sound, light, color, scenery, camera angle / movement, and so on. Then this movie is probably not for the crowd who thinks "The Fast and The Furious" is the biggest movie. Granted, it was entertaining, but shallow.

Conclusion: This film helps to realize that life is not about how much money you have or what you own. Rather, it's about your relationships with family and friends and the experiences you share together. QUALITY NOT QUALITY

summary: Bruce Nolan, a television reporter in Buffalo, N.Y., is discontented with almost everything in life despite his popularity and the love of his girlfriend Grace . At the end of the worst day of his life, Bruce angrily ridicules and rages against God and God responds. God appears in human form and, endowing Bruce with divine powers, challenges Bruce to take on the big job to see if he can do it any better.
translation: A very funny movie. It was good to see Jim Carrey in top shape again. It was definitely worth the price. Morgan Freeman and Jennifer Aniston both played outstanding supporting roles in this film. I think they may have played the dog a bit too much, but still watch a good movie.

summary: The first half of the film portrays the struggle of the under-armed, under-manned colonists against the British Redcoats at Lexington, Bunker Hill and Valley Forge. Other landmarks of the American Revolution shown include the Boston Tea Party, Paul Revere's midnight ride and Patrick Henry's (played by Frank McGlyyn Jr. and not played by his father Frank McGlynn Sr) inflammatory speeches to the VIrginia House of Burgesses. The second half dwells on the bloody Indian War of Mohawk Valley. THe parts are tied together by the troubled romance between a young patriot, Nathan Holden (Neal Hamilton)and Nancy Montague (Carol Dempster), the daughter of a Tory Judge.
translation:
I waited until July 4 to write this because. , , Well . , , because it just feels right to do it that day.

1924 D.W. Griffith needed a hit, he had not had much since ORPHANS OF THE STORM (1921). Since then he has worked steadily, but his films were smaller and had failed to hit the right note in the audience. He was planning a film about Patrick Henry when he was contacted by members of the "Daughters of the American Revolution" (DAR) who asked if he could broaden his ideas to include more of the American Revolution. This movie is the result. When he was done, he had a 14-reel history lesson and Patrick Henry was nowhere to be seen.

We all know the story of the Revolutionary War, but Griffith threw a love story with him Patriot Farmer Nathan (Neil Hamilton) falls in love with Tory aristocrat Nancy Montague (Carol Dempster, a leading lady for Griffith for many years ). To make matters worse, Nancy's father hates Nathan. , , Good, not only Nathan, he hates all the rebels. It does not help if someone bumps Nathan's arm during a battle on the streets of Lexington, causing him to unload his gun and accidentally hurt Nancy's father!

The love story is the paralelling (mostly correct, but partially embellished) History of Capt. Walter Butler (Lionel Barrymore) a renegade British officer who feels that he owes no one loyalty. With thousands of Indians forming the Six Nations on his side, he hopes to destroy the colonists and become the monarch of his own empire.

Comparisons with BIRTH OF A NATION (1915) are inevitable. The Montague family might as well be the Camerons from the previous film, while Nathan could be part of the Stoneman family. The sequence of the Battle of Bunker Hill is very similar to a scene in BIRTH OF A NATION with the attacking army, in this case the Redcoats, storming a ditch full of patriots. The only thing missing is Henry Walthall driving through no man's land to stuff a flag into the cannon mouth. Amazingly, the fighting scenes in America seem to miss the energy of BIRTH's fight scenes and fail to engage the audience. Something is missing clearly. It is not a scope, G.W. "Billy" Bitzer's camerawork is pretty good. Maybe something is missing. , , I dare say. , , Sincerity?

The brutality of Capt. Butler and his men are well underlined, though much of it happens in the long shot or offscreen. Do not expect any heads to be replaced in close-up, as we saw in INTOLERANCE (1916). In one scene, Butler's second command, Captain Hare (Louis Wolhiem) pierces the eyes of a captured colonist. For the rest, the camera focuses on Hares face as he obviously has a good time doing so. Lionel had worked with Griffith since 1912. One story says that he asked Griffith for work and D.W., who knew the reputation of his illustrious family, said, "I do not hire stage actors." Lionel replied, "And I am nothing of the sort, sir." He makes a very good and fairly credible villain. Louis Wolhiem appeared three times with Lionel's older brother John; in SHERLOCK HOLMES and DR. JEKYLL AND MR. HYDE (both 1920) and later in THE TEMPEST (1927). As Captain Hare, his wild, staring eyes and disheveled hair not only mark him as a villain but also make him crazy.

Neil Hamilton later remarked that America was on horseback for the first time and "I was scared to death." He hides his displeasure but very well and we can believe that he was quite equestrian when the shooting was over. Mr. Griffith was very much in love with Carol Dempster and eventually asked her if he wanted to marry him. She refused and soon left his corporation, after which her star status gradually weakened.

Speaking of horses, an accidentally amusing moment that needed to be unofficial came during the presentation of Paul Reveres ride. He rides his horse directly onto a family's porch to announce, "To the guns, the regulars are coming!" but when he tries to leave the horse, he can not overcome the steps backwards and stumbles his rider to the ground! I am amazed that Griffith did not make another attempt.

Is America a classic? YES! Do not wait for the 4th of July to see it, it is always pleasant.

summary: Paris, je t'aime is about the plurality of cinema in one mythic location: Paris, the City of Love. Twenty filmmakers have five minutes each; the audience must weave a single narrative out of twenty moments. The 20 moments are fused by transitional interstitial sequences and also via the introduction and epilogue. Each transition begins with the last shot of the previous film and ends with the first shot of the following film, extending the enchantment and the emotion of the previous segment, preparing the audience for a surprise, and providing a cohesive atmosphere. There's a reappearing mysterious character who is a witness to the Parisian life. A common theme of Paris and love fuses all.

The problem with this movie is that only a few of the clips call Paris. The others are so scattered in theme, tone, willpower and production that you can also see "The Years Best Commercials, 2006". It is really everywhere. It does not develop over its term, and nothing rules the directors. No construct successfully connects the pieces ... boredom sets in. I'm at the hour, twenty minutes and Elijah Wood is in some stupidity, over - commercial, over-produced vampire Shtick. It has about as much to do with Paris as old ladies knitting in the Antarctic. Fantasy turns up, I think first in the Coen Brothers segment (Uh, thank J & E for ruining another movie) and then makes far too many appearances. The point of being in Paris is that you do not need fake crap to make your days extraordinary. Why divide it into neighborhoods when Quartier de la Madeleine is equated with vampires for a loser director? Was a genre ever over-represented as the vampire movie? Every three years we get the same lame vampire clich√©s. Worse yet, the change from segment to segment is pretty artless. The transitions are lost. This does not feel like it's going to be sloppy.

summary: Dr. Bill Cortner has been performing experimental surgery on human guinea pigs without authorization and against the advice of his father, also a surgeon. When Bill's fianc√©e Jan Compton is decapitated in an automobile accident, he manages to keep her brain alive. He now needs to find a new body for his bride-to-be and settles on Doris Powell, a glamor model with a facial disfigurement. Jan meanwhile doesn't want to continue her body-less existence and calls upon the creature hidden in the basement, one of Bill Cortner's unsuccessful experiments, to break loose.
translation: I bought this movie on DVD so I could get an episode of Mystery Science Theater 3000. Luckily, Mike, Crow and Tom Servo can be seen because the movie itself is not on screen. Although there is an action, a story to follow, and a few actors who can act, there is nothing else. summary: Alex, a sad-eyed mournful man, goes into psychotherapy: he discloses he's a hit man. He also tells the doctor, after a few sessions, that he's attracted to a young woman he's met in the waiting room. She's Sarah, 23, quick, edgy, and perhaps attracted to him as well. But he's married, the dutiful father of a young precocious boy, so Sarah brushes him off. In flashbacks we see him get his start as a killer, at his father's prompting: it's the family business. Dad gives Alex his next assignment: to kill the therapist. Alex keeps returning to Sarah, calling her, stopping by her apartment, as he decides what to do about the hit, his father, his marriage, and his malaise.
translation:
It's easy enough to see why Panic never got a good cinematic look: it's far too clever, and the audience would probably have had a hard time comparing it to American Beauty in his exploratory midlife crisis and Sopranos and Analyze This in his Study illegal activity in family life. Although Panic seems to come from unoriginal material, Brommel's lifelike characters, coupled with skilful dialogue and attentive directing, make the film a realistic look at the demise of a middle-aged man. William H. Macy plays the lead role as Alex, a contract killer who works for his father's (Sutherland) contract business. He leads a double life, with his wife (Ullman) and his son unaware of his real business. In his middle age, he becomes increasingly disgusted by what he has done all his life. Beneath his quiet, clogged facade, resentment against his father's controlling grip on his life frightened him. When he meets a young woman (Campbell), he feels inspired and decides that it's time to give up the family business.

The fact that writer / director Henry Brommel chose to make the profession his main character was trying to break away from contract killing is disposable. He could easily have replaced it with some unwanted occupation; His characters are so well developed and believable, scenes so smoothly and realistically handled, and dialogues so insightful and naturally written that the focus is more on Macy's contradictory character than on his job as a killer. Brommel's script feels like a Shakespearean tragedy, with a certain theme of fate.

In Macy, Macy creates a tragic, slightly likeable character and always delivers a brooding, great performance, as you would expect. Donald Sutherland is also effectively repugnant and offensive as his arrogant father, and Ullman's dramatic turn as Macy's wife is a welcome change for the comedian. Consider a scene in a bicycle shop, where her mood is subtly darkened and stands out in a poignant scene of emotional confusion.

Henry Brommel's first film Panic is a film well done in its sincerity. With a top-notch cast, a plausible script, tight dialogues, and a nice direction, this character study will hopefully just be a foretaste of Brommel's ability to create characters that seem real.

8 out of 10

summary: An epic portrait of late Sixties America, as seen through the portrayal of two of its children: anthropology student Daria (who's helping a property developer build a village in the Los Angeles desert) and dropout Mark (who's wanted by the authorities for allegedly killing a policeman during a student riot)...
translation:
Mark Frechette plays as Mark, a radical left-wing extremist. Mark is accused of killing a police officer during a campus uprising and flees all the way to the desert. He steals a small plane at the airport and flies himself.

As soon as he flies across the desert, Mark discovers a car from the air. A young woman named Daria comes out and sees Mark orbiting the plane. Mark crashes the plane several times very deep, which causes Daria to duck or get hit. When he lands, he meets Daria, strangely charmed by Mark's aerial leaps.

After hours of emotional conversation Mark and Daria get naked and love each other in the sand. But as Mark eludes the law, they realize he has to keep going. So Mark and Daria's short speech is quite poignant, because she can not develop into a full-fledged romance.

Zabriski Point was the eraserhead of the early 70's. Both films have a vague, vague quality, along with intricate meanings and characters. Frechette was as ruthless in person as his character was in this film. A few years after making Zabriski Point, Frechette deprives a bank in real life. During his term, Mark died an unworthy death. He was killed by a 150 pound weight that fell on him when he was lifting weights.

The best thing about this movie was the great cinematography and special visual effects. The incredible slow motion scenes of debris floating in the air after a blast were a stroke of genius. Although Zabriski Point was not as groundbreaking as Easy Rider, he still found resonance in the counterculture of the early 1970s. I recommend it for those who like avant-garde films showing the upheaval, the youth rebellion in the early 70s.

summary: It seems everyone is trying to get into heaven; at least those whose time is up. For Lance Barton, a struggling comedian and bicycle messenger, it's the last thing on his mind. His due date upstairs is 50 years away. In the meantime, he's got big dreams to pursue on Earth, such as landing a slot at the final Amateur Night Contest at the famed Apollo Theatre. Lance's has one little problem though - he ain't that funny. Thanks to an over-cautious emissary from heaven, Mr. Keyes, he's going to get hit (literally) with a much bigger problem. Showing that even God has difficulty finding good help these days, the inept minion mistakenly plucks Lance from a traffic accident - before it takes place. Transporting him to the Pearly Gates, or more accurately, the velvet roped-lines of the hottest club around, the error is finally addressed by Mr. King, the streetwise, no-nonsense head angel who manages the place from his plush windowed office. Since returning to his own body on Earth is ...
translation:
I had not seen the movie trailer when I saw the movie, instead I based my judgments on the opinion of a friend. Now I like Chris Rock and his comedy, but this movie just falls on his face.

During the movie Rock delivers some funny jokes, but unfortunately the movie lacks the comedy. The film seems to want to integrate both laughter and love in one, and the effort fails. The love story in the movie is simple (fortunately), but it reduces the movie too much by making rock serious and boring. After all, the film is primarily intended to be a comedy in which laughter should be in the foreground. Not much of it in the movie.

The plot is pretty uninteresting overall. Some parts were discontinuous overall. If the supporting actors are funny, they certainly did not do a good job. The Angels from Heaven were trying to make some jokes that were dry and boring. Rock's first incarnations were also boring. If there was one thing they did right, they made Rock funnier by comparison.

summary: The aftermath of a high school shooting leaves Deanna Cartwright seriously wounded and nine others dead, including the perpetrator. Det. Martin Van Zandt is assigned the unenviable task of investigating the crime and finding someone to hold responsible. His attention settles on Alicia Browning, a darkly troubled outsider who, as the only person present throughout the entire incident, is both the key witness and a possible suspect. Further complicating her isolated existence, Alicia's high school principal compels her to pay a reluctant visit on the still-hospitalized Deanna. Privileged and popular, Deanna differs dramatically from the alienated Alicia. Yet, beneath an upbeat appearance, she is struggling desperately with the emotional and physical scars left by the attack. Over the next few days, united by nothing more than their common suffering, the two young women form an unlikely friendship to cope with the tragic events that threaten to overwhelm them.
translation:
"Home Room" was an absolute surprise. Since I had no idea what it was all about, it took a lot of time because it can not take any punches and what we see is how life changes through the act of an angry young man who decided to bully his classmates who are the innocent victims of his hasty actions.

Paul Ryan, the director who edits and edits his own material, is a talented man rewarded with an incredible acting by his cast.

Alicia Browning is an older girl trying to graduate from high school. She has been away for several years and does not seem to be in the same wavelength as the other students. For one thing, she is a rebel with a punk look, lots of makeup and a mouth that will cut anyone who dares to come near her. Alicia was among the students in the home room, where nine students have died, allegedly killed by her friend. Alicia, we realize, is an injured girl who has suffered a terrible ordeal in her life, but we have no clues to this effect.

What follows is the aftermath of the tragedy as it focuses on a young woman who has survived it. Deanna Cartwright is a wealthy teenager who should not have been in school at all. When a ricochet hit her, she was hospitalized with more than one wound. She tries to overcome this dark period in her mind, but the nightmares do not let her forget her.

Alicia is taken to the hospital by the Headmaster. Since she does not cooperate with the police, the headmistress wants her to see Deanna in her dreadful condition, and maybe she'll get softer and tell the authorities what she knows. Alicia does not like Deanna, but in a few days both girls will make peace. We only know in the last sequence what really happened on that terrible day at school.

Busy Phillips is an excellent Alicia and Erika Christiansen is as good as Deanna. Victor Garber, James Pinkins, Taylor Holland and the rest of the cast play as an ensemble.

The film has an intensity because it does not explicitly show how it came to filming, what the tone of Mr Ryan wanted to give this movie.

summary: A ritualistic serial killer is beheading victims all over a city, and those surrounding the case are pulled into his world as they try and stop him.
translation:
I own this movie. I bought it for $ 3.99 from a fairly large video retailer to do some "indie" movie research because I had just completed and edited my own feature. summary: Janine Reynaud stars as a nightclub stripper who free-floats through a spectral 60's landscape littered with dream-figures, dancing midgets and bizarre S&M games.
translation:
As you probably know, Jess Franco is a prolific type. He has made hundreds of films, many of which are crap. However, he managed to sneak occasional quality work throughout the assembly line production. "Succubus" is not his best work (either "The diabolical Dr. Z" or "Vampyros Lesbos"), but it has many of its brands that make it a must-have for anyone who is interested in plunging into his large catalog , He combines the erotic (alternating between frontal nudity and something left to the imagination) and the surreal seamlessly. This is a very dreamy movie full of atmosphere. I particularly liked the constant name dropping. Although it sounds incredibly upbeat, listening to all of Franco's influences is amusing.

However, there are many users who do not like "succubus" and I can see where they come from. It's cozy, but I can handle it. More problematic is the incoherence. The script here was obviously rash, and within five minutes of the movie, I had absolutely no idea what was going on (and from that point on it never really came together). For those who want something with their style, look elsewhere. Even if it's a horror movie, it never gets really scary or even exciting. Nevertheless, I was entertained by all the psychedelic stupidity that did not bother me too much with these big mistakes. (7/10)

summary: Larry Burrows (Jim Belushi) is unhappy and feels powerless over his life. He believes his entire life could have turned out differently had he not missed that shot in a baseball game when was a kid. One night he meets this mysterious man named Mike (Michael Caine), who could change his fate by offering him that alternative life he always dreamed of. But as Burrows embarks on this journey of self discovery he realizes that even this new life has its problems and drawbacks..
translation: Okay, so borrow it from "It's a Wonderful Life", but that was 44 years before this movie, so why not try again. Belushi has a lazy 35th birthday. He did not get his Wheaties, his coffee and lost his job. The maker is when his self-described "big blue piece sh **" car collapses at the end of the day. He goes to an empty bar to call for a tow truck. While waiting, he is recognized by the bartender (Caine) as the boy who lost the city's baseball game 20 years ago. That makes him think what life would have been like if he had won the game. He finds out that Caine unknowingly serves a potion in a jar that gives him a mansion, the Ball Queen (Russo) as his wife, and makes him president of the sporting goods company he's been puked out of. Caine later reveals himself as the one responsible for the change, but Belushi is not on board. He never completely adapts, and in an action that does not kill the movie, but is still strange, he tries to protect his wife (Hamilton) from his real life, which is now married to someone else. The good move is that they do not spend too much time with it, because basically they are ripping "Ghost" while Belushi Hamilton keeps telling things she just knows. It also brings a hokey dramatic element, as two of his lovers in the shadows, new wife Russo and his unbalanced lover Cox kevetch.
