The Ante keeps on rising as Mad Dog's only goal is to come back from Hong Kong and back to Thailand by all means necessary, and the cops continue to try to catch him alive ...

I could probably write ten paragraphs about this complex and thoroughly layered movie, but I do not want to reveal too much. I've seen DOG BITE DOG, who did not know anything about the premise, and I think that's the kind of movie that's definitely better appreciated that way. As for the comparisons with the older CATIII films, there are some similarities. DOG BITE DOG has some hyper-violent moments reminiscent of the "good old days" but is never as greasy or greasy as old-school classics like THE UNTOLD STORY or RED TO KILL. Where many of the older CATIII films were mainly "shocked", DOG BITE DOG is a far more elaborate and well-rounded production (though that does not take away from the CATIII films that I love so much.).). This movie is much more "emotional" than exploitative. As we learn more about the characters and their backgrounds, audiences begin to connect and identify with each other. There are really no clear "good" and "bad" types, as Mad Dog shows moments of extreme compassion and the police uses extremely unorthodox methods to try and mold the killer. There is also no nudity / sex in this film, which is a typical feature of older CATIII films. Personally, I would compare DOG BITE DOG more with Parks SYMPATHY FOR MR. VENGEANCE or perhaps the BANGKOK DANGEROUS of the Pang Brother, as both films mixed extreme emotional undertones with strong and unrelenting action and violence. Once again - there's pretty much nothing I did not like about this movie. The drama is dead, the camera is sharp and well done, and the whole film skillfully blends several elements together, as it's not often seen. Is this movie (and others like it ...) the "rebirth" of the CATIII movie - not exactly - but it's a very solid movie that's definitely worth a visit ... 9/10

summary: When it comes to romance, Missy's attitude has always been whatever. After all, her artistic career is flourishing...her spacious New York City loft is fabulous...and her relationship with a married man is totally uncomplicated-what more could a modern girl want? But then Missy meets Brat, who's sweet, genuine and shares her fondness for 70's sitcoms. Unfortunately, he's also dating her pal Spaz. When Missy and Brat unexpectedly fall for each other, will she lose her identity...and her best friend? No matter how far you run, true love always finds you.
translation:
My girlfriend has a habit of going to blockbusters and choosing films that nobody has heard of before. Granted, sometimes it has led to some funny discoveries. Often the best thing to say is that they definitely run for an hour and a half.

She brought "advice from a caterpillar" home. She was excited because the box said it was funny. Fortunately, the propaganda on the boxes never.

This movie was an exercise in patience. This is one of those films in which, unless you are a sophisticated and superficial person who likes to watch movies about yourself, you will hate every character in the movie. Until the introduction of a nice character. Which of the nerve-wracking characters will fall in love and act in such a way that in the real world he will drive anyone away.

MILD SPOILERS FROM HERE

So a bunch of emotionally unstable, haughty, flashy artists swear the love and find success in their careers. Then they meet a nice, intelligent, emotionally mature and loving character (almost perfect type). Then we see how the woman, the annoyed arrogant artist (in her 30s?) Freaks out when she falls in love. So she tries to escape the nice, intelligent, emotionally mature man and stay with the married man she has big but empty sex with. She is rude to the man and does everything in her power to drive him out. In the real world, she would have been pretty successful. I definitely wanted to escape from her and I was not even in a relationship with her!

Although it's nice that the man "fought for his love," I never wanted her to have him. (Not my girlfriend either) She did not deserve it. And why I wonder if the director thinks that the "almost perfect guy" should be punished by having to relate to her? When the artist asked the "almost perfect guy" to leave, we screamed that he should leave as well. There is a problem with a movie when the heroine of the movie is so annoying, childish and stupid that you want her to fail.

In addition, let me say that Andy Dick has even made me laugh a couple of times, even though his character was also pretentious to annoyance. In terms of the other characters, they were well-played, morally bankrupt and annoying characters.

It's a comedy and I can say that I laughed a few times in the movie. Unfortunately, not much has been laughed up to the last 10 minutes. But by the time I had those laughs, I had prayed that the movie ended far too long. I had to get those lazy characters out of my life.

If you want to see people you hate fighting with a love for people they do not deserve, then that's the movie for you.

summary: In a world overtaken by eternal darkness, the buttoned down entomologist abandons his phantoms to embrace the unknown. Oscar is a conservator at the Natural Science Museum, and spends most of his days surrounded by bugs. When Oscar isn't tending to the tiny specimens that line his home and workplace, he can frequently be found reflecting on his childhood traumas in the psychiatrist's office. One day, Oscar returns home from work to find an African woman from the museum lying in his bed.
translation:
Very interesting and fascinating movie. The similarities to David Lynch (who is literally quoted in the film with red curtains) and the novels of Franz Kafka (the housekeeper in this movie is called Mrs. Grubach, as well as those in The Process ...) are clearly present, but are written in this Case accompanied by clear references to the colonial past of Belgium in Africa. The exact content of the film I can not clearly describe: This colonialism is an important part, as well as the inability to cope with such a past, but also the personal memories of the main character are a central theme and his pursuit of social responsibility contact and love. These are the symbolic themes that I have derived from the movie, but in fact they are nothing more than impressions.

But even if you're just trying to follow the linear story without these symbolic backgrounds, you'll still discover an extremely intriguing movie full of gorgeous imagery (beautiful close-ups of Beatles, larvae and other nasty insects alternate off with great dream sequences and also the dark atmosphere gives the film a special style). Maybe I can say that I did not quite "understand" the movie, but I watched hypnotized for 1.5 hours, deeply impressed by the visual quality and the mesmerizing mystery.

summary: Two ghosts, separated by time, who have roamed the grounds of a historic English mansion, searching for each other are brought together by Ally (LAURA PENNEYCARD), a photography student who is experiencing dreams she can't explain and Emmett (GEOFF SHAW), the son of a wealthy industrialist. Emmett befriends Ally and together they unravel the truth behind the disappearance of his long lost love, Catherine a beautiful servant girl. However, Ally must first overcome her fears of his ghostly appearance before she can help Emmett find Catherine and reunite their love. Shot in the beautiful location of Hylands House, this lavish drama with a supernatural theme, leads you through past and present in a series of spine-chilling nightmares, ghostly appearances and suspenseful chase sequences, which moves into a beautiful romance tale, drawing on all your senses from the outset.
translation: It's one of those dramas that is so bad that it almost reaches the point that it's very funny, the script is absolutely terrible, the direction is horrible, illuminating the pure anchor, the only thing it really is that bad of lets, the sound design is just pretty bad; it does not add tension to the story, although it tries, but at least does not destroy any speeches. There are continuity problems of the seasons of outdoor shooting everywhere. And last but not least, acting is appalling. For a professional production, it has the feeling of a university media project, you have to apologize for the apology for someone who had to make a name for it.

summary: This casts key characters from the Jungle Book into a 1930's pacific setting where Baloo is a bush pilot who finds himself as part of a struggling courier company.
translation:
When you see this show for the first time, you may be wondering if you are in an alternate reality. Colorful and imaginative characters? Entertaining dialogue? Plots that seem to have some depth, sometimes even create atmospheres of tension and drama? I mean, this is a syndicated children's show right? This is the same place where kids like "Pok√©mon", "Pepper Ann", "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers" and "VR Troopers" (please note that three of the above titles are crass Japanese exports, courtesy of Fox Network and Saban Entertainment). Do not worry, you are just sampling some of the high quality dishes that were available to the children in the late 80's and early 90's. Some examples of this period would be "Transformers", "Garfield and Friends", "Captain Power" and "C.O.P.S." (a cartoon NOT to be confused with the live action show on Fox). In addition to these prime examples, Disney also returned to syndicated programs for children who had a lineup called "The Disney Afternoon." Aside from a rundown show called "The Gummy Bear", early shows like "Darkwing Duck", "Duck Tales" and "Chip 'N Dale's Rescue Rangers" gave credit to the Disney Animation teams, who also played theater classics like "The Little Mermaid", " The Beauty and the Beast, The Savior Down Under and The Great Mouse Detective. But above all these miracles shine "TaleSpin". The premiere of "Plunder and Lightning" was a two-hour thrill ride and won an Emmy. To my great joy, the rest of the episodes were appropriate to the promise of the premiere.

While I enjoy the plot and the dialogue, the main attraction for me is the characters. There's Rebecca Cunningham, an independent woman, but still fallible; Kit Cloudkicker, full of teenage fear and optimism; Louie, with his loyalty and support; Frank Wildcat, the most entertaining engineer since Scotty on the original "Star Trek"; Cute and witty, but with some depth that most children do not have, and of course in the middle of everything, Molly Cunningham has Baloo, which I would describe as a sloppy version of James Bond. Because if there's trouble, Baloo rescues the day with the help of his sleeker and fastest Sea Duck (Read: James Bond's Aston Martin). Of course, every great show has to have big villains, and TaleSpin does not disappoint. From the megalomaniac of the businessman Shere Kahn over the vain and ever-failing air pirate Don Karnage to the hilarious and awkward Soviet-satirized Thembrians. The animation is good, the music is appropriate, and the episodes are (to me) the best kids programs have ever had. Have fun for the whole family!

summary: Tony Rome is a Miami based detective who while diving in the ocean finds the body of a young woman. He is hired by Gronsky to find her killer. Tony has to sift through a stack of suspects, plus trying to elude the police.
translation: Detective Tony Rome (Frank Sinatra) returns to the screen after his self-titled debut, this time it's a movie made to laugh. During a diving trip, Rome finds the body of a blond beauty on the seabed, her feet trapped in cement, as you would expect. Rome immediately on the case after the employment of man mountain Waldo Gronsky. Rome is in immediate danger as he has to examine some types of mafia that turn the tables and he himself is the prime suspect, he must now go on the run and hope to solve the case alone. Powerful Sinatra struggles to sell us the lame jokes and make us believe he's a good detective, let alone sexually attractive to the lazy Raquel Welch, but he fails miserably on this hammer-filled vanity project. The honest laughable dissolution that surrounds every woman is amazing, every woman in the movie is a dither-head, who likes to bend in front of the camera, director Douglas of course agrees every time she bends her ass in the ass back muscles. There is even a ridiculously campy homosexual figure who believes that this is a film of "real men" for "real men" to affirm their own flagging sexuality, it is a shameful rubble.

summary: After the passing away of his wife, wealthy Delhi-based businessman, Harishchandra, took it upon himself to bring up two sons, Sunil and Prem. When they grew up he got Sunil married to Bhavna, and let Prem complete his education, even let him study abroad. Soon Sunil and Bhavna gave birth to a son, Rahul. When Bhagat told him that he had found a suitable match for Prem in Poonam, the niece of Krishnakant, a fruit merchant from Madhupur, Uttar Pradesh, the family traveled there, met with Krishnakant, his wife, Rama, and daughter, Rajni, and instantly approved of Poonam. Prem and Poonam also approved of each other, the Astrologer was consulted and a marriage was scheduled to take place in six months time. Shortly thereafter the engagement took place. The two families met again in Som Sarovar, Nainital, to let everyone get acquainted, and when Prem got his first contract from Japan, Krishnakant took his family to Delhi to celebrate. With the deadline for the marriage drawing close, both ...
translation:
VIVAH is, in my opinion, the best movie from 2006, written by a director who has proven successful throughout his career. I'm not so into romantic films these days because I see them as "old wine in a new bottle" and so predictable. However, I've seen this movie three times already ... and believe me, it's a great movie.

VIVAH goes back to the traditional route, showing simple characters in a sensible and realistic story of travel between engagement and marriage. The film entertains in all ways how it can be reflected on what we do (or would do) when it comes to marriage. In this sense, Sooraj R. Barjatya has done well his homework and incorporated a very realistic story into a well done entertaining movie.

Several sequences in this movie interest you immediately:

* When Shahid Kapoor comes to see the bride (Amrita Rao) - as he tries to look at her without to make it clear to him and her family. The song "Do Anjaane Ajnabi" fits well with the mood of this scene.

* The first conversation between Shahid and Amrita when he comes to visit them - eg a shy Shahid who does not know exactly what to talk about but draw from a decent conversation. Also, Amrita's naive nature, limited eye contact, shy features, and the answer to Shahid's questions.

* The emotional collapse of Amrita and her uncle (Alok Nath) as she feeds him at Shahid's party into the daughter-in-law of another instead of her uncle's beloved niece.

The film clearly belongs to Amrita Rao all the way. The actress portrays the role of Poonam with the conviction that one can not imagine anyone replacing her. She looks beautiful throughout the movie and portrays an innocent and shy traditional girl perfectly.

Shahid Kapoor is also brilliant. He delivers a promising performance and shows that he is no less than Salman Khan when it comes to playing in a Sooraj R. Barjatya movie. In fact, Shahid and Amrita undoubtedly make a sweet couple on the screen. Other characters - Alok Nath (excellent), Anupam Kher (brilliant), Mohan Joshi (very good).

On the whole, VIVAH, as promised, keeps a well-made and realistic story of two families. The film has first-class performances, an excellent story and great music suitable for the film, and is directed by the fabulous Sooraj R. Barjatya. You must have seen something like that!

summary: Michael O'Hara, against his better judgement, hires on as a crew member of Arthur Bannister's yacht, sailing to San Francisco. They pick up Grisby, Bannister's law partner, en route. Bannister has a wife, Rosalie, who seems to like Michael much better than she likes her husband. After they dock in Sausalito, Michael goes along with Grisby's weird plan to fake his (Grisby's) murder so he can disappear untailed. He wants the $5000 Grisby has offered, so he can run off with Rosalie. But Grisby turns up actually murdered, and Michael gets blamed for it. Somebody set him up, but it is not clear who or how. Bannister (the actual murderer?) defends Michael in court.
translation: Orson Welles' "The Lady From Shanghai" does not have the brilliant script of "Citizen Kane", but the camera of Charles Lawton, Jr., the unforgettable scenery (like the scene in the aquarium, the sea scene with a stunning, blonde Rita Hayworth, the "Please Do not Love Me" song and the truly amazing climax of "Hall of Mirrors," and the wonderful cast (Everett Sloane in his greatest performance, Welles in a wonderfully understated role, the previously mentioned Miss Hayworth - Welles' then The bizarre murder-mystery plot is funny and convincing, not inscrutable, the viewer is surprised by the twists and turns, and Welles' final line is an unannounced classic. "The Lady From Shanghai "gets four stars from this impartial referee.

summary: In 1547 Fernando De Gama, a young "Soldier of Fortune" from Portugal, set sail for the Orient in a bid to find the man that murdered his father and, with luck, like many of his fellow countrymen,to make his fortune. A vicious storm in the Indian ocean almost ended his plans when the ship he was on sank. The sole survivor, he was washed up on a tropical beach only to be captured by Arab slavers and taken to Ayutthaya in the kingdom of Siam where he was offered for sale as a slave. He is rescued from slavery when a beautiful young woman Maria, also from Portugal, living in Ayutthaya with her father, buys him from the Arabs and restores his freedom. Not suprisingly he falls for Maria and Maria him, much to the chagrin of Maria's Father. As an experienced soldier his services are soon in demand when the King of Siam declares war on a Northern renegade pretender and all of the Portuguese colony are press-ganged into the service of the King. Predictably, Fernando's experience and gallantry ...
translation: This is a film that seeks to retell Thai history in the ancient city of Ayutthaya. I decided to watch this movie because I thought it was inspired by many Thai films I saw and enjoyed, one in which Thai actors speak Thai and martial arts craze. Well, that's none of it. This movie is completely shot in English, is full of Anglo actors and has production values ‚Äã‚Äãthat are so awful that it's ridiculously bad .... but not funny! Who can we blame for this garbage? Acting, dialogue and most sets were pretty bad. Some of the fight scenes looked like they had been choreographed by the local High School Drama Club. The special effects were also mostly bad, but some were just cheap animations that were patched on the screen, giving a particularly cheesy effect. There's a big outdoor epic fight scene where a few thousand extras in a costume are running across a field, but when we see the two armies clashing in combat - HA! What a joke! The movie shows some beauties. What a pity that they did not show a bit more skin. At least that would have been worth something for the boys. Do not worry.

summary: Based on the true story of Dr Jerri Nielsen who contracted breast cancer during her one year outpost at the South Pole. Just as winter approached and everything is on lock down for 8 months with no flights available in and out of the Amundsen-Scott station, Dr Nielsen had to find a way to treat herself whilst enduring harsh weather conditions and limited medical resources.
translation: I have always admired Susan Sarandon for her integrity and honesty in her private life as well as her talents as an actor. So I found it odd that she appeared in a movie that distorted those facts so much. The salvation of her character from the South Pole was carried out by a Canadian charter company from Edmonton, Alberta, flying a Canadian designed and built Twin Otter aircraft. The trip was rejected by the US Air Force, the Navy, and the Coast Guard as beyond their capabilities. A few years later, the same company made a similar rescue to bring a man out of the South Pole base. I think the movie is a very gripping theme, documenting a very brave woman from a daunting task. I do not understand why the producers would find it necessary to ignore the bravery of the rescue pilots and show the rescue plane as Hercules of the USAF.

summary: A documentary on the evidence which shows that the Apollo 11 astronauts never actually landed on the moon.
translation:
There are so many incorrect statements in this so-called "documentary" that I saw myself shouting on TV.













on the science behind his claims.

He relies either to be inaccurate, not to tell the whole story, or the old favorite "government always gives us" allusions, and people believe what they are told, not the Check accuracy or details behind the claims.

In addition, his "exclusive" or "unpublished" footage is freely available on the internet from various sites.

Continue Reading the circumstances surrounding the filming of this production shows that he has used false pretenses to gain interviewing and has used creative processing of responses to promote his own opinions.

All allegations made by Mr. Sibrel about "inaccuracies", "errors" or "whistleblowing" in the Apollo program were thoroughly refuted.

How do I get back those 40-minute minutes of my life?

summary: Hunt Stevenson works for a large car manufacturer that has just been bought out by a Japanese firm. Suddenly finding himself having to justify his own job, he's forced to choose between redundancy or the seemingly inhuman Japanese work ethic that the new owners have brought with them.
translation:
I remember seeing "Gung Ho" as a child with my mother and wondering why she would always cry for the last few minutes. Of course I found the whole movie hilarious, especially the mannerisms of the characters. It was not until I was much older and looked at it again that I realized how much deeper this show actually is.

Michael Keaton and Gedde Watanabe shine in their role as reluctant mediators. Keaton stops surprising me with his true style of delivery, and Watanabe adds humor and pathos to the mix. I also found that Patti Yasutake (Umeki) was just fabulous in her role as a comic book relief.

I think this movie is one of the most underrated movies of the 80s. We can all learn a lesson from the fusion of American and Japanese workers in this film ... sometimes you can really have "the best of both worlds". And now I understand why my mother felt like she did in those last moments. I would rather have one of these cars as well.

summary: Charles Brady and his mother Mary move to a small Indiana town, having recently fled Bodega Bay, California after draining and killed a young girl there. They are sleepwalkers - they can change their appearance and they need the lifeforce from young women. Charles has picked out young Tanya Robertson, whom he meets at a local high school, as his next victim. He asks her out for a date and invites her home... however, she did not suspect his real interest in her. On their first date, a picnic at a nearby cemetery, Charles attempts to drain the lifeforce from Tanya for himself and his mother.
translation: Monstrous mother-son duo (Alice Krige and Brian Krause) suck vitality of virgins, and their latest goal is pretty, but lonely Tanya (girl Amick). However, these monsters are allergic to cat scratching ... I've never been a fan of sleazy, overrated bestsellers like King, Koontz or Barker, but this B-movie, written by Mr. Dung himself, is not nearly as bad as he could be His. Yes, it can be terribly awful at times, but there are actually some surprisingly impressive details: a good old-fashioned graveyard, a sinister soundtrack, and a candlelit gothic-house scene, a mirror showing the monstrous form of the villains. Naturally. The film is polluted by Mr. Dung's foolish talk and the toilet-seat obsession with denigrating fat people, resulting in a pointless subplot of rapist teachers, but there are roses under dung.

summary: Stanley Cox is an illiterate short-order cook who has never taken a chance at love. Iris King is a newly widowed factory worker who has vowed never to love again. But as their friendship slowly blossoms and Iris helps Stanley learn to read, his strong yet gentle kindness helps mend her broken heart. And where two lonely strangers stood trapped within the past, Stanley and Iris can now begin a new chapter of their lives - together.
translation: "Stanley and Iris" show the triumph of the human spirit. For Stanley, it's the struggle to read and realize its potential. For Iris it is the courage to love again after becoming a widow. The beauty of the film is the dance that Robert DeNiro and Jane Fonda do together, start and stop before everyone has the skills and the courage to trust each other and move on. In this sense, it gives us a very good overview of how life is often, and is therefore credible. Unlike other reviewers, I found the characters that were rendered consistent throughout the image. The supporting actors are also carefully selected and add a character depth, which is added to the main characters by the supporting performances. All in all, an excellent movie. The best I can make of it is hope.

summary: Emma Woodhouse has a rigid sense of propriety as regards matrimonial alliances. Unfortunately she insists on matchmaking for her less forceful friend, Harriet, and so causes her to come to grief. Through the sharp words of Mr. Knightley, and the example of the opinionated Mrs. Elton, someone not unlike herself, Emma's attitudes begin to soften...
translation: From the flood of Austen movies from the nineties, this is my favorite, even more than "Persuasion", which has converted me to Austeniana. Before I saw this "Emma", I had seen two earlier versions, but in one, Emma seemed completely wrong, more like Lady Teazle, and in the other, she seemed half wrong, like a possible cheater, while she was here just seemed right, young and silly and stubborn. In general, I thought that the attitude and the atmosphere of the production conveyed the charm of the novel extraordinarily well; in fact, it's one of the cutest, funniest things I've ever seen, more like a Christmas treat. The script is unusually well formed, and the additions to the adapter, such as the lightwell that reveals Harriet to Emma in the church, are all fine. Mark Strong as Knightley is not what I expected, but I enjoyed it very much: he emphasizes the factual, practical side of the character, as opposed to Emma's affects, and his choleric outbursts against Frank Churchill are quite funny. Bernard Hepton makes Mr. Woodhouse a figure of almost Carroll's absurdity; Samantha Morton as Emma's prot√©g√© is as soft and as tight as she should be. And as in the "Pride and Prejudice" of producers is taken to ensure that the possible coupling of characters - in some cases clearly - can be believed. This production was and remains a pleasure for me.

summary: Jim Morris is a Texas high school chemistry teacher and coach of the school's baseball team. He's always loved baseball and as a way of motivating his players, he agrees to go to a professional try-out if they win the championship. He once had aspirations to be a professional baseball player but an injury brought that to an end. Sure enough, the 39 year-old father of three finds himself at a camp for the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and he somehow seems to have regained his pitching arm, easily throwing a 98 mph fastball. Signed to a contract, he toils in the minor leagues while his supportive wife stays home raising their children. He soon finds himself called up to the big club and pitching for Tampa which is in Texas playing the Rangers. Based on a true story.
translation: What a fun movie experience! I expected a cheesy children's film and found that it was more fun than my teens. Take a handkerchief, it is not sad, it only moves in parts. After all, it's a "feel-good" movie for the whole family. Note: It's 2+ hours, so be sure to leave the smallest "squirmers" for that location. AP

summary: Carter Page III holds a special place in Washington society: the gay son and grandson of powerful men, he has connections, manners, and he's no threat, so he's an available escort when a woman's husband would rather not accompany her to a public event. When the secret lover of one of his women friends is murdered, she asks Carter to cover for her, and his acquiescence gets him into immediate trouble with the police and an ambitious prosecutor. Carter, with the help of his lover Emek, starts his own investigation. They're warned off by someone's hired muscle. Can Carter figure out what happened or will he lose more than he realizes he has? Human behavior is a mystery.
translation:
This movie is a giant pant. Paul Schrader is completely lost in his own bad script. And his directorial work is as comatose as it can possibly be without him actually sleeping during the process.

But the worst thing is Woody Harrelson, whom I usually like when he is properly staffed. He plays "The Walker", a gay man in D.C., who plays the bored wives of the Washington elite a social companion. He could not have been one-dimensional if he had been cut from a magazine and whirled around with an ice-stick in front of the camera. His "southern accent" is that off-the-shelf version that decodes from the beginning to the end of every line he delivers, as if the heat and humidity of the south still drains him of every single energy he has , It is monotonous. But that's not the worst accent in the movie. His "friend", played by Moritz Bleibtreau, tries to influence a kind of Mid-East accent that is so awkward it can barely deliver the bad lines written for it. He is unable to roll his r, although in real life he is German and speaks several languages ‚Äã‚Äã- one of which is Italian! That's a good reason to occupy someone, do not you think?

From storytelling to screenplay, directing, cinematography and leads, this film is bad from start to finish. The only bearable moments in the film came from three supporting actresses: Lily Tomlin, Lauren Bacall and Kristin Scott Thomas. Only these three managed with dignity in tact through the film. In fact, all three are excellent, even though they are trapped in a really bad movie. Unfortunately, nobody could ever be good enough to solve these endless mistakes. If you like these three actresses, look at them in something else. This movie is not worth your time.

summary: Inside a snowflake exists the magical land of Whoville. In Whoville, live the Whos, an almost mutated sort of munchkinlike people. All the Whos love Christmas, yet just outside of their beloved Whoville lives the Grinch. The Grinch is a nasty creature that hates Christmas, and plots to steal it away from the Whos which he equally abhors. Yet a small child, Cindy Lou Who, decides to try befriend the Grinch.
translation: Ron Howard has directed? The 1966 cartoon is charming and teaches a simple lesson for children with a simple plot. In this movie, Howard gives us a Whoville filled with greedy, manipulative, egocentric whos. Jim Carrey is terrible, but I'm sure it's not his fault; I imagine the script calls for the most vicious person imaginable, so Carrey channeled Tom Green and the result is movie magic. Similar to Danny Devito's "Penguin in Batman Returns," Carrey's Grinch is so unlike any kind of comedy one could derive from his character that simply evaporates. While the 1966 cartoon showed a Grinch we could all identify with, Carreys Grinch is the evil, soulless old man we've all seen at some point, mumbling to himself in a parked car or toddlers stumbling his cane in the supermarket. This Grinch has no humanity, sense of humor or insight, and his salvation at the end of the film sounds wrong. The whole movie sounds wrong: There's a stupid Christmas lights contest, a failed attempt to explain why the Grinch is such an idiot by digging into his childhood, and an undecipherable secret as to why some of the Whos do not have that weird lip extension of them , In contrast to the 1966 cartoon, I would imagine that children would find this film tiresome, irritating and full of conflicting messages. Did we really have to see Slutty Smurf, aka Christine Baranski as Martha May Whovier? In addition, Ron Howard filled the cast with his untalented relatives. Throw the required butt jokes, fart jokes, sex jokes and other compulsory Carreyesque low-brow humor, and you have a movie that is so far from the 1966 cartoon (or book that inspired it), such as George W. Bush rational, clear thought. Thumbs down on this big fat turkey.

summary: Married couple Jim & Ella Merchant set up their single friend Al Schmid on a blind date with Ruth Hartley. The two hit it off and begin dating. A welder, one day at the workplace, Al learns of a friend's enlistment in the Marine Corps and decides to join himself. Al and Ruth have a last date, with Al insisting that she forget about him as he is about to go into combat. However, when Ruth goes to meet his departure train, he is overjoyed and gives her an engagement ring. Assigned to Guadalcanal, Al and his squad are tasked with preventing the Japanese from breaching their line. During a night attack, many of his fellow Marines are slain, but Al ends up single-handedly saving the day, killing scores of Japanese. However, he is wounded by a suicide bomber near the end of the the battle. At the hospital, Al learns that he is blind, a condition that persists even after surgery. Feeling sorry for himself, he dictates a letter to a nurse, informing Ruth that he is relieving her of any ...
translation:
Definitely among the top five best John Garfield films must be Pride of the Marines. It is the true story of Marines privateer Al Schmid, who at the expense of his own sight during a wounded fought off a horde of storming Japanese on Guadalcanal.

The story is divided into three parts, Al Schmid's home, where he is a simple worker who is getting serious with a woman and does not like anything better than his bowling night. Pearl Harbor gets bombed and he goes to war like millions of others.

The second part is in Guadalcanal and we see part of the action where he is in an isolated machine gun nest and holding Japanese troops. His action prevented naval positions from being overrun, but a grenade makes in his eyesight.

And of course the third part is his painful adaptation to civilian life and to reassure oneself that people are not just taking care of him out of pity, especially this girl he saw Eleanor Parker.

This film was aired on TCM on John Garfield's 95th birthday and there was a documentary about Garfield hosted by his daughter. One of the interviewees said that Garfield was the most believable in working class roles when he had and held a union card.

In this regard, he was lucky that he landed at Warner Brothers in Hollywood. Although he was repeatedly typed into gangster roles in the tradition of this studio, Garfield was terrific in these parts because of his background, for he came from the kind of life Al Schmid had, with the exception of Garfield's Jewish background.

In this regard, he was perfect to play the role of a working-class hero like Al Schmid, who took responsibility for defending his country. No Super Heroics here, just a guy who would have preferred to be in Philadelphia but had done a job that needed to be done.

It's a big part for Garfield. It's a movie you should not miss. But I wonder what happened to the real Al Schmid.

summary: Three bored millionaires gather nine people in an old mansion, and give them a proposition--if they can meet and conquer their biggest fears, they'll get one million dollars in cash.
translation: This movie had something that sounded like a good premise: 9 people facing their fears to win a million dollars. Unfortunately, it was not a good movie. There are several scenes that are far too long and really pointless like the dance scene. A few scenes are just a pretext to focus the camera on female body parts. Acting is bad, but some of the lines are amusing in their abominations. What's really strange is that it turns into a 5-minute Western at the end of the movie, and in the end, the spins they were made of make no sense to the rest of the movie. It seemed like the director had just added something because he thought it would look cool while the plot of the movie was ignored up to that point. It just did not make much sense. The only scary thing was the old people dancing down the hall, but that's not nearly as good as to make up for the rest of this mess.

summary: Two extremely clever British men are in a game of trickery and deceit. Andrew Wyke, an aging famous author who lives alone in a high-tech mansion, after his wife Maggie has left him for a younger man; and Milo Tindle, an aspiring actor, equipped with charm and wit, who demonstrates both qualities once again. When Wyke invites Tindle to his mansion, Tindle seeks to convince the former into letting his wife go by signing the divorce paper. However, Wyke seems far more interested in playing mind games with his wife's new lover, and lures him into a series of actions he thoroughly planned in seeking revenge on his unfaithful spouse.
translation:
The main reason for writing this review is, I found this "revision" of a great game and dignified 1972 movie, a horrible movie experience. If I can stop someone from looking at him, I've done a good thing.

This "new" version is full of talent and everything goes awry. Kenneth Branagh OK, an ugly, sterile, a music notation. He films the film from any artistic, distracting, self-centered perspective. We see reflections of the actors in stainless steel, on security monitors, shots from 200 feet high, close-up of eyes, chin and so on. The script, by a Nobel laureate, introduces long stretches of unpleasant homosexual banter, which are faked by both parties, .... I think ?? Given the character "Twists", how would I know? The characters themselves, so richly drawn in the original, are crass and unsympathetic. The runtime was shortened by one hour, which is either the real problem or the friendliest thing the director has done for us. The actors effectively execute their lines, but nothing they say or do is remotely believable. Jude Law is more than Caine, but as a producer he got Branagh's blessing.

All in all, I thought it was ugly to see it, not the shell of a former classic. Why was it done ??? The paying public spent less than $ 4 million worldwide to see it! A vanity that fails at every opportunity.

summary: Luke Skywalker battles horrible Jabba the Hut and cruel Darth Vader to save his comrades in the Rebel Alliance and triumph over the Galactic Empire. Han Solo and Princess Leia reaffirm their love and team with Chewbacca, Lando Calrissian, the Ewoks and the androids C-3PO and R2-D2 to aid in the disruption of the Dark Side and the defeat of the evil emperor.
translation:
"Return of the Jedi" is often remembered for what it did wrong, not what it did right, and that's a shame, because the last chronological episode in the Star Wars saga is a shining example for epic storytelling. It manages to summarize all the storylines of the previous films in a grand finale and makes that very convincing.

Yes, there are Ewoks - cute and cuddly bears who were supposed to expand the Star Wars demographics - and in the middle the movie tends to slow down a bit. But the last hour is probably the best part of the whole saga, where Luke finally meets Darth Vader, the most famous villain in film history.

The return of the Jedi has done so many things right that people tend to miss: there was an incredible end to the Darth Vader storyline (which from being unbelievable in "Empire Strikes Back" to being very convincing here An exciting opening in Jabba's Palace, a masterful performance by Ian McDiarmid as Emperor, Luke finally comes in his own, the dissolution of Solo and Leia Romance, and the extremely powerful final moments on the Endor Moon.

Yes, there are slight annoyances. But they are the annoyance of a generation of moviegoers who have had time to neglect every single scene. It is still a magical and moving piece of cinema that also serves as a great final chapter. It's not a "good" movie - it's awesome!

summary: Documentary about T-Rex includes concert footage and staged sequences. Ringo's directorial work is mindful of touches used in "Magical Mystery Tour."
translation: BORN TO BOOGIE is a real "find" - although I've been a rock fan for nearly thirty years, I only saw it a few days ago and counted it as one of the top rock movies of all time. The music is terrific (the cream of T. Rex) and the pictures are always exciting and unusual, leaving the viewer looking for further direction from Ringo Starr, who has done a good job here. If you love the music, you'll be in T. Rextasy all the way, because Marc Bolan really is the star of the play, Front and Center. Also, the fact that some songs are repeated does not matter: different locations, costumes, musical arrangements and bizarre visual concepts are used to give different textures and a lot of upbeat humor that could "only" have ended As rich and packed as BORN TO BOOGIE is, the movie is only about an hour long, but what is there is totally satisfying, which is my only criticism - the video package says about 71 minutes, and at least one online Source claims the movie is 67 minutes, but apparently it's more like 61 minutes of rocking fun.

summary: "Offside" is about a group of Iranian girls who attempts to enter Tehran's Azadi Stadium dressed as boys in order to watch a big football match but some get caught and arrested. After the establishment of the Islamic Republic in Iran, women are not allowed to enter the stadiums.
translation:
I got the impression that this movie is as much about human sexuality as it is about anything else, intentional or not. We are also shown how absurd and paradoxical that women are not allowed to experience such a nationally important event, forgetting the past of our respective "advanced" nations. I write from Japan, where women only had the right to vote 60 years ago and technical technicians are a new phenomenon. Pubs in England used to be just men, the business world was until recently completely taboo for women in America, and women in China had their feet tied so that they could not develop feet strong enough to escape their husbands. Iran is going through this period in our time, and we get a good overview of how ridiculous we all have ever been. Back to the subject of sexuality, we must wonder what it really is about women who make them unfit for football (the official reason is that the men are bad). Especially such boyish girls, a couple so much that one even has the feeling that also lesbian topics are on the agenda. I think one point is that not all women are the same, and the women the police are trying to "protect" are not those who would try to get inside. The opening scenes of the approach to the stadium make you appreciate the bravery of the young women who try - and each one for themselves - to even enter. It is a brutal male world. Any woman brave enough to go try should be allowed! The world of sexuality is not one size.

Meanwhile, the arrested criminal girls gather in the makeshift pen and wait for their deportation to who-knows-where, and in a much more subtle way, start connecting with the guards who watch over her. These had clear ideas of women and femininity, which were challenged head-on. The change of attitude is glacial, but visible.

Since the film is pure Iran from the first moment, the stranger needs a little relief, but the characters have a special way of loving themselves to you, and you get the whole picture and even understand the misunderstandings of the men and give them carelessness. The alleged villain is the invisible patriarchy of the ayatollahs, which remains unseen and unnamed and is unlikely to be recognized.

I know that this movie was filmed during the Iran-Bahrain incident, which was awe-inspiring for everyone involved.

summary: Maggie Peyton is the new owner of Number 53--the free wheelin' Volkswagen bug with a mind of its own; she puts the car through its paces on the road to becoming a NASCAR competitor. As a third generation member of a NASCAR family, racing is in Maggie Peyton's blood, but she is forbidden from pursuing her dream by her overprotective father, Ray Peyton, Sr. When Ray Sr. offers Maggie a car as a college graduation present, he takes her to a junkyard to choose one from an assortment of very used cars. Maggie has her eye on an old Nissan, but a certain rusty, banged up '63 VW Bug seems to be clamoring for her attention. To her surprise, Maggie leaves the lot with Herbie. As she prepares to leave town for a position with ESPN News, Maggie discovers that Herbie has a mind of his own--and an alternate route for her future.
translation: I went to see this movie with my 17 years. Daughter. I insisted that we show the matinee, not because I'm a tightwad, just the feeling that I had it. In the sense of NASCAR this is the dream of a sponsor. So much blatant advertising, it almost qualifies as an info business, if it were not for the so-called acting. Continuing with the tradition, the Herbie franchise continues with its cheesy storylines, the car is just a "vehicle" (no pun intended) for this movie's bead ball. Earlier Herbie rates (although cheesy) were produced at more severe times, making them a bit easier to digest. Ms. Lohan, Disney's acting drama queen, has few acting skills. I was surprised that Mr. Keaton and Mr. Dillon would be involved in such a project. Only the snack bar was a major rip off!

summary: Set in the late 1920s, The Luzhin Defence tells the story of a shambling, unworldly chess Grand Master who arrives in the Italian Lakes to play the match of his life and unexpectedly finds the love of his life. Discovering his prodigious talent in boyhood overshadowed by his parents' failing marriage, Luzhin's lyrical passion for chess has become his refuge and rendered the real world a phantom. Already matched up by her family to the very suitable Comte de Stassard, when Natalia meets Luzhin, she is drawn to the erratic genius and offers him a glimpse outside of his chess obsession. But it is a world he is not equipped to deal with and his two worlds collide to tragic effect.
translation:
A film of outstanding brilliance and a poignant and unusual love story, the Luzhin Defense charts the intense attraction between an eccentric genius and a woman of beauty, depth and character.

There is John Turturro, which is probable to this day (luckily they did not give it to Ralph Fiennes, who would have had it murdered.) Emily Watson also shows the richness of her experience (from her outstanding background on stage). To reach the tormented chess master (Turturro), her character must show both intelligence and the love of a woman. Watson does not portray beauty sexuality, but she brings a self-awareness to her parts that is tempting.

In a chance meeting between Natalia (Watson) and Lushin, she casually keeps him from losing a chess piece that has fallen through a hole in his clothes - a custom-made piece that, like Later in the film, we recognize his hopes and hopes. Later, as her love affair develops, she subtly compares dancing to chess (Luzhin has learned to dance, but never with a partner); She encourages him to lead her with "bold, brilliant movements" and allows him to relax enough to play his best later (and recognize herself as her lover).

This is a story of a woman who inspires a man to his greatest achievement and finds her own deepest fulfillment, emotionally and intellectually (or so we are led to believe - Natalia is certainly within the timeframe is more of a liberated woman than someone who makes herself a stereotyped wife and mother).

The Italian sets are breathtaking. The complexity of the characters and the way the dialogue unfolds them is a delight to the intelligent moviegoer, but the film is accessible enough to make it a popular mainstream hit, and rightly so. Chess is merely the photogenic backdrop for the development of an emotional and emotional film, though the game is treated with enough respect to almost convince a chess player that the characters existed. Although a tragedy of notable height is from a classic author, the final solution is nevertheless surprisingly uplifting.

summary: Min-jun and Ji-won are first-rate "players" who are used to getting their way in the field of love and sex, until they run into each other. Let the games begin.
translation:
With a story and a script written by a high school student, "The Art of Seduction" fails to deliver the romantic, challenging experience it tries to attribute to itself. The two main characters have the potential to be interesting - both male and female lead roles are "swinging singles (or in the female lead, engaged)", but "The Art of Seduction" does not even try. Based on an open exploration of the personalities of these two characters, "The Art of Seduction" avoids everything that is relevant to a base of thin, lean stereotype.

"The Art of Seduction" is insulting - insulting to its characters, offensive to men and women and offensive to the expectations of the public. It takes the terribly beautiful people we all know and plays out their painful interactions while expecting us to idolize them. Ji-wan is an immature, spoiled, manipulative bitch. The viewer is expected to like and forgive their mistakes because they are pretty. Min-jun, well, he's exactly the same. They are not nice people either. The "humor" in this film is mostly about Ji-wan's and Min-jun's devious attempts to excel in the honorable art of lying and manipulation. There is no character development, and we never know why Ji-wan and Min-jun are like that. It is simply expected that we will take them as they are, and ask no questions - they are cute !, and that's what matters. The rich references to celebrity starring in the reviews of azn Cinema Scenesters may point to "Art of Seduction's shallowness."

If you are still in high school, you like Grease or you are a Yellow Fever victim, you may like this movie.

Despite his "romance" tag, this is not a very good date movie.

summary: nan
translation:
Apart from the Brady Variety Hour, this was one of the highest television programs I've seen in a while. The quality of the video production was not too bad, but the overall appearance was unmistakable at the beginning of the 80s. And Marie Osmond looks like she fought the Avon Lady ... and lost a lot of time. Far too much eyeliner.

It was kind of embarrassing to watch veterans Danny Kaye and Eric Severeid doing so. It was even more interesting to see Alex Haley talking about the African Pavilion in the World Showcase, which would open in "about a year".

So far it's been 17 years and it's not open yet (unless you count Disney's Animal Kingdom.) Despite all the shortcomings, this is still an interesting visual piece of Disney history.

summary: nan
translation: I saw McCoy's reunion and was pleased to see Richard Crenna and Kathleen Nolan and Tony Martinez !!! It was wonderful to see them now because I always watched the show grow up when the TV said that there would be a reunion so excited !!! The only thing I could not figure out was why Lydia Reed (Hassie McCoy) and Michael Winkelman (Luke) were not there. I know that Walter Brennan had died.
