summary: The sleepy little town of Comet Valley has been invaded by plants from outer space. Intent on taking over the Earth, the space plants have found a way to pollinate humans, thus turning them into walking seed carriers. Can the resourceful residents fight off the alien invaders, or is the planet doomed to become an alien garden?
translation: This movie reminds me of some really bad science fiction movies from the 50s and 60s. It's not scary or interesting, but it's boring, cheesy and stupid. Special effects are ridiculous, all actors are ridiculous and the end is just terrible, wasting your money, renting or buying something better. I give him 3.5 out of 10 (I found this turkey quite amusing because of its stupidity).

summary: Bobby is a Los Angeles teenager who buys a customized Dodge van to pick up girls and spruce up his dull life, all while trying to win money racing other vans in order to pay for his own.

"It was not me! It was, um, my twin brother Rupert!" Bobby says to Dugan when he is confronted in Sally's apartment. I have used this line dozens of times over the years (nobody has yet to believe it).

summary: A mild mannered CIA researcher, paid to read books, returns from lunch to find all of his co-workers assassinated. "Condor" must find out who did this and get in from the cold before the hitmen get him.
translation:
In general, I do not like watching movies by Sydney Pollack ("The Firm" is an exception) and I've never been a fan of Robert Redford. Still, I thought, "Three Days of the Condor" must be good because of the many praising comments it has received.

Although the widescreen camera is very pleasing to the eye and Max von Sydow does a good job of being the weird professional killer, I found the whole thing extremely disappointing. The film undeniably radiates a paranoid atmosphere, but everything is ruined by the kinky storyline that seems to make no sense.

The film also contains one of the most unsatisfactory endings I've ever seen and which really goes away hanging in the air. And what can one say about this absurd romance between Redford and Dunaway? I would much rather see Hitchcock's movies five times in a row than sit through this trash again.

summary: Wong Kar-Wai's movie about two love-struck cops is filmed in impressionistic splashes of motion and color. The first half deals with Cop 223, who has broken up with his girlfriend of five years. He purchases a tin of pineapples with an expiration date of May 1 each day for a month. By the end of that time, he feels that he will either be rejoined with his love or that it too will have expired forever. The second half shows Cop 663 dealing with his breakup with his flight attendant girlfriend. He talks to his apartment furnishings until he meets a new girl at a local lunch counter.
translation:
Average viewers looking for a sense of inner coherence in a movie should probably give it a pass. It creates the same feeling as if one were staring at a strange arrangement of individual images that seem to have a relationship to each other but never merge into a totality.

While this isolated approach may create a kind of cinematographic montage may appeal to a few students or critics steeped in the inner language of contemporary filmmaking, it irritates and condescends for us citizens who are just embarking on hay wagons have fallen. An obvious avoidance of accessibility may well be the deliberate hallmark of writers like Kar-wai Wong and Tarantino, but for me it seems warmed up like Andy Warhol. The only redeeming feature that I find is in the production values, and they will not cut everything themselves there.

This is one of those productions where you watch and listen and anxiously wait and in vain for a clever development of an idea or thought to sustain all the remarkable and beautiful individual scenes. We are sorry. The calligraphic credits start to roll unexpectedly as soon as your interest starts to rain. I get to read the same big yawns and disappointments, which I think are very knowledgeable and thorough comments on this movie that never lead to anything really understandable. Ideas and images without any external context are not my idea of ‚Äã‚Äãfun.

Call me a philistine roaming the streets of Hong Kong looking for a bowl of Chop Suey.

summary: Murderous screenwriter Stanley Caldwell, who incidentally is thought to be dead, returns to the scenes of his crimes.
translation:
* Possible spoiler *

'Return to Cabin on the Lake' is a useless movie. The drama was not good and the plot was not even interesting.

'Cabin on the lake' is a good TV movie. The sequel was not. Judd Nelson was very good in the first movie and added a lot more character to his character. It seemed he was not interested in doing the sequel. His acting was good, but it could have been better. I do not want to comment on the rest of the cast, because in my opinion they are not even worth mentioning. But I will do it. The character of Alison is not even shown in the first part of the movie. Suddenly, she is the focus of attention alongside Stanley Caldwell. The role made no sense and it should have been better thought out. Dahlia Salem was absolutely terrible. Her acting was far below average, and casting people should have been looking for someone else. The director, Mike, was a confusing character. He seemed intent on being there, but it did not seem that his death was necessary. The play for this role was good, nothing great, but better than Salem's.

The plot was really bad, if you think about it. Stanley, who is probably dead, is on his way to "Cabin by the Lake," the film based on his screenplay. He stumbles over the director and in a short time the director is dead and Stanley directs the show. Yes, out of nowhere the crew will just let that stranger in and finish the movie without knowing anything about him. There are a few killings, not a lot, and those shown are ridiculous. One of the actresses on set is electrocuted while filming a scene. Another character is chewed by a motorboat. And you get entangled in drowning in a plant. These authors must have been happy with excitement.

I just have to say that I was not impressed by the shooting of the film. The way the company changed from a low budget back to a normal state quickly became irritating. The new hut on the lake was badly laid out. We're only showing it in a few scenes, and the whole thing with the chain in the basement was useless. It only worked in the first movie because we were shown the room a lot more, but it did not work in this one.

There were too many characters in this sequel. All but a few had no reason to be there. The spectacle of what little is shown was really bad and ... they just had no purpose in this movie.

All in all, "Return to Shack at the Lake" is a continuation of the collecting upstairs from where the first one has stopped. I can take "hut by the lake", but that was just not impressive. Judd Nelson should have avoided that, and so should you. It's nothing like the first one and it was all too slow. Nothing happened in the first hour and it continued for the second. Not to mention that the writing was awful. Use this only if you need help to sleep.

Well, we see that Stanley defies death and is still alive and well. By the way, it sounds like a third episode of a movie alone would be good. Stop throwing sequels and we can be fine!

(Did the filmmakers not notice that they showed us how they filmed the sea scenes from the first one? They were all made in a tank - never, never reveal the secrets of filming.)

summary: A comedy about bending the rules to reach your goal, Bend It Like Beckham explores the world of women's football, from kick-abouts in the park to freekicks in the Final. Set in Hounslow, West London and Hamburg, the film follows two 18 year olds with their hearts set on a future in professional soccer. Heart-stopping talent doesn't seem to be enough when your parents want you to hang up your football boots, find a nice boyfriend and learn to cook the perfect chapatti.
translation:
Gurinda Chada's semi-autobiographical film (2002) is a gentle, poignant comedy in an ethnically diverse community near Heahthrow Airport in West London. Like the planes that constantly arrive and depart from the headboards, we follow the ups and downs of the two main characters, Jess Bhamra (Parminder Nagra) and Jules Paxton (Keira Knightley), who build an unlikely friendship that shares their common passion for football and their own technical enthusiasm for David Beckham on the subject.

Much of the comedy comes from the misunderstandings of the families of these two talented girls who break all the expectations and conventions of their very different family backgrounds.

Somewhere in the middle, as a broker, peacemaker and casualty athlete, Joe (Jonathan Reece-Myers) - team coach of the Hounslow Harriers - joins in times of crisis and remains the main target of affection for the two main characters.

At some point, and not without many obstacles and triumphs along the way, we finally see our dedicated and beloved football heroines rise to make their dreams come true.

With great performances by Bollywood veteran Anupam Kher (Mr. Bhamra), Shaheen Khan (wife Bhamra), Juliet Stevenson (wife Paxton) and Frank Harper (Mr. Paxton), this is really a movie, that captures the urgent passion of youth and crosses all ethnic boundaries.

Pinky Bamrha (Archie Panjabi) and (Taz) Trey Farley are struggling with their own struggles but still contribute greatly to our understanding of the movie's main characters.

This film tells in a very special way an important story by chance of football. It celebrates the development of the understanding of ordinary people in ordinary families and the innate ability of young people to teach the old.

summary: Jim Morris is a Texas high school chemistry teacher and coach of the school's baseball team. He's always loved baseball and as a way of motivating his players, he agrees to go to a professional try-out if they win the championship. He once had aspirations to be a professional baseball player but an injury brought that to an end. Sure enough, the 39 year-old father of three finds himself at a camp for the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and he somehow seems to have regained his pitching arm, easily throwing a 98 mph fastball. Signed to a contract, he toils in the minor leagues while his supportive wife stays home raising their children. He soon finds himself called up to the big club and pitching for Tampa which is in Texas playing the Rangers. Based on a true story.
translation:
An end to an era was here in the States in the spring of 2002 with "The Rookie," a Disney live-action movie that seemed to be the "Best of the End !!!!!" It was right here in Texas! In fact, the story began in West Texas, as a local area code on a sign shows there. It was about a high school coach who was so convinced of his high-class baseball team that he decided to become professional !!!!!

What I liked about this movie: It was so cute !!! !! It was a very good sports movie, ala "The Mighty Ducks" trilogy. It also had moviegoers across Texas, from somewhere between Panhandle and El Paso to the Metroplex (where I live). I can say, because I recognize this ball park (was "The Ballpark in Arlington," now it is "Ameriquest Field")! It was nice to see that Disney's "Golden Age" ends here in my area !!!!!

RIP

Golden Age of Disney

1920s-Spring 2002

"Everything started with a mouse .. and it ended up in baseball. " (sobbing)

10/10

summary: Georges has Down's syndrome, living at a mental-institution. Harry is a busy businessman, giving lectures for young aspiring salesmen. He is successful in his business life, but his social life is a disaster since his wife left him and took their two children with her. This weekend his children came by train to meet him, but Harry, working as always, forgot to pick them up. Neither his wife nor his children want to see him again and he is driving around on the country roads, anguished and angry. He almost runs over Georges, on the run from the institution since everybody else went home with their parents except him, whose mother is dead. Harry tries to get rid of Georges but he won't leave his new friend. Eventually a special friendship forms between the two of them, a friendship which makes Harry a different person.
translation:
Although the plot elements seem to "The Eighth Day" as if they have been done many times, the film still has much of the spark, mystery and symbolism that Jaco Van Dormal's first film had. Although it is not as good as "Toto the hero", which will always be on my favorites list, the film still leaves a lot of emotions. Daniel Auteil, from the distasteful "The Closet" of 2001, plays down his role and is afraid of playing too much (rightly, the role could have been ruined if the actor were too dramatic). However, I felt that the part was a bit more realistic and focused more on the character itself than on the character's growth.

Do not go into this movie and expect the dark humor and the unexpected twists You have "Toto the hero" because you will be disappointed. However, the film still serves as a decent, if not faulty film

summary: The location is Mercy Saskatchewan, a small town in the Canadian prairies. A small but devout community of Muslims has settled there, headed by community leader Yasir Hamoudi, a local building contractor. He is married to Sarah, a Caucasian ex-Christian who has converted to Islam for her husband. Their adult daughter, Rayyan, is a feminist Muslim doctor. The religious leader of the Muslim community - the Imam - is Amaar Rashid, a young, Canadian-born ex-lawyer from Toronto, who came to Mercy to replace Baber Siddiqui, who was deemed too extreme by many in the Mercy Muslim community. The local diner is run by Fatima Dinssa, a Nigerian Muslim who is strict about her religion but more liberal in her cultural values. The Muslims in Mercy are co-existing with their Christian neighbors, sometimes harmoniously, sometimes not. Reverend Duncan Magee welcomes his Muslim neighbors, especially if they enhance the social and economic fabric of the community and his parish. Likewise, Mayor Ann ...
translation:
Who likes horrible "comedy" shows like Little Mosque on the Prairie? The only two types of people I can imagine are: One, Muslims and self-proclaimed liberal defenders of every ethnic group who are so excited is a show about Muslims that it does not even matter if the show is good or funny at all (which it is not). Two, old people and people whose idea of ‚Äã‚Äãcomedy is unbelievably predictable, poorly written, stale jokes.

CBC really needs to take a look at what they do and who their audience is. If you write comedy only for really old people, guess what's going to happen, their audience is going to die soon and they will not have an audience anymore. I wonder, who ever writes for this show? Do you think that they are actually Muslim or hip, funny young people? No, I'll bet they are old white guys who wrote the same jokes for the same kind of bad CBC shows since the 1960s.

If you look at CBC's comedy shows, Air Farce is finally taken out of the air (thank goodness!), but we still have lame ducks like this hour has 22 minutes and Rick Mercer, for whom we pay, not to mention this poor excuse for the "comedy" Little Mosque on the Prairie. It should be offensive and funny? Only the CBC would think that this lame show is ever open or funny. Shame on the CBC because we wereted our taxpayers on shows that only a few people would see.

summary: An actor and would-be screenwriter, who at the very moment of his meeting with Fate, comes to discover that life is random and fortune is sightless. He is thrown into a vortex where time, dreams, and reality collide in an increasingly whirling slipstream. It's a surreal and dreamlike tale of one man's journey.
translation:
What Hopkins manages with this effort, as a writer and director, makes us feel that we know absolutely no one in the film. Maybe that's the problem. His film has a lot of ambition and his intentions were obviously complex and drawn from very deep inside, but it's so impersonal. There are no characters. We never know who someone is, so there is no investment from us.

It could be a scriptwriter who mixes with his own characters. Is it? Could be. By that I do not mean that Slipstream is ambiguous; I mean that there is nothing to say. Hopkins' film is an experiment. At first glance, one could argue that it is a would-be scriptwriter who realizes, at the moment of his meeting with fate, that life is a stroke of luck and / or success is a blind coincidence, as he becomes in a "slipstream "hurled by collisions between times, dreams, thoughts and reality. Nonetheless, it is so tirelessly cerebral that it leaves no room for any hint of emotion, even for the tiny, rather rudimentary extent that allows us to connect with its characters.

I did not think the Nippy and Extravagant school of shaky, machine-gun speed camera work and editing broke me, but thinking about the movie I start to realize that it had a lot to do with it. There are so many films of the last decade in which the cuts or camera movements have sound effects, as well as other atmospheric technical Doodads. I suppose that in this case it was justified that his purpose was to compose the impressionistic responsiveness of dreams. However, I hardly knew anything about Slipstream when I saw it, and I came out in the same way. And I do not care, because Hopkins does not bother us to take care of it. There are interactive films and there are films that sit and knit in a rocking chair without being aware of their presence. Slipstream is the latter.

summary: Barbed wire. Thumbtacks. Cheese graters!?! For the WRC wrestling federation, it's just another day at the office. Join Sam the Dirty Bum as he presents the greatest feuds between these backyard warriors in SPLATTER RAMPAGE WRESTLING!! Watch in horror as they do everything from dive off rooftops through tables, to setting each other on fire! The Masked Mauler...Skulls...Puppy Lover...all these wrestlers have one goal in mind- to be crowned champion of the WRC! It's violent, it's extreme, and it's insanely hysterical!
translation:
Yeah, unfortunately I found the DVD and realized that it was unbelievably awful.

First of all, the characters are shit. I mean, come on, if a dork in an orange hat that calls itself 'Orange Sherbert' is the best creative idea these guys could muster for a character, then they definitely should not be in the movie scene. Bad "costumes", bad "interviews", and basically there is no "wrestler" on this whole disc with any charisma.

The "Wrestling" in Splatter Rampage Wrestling is nothing but these idiots hopping gently and playfully together on a trampoline. They make sure that they chuckle all the time together and that the experience sounds more like a toddler's playtime than a "wrestling deathmatch".

Basically, Splatter Rampage Wrestling is a pretty dull Backyard wrestling clone. Only, instead of blood, weapons, chaos, and WRESTLING, we get a trampoline, giggling kids, terrible audio, and a guy called Orange Sherbert.

Wrestling fan or not, avoid this DVD. It is terrible.

summary: Captain Drummond and his girlfriend want to marry but a hidden treasure in the house in which they want to celebrate their marriage is complicating the situation.
translation:
This Drummond entry lacks continuity. Most of them have their elements of silliness, the postponed wedding and so on. However, this has an endless series of events that take place in the near dark as the characters move from one place to another. The house seems more like a city. There is also Leo G. Carrol, who is such an obvious suspect nobody seems to see. He is a stranger and behaves quite suspicious, but Drummond and the people seem to pick up nothing. Still, it's a pretty good action and a pretty good ending.

I know that Algie is supposed to be a cartoon character, but like Nigel Bruce in the Rathbone Sherlock Holmes flicks, he's so arrogant that it's hard to imagine anyone with taste or intelligence around him. Is there a story behind him that will explain how he and Drummond became associates?

summary: Director Al Pacino juxtaposes scenes from Richard III, scenes of rehearsals for Richard III, and sessions where parties involved discuss the play, the times that shaped the play, and the events that happened at the time the play is set. Interviews with mostly British actors are also included, attempting to explain why American actors have more problems performing Shakespearean plays than they do.
translation:
Shakespeare seems to have a high forehead, which in turn corresponds to a group of people who do not see what it really is. At some point in this movie, someone (Pacino's producer, I think) warns him that the movie is out of control, that it was all about how the masses think about Shakespeare through the vehicle of RICHARD III. Instead, he decides to spin a choppy game with random comments. Some scenes seemed to be included as home movies for Al (was there any reason for a quick visit to Shakespeare's birthplace except for a laugh about something unexpected happening in there?), And before the movie really starts, we'll be treated to watch Al prance around and act nice and funny for the camera. I thought his silly plot with Kay towards the end of Godfather III with the knife at his throat was an act - but apparently it's the way Al really behaves personally.

Enough long-winded. Here's a shotgun, why I did not even make it: 1) pretentious - Al always knows when the camera is on top of him, whether he is acting as Richard or in a 'real' conversation with someone - you can see it in the corner of your eye Even some of the actors who stand around the sample table become unkempt and hammer to the utmost. If someone who reads this has ever spent time with a group of actors and is witnessing these things from the outside, it is unbearable. "Look at me and chew the whole landscape!" 2) Winona Ryder. When she appears as Lady Anne, this movie comes to a screeching stalemate from which he never recovers. She has nothing to add in the discussion scenes, but the camera stays with her to bring in the kiddoes. Their performance is terrible to boot. 3) The only things you really learn from it are told to you by the scholars who try to keep the filmmakers out of the picture. Of course you also learn that Pacino should not direct (or Richard in the first place). I'd rather see BOBBY DEERFIELD than that.

Finally, read the play and learn it yourself. Get out there and look at it. In 1997, I saw the play performed at the Ethnic Cultural Theater of the University of Washington, and it did what we see in this movie as a high school drama (apart from the groundless throat of Clarence, my God, was that necessary ?! ) It's all just a bunch of sound and rage, which means Nada.

summary: Four sisters in New Zealand fall for four U.S. soldiers en route to the Pacific theater in WWII
translation:
Unusual? Yes!

Unusual backdrop for an American war movie, New Zealand.

Unusual theme, four sisters and their relationships with American soldiers, from one who is the illegitimate child of the dead son of a senator, to another who lives with seven marines (one after another) before he is murdered by her returning prisoner of war New Zealander husband.

Unusually, Paul Newman delivers such a poor performance so soon after his unforgettable role as Rocky Graziano in the ingenious "Somebody Up There loves me".

Unusual for two fine "stars" Joan Fontaine and Jean Simmons, leaving so little of themselves in a movie /> Unusual that I could try a review on such a Write a bad movie, give him a miss!

summary: Whilst crossing a ledge, 4000 feet above the earth, Gabe's friend's equipment fails to work and she slips out of his hand, falling to the ground. Almost a year later, Gabe is asked to go back to the same mountain range and rescue a group of 'stranded' people. The only catch is that these so called 'stranded' people are in fact looking for three boxes filled with $100,000,000 and they need a mountain ranger to lead them to them!!
translation:
After sensing many things on the ridge, an ass mountain rescuer Gabriel Walker (Stallone) returned for his girlfriend Jessie (Janine Turner), while the cloudy sky, where the weather is a little threatening, is spectacular. Precarious hijackings go awry and 100 Millions of dollars taken from a Treasury Department plane are lost in the middle of nowhere, followed by a crash landing ??

stranded by the snowy peaks, and mountain guides need to recover the stolen money, the well-trained hikers make an emergency call and ask for the help of a rescue unit ??

Unfortunately, Gab and Hall (Michael Rooker) have to band together to get to the scene of the accident, unaware that the emergency call was a fake and a bunch of merciless terrorists led by a psychotic (John Lithgow ), just waiting for them to find a way out of the stormy mountain with the crated money boxes?

With stunning footage, dizzying landscapes, dizzying heights, dangerous climbs and freezing temperatures, is "Cliffhanger" definitely Stallone's best action adventure movie?

summary: All the hot gamblers are in town, and they're all depending on Nathan Detroit to set up this week's incarnation of "The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Crap Game in New York"; the only problem is, he needs $1000 to get the place. Throw in Sarah Brown, who's short on sinners at the mission she runs; Sky Masterson, who accepts Nathan's $1000 bet that he can't get Sarah Brown to go with him to Havana; Miss Adelaide, who wants Nathan to marry her; Police Lieutenant Brannigan, who always seems to appear at the wrong time; and the music/lyrics of Frank Loesser, and you've got quite a musical. Includes the songs: Fugue for Tinhorns, "Luck Be a Lady", "Sit Down, You're Rocking the Boat".
translation:
- Together with South Pacific, Guys and Dolls is for adults - it's cheeky, sexy, and full of men will be men and women along.

There's an energy and a drive that makes this stand out from the pack - the power of Jean Simmond's appearance and the charm of a young Brando and an already masterful Sinatra add to the overall look and feel of the pack Piece at.

Guys and Dolls wins as it is outrageous what it is: an MGM musical.

Still good to look at and hear with great melodies and dance numbers - it will remain one of the classics of the 20th century and be seen with pleasure for years to come.

Warmly recommended.

summary: The real-life struggles of the Bakhtiari tribe of Southern Persia (Iran) to migrate with 50,000 people and ten times as much livestock over seemingly impassable natural barriers of mountain and river during harsh weather conditions to reach grazing lands for their cattle and other livestock. Their hardscrabble life is portrayed with poetically beautiful cinematography in possibly the greatest documentary of the silent era.
translation:
This was unbelievable, meaning that it was hard to believe that the "forgotten tribe" would make this amazing migration twice a year and that the filmmakers Cooper and Schoedsack did not stage some of the scenes and recordings. But what shots are they! The cinematography is brilliant under the most extreme conditions, and the score of Iranian music added to the video gives this memorable documentary extra wealth.

I had the pleasure to see this and "Kon Tiki". That same weekend, that was a thrill and certainly made me realize how tough and hardy and courageous people can be, whether for primitive survival or the need for adventure or on behalf of science.

summary: The end of the 14th century. Parents send the eldest son Jan to study in Hamburg, and the youngest - Klaus - to the monastery. No sooner had the children moved away from their homes, as on Klaus'es eyes the robbers kill their parents and burn the house. Only thanks to the loyal monk Wigbold Klaus managed to survive the shock. A few years later Klaus St√∂rtebeker finds his brother Jan and his long-time friend Elizabeth Pren in Hamburg. From her, he learns that she is expected to marry Simon von Wallenrod, whose father Klaus suspects of killing his parents. But the Pranks and the Wallenrods are rich and respected people, and Klaus is a poor man. And now he becomes a pirate...
translation: How can a big German television station radiate such a chaos? It is amazing how the leading actors avoid any acting talent - even the well-known Gottfried John behaves very poor - especially in the double murder scene - how amateurish .......! The screen plan is very, very extended - maybe to fill in 2 parts of the movie. Be careful not to fall asleep while you watch! The set is obviously very often a blue screen, z. the scenes on the ship with unreal sea in the background ...! In the German version of the sound and the synchronization is very poor - probably the reason: different languages ‚Äã‚Äãof the actors - but: other international productions are much more professional. Note: Do not pay attention - it's a hell of a waste of time!

summary: A stranger comes to town looking for his estranged wife. He finds her running the local girls. He also finds a town and sheriff afraid of their own shadow, scared of a landowner they never see who rules through his rowdy sidekicks. The stranger is a town tamer by trade, and he accepts a $500 commission to sort things out.
translation:
I can not remember that I've ever seen this movie before tonight, probably the title sounded so ordinary that it passed me by. But it's a well-made Western, with an interesting, brooding tale, complemented by actors that roll from good to stupid.

Robert Mitchum goes into the wide open city looking for his wife and news from her daughter and stays for a time as a city tamer. As always, the good business people have mixed feelings - they want to get rid of the bad guys but like the business they bring. It still applies: Relaxed alcohol and gambling law and industry promotion, but pretend to complain about the shabby effects it can have on ordinary people. What's fascinating about this film is Mitchu's cynical-intensive portrayal of the city's cleansing of the wicked and the city's acceptance that its violent methods were the only ones. Favorite piece: the sudden death of 2 of the bad guys in the Red Dog limousine. The shooting of the main salon bordered on evil, but it was an effective way to combat the spread of poison.

Overall, a very good movie with its only guilt, which tends to be a little hokhness - not so good for do-gooders who would probably bargain with evil for a lifetime instead of getting it break up.

summary: Harry Mitchell, an L.A. manufacturer with a fancy car, a nice house, and a wife running for city council, has his life overturned when three masked blackmailers appear with a video tape of Harry and his young mistress. He's been set up, and they want $105,000. To protect his wife's political ambitions, Harry won't go to the police; instead, he shines them on and then doesn't pay. They up their demands, so he goes on the offensive, tracking them down and trying to turn one against the other. Their sociopathic leader, Alan, responds with violence toward the mistress and menace toward Harry's wife. Will Harry let up and pay off Alan or can he find some other solution?
translation: The villain in this movie is a sob and he seems to enjoy what he's doing, that's what I think makes him so mean. I do not think most men like this movie, especially if they cheated on their wife. This is one of those movies that pretty much stay pretty nasty right up to the end. But then there you have it, a candy bar end that lets me look back and say, "HOKIE AS BRIGHT." A pretty good movie until the end. End is the end that we would like to see, but not the end of such a mean beginning. And then there are the consequences of what happened. I guess you can get an idea of ‚Äã‚Äãthe true end yourself. I have the feeling that only one character should have survived in the end.

summary: Air Force fliers Rick Williams and Mike Nolan attempt to meet film star Nell Wayne, with whom Rick shares a hometown but not much else. Fellow film stars Doris Day and Ruth Roman mistakenly believe Rick to be very close to Nell and arrange for him to meet her. The pair begin to form a match, especially after Nell, Doris, and Ruth arrange for Hollywood stars to perform for G.I.s in transit to and from the Korean War, at Travis Air Base. But Nell thinks Rick is getting ready to ship out to the war, when in reality, he and Mike ferry troops part of the way then return to Travis Air Base with returning soldiers. Nell is furious with Rick for letting her believe he was headed to a war zone, especially because the press has made a huge story of their romance. Meantime, a new program, Operation Starlift, has been set in place by the Air Force and the Hollywood studios, whereby stars are flown to San Francisco to perform for the outbound and inbound troops. Movie stars such as Randolph Scott,...
translation: The realistic philanthropic gesture of actress Ruth Roman to entertain the troops who arrived and departed from the Korean War at the Air Force Base near San Francisco brought this All-Star-Warner Bros. greeting to patriotism and song. Many celebrities appear as a love-hate romance develops between an aspiring starlet and a painfully green and skinny Air Force corporal (Ron Hagerthy, who looks like he's delivering newspapers off his bike). Seems the corporal made the actress think he was going to fight when he was actually part of an aircraft carrier crew flying to and from Honolulu (they would think she was happy he was bailing out but instead she acts just like most childish women in movies of the 1950s). Doris Day is in the first thirty minutes or so, and her distinct laughs and brave song numbers are the most enjoyable. Roman is also here and looks glamorous, while James Cagney makes fun of his canvas character and Gordon MacRae sings in his beautiful baritone. Jane Wyman also sings Doris Day's lead in a hospital night reprise, which makes one wonder, "Did you run out of sets?" For undemanding spectators an interesting look back on another time and place. Nevertheless, the low rental production and only reasonable technical aspects make "Starlift" strictly a second-banker. * 1/2 of ****

summary: On the Franco-Austrian Frontier during WW I, an oriental priest, chaplain of a French colonial regiment, is condemned to life imprisonment because he possesses the power of turning men into zombies. As the priest,in his prison cell, is preparing to burn the parchment containing the location of the secret formula, Colonel Mazovia kills the priest and takes the partially-burned parchment. Fade to after the war to an expedition of representatives from all the Allied countries (only those with colonial interests it appears) being sent to Cambodia to find and destroy forever the Secret of the Zombies. The group includes Colonel Mazovia (somewhat akin to sending the fox to guard the hen house); a student of dead languages, Armand Louque; Englishman Clifford Grayson; and General Duval and his daughter Claire. Armand falls in love with Claire, who accepts his proposal of marriage in order to spite Clifford whom she really loves. Later, when Claire, following an accident, runs to Cliff for ...
translation:
Of the many problems with this film, the worst is continuity; and I reworked it on a VHS for a college cable channel many years ago and tried to figure out exactly what went wrong. It seems they actually made a much longer movie and then cut it down for the standard movie show. For how much longer? To fill all the holes in the storyline as we have them would take another three hours of narration and character development - especially given the fact that the movie we have is just so slow and takes itself so seriously.

That's breathtaking; What could the Halperins have been trying to do here? Her previous film "White Zombie" was a successful low-budget attempt to copy the early monster movies of Universal Studios (The Mummy, Dracula, etc.) and, as such, be pretty close to the zombie mythology that would be familiar to those in North America popular magazines.

Revolt of the zombies, on the contrary, is supposed to have been intended as an allegory for the politics of modern war. Not only would this explain the opening and change of Dean Jagger's character to megalomania, but it would also explain why the zombies do not do much in the movie except to stand around looking frightening and waiting for orders - they're just allegorical soldiers not the undead cannibals we all love and loathe in zombie movies. I've coped with all my aversion to the modern war and its politics - but I think a movie should be entertaining at first, and educational later. And definitely - a movie about zombies should be about zombies. Really one of the most bizarre movies in Hollywood history, but not one that I can recommend, even for historical value.

summary: Gerald is a yuppie-like transvestite in his thirties. His wife arrives home earlier than expected and discovers female attire spread over their apartment. Not knowing anything about his habit, she misinterprets this and throws him (and the attire) out of their home and marriage. He rents a room in Monica's house, recently divorced and around 50. Their relation- ship evolves from landlady/tenant over friends to lovers. Monica learns about, begins to understand and finally appreciates and supports Gerald- ine, Gerald's alter ego. His transvestitism, a rarely filmed subject, it's ups and downs, is treated with a lot of respect, warmth and humour.
translation: Julie Waters is always wonderful, but Adrian Pasdar is a positive revelation in this weird comedy about a transvestite who can not suppress his obsession and the changes he undergoes when discovered. He persistently avoids the vulgar, rough, simple jokes for real wit and true insight and has an absolute ball. A very nice, restrained comedy

summary: This unique short film follows the night of a young British insomniac named Jack, narrated almost hour by hour from a first hand perspective. You see what he sees, you feel what he feels, you experience the horrible delusions and the verge of insanity as he struggles to find the thinning line between reality and the subconscious.
translation:
Surprisingly well done for an independent film, An Insomniac's Nightmare paints a stunning picture of what it would be like to suffer from insomnia. Wonderfully well written and staged, it creates the atmosphere of a dream when the viewer undergoes a night in the life of an insomniac.

With Dominic Monaghan as Jack, we can see everything he sees as the long hours of a lonely night draw. The narrative is almost mesmerizing, and from the first few lines it is impossible to turn away. Fascinating and slightly disturbing, it shows how someone cope with lack of sleep, balancing on the edge between reason and madness.

With the turns around every corner, the insomniac's nightmare is provocative and rousing. It is highly recommended.

summary: A political satire set in Turaqistan, a country occupied by an American private corporation run by a former US Vice President. In an effort to monopolize the opportunities the war-torn nation offers, the corporation's CEO hires a troubled hit man, to kill a Middle East oil minister. Now, struggling with his own growing demons, the assassin must pose as the corporation's Trade Show Producer in order to pull off this latest hit, while maintaining his cover by organizing the high-profile wedding of Yonica Babyyeah, an outrageous Middle Eastern pop star, and keeping a sexy left wing reporter in check.
translation:
Do not confuse "War Inc." for a sharp-cut satire or a clever comedy full of inside jokes for news fans. It is not.

This is an old-fashioned screwball comedy, with ridiculously coincidence plot twists, stick characters (given some depth in fun performances by John Cusack, Joan Cusack, Marisa Tomei, and Hillary Duff) and a direct rapprochement the political content.

You see, the political points of filmmakers are things that almost the whole country already know are true. Yes, we understand that the corporations profiting from the war are corrupt, incompetent pigs, the political leaders responsible for them are even more awkward buffoons, and American imperialism has never looked any brighter than now - but none of that is the point.

Here is all this noise that they lament - sometimes ingenuously - as the backdrop for a silly tune, like John Cusack's character (the hit man with heart) trying to help his life with help the good-natured journalist who does not trust him (Tomei), and the young Middle Eastern starlet who wants to break off their marriage (Duff). Cusack's sister, Joan, plays his assistant with an almost caricature-enthusiastic quality. Ben Kingsley seemed to me wasted in his smaller part as an unscrupulous CIA boss.

That's all, and it works. It's just funny, but if you somehow can not see the reality and you think the war is going well and everyone is doing a good job and there is no corruption and the people in the Middle East wish that our western culture would replace them You could not find it funny.

For the rest of us it was a light comedy with a political edge.

summary: Visionary scientist Janos Rukh convinces a group of scientists and supporters to mount an expedition to the African continent to locate and study an ancient meteorite of great significance. He exposes himself to the highly toxic radiation of the meteorite, and while an antidote devised by Dr. Benet saves him from death by radiation poisoning, his naked touch causes instant death to others. Back in London, the benefits of the meteorite's controlled radiation offer Dr. Benet an opportunity to restore eyesight to the blind. The antidote's toxicity excites Prof. Rukh into paranoid rages as he seeks revenge against the members of his expedition, who he accuses of stealing his discovery for their own glory.
translation:
Prof. Janos Rukh (Boris Karloff) discovers Radium X - a powerful force for nuclear power. Unfortunately, Rukh has been contaminated by radium and begins to glow in the dark - and his touch causes instant death. Dr. Felix Benet (Bela Lugosi) is developing an antidote - but Rukh is starting to go crazy with radium and the antidote, and sets about killing everything he thought was wrong.

The plot is silly and The "effects" that make Karloff shine in the dark are ridiculous, but that's still a funny little cooler. It moves fast, has a great atmosphere (note Rukh's "house" and the movie starts on a dark and rainy night) and Karloff and Lugosi (as always) give great performances. There are also good plays by Franic Drake (as Rukh's wife) and Violet Kemble Cooper (as his mother). So it's fine, but only one step below the other Karloff / Lugosi movies. The plot is just too farfetched for me to swallow. Nevertheless, I liked that. I give it a 7.

summary: Eight-year-old Mac has outgrown his imaginary friend, says his mother, so he takes his buddy Bloo (a walking, talking security blanket) to Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends. Here all sorts of odd characters, given up by their creators, are welcome to stay until new kids come to adopt them. Mac strikes a deal with Madame Foster, the proprietor: as long as he comes to visit every day, Bloo will not be put up for adoption.
translation:
This is the worst show I have seen in years. I believe it should be taken by T.V. because of its retardation. It's so stupid that I could faint when I look at it. (Although I never watch it because it's sooooo poor)

Goofs: If Mac says he can not eat sugar, in another episode he eats sugar. Almost everything in the world has sugar in it !!! In the episode "Eddie Monster," when Eddy Terrance screams, he falls twice in the box. During the time he falls, he does not fall in, he falls aside. What stupidity. I can not even say the word "Foster Home". I even did a song with my band about how restrained this show is. Byyyyyyyyeeee

summary: Rural Louisiana, summer of 1957, Elvis is King. At 14, Dani is coming of age. Her older sister is beautiful, smart, and off to Duke in the fall; her mom's pregnant with number four (Dad wants a son), and Dad's pretty strict. Life gets sweeter when 17-year-old Court Foster, his widowed mom, and two little brothers move into the vacant farm next door. Court likes Dani's high spirits and direct way, and though he has a man's responsibilities on the farm, they go off swimming sometimes. The waters of adolescence are deeper than Dani realizes as hers and Court's feelings get jumbled. Then Mother Nature throws wrenching surprises at Dani, and she must come to terms with new emotions.
translation:
"The Man in the Moon" is a pretty good movie. It is sometimes very touching and very well done in every way. I would not say that the movie was terribly original, but what is it today?

The performers have all done a great job in their respective roles. I've really enjoyed seeing Reese Witherspoon at such a young age and doing a pretty good job. Jason London is also doing a good job. And the only other person I recognized was Sam Waterston, who did a fantastic job with his role. I really liked Sam's character (Matthew Tran). Sometimes he seems to be the kind of father you fear, but in the end you really like his character. The rest of the cast was also very good.

If you started watching movies about growing up and dealing with what life throws at you, then you should watch this movie. I'd suggest reading the storyline, and if that sounds like something you're interested in, then go for it. Hopefully you enjoy the movie, thanks for reading,

Chris

summary: --**Contains Spoilers**----Air Force pilot John Sands has been wrongfully imprisoned in a military detention center, where his memory is to be chemically wiped because some of his superiors feel threatened by the knowledge that he gained from his assignments to operations that were deemed too sensitive for the regular intelligence services. Later, after John escapes from the detention center, a top secret Air Force Stealth Bomber known as the X-77, which uses the latest in stealth cloaking technology, making it capable of going anywhere undetected, is stolen by corrupt Air Force pilot Ratcher. General Tom Barnes, John's former commander, hears that John has been arrested after taking down a group of men who were robbing a rest stop. Knowing that John was Ratcher's trainer, Barnes sends John to northern Afghanistan with fellow pilot Rick Jannick to recover the X-77, promising John that he will be a free man if he succeeds. Barnes has Admiral Frank Pendleton, who is on an aircraft ...
translation: Like Steven Segal films go, this is the bottom of the barrel. His best was only food for bored teens. This tilts the scales and then drops. The characters are all made of cardboard. The story is twice as lame. I can not ruin it by telling you the end. You know how all Steven Segal movies end up when you see one. Here goes. He's a Super Dooper government agent who knows too much to set himself free, so instead of killing him, he decides to fool his brain until he remembers squats. He escapes naturally, is arrested, and finds himself with his old general, who needs his only man in a million years' experience to get back a stealth plane handed over to a terrorist gang in Afghanistan by an Air Force pilot, Surprise, Segal. All heroes, with the exception of Segal's character and gloomy girlfriend, die heroically and Steve Baby saves the whole world in a single swell. What ever. Made with a bit of excess Air Force and Navy Flying Film. And a lot of boom-boom. Obtain Popeye cartoons.

summary: Raggedy Ann and the rest of the toys in Marcella's playroom are curious about a package that has just arrived. They look inside and discover it contains a beautiful French doll. The haughty girl, named Babette, is horrified by her new home. She wants to go back to Paris. Meanwhile, the Captain, a pirate in a snow globe, sees Babette and falls in love. He tricks Raggedy Ann into freeing him and then immediately kidnaps Babette and sails out the window. Raggedy Ann and Andy leave the playroom to rescue her. Their adventure includes meeting a blue camel with wrinkled knees; the Greedy, a living, self-consuming taffy pit filled with every candy and confection known to the palate; King Coo Coo and the Loonie Knight, who love to laugh, but only at the expense of others; and Gazooks, a tickle monster hired to give King Coo Coo the last laugh. Finally, they find the Captain; but the damsel in distress proves more capable than they had imagined.
translation: ... in our household. Like all the others who have commented on this film, my brothers (7 & 4 years old at the time) and I (10) have seen this movie over and over again. We all loved Star Wars, but we kept coming back to this topic because of the great songs and the adventure. We all loved the camel and sang with it during his song with full force. There are some slow moments (the time spent with King Koo-Koo in his yard) and we got bored after the song by The Knight in general ("The reason I'm {sound effect} because I love you "), but we loved the journey to save Babbette and the end, and everyone was a little startled by the image of King Koo-Koo hovering there, dominating the whole horizon, laughing insanely in the end , I still sing today "Hurray for me! Babbette of gay Paris!" around my friends (I'm 33 now), who only look at me as if I had lost my mind; but when I sing it, I'm 10 years old and remember the wonderful year of Star Wars again.

summary: The true story of Otomo, a Black man seeking work and asylum in the German city of Stuttgart. However, all he finds is racism, police trouble and his final destiny. His one-day journey leads him to a run-down temporary employment agency where he is being rejected because he doesn't own an ID and proper shoes. Downcast he continues his purposeless trip. In a streetcar he encounters a racist trolley controller who wrongfully accuses him of having an invalid ticket. As the situation escalates, Otomo head-butts the controller and flees. With the police on his heels, Otomo decides to leave the country. He runs into a truck driver who is inclined to take Otomo to the Netherlands if he pays him 400 Deutsche Mark in advance - a load of money he doesn't have. His need of money leads to desperate measures, but also to a new love. However, Otomo's bloody final encounter with the police is not too far away.
translation:
A certain illegal so-called asylum seeker comes to Stuttgart and finds that Germans are "racist".

This is just another forgotten steaming nugget in a long list of post-WWII anti-German propaganda films that aim to make Germans feel "bad" so they do not degenerate welcome in their country he can hunt German blondes and sell drugs to German teenagers.

If you're looking for good German films in general, you'll see "The Tunnel", "The Downfall", "Europe Europe" and "Lola Runs."

But not that .

Also "The Experiment", with the same male actor from "Lola Runs".

summary: Emma Woodhouse has a rigid sense of propriety as regards matrimonial alliances. Unfortunately she insists on matchmaking for her less forceful friend, Harriet, and so causes her to come to grief. Through the sharp words of Mr. Knightley, and the example of the opinionated Mrs. Elton, someone not unlike herself, Emma's attitudes begin to soften...
translation: This is indeed a god adaptation of Jane Austen's novel. Compared to the American version with Guinneth Paltrow, the script was written to be as close as possible to the book. But the acting was terrible. Besides Kate Beckinsale, whom I believe is a true reflection of Emma in the book, all the other actors have gone to great lengths. Mark Strong was not the "gentleman" he should be. He was often rude and insulting, had no feeling at all, and throughout the movie you could not see his love for Emma "growing" at all. This had a terrible effect on Kate Beckinsale, who apparently tried to "oust" her lead role and her partner. There was also no chemistry between the entire cast. Harriet Smith, played by Samantha Morton, seemed to have no real attachment to Mr. Elton, played by Dominic Rowan. Therefore, she did not seem so heartbroken as she was portrayed in the book. The settings of the film are too bad. The costumes are even more. I would have imagined Emma Woodhouse dressing herself here more fashionably and elegantly. The end is too long. It's good that it's like the end of the book, but it's a killer ending to a movie. And again, in the face of Mr. Knightley, I can not feel happiness. In the end, I thought that adaptation would remain true to the book, but with poor actors. It seemed like the movie was made without budget. I would prefer to see the "lighter" version with Paltrow and Northam, though it's clear that it was a "blockbuster" to ruin all of this script (except for the good Olivia Williams and the better Kate Beckinsale) ,

summary: On the top floor of an abandoned tenement, Harry Lesser struggles to complete the novel he has been writing for almost ten years. Then Willie Spearmint, black militant and aspiring writer, moves into another part of the building to work on his own book.
translation: Never has a movie made me write a review, but that was just awful. I kept on trying to figure out what this film was about, choosing it as its first serious role, but honestly it was a bad choice. I made a good book, but for me as a movie it certainly did not work , I thought it was unbelievable, lacking atmosphere and I found many of the scenes to be staggeringly stilted. A musical maestro, he may be a serious actor of Dylan Mcdermott, and Rose Byrne was passable but not enough to make a weak conspiracy with a weak dialogue. maybe I just missed the point, but for me it did not fit into any genre, it did not arouse any empathy with the characters, nor did it cause any tensions, in fact I prayed myself for the very end and overcome a deep desire, all to beat three main characters!

summary: A young boy stumbles into a mysterious girl who floats down from the sky. The girl, Sheeta, was chased by pirates, army and government secret agents. In saving her life, they begin a high flying adventure that goes through all sorts of flying machines, eventually searching for Sheeta's identity in a floating castle of a lost civilization.
translation:
I have seen almost all of Miyazaki's films, and they are all beautiful and captivating. But this one rises above the rest. This movie really impressed me!

I fell in love with Pazu and Sheeta and their loving, caring friendship. They were what the movie did for me. Of course, the animation is also excellent and the music captures the feelings in the film perfectly. But the characters are the shining point in this movie: they are so well developed and full of personality.

Now let me clarify: I'm really talking about the Japanese version of the movie (with English subs). While the English dub is (mostly) good, it simply fades in comparison to the original language version. The voices are better, the dialogue, everything. So I suggest watching the movie (and hearing it) as it was originally.

summary: (Korean with English subtitles) Helmed by one of Korea's leading directors, Hong Sang-soo, Jisook joins two of her girlfriends for a holiday in Korea's Kangwon Province. But in an eerie twist of fate, her former lover, Sangkwon, plans a getaway for the same destination, where tragedy brings them together once again.
translation:
The power of Kangwon province is director Hong Sang-Soo's second feature effort and clearly much of what he has begun in his previous film in this film, including the multiple-connected tales (in this case two) and stories of distressed or troubling relationships , as well as a strong dose of irony.

One thing that is clearly reduced from his previous work is the flights of the imagination that contain elements of surrealism. However, this film also contains a moment of surreal moment, which contrasts with the otherwise rather realistic depiction. The two stories follow a young woman traveling with her friends to Kangwon province just to feel attracted to a stranger. The second is about a man taking a trip to Kangwon province with his friend and fighting with his relationship.

Once again, Hong has a strong sense of irony and the flaws in human nature, and yet I do not think he is totally disagreeable with his characters, who are just showing enough compassion He draws criticism with his irony. I think the thoughts that I love about Hong's films are that they just feel so real, especially the complex and contradictory characters. Not to say that every person is a hypocrite or suffering from confused feelings, but that these characters he and the actors present are fully developed and believable.

This is not a fast paced movie. There's a lot of lingering and like in the previous movie, things do not always connect instantly, so patience pays off in a surprising way. It does not seem to be an element of the film that is not deliberately put into the film, and it makes me a little hyper-aware of various seemingly extra characters as they get drawn into the mix as the movie progresses. >
Power is an excellent movie that manages to bring personal emotions, regrets and yearnings into a story that highlights the irony and fallibility of human choices. It's a pretty heavy balance, and it's surprising how Hong manages to do it twice in a row. Technical production values ‚Äã‚Äãhave become much better since the first film and the direction have become clear. This movie does not pack the same emotional wallop as the first, but it does gain a lot in its safe exploration and the refinement really helps to tighten the overall vision. Great consideration for art cinema lovers. 8.10.

summary: Popular songwriter Oliver Courtney has been getting by for years using one ghost writer for his music and another for his lyrics. When both writers meet at an inn, they fall in love and then try to sell their songs under their own name. The problem is every song publisher thinks they're copying Courtney's style.
translation: This great movie is based on a myriad of talented actors and top-notch musicians - Levant, Crosby, Martin, Rathbone, Manone are at home in history, apparently delivered by Billy Wilder. One would like to know more about how much he had to deal with, because it is a very clever modification of the sterile master / the fruitful servant story - almost an allegory of the entertainment industry, which is operated by dried Numskulls, but to a living world of art and play through a exploited subclass of Nobodies and non-WASPs. Looking at the last six decades of music, television and film in the US, it's hard to take the basic insights of this film as prophetic.

summary: Marcel De Lange is a struggling sculptor whose work and sanity are derided by the New York art critics. After waspishly officious critic F. Holmes Harmon ruins a sale for De Lange by dismissing his expressionistic cubist work as "tripe" and later gloating about it in his column, the distraught artist goes to the river to drown himself. There he discovers the half-drowned body of the notorious serial killer, the Creeper, and takes him back to his studio to recover. Feeling empowered by the friendship of the acromegalic sociopath, De Lange tasks him with murdering the critics who have pilloried him in print. When successful commercial artist Steve Morrow is wrongly suspected of the crimes, his art critic girlfriend Joan Medford decides to follow her instinct about a mysterious bust De Lange has suspiciously covered in his studio, and she decides to snoop around.
translation: This is a typical later universal horror strip: its technically sophisticated, albeit by the numbers, with a cookie-cutter plot and some serious overacting. The most interesting part of this film is his stuntcasting by Rondo Hatton, a man with a bone disorder as the movie's "monster". It is sad to see that this man is being exploited, but he probably took good advantage of the money they paid him. Hatton is less frightening than the studio hoped, as I often felt pity for fear or even disgust. Martin Koslack is on board as the crazy artist of the film and he is very amusing in this part. For my part, I enjoy seeing Koslack in almost everything; For some reason, the man amuses me. The only other part of the film that entertained me is the film's absurd attitude to the art world. Here we are shown evil art critics who admire their ability to break artists; this is side by side with the male "hero" of the movie, who is an "artist" who paints ... brings that ... pin-up girl. Somehow the work of our hero is discussed side by side with the absurd sculpture of the villan. Amusing is also the hideous critic of the film, who once claimed he despised the heroes' pin-up art because "such women do not exist", to which our heroine replies with the assurance that the critic just can not get enough out. After all, there is a bit of a subplot about the domestication of the heroine (who is herself an art critic) by the leading man ... totally antifeminist and ridiculous to witness. Overall, this movie is a rather mediocre picture with a few amusing elements.

summary: A deceptively charismatic ex-convict is welcomed into a Beverly Hills family as their new houseguest. Will they grant him a second chance at redemption. Or will they realize too late that some people really are born evil?
translation: From the beginning you know how this movie will end. It's so clich√©d that your typical NRA member does not like this movie. I give it 2 out of 10 just because of the action of William Benton. I can not believe that people chose 6+ for this movie. It is so prejudiced against a "particular point of view" (once a thief ...). People are not born bad. You are not born too well. You were born with a clean slate. It is society, parents and education, what makes them who they are. And if they choose the wrong direction, it certainly will not be the American penal system that gets them back on track! Avoid this movie like the plague. I bet you have better things to do with your time than waste it with that piece of crap.

summary: It's been 5 years since socialite Ursula Stanhope left civilization to marry George, lovable and clumsy King of the Jungle. Now father to George Junior, George finds himself stressed at having to juggle his cherished roles of jungle king, Junior's dad, and Ursula's loving husband. George's stress level goes way up when Really Mean Lion challenges him for leadership of the jungle, and Ursula's mother Beatrice teams up with Ursula's ex-fiance Lyle in a plot to forcibly take away all that George holds most dear.
translation:
The kids, ages 7 to 14, made such a big kick out of this movie that we copied all the other kids on our birthday list this year. They all loved it! Children from 2 to 7 see it always and often and we enjoy seeing it with them.

It's rare for a movie to keep the kids entertained for so long, and it does offer adults a laugh, too. Most people enjoy it more than the first one.

Top quality production and a superb cast, led by Christopher Showerman as a superior George - athletic, energetic and totally believable, with a lovable innocence and a special skill to put a tree in the face - well supported from the inimitable Christina Pickles as the evil mother-in-law, Thomas Haden Church as the villain rival, and everyone else. That is fun.

summary: Rock-and-roll icon Conrad Birdie is about to go into the Army, and plans are being made to arrange his final going-away concert.
translation: This is a great movie, I made it a while ago. It had an extra Zing-- to it. I loved Vanessa Williams as Rosey and also Jason Alexander has a good voice. It was great. The attitude was also very good. Besides the fact that it takes 2 hours and 50 minutes, it is quite long. Overall, I give 8.5 stars. They also added a few parts, but it was still cool.

summary: Bourne is once again brought out of hiding, this time inadvertently by London-based reporter Simon Ross who is trying to unveil Operation Blackbriar--an upgrade to Project Treadstone--in a series of newspaper columns. Bourne sets up a meeting with Ross and realizes instantly they're being scanned. Information from the reporter stirs a new set of memories, and Bourne must finally, ultimately, uncover his dark past whilst dodging The Company's best efforts in trying to eradicate him.
translation:
I'll start by saying that I'm very pleased with this highlight of the Bourne trilogy. Please, oh, please do not spoil it by doing a sequel from now on or a prequel. Just leave it alone. Right..moving on.As talented and versatile as Matt Damon is ... it seems he should only play Jason Bourne.

If you are a fan of the first two Bourne films, you will not be disappointed with the third installment. It keeps working and adds a little more. I was delighted to see how well all the information we receive in 'Identity' and 'Supremacy' is interlinked in 'Ultimatum' to finally capture the full picture of Jason Bourne's troubled past. The action sequences are fast paced and keep you on the edge of your place. The battles between Bourne and the assassins are always fun. I have always been a fan of CIA agent films and how the CIA brings their Intel together, and this film is right on this street, which makes it even more exciting for me.

If you want to watch The Bourne Ultimatum without seeing the previous 2 installments ... you'll enjoy the movie anyway, but I'd still recommend seeing them first. This would allow you to fully understand and be guided by the character Jason Bourne and to be a part of his world. So you can enjoy the movie even more and enjoy. I'm not sure which one is the better of the first 2, but I personally think that ultimatum could, only could, have the advantage of comparing the trilogy.

summary: An evil plot slowly unfolds. A mysterious villain is planning a vast symbiote invasion of New York, and at the same time-has framed Spider-Man of stealing Dr. Octavious' new machinery. That's not the only trouble plaguing Spidey. He must also save J. Jonah Jamison from the Scorpion, stop Rhino's Rampage, and save Mary Jane from Venom.
translation:
I think Spider-Man is the best superhero ever, and this game is the best superhero game ever. While it may be a bit simple, you have to play it several times to get all the costumes and comic covers, which is how easy it is to get through the game. It initially seems hard to control, but once you get the hang of it, you'll be web-hauling like Spider-Man himself.

The bosses, while how the levels are a bit simple, are fun. The first boss, Scorpion, is incredibly easy to beat, which should not be so, as the comic fans know, Scorpion is one of Spider-Man's deadliest villains. The second boss, Rhino, is also very simple. The 3rd boss is Venom, who in my opinion is the lightest boss in the game, which definitely should not be. The fourth boss is Venom again. This time he is a bit harder to beat, but still easy. The fifth boss is Mysterio, who I think is the funniest boss in the game. He's also one of the harder bosses, but again, still pretty easy. The next boss is Carnage, who is easy to beat. But Carnage is actually fun to fight. 7. Boss is Doctor Octopus, who like all other bosses is light but not as easy as the others because he has a shield. The 8th and final boss is exclusive to the game, never in a comic or cartoon. I will not spoil it for you for those of you who have not played the game, but the boss is the only boss in the game who is not too easy. Took me 4 or 5 attempts to beat while the others beat me on the first or second attempt.

All in all a very good game. I gave him 8 out of 10 points. The reasons why I did not give them a 9 or 10 are that if you get all the costumes and comic covers, it gets boring (getting all the stuff will take a while), it's not very accurate after the comics or the Animated series, the bosses are too easy, and they should have used Hobgoblin and / or Green Goblin as boss, I think it would be fun to fight against someone flying in the air! You also did not use them in the sequel to this game! Well, the Green Goblin is the bad guy in the upcoming Spider-Man movie, so hopefully they'll make a video game based on the movie.

summary: Based on the true story of Lindy Chamberlain. During a camping trip to Ayers Rock in outback Australia, she claimed that she witnessed a dingo stealing her baby daughter, Azaria, from the family tent. Azaria's body was never found. Police noted some apparent inconsistencies in her story, and she was charged with murder. The case attracted a lot of attention, turning an investigation into a media circus, with the public divided in their opinions.
translation: "A Cry in the Dark" is a masterful piece of cinema, spooky and incredibly provocative. The true story of Lindy Chamberland, who had a terrible sight in 1980 when she brutally pulled her 3-month-old baby from her family's tent while camping in the Australian Outback. Azaria (the baby) was never seen again, and the result of her terrible disappearance caused a veritable rush of life around the world. Meryl Streep makes the role of Lindy immaculate, as she always does. But the one thing that helps "A Cry in the Dark" is never the case. A truly inspired and close look at this bulging case, tears are caught in the eye. The concept is no less terrifying, and afterwards one is pursued, but also inspired.

summary: Mary is a free-spirited young woman with a run-down New York apartment and a high fashion wardrobe. She calls her godmother, a librarian, for bail money after being arrested for throwing an illegal party. To repay the loan, she begins working as a library clerk. At first she hates it, but when challenged decides to master the Dewey Decimal System and become a great library clerk, while romancing a falafel vendor and helping her roommate in his goal to become a professional DJ.
translation: I work in a library and expect this movie to be released 5 years ago. Well, I really liked Parker Posey (she's a wonderful actress) and Omar Townsend was really cute like her boyfriend (he could not play, but if you look like him, who cares?), But the movie was bad. It was not funny or cute or much of anything. Posey kept the movie afloat with her energy. But she learned the Dewey decimal system OVERNIGHT and then tons of books in time with the music? !!!! Come on! I also had a problem with the way she looked when she ended up becoming a full-fledged librarian - hair in a bun, glasses, no sense of humor - can we please let that stereotype go? Worth seeing for Posey and Townsend, but that's about it. The TV series was much better.

summary: Professor Wassermann (John Stacy) is asked by industry magnate Morgan Hunnicut (Eddie Faye) to lead an expedition to study the giant Yeti creature found frozen in a large ice block on Newfoundland's coast. The professor does not know that Hunnicut intends to use the prehistoric creature as a trademark of its multinational industrial group. A very big mistake.
translation:
Here is another movie that should be loaded into a satellite, fired into space, and pointed towards the galaxy Andromeda to show the best of humanity possible civilizations. This movie is so lovingly stupid and revealingly honest that it is little more than a rip off of the already bad movie classic KING KONG of 1976, which not only manages to stage this film idiotically in pure guttural laughter, but successfully predicts much of Peter Jackson's wretchedness Computer cartoon from 2005, which bears the same name, which is a "romance" between the giant (here a Yeti) and a beautiful human woman (Antonellina Interlenghi of Umberto Lenzi's CITY OF THE LIVING DEAD, which is very light eyes).

The movie was made for kids, except for some fish bone references and a bizarre nipple tweak to say goodbye to having sex forgotten - the Yeti even has some kind of huge jockstrap around it masking monstrous package, the result is even more amusing than the anatomical correctness. But in return, you get a crazy old scientist, two curious kids, Tony Kendall, who in a rare twist is a duplicitous bastard of a villain, a helpful, intelligent collie dog, who gets his own adventure (Dog Adventure movies were great) in Europe for a while) and naturally turns out to be the hero in the end for rescuing the Yeti, who turns out to be the good guy, glorious stuff like front end loaders, decorated like giant monkey hands, a monster whose size literally changes scale from shot to shot , some inappropriately terrible deaths that make the carnage in GODZILLA VS THE SMOG MONSTER look tame compared to crowd-reaction shots that consist of either Spanish, Italian or Canadian extras, depending on the scene (you can sort out where they are turned up, as the extras are dressed, and some of the most enthusiastic in staged but incompetent special effects always work in a huge monkey movie.

Here the movie has convinced me: It's just enthusiasm to be ma de. Frank Kramer is actually the same Gianfranco Parolini, who brought the world of SARTANA and GOD'S GUN to the world in 1968, and was a very important director in the spaghetti western and action / adventure genre film scene of the 1960s / 1970s and at the time of YETI He probably pleased to get the job. I would say that this is his most adventurous movie, or rather the one with which he had the most chances, and perhaps would have felt more comfortable using those opportunities with the movie for children and families. The film has a kind of reckless devotion to the way it was made, which makes the technical mistakes or inconsistencies completely meaningless. Or rather, they are part of the fun, and if the movie had been played seriously, it would not have worked - WHAT IS EXACT WHY PETER JACKSON'S FILM IS Caught.

He forgot to have fun with the material and let it dictate the result with his army of stupid Power Macintosh pod people animators, and with all his mistakes + Klunker, Kramer's YETI is actually closer to the mind Why do we see films like this, some of which are there to see actors in monkey suits ripping off miniature sets on sound stages, not seamlessly animated, bland hours of nothing but disk space. I would rank this with KING KONG VERSUS GODZILLA and IT! Curse of the Great Golem as one of the most incredible monster movies of all time. Because the movie looks so "wrong", you can go through the story and just have fun watching stuff being broken, trampled, thrown around and shattered. Knowing this, and endowed with a fruitful, energetic enthusiasm for making the film, Parolini has pulled out all the stops and put in a full-on adventure that could be a bit rough for some of the little rascals, but the first movie, the I'll be sharing with the grandchildren someday, when their stupid parents leave me with them for a weekend. This is stuff for eternity and one of the most expressive expressions of humanity ever committed to celluloid.

10/10, it's about ten minutes too long, but who cares, you only come by once and I'd rather go out with a smile on my face.

summary: A documentary on the evidence which shows that the Apollo 11 astronauts never actually landed on the moon.
translation:
The only reason why I did not rate this here is that Sibrel shows that he masters the technical aspects of filmmaking. It's a tech-savvy movie.

It has been said that this is a movie based on lies and distortions that are pretty easy to disprove. Most of the documentary is spent on propaganda techniques to destroy the space program rather than actually acting. And Sibrel's "irrefutable proof" that the landings were forged is easily disproved if one knows about orbital mechanics.

I do not recommend it, but if you do you can see it for free on google video. Do not let Bart Siberel benefit from your curiosity.

summary: After the passing away of his wife, wealthy Delhi-based businessman, Harishchandra, took it upon himself to bring up two sons, Sunil and Prem. When they grew up he got Sunil married to Bhavna, and let Prem complete his education, even let him study abroad. Soon Sunil and Bhavna gave birth to a son, Rahul. When Bhagat told him that he had found a suitable match for Prem in Poonam, the niece of Krishnakant, a fruit merchant from Madhupur, Uttar Pradesh, the family traveled there, met with Krishnakant, his wife, Rama, and daughter, Rajni, and instantly approved of Poonam. Prem and Poonam also approved of each other, the Astrologer was consulted and a marriage was scheduled to take place in six months time. Shortly thereafter the engagement took place. The two families met again in Som Sarovar, Nainital, to let everyone get acquainted, and when Prem got his first contract from Japan, Krishnakant took his family to Delhi to celebrate. With the deadline for the marriage drawing close, both ...
translation: Vivah is by no means a classic. But in the days of hardcore action, groundbreaking special effects, and complex plots (none of which Bollywood knows), it's refreshing to see a simple movie like Vivah. The story, as we all know, is a journey from the couple's first meeting to their wedding after a few shy moments and trial periods. Not more, not less. The music is not quite in the same league as MPK or HAHK, but neither are the senses. Two songs stood out for me - Mujhe Haq Hai & Do Anjaane. While Milan Abhi Aadha and Hamaari Shaadi were to appease. Shahid is honest and shows a lot of potential. It's good to see that he plays something different from the "cool guy" he normally does. Amrita is very sweet and plays the role of a docile small-town girl perfectly. Alok Nath, Anupam Kher & Seema Biswas are great supporters and the rest of the cast is doing a decent job. Suraj's direction is simple but effective. The main flaw of the movie is the slow speed that could test the patience of many young viewers. But all in all a good, clean, decent family movie.

summary: Youngsters from different countries, races, and social background are forced to integrate when they all enroll in Columbus University. They all have their own problems, such as finance, harrassment, personal safety, and self doubt. Additionally, campus life seems to be causing a problem for everyone: racism. Students, already under pressure to perform in the classroom, on the track, or in front of their friends, are strained to the breaking point by prejudice, inexperience, and misunderstanding.
translation: This was a great movie that had many problems. It was about questions of racism and class. But it also had a message to know oneself and take responsibility for oneself. This film was very deep, with the message that you and only you can control your fate. It has also shown that the only way to fit into society is to know yourself and be familiar with what you are. What others think about you is not important. I think this movie has shown it wonderfully. The actors I think were able to convey every character wonderfully. I just found it amazing how deep the movie really was. At a glimpse, you would not see how deep the movie is, but on a wider view you can see the underlining meaning of the movie.
