summary: Jimmy is drafted and ends up in Fred's troop on his way to Europe. Jimmy becomes vicious with his gun, wins a medal, and weds Fred's nurse girlfriend, Rose. Back home years later, Rose discovers Jimmy is a gangster, has him arrested, and finds a job in Fred's circus as Jimmy escapes, determined to kill Fred.
translation:
Wedged between San Francisco and Captains Courageous two of Spencer Tracy's biggest roles is this very strange movie about the war and the impact on some people. They gave him a gun star Spencer Tracy and Franchot Tone in the only movie they've made together, and Gladys George as the woman who loves them both.

Tracy and Tone are a few of the First World War conscripts, Tone is a feeble character who almost goes over the hill in Bootcamp, but Tracy stops him. Tracy is still playing the lovable, blood-soaked, younger Wallace Beery guy MGM intended for him when they turned him down from Fox.

Over at the front, Tone gets a chance and takes it when he reaches a church tower during a fight looking at a German MG nest. He's learned how to shoot and he's making a sergeant York. But Alvin C. York was never changed by the war like Tone.

wounded in battle clay heals in a hospital with Gladys George looking for him. Tracy goes to WOLL to visit his buddy and he and George get things going. Later, when Tracy is reported missing, Tone and George marry. Tracy is broken when he comes back and finds out about the marriage, but he walks step by step.

The rest of the movie is about Tone, who uses the martial skills he has learned in gangster trading. He's a killer now and George does not really know what he's doing professionally. I think you can do the rest.

The part of the film that troubled me is that I can not believe that Gladys George could not figure it out. She is a street smart girl, her part is very similar to the one she played in the Roaring Twenties opposite James Cagney.

Speaking of The Roaring Twenties, Humphrey Bogart's character development is similar to Tone, although he was not the central character of the film. In fact, there are elements of They Gave Him A Gun that can be found in Taxi Driver and in Clint Eastwood's classic The Unforgiven.

The fighting sequences of the First World War are very well staged by director Woody Van Dyke. For some reason, Leonard Maltin shot this movie, I think it's much better than he let it be.

summary: A film about struggling to deal with paralysis. Author Joel Garcia breaks his neck while hiking, and finds himself in a rehabilitation centre with Raymond, an exaggerating ladies' man, and Bloss, a racist biker. Considerable tension builds as each character tries to deal with his new found handicap and the problems that go with it, especially Joel, whose lover Anna is having as difficult a time as he is. As Raymond reveals a dream about dancing on the surface of a lake to stay afloat, it becomes apparent that each of them must find his own Waterdance to survive his tragedy.
translation:
_Waterdance_ artistically examines a variety of aspects of the life of the spinal injured. From the small torments of flawed fluorescent lamps to sexuality, masculinity and depression, the experience of disability is revealed.

The diversity of the central characters themselves underlines the complexity of the material studied - Joel, the writer Raymond, the black man with a grim past, and Bloss, the racist biker. First, these men are united by nothing but the nature of their injuries, but retain their competitive spirit. Over time, shared experiences, both good and bad, brings them together as friends to support each other.

Most obvious of the changes is that experienced by Joel, who initially distances himself from his fellow patients with sunglasses, headphones and curtains. When he comes to accept the changes that disability has made in his life, Joel throws these props and begins the battles of the men with whom he shares the church.

The dance in The Title is a reference to this daily struggle to keep your head above water; giving up dancing means rejecting life. _Waterdance_ is a moving and powerful film on many levels, and I do not hesitate to recommend it.

summary: Godard's documentation of late 1960s Western counter-culture, examining the Black Panthers, referring to works by LeRoi Jones and Eldridge Cleaver. Other notable subjects are the role of news media, the mediated image, a growing technocratic society, women's liberation, the May revolt in France and the power of language. Cutting between three major scenes, including the Rolling Stones in the studio, the film is visually intercut with Eve Democracy (Wiazemsky) using graffiti which amalgamates organisations, corporations and ideologies. Godard also examines the role of the revolutionary within Western culture. Although he believes Western culture needs to be destroyed, it can only be done so by the rejection of intellectualisation. "There is only one way to be an intellectual revolutionary, and that is to give up being an intellectual"
translation:
The film school intellect can do anything they want about the important (imaginary) meaning of this movie, but it's just that: intellectual drool. This movie is bankrupt creatively, and some confuse it with endless, indulgent wanking as a substance. Yes.

Obviously Godard was not a Stones fan. Too bad, because that could have been great. He catches the birth of this timeless song and instead chooses the music with a guy reading from a True Detective mag or crap.

Then there are the endless shots of something that looks like the 1960s librarians painting words on people's cars. And then there's the seemingly never-ending "interview" in which the actress was brilliantly instructed to answer only yes or no to all the really deep and intellectual questions. There's a guy in a purple suit reading more crap out of a book that lasts for, oh, only about 20 minutes. And black panthers or something on a junkyard.

It sounds almost fascinating?

But for unwashed movie school hipsters who do not care about the lost opportunities to have full access to the Stones, Sympathy for the Devil brings to the world and would rather hear something English guy, instead read while staring at the covers of Nudie Mags, this movie is a real winner!

summary: "The Straight Story" chronicles a trip made by 73-year-old Alvin Straight from Laurens, Iowa, to Mt. Zion, Wis., in 1994 while riding a lawn mower. The man undertook his strange journey to mend his relationship with his ill, estranged, 75-year-old brother Lyle.

MULHOLLAND DRIVE has made me a definite fan of David Lynch. He is a modern genius because he is not just a filmmaker. His stories and style have a spell that crosses the screen. So THE STRAIGHT STORY was a surprise to me, with its easy-to-follow storyline and sunny sets. Even so, Lynch is here, and while that may not be his best, it's a movie that should not be missed. Late Richard Farnsworth performance is one of the reasons.

8/10

summary: Dublin, 1920. Gypo Nolan, strong but none too bright, has been ousted from the rebel organization and is starving. When he finds that his equally destitute sweetheart Katie has been reduced to prostitution, he succumbs to temptation and betrays his former comrade Frankie to the British authorities for a 20 pound reward. In the course of one gloomy, foggy night, guilt and retribution inexorably close in...
translation:
I have no doubt that Victor McLaglen won his Oscar for Best Actor for this film because he split three times among the bounties of Clark Gable, Charles Laughton and Franchot Tone. But The Informer is still a good movie because John Ford would not have gotten his first Oscar for Best Director if it had not been for him. No division into his award.

The film and story of Liam O'Flaherty on which he is based includes a poor fool from a man named Gypo Nolan, who was once a member of the Irish Republican Army. He was taken out of the register for a moronic trick he had to pull and get back. He's on his last penny and if he can not come back, he wants enough for the passage to America. There is a reward of twenty pounds for information leading to the arrest of a former comrade named Frankie McPhillip, played by Wallace Ford. In a moment of weakness, he goes to the Black and Tan Gendarmerie and informs about McPhillip.

The IRA is eager to find out who beat McPhillip and they are pretty sure it was McLaglen. He does not have the joke to really cover his own tracks. He makes a faint effort to involve another man named Peter Mulligan, played by Donald Meek. He also picks up a hanger made by J.M. Kerrigan is played.

The whole act of informer takes place in Dublin in 1922 from about six in the evening to the next morning. A necessity shoots it in the dark and shadow, perhaps making it the first noir thriller. If it had been done after the Second World War, the Informer could have been considered a great Noir classic, like Odd Man Out or The Third Man, which is very similar.

John Ford knew this world very well. He took a break during the rebellion and was in Ireland at the time and had a brother who was in the IRA. His real name before he became anglicised was Sean O'Fiernan.

Preston Foster plays IRA commander Dan Gallagher. In the book, Gallagher is a harder and meaner man than Foster has him here. I suspect that John Ford wanted him as a sympathetic character to arouse the movie fans an interest. He makes it clear that Foster will have to eliminate the informer because the Black and Tans will grab him and get a little bit more out of him and endanger the whole organization.

The IRA Trials Scene is the highlight of the film. When Foster asks Donald Meek if he recognizes the authority of her court, Meek is unable to say no. The justice and the jurisdiction of the king do not run here. It shows clearly that the British, despite occupation by army troops and gendarmerie, in fact lose their influence on the population.

Of course, The Informer has a rather bleak story, but has fewer John Ford touches than you would expect. Even as McLaglen spends his money on a drunken lane, the IRA is constantly in the shadows watching every penny.

The Informer is a story told in a grim and bleak time about Ireland.

summary: Behind these bars lies an unbridled fury. Caged Terror-a tale of madness, infidelity and revenge. Richard and Janet, a city couple, find that just the opposite is true as their weekend getaway is transformed into a frightening and primitive wilderness. Camping for the night in a seemingly abandoned farmhouse, the two are suddenly joined by strangers who have been secretly watching them all afternoon. Strangers who will soon cage Richard like a trapped animal and ravage his wife. Strangers who will drive Richard berserk in the cold and inhuman isolation of Caged Terror.

summary: In long flashbacks, David Owen looks back to when he lived in Manhattan with his wife and baby. The unnecessary noises of the city interrupt his life to the point that he takes a baseball bat to the windshield of cars whose alarms are blaring. After a few arrests, his wife kicks him out. On his own, he learns to avoid arrest and leaves a calling card as "The Rectifier" when he breaks into an offending car. Gruska, an enterprising young reporter, tracks him down. He tells her his story, they become lovers, and she organizes a petition drive for a ballot initiative to ban car alarms. The mayor becomes the Rectifier's b√™te noire. Can David fight City Hall and win?

summary: A cross-dressing mental patient escapes from an asylum and robs a bank. The money is soon stolen from him, and he embarks on a killing spree in an attempt to retrieve it.
translation:
Ed Wood fans are primarily an obsessive bunch, but this movie has driven me to a fan base I've never seen before! One of the most intense thrills of non-mainstream movie flattery - at least as far as I'm concerned - is the pleasure of discovering the dark. I remember that as a teenager, I wanted to see Eddie's "Revenge of the Dead" (the "Night of the Ghouls"), which had been in the vault for a few decades at the time. Likewise, such arcane masterpieces of low budget filmmaking as Doris Wishman's "A Night to Dismember" or half of the works of Jesus Franco! In the last few years video and DVD have made these once incomprehensible treasures almost accessible - even to those of us on the "wrong" (!) Side of the Atlantic ....

And then, see, there was "I woke up early in the day when I died" - a movie that was supposed to be SO, but disappeared into the air even before Fangoria printed the first rather long article about it, which first made me hungry. The 1990s NEEDED a hard-to-find movie that would REALLY pay off. And that 's for sure ... I do not want to add too many comments to all these wonderful aspects of the film - its classic yet kitschy cast, its haunting but often hallucinogenic images, its wondrous moments of "pure cinema" (in the sense of the French cineastes of the 1920s) and surrealism or even his most memorable soundtrack - because all this eloquently described by other users here.

What I would like to briefly mention is the joy that I have received by finding certain obscure artifacts relating to this almost-lost-to-us - but - thank goodness - not very movie! I think the German video I recorded on a cold, fresh winter day in Cologne is pretty well known by Ed Wood's followers. It is also common knowledge that a billboard has been published for the film. Fortunately, there is more to find !!! For one thing, there are a number of reviews from the film's German THEATRICAL release - I've used several of them in my translation classes to "reify" my students ... some of these critiques are positive eulogies on the film's artistry and entertainment value - and Most interesting of all, most critics have placed it directly in the American Trash and European Arthouse traditions. Secondly, there is the score of Larry Groupe ', which can be purchased by the man himself - many of the tracks exert a truly emotional attraction on the listener, especially considering the current "arched" status of the movie and becoming a little melancholy same time. Finally, for the time being, I would like to mention Promo SOUNDTRACK, which released Cinequanon in extremely limited numbers. BEG, BORROW, STEAL, KILL or do whatever it takes when you get the chance to buy one !!!!!! It contains 14 pieces from the film, including Eartha Kitts Ballad, Darcy Clay's "Jesus I Was Evil" (two versions are also available on New Zealand CD, though that's another story!), The cool radio music to which Christina Ricci dances, and also these fantastic techno-drops by Minty and ZHV (the latter is Billy Z's own techno band) .....

Become obsessed - let Ed Wood rule your life.

summary: The career of a Nazi officer shown as flashbacks from his trial as a war criminal.
translation:
The only reason I give this movie an 8 out of 10 is that, in my opinion, there are few films that are perfect. This little B picture is an exciting story, well told. Alexander Knox has always fascinated me, but I have only seen him a few films. Here he plays Wilhelm Grimm, a sad little man who turns into a monster. He betrays everything and everyone without remorse. The performance is one of the coolest performances I've ever seen. Since World War II, actors who play Nazi or other evil-type films have occasionally been nominated for Oscars. I imagine the Academy, being made during the war, felt as if it were honoring a performance as if it were honoring evil. But this kind of accomplishment brings Knox in - a man so bitter and consumed with guilt that he does not care to make others suffer. I still can not get over it.

Marsha Hunt, who normally plays the Filbert gallows or the social butterfly, will probably be against the type in probably the best performance I've ever seen. Maybe not Oscar-worthy, but the best of her career. Nothing against her; I enjoyed them in those "small" roles she has often played. But here she proves that she is up to the task of heavier drama.

If you love human drama stories or stories about the fate of those who suffered from the Nazis, I recommend this fine little movie.

summary: The Muppets graduate from college and decide to take their senior revue on the road. They hit the streets of Manhattan trying to sell their show to producers, finally finding one young and idealistic enough to take their show. After several mishaps and much confusion, things begin to come together for them.
translation: But if you like the Muppets, I defy you for not liking them. Basically the same act regurgited (this time New York, not LA) it offers a lot of fun cameos and Muppet Hi-Jinx. Many of the Muppets leave the film pretty early as it's about Kermy and Miss Piggy. I just happened to enjoy it. Fun to see with your kids.

summary: Writer/Director Alex Ferrari and writer/producer Jorge F. Rodriguez, a filmmaking duo that hails straight from Hollywood - Hollywood, Fla., that is - recently joined the wave of ultra-low-budget proto-Spielbergs with their revolutionary short film Broken, an action/sci-fi piece complete with explosions, automatic weapons, and a stylish, neo-noir look that isn't all that far removed from its main stylistic inspiration, the Matrix trilogy. This making-of documentary for the short film BROKEN (2005). It is extremely informative clocking in at almost three hours. We are presented with interviews with the director, cast members and special effects artists, who give their insights into the efforts that were needed to bring this $8000 project to completion.
translation:
As a low-budget company, where the filmmakers themselves produce and distribute the DVDs, perhaps we should not expect too much from the broken-in-disc form. And most notable of all this achievement is the fact that this release has enough extras to spot a James Cameron DVD and a very nice presentation.

With regard to the latter, the only big mistake is that Broken comes with a non-anamorphic transmission. Otherwise, we get the movie in its original ratio of 1.85: 1, show no technical flaws and look like you should expect. Considering the fact that Ferrari reaches out when assembling this disc, one can actually guarantee such a fact.

The same goes for the soundtrack. Both DD2.0 and DD5.1 ‚Äã‚Äãmixes are offered here, and while I'm unsure what should be considered "original", the fact that Ferrari was involved in both things should not be considered inferior. In fact, although the DD5.1 ‚Äã‚Äãoffer more atmosphere viewing experience due to the way in which it uses the score, both are equally good and free of technical defects.

As for extras, the disc is positively overwhelmed by them. Look at the sidebar on the right side of the screen and you'll notice lots of comments, lots of featurettes and different galleries. Given the way in which everything has been broken up into tiny pieces and not put together for a long documentary, there is really little to discuss. For example, the "Anatomy of a Stunt" motive is exactly what it claims to be, and the same goes for the rest of the pieces. As such, we receive coverage of just about every aspect of pre-production, production and post-production of Broken. And while it might have been preferable to find them in a more digestible "making of", we have easy access to everything we desire.

Of the different pieces, maybe it's just the comments that need some kind of discussion. On the other hand, there is also predictable air for each of the chat tracks. The one with the actors is overly joking and does not take the movie too seriously. Ferrari's pieces are unbelievably enthusiastic about the whole thing. And the technical ones are, well, extremely technical. Of course, we also get some crossover with what has been discussed elsewhere on the discs, but in just 19 minutes, all these pieces are no longer welcome. All in all, a nice extras package.

summary: A young boy is possessed by the spirit of an Indian medicine man and begins to terrorize the local population.
translation: My grandmother bought me this movie when I was 5 (I always love scary movies) and even then I enjoyed it. The atmosphere is fantastic and the story original and entertaining. I especially like the scenes in which the RV is attacked in the desert. The Rocks are indeed convincing for such a low budget strip. The drama is above average for these types of films and the music is scary. This is definitely a jewel of jewels. I recommend it to anyone who likes these strange movies from the late seventies, early eighties, like "Alice, Sweet Alice", "Poorly Pretty Eddie", "Nightmare", "Hospital Massacre" and "Return of the Aliens, the Deadly Spawning" , Definitely a classic !!

summary: Bohemian Alex Morrison has just finished directing his first feature length movie. In its previews, the movie is considered a critical, artistic and surefire commercial success. As such, Alex seemingly has his choice of what his next project will be. Alex has a few thoughts in his mind, such as a biopic of Lenny Bruce, or a movie about a black uprising in Los Angeles. As he makes the rounds both in the Hollywood community and European movie centers for ideas, he fantasizes about movie scenarios of those everyday situations he is in. These fantasies are influenced by his movie idols, some who he meets such as Italian director Federico Fellini and French actress Jeanne Moreau. Concurrently, he is considering what to do about his personal life. He, his wife Beth and their two daughters live a middle class lifestyle. He is wondering whether it makes sense to "move up", which means that movie making not only has to achieve his main purpose of saying something meaningful, but also has to be...
translation:
As expected, a Mazursky film shot in the '70s would be counterculture, sympathetic to the hippies - and has many hippies - and of course childishly anti-authoritarian (eg, the Mexican scene) border when Sutherland provokes a customs officer by he shows little respect and then accuses the last of letting him just open his luggage because he (Sutherland) has long hair). The constant left-dribbling could have annoyed me if I had not been prepared for it before; Sutherland greets his family and friends about possible filming ideas for his next film, and most of these ideas are about either blacks or Indians (of course he would be greeted with open arms in today's Hollywood). One of his movie ideas is about a black uprising in Beverly Hills - sort of a racial war in the middle of L.A. This is the kind of nonsense Mazursky thinks when writing scripts for his films. Fortunately, some of Sutherland's hippie friends make fun of this premise of the Black Revolution, and the resulting dialogue is not bad; A little later, the Jew argues over Sutherland as he makes a movie about "masturbation and the black problem" as he talks about masturbation. Another funny moment is when Sutherland's older daughter with her white schoolmates plays a PC crap on stage and they all say, "We, the Blacks of the Republic of South Africa ...".

There's always a certain amount of lawlessness when Hollywood shoots a movie about Hollywood - especially when Hollywood shoots a movie about Hollywood discussing movies in Hollywood. Well, that's really very, very forgiving. The scene with Fellini (playing herself) is more amusing than annoying. Mazursky throws in the usual flower children and anti-Vietnam crap and makes fun of corporate Hollywood, but he's also part of the "Phony Hollywood" (lyrics in the surreal war) segment like any other; I'm pretty sure he's doing the wrong little talk at Beverly Hills parties and grinning badly as he shakes hands with people he either does not know or likes, but does not want the money for his next (left) project) , As for his hair, he has the worst hair I've seen in a long time (on film or elsewhere); It's kind of like the kind of long hair a middle aged accountant would have if he grew it long. The film remains relatively interesting despite its aimlessness, but somewhat boring in the last third. If you would like to read my parody / biography of Donald Sutherland (and other Hollywood actors), contact me via email.

summary: A con-man and a wannabe professional magician team up with a waitress and an old professional on their way to Vegas.

summary: Two American tourists on a romantic camping trip are brutally murdered. A few days later, during the ancient festival of Samhain, a group of American university students moves into a beautiful cottage, surrounded by a lush forest and a majestic lake They are here to learn about the rituals of the ancient Druids and other Celtic legends. But in the remains of an abandoned copper mine, lives the ancestors of an incestuous clan of cannibals. Stalked by a hulking, disfigured mutant, the students and their chaperone are in for the most harrowing time of their young lives. And keeping their heads on their necks will become their main concern...

summary: In 1918 in World War I, in the Meuse-Argonne Sector in France, the former New York lawyer and Major Charles White Whittlesey is assigned by Gen. Robert Alexander to a massive suicidal attack against the German forces in the Argonne Forest with his five-hundred-man battalion. However, the forces supposed to be giving support through the flanks retreat and the communications with the headquarter of the 77th American Division are cut. Major Wittlesey holds his position with his men, mostly Irish, Polish, Italian and Jewish immigrants from New York, surrounded by the German army. Without food, water, ammunition and medical supplies, only two hundred men survive after five days of siege.
translation:
When this film was first shown on television, I had high hopes that we would finally have a decent movie about World War I, as experienced by American soldiers. That's not it.

It should be a good movie about the First World War. Although it was made for television, it is obvious that a real effort has been made to use appropriate equipment and props. But the writing and the direction are missing very much, even if the makers of this film obviously borrowed from some well-made war films. War movie stereotypes abound, like the arrogant general who apparently does not care about the lives of his men. When will Hollywood realize that although there were many bad generals, most of the combat unit's generals themselves have seen much fighting and are not naive about what the average grunt experiences? The first part of this movie seemed to be "Paths of Glory" with American uniforms. Except that "Paths of Glory" was emotionally enthralling. Later there was Chamberlain's accusation (except uphill) of "Gettysburg" and even the capture of the American soldier by a ring of enemy soldiers from "The Thin Red Line". But in "The Thin Red Line" the soldier was alone trapped. In this film, in the middle of a battle, a ring is formed around the new prisoner.

If this movie uses a military advisor, ignore it. Although the actors (and I never forgot they were actors while watching) formed military tactics, I did not see much of it. The American soldiers got up to be shot while the Germans attacked. And the notorious stormtroopers, who seemed to be blind, did not seem to use tactics in their attack. In real war tactics was what made the stormtroopers so effective. But the dumbest scene was the attack of German flamethrowers. In this scene, the German flamethrower in a broad line towards the defending Americans. If that had been real, they would never have come close enough to use their flamethrowers before they were all thrown off the defenders' bullets.

Okay, most war movies are unrealistic when it comes to tactics. But it is still disappointing. But what really distracted me from this streak was the typical anti-military point of view that filmmakers consider important. True, war is hell. But most American soldiers, though they grumble and complain, tend to believe in what they do and can be pretty coddled about it. My grandfather served in the First World War. And although he died four years before my birth, I was told how proud he was of his service.

summary: Tough guy Thomas Beckett is a US Marine working in the Panamanian jungle. His job is to seek out rebels and remove them using his sniper skills. Beckett is notorious for losing his partners on such missions. This time he's accompanied by crack marksman Richard Miller, who's more of an office-type. Together they plan to seek out an important rebel leader, whilst avoiding a rogue marksman who frequents this part of the jungle.
translation:
Sunday would not be Sunday without an action movie, and if you want intense fighting, contact Tom Berenger (Platoon).

Here he plays a sniper in the jungle, chasing after rebels and drug lords. Life is a slut, so he gets a green office type (Billy Zane) to help with the mission.

The film is in the hands of Luis Llosa, who has incited Anaconda. he does not do much better here, but Berenger makes the movie worthwhile.

Sure, it may be a bit long - who wants to see a lot going through the jungle, but is good, tense action when the time is right.

summary: A husband picks up a job as a janitor at an insane asylum scheming all the time to be close to and free his wife from the institution where she recently attempted suicide. A score was added when in 1970 the reels were unearthed after they were considered lost for decades. The director approved and subsequently repudiated this version.
translation:
An old man works as a janitor in a psychiatric ward to be near his wife, who is patient and tries to get her out.

This is certainly one of the most forgotten silent era masterpieces and a curiosity in the history of Japanese cinema. Long thoughts lost, a print was found in the 70s and a music soundtrack was added, which fits perfectly with the pictures. It might have been affected by the Cabinet of Doctor Caligary (director Kinugasa claimed that he never saw the German movie). However, it surpasses it stylistically and in its more convincing (and cooler) portrayal of the inner state of mind of inmates in asylum. To achieve this, the film uses every single film technique available at the time: multiple exposures and blurred subjective viewing angles, tilted camera angles, fast and slow movements, expressionistic lighting, and overlaying among others. It's also a very complicated movie to follow as it has no subtitles.

The film begins with a montage of rain shells hitting the windows of the hospital, wind shaking trees and thunder. The disturbing weather metaphorizes the mental state of the patients and introduces one of them: a former dancer. The combination of sounds produced by rain, wind and thunder serves as music that causes the dancer to enter into a hectic, almost hypnotic dance. In another sequence, in which the same patient plays another raging dance, she is watched by other inmates. Multiple exposures of the dancer represent the patient's perspective and their confused "view" on the world. These are just two examples from this amazing movie that seeks to portray the subconscious and the patient's view of the "healthy" world.

You have to see in three words.

summary: Seven of today's top scientist/researchers are the subject of this humourous exploration of real people behind the white lab coats; more about what makes the tick than what they have per-se accomplished. Chosen because the subjects are the very best in their particular fields, featured are Gertrude Elion, Ashok Gadgil, Michio Kaku, Maja Materic, Steven Pinker, Karol Sikora and Patricia C. Wright.
translation:
I thought the movie was a bad documentary. Nothing of substance was discussed. It seemed to cheapen the ideas and provided nothing new. The film lacked the miracle or the romance or anything that would really make you science. Most scientists appeared "stereotypical" and sometimes weird. One woman said that her prices did not mean much, only children who were helped. She said that after a 10-minute scene explaining all her awards. "Humble scientist" play, are we? "I have equations dancing in my head," said another. I do not see how that explains something to us. Significant effects of science on our culture have not been addressed. Politics of science was barely touched.

No bad movie for 10-14 year olds. Apart from that, I felt that it was boring and not decrypted.

4/10

summary: Colonel Pepper brings his daughter, Peggy, to Hollywood from Georgia to be an actress. There she meets Billy who gets her work at Comet Studio doing comedies with him. But Peggy is discovered by High Art Studio and she leaves Billy and Comet to work there. For her new image, she is now Patricia Pepoire and ignores Billy when he sees her on location. When she is not longer wanted by the little people who do not understand "ART", she plans to marry Andre to get a fake title. Billy will not let her go without a fight.
translation:
There are some wonderful things about this movie. Marion Davies could trade with the right property; She is wonderful in comedic roles. William Haines could act, and you can see why he was one of the most popular men on the screen. (Until a potential scandal forces him out of business).

The story is a bit hackneyed, but so nicely done that you do not realize it. King Vidor's direction is one of the main reasons for that. The producer? The young genius, Irving Thalberg.

It's about filmmaking, and you can see the process of making it in 1928, the cameras, stage sets, directors, directors, and actors who worked hard. You see (briefly) some of the main stars of the day; Even Charlie Chaplin is doing a lap like himself, looking for an autograph. You'll also see Eleanor Boardman, Elinor Glyn, Claire Windsor, King Vidor and many others that are otherwise just names and old photographs.

Please, even if you are not a fan of silent films Take the time to see this movie if you can. It is really a great journey into the past.

summary: Erik, and Cooze start college and pledge the Beta House fraternity, presided over by none other than legendary Dwight Stifler. But chaos ensues when a fraternity of geeks threatens to stop the debauchery and the Betas have to make a stand for their right to party.
translation:
* First, although many say it's the worst of the series, I do not think it's true, this one consideration ideally reflects the 21st century teen mentality .it brings perfect opportunities to laugh and remind you of good teenage times in which you have the same fun as the characters have, like doing.

* In the end, I believe that if you're a teenager, you must necessarily watch the movie, and even if you have one really adult man or woman, you should see it if you still have a teen mind or you often think about how it was a teenager or something. Thank you for reading!

summary: Cinderella, the beautiful and kind-hearted daughter, sees her world turn upside down when her beloved mother dies, and her pained father remarries another woman, the wicked Lady Tremaine, who has two equally cruel daughters, the jealous Anastasia and Drizella. But, once more, things will go from bad to worse, when Cinderella's father, too, dies, leaving her all alone in the Lady's clutches to serve as her maid-of-all-work. Under those circumstances, a shabby and neglected Cinderella doesn't stand much of a chance of attending the King's royal ball--let alone, captivate the handsome Prince--unless she turns to her loving Fairy Godmother who has quite a few tricks up her sleeve. Nevertheless, will the wronged damsel ever find peace--and with it--her own Prince Charming?
translation: I do not think I have to tell you the story. Because it has been told for years and years. So I will just share my feelings. I saw Cinderella for the first time when I was five years old. From then on, I was a Disney kid in a good way. The animation is now childish and old-fashioned, but that's part of their charm now. Now, in times of high school musical and computer-generated imagery, it seems people have forgotten the genius and magical essence of early Disney movies. Luckily, I was born before, so I became familiar with this classic. And it seems, no matter how old I am, I'll go back to this five-year-old watching it on VHS. Which is the true magic of Disney?

summary: A series of comedic short films guaranteed to offend.

Okay, now go to The Underground Comedy Movie. That vision you just had seems to be the funniest thing ever. UCM is the worst movie I have ever seen. There were a few cheap laughs ... very few. But it was lame. Even if the intention of the film was to be lame, it was too lame to be funny.

The only reason I'm not angry because I wasted my time was someone else I know. He wasted his money. Vince Offer has not written or directed anything yet and it's no surprise then why.

summary: This unique short film follows the night of a young British insomniac named Jack, narrated almost hour by hour from a first hand perspective. translation: I rate that as ten just because I find it so impressive what an 18-year-old can do with a video camera. It's not epic, but it's very engaging and never got boring. If tens of millions of dollars can go into the countless bad movies that are poured out in bulk, then give this director the same amount of money and see what happens. I know that I will be queuing for their first big release in the local cinema. Damn good job and worth the money. What a script! It may be a low budget, but it beats half of the big pictures I've seen lately. Nanavati knows how to tell a story, both in writing and on screen. Serious kudos to her, can not wait to see more.

summary: Paulie, an intelligent parrot who actually talks, relates the story of his struggle to a Russian immigrant who works as a janitor at the research institute where he is housed and neglected. Paulies story begins many years earlier when he is given as a gift to a little girl who stutters. Eventually, he teaches the girl to speak correctly but is taken away by her father because he believes the girl cannot distinguish fantasy from reality because she believes the bird can talk. Paulie goes through a series of adventures with a pawn shop owner, an ageing widow, a Mexican-American troubadour and a would be thief before being taken to the institute where he now lives.
translation: I do not know who in a simple human and funny movie like this has many pleasures for your heart. I enjoyed every minute of it and guessed the end of the movie - but that did not disappoint me at all. It will not only touch your heart, but it is such a good family friendly movie - we need a lot more like this!

summary: Dublin, 1920. Gypo Nolan, strong but none too bright, has been ousted from the rebel organization and is starving. When he finds that his equally destitute sweetheart Katie has been reduced to prostitution, he succumbs to temptation and betrays his former comrade Frankie to the British authorities for a 20 pound reward. In the course of one gloomy, foggy night, guilt and retribution inexorably close in...
translation: This film is about the Irish rebellion in the 1920s and, more specifically, the life of a man after he informs a friend about the bounty premium and the consequent consequences. When I saw the movie, I felt that the script could be taken and with a few minor updates, again, and unfortunately it would still fit in with contemporary events. But the remake would not be nearly as good. A great performance by Victor McLaglen (for which he rightly won an Academy Award) and a stellar ensemble cast that includes most, if not all, actors with brogues in Hollywood at the time, are most of them recognizable character actor, then or straight were founded starting. A very good movie, worth seeing. Highly recommended.

summary: In 1947, in New Mexico, a radio operator receives a signal following regular patterns. While investigating the occurrence, he vanishes. In the present day, the same signal is transmitted from a base in the Falkland Islands to United States of America and a satellite captures images of a unknown object in Antartic. The cryptologist Julien Rome (James Spader) is invited to investigate the mystery in the South Pole and he flies to a research base. While a team tries to open a weird shell probably from the outer space, Julien solves the message, which proves to be a distress signal ordering not to open the case.
translation: I'm so happy that I did not spend any money to go to the cinema :-). It is nothing more than a compilation of elements from some of the other classic titles like The Thing, Final Fantasy, The Abyss, etc., which are framed in a rather dull and meaningless scenario. I really can not figure out what the purpose of this movie is - it has absolutely nothing new to offer in its history, which is also pointless. And there's nothing to see - the FX'es look like they're from a second-hand store, usually seen in other movies. But it's definitely a good lullaby.

summary: A hapless Navy grunt is assigned SP duty. The catch: he must escort a beautiful female prisoner on her way to prison for going UA. She in turn will try anything to escape.

summary: Hard drinking, burnt out ex CIA operative John Creasy has given up on life until he's hired as a bodyguard to protect nine year old Pita Ramos. Bit by bit, Creasy begins to reclaim some of his soul, but when pita is kidnapped, Creasy's fiery rage is finally released and he will stop at nothing to save her as he sets out on a dangerous, revenge fuelled rescue mission.
translation:
This must be one of the best, if not the best, movie I've seen in a very, very long time. Had enough action to satisfy a fan, and yet the plot was very good. Rent this movie, buy this movie, go out and watch this movie. You will not be disappointed.

summary: Meg and Charles Wallace are aided by Calvin and three interesting women, Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit, and Mrs. Who in the search for their father who disappeared during an experiment he was working on for the government. I read the whole book "A Fold in Time" and then saw the movie. The movie contained all the elements of the book, but since the book was 190 pages long and the movie was 2 hours long, it really felt crammed with too many effects and bad drama.

summary: When two friends, Lexi and Jennifer try and get in shape, they start to get rid of their food by vomiting it up. Lexi is then taken to a bulemic center by her worried mom. When she recovers she tells her mom that Jennifer might still have the same problem. Lexi's mom confronts Jennifer's mom and Jennifer get mad at Lexi. Lexi tries to reason to Jennifer at a beach party while Jennifer is drunk and Jennifer refuses and runs away from her. She is then hit by a passing car and Lexi becomes depressed and the vomiting starts again.
translation: I've seen some movies about eating disorders, but this one was definitely my favorite food. The problem with the others was that people with eating disorders are automatically getting better towards the end, or accepting that they need help, and so it is. This movie, which I thought was more realistic, because in this movie, the main character Lexi is not automatically better. It gets better and then has a disadvantage. I think this movie shows more than the others that I've seen, that recovery does not just happen, it's hard work and takes time, it's a long road to recovery. I think this movie shows it all very well. There should be more films like this.

summary: William and Emma Peters buy an old house where a brutal murder happened years ago in very bad condition with the intention of restoring it. They move with their daughter Sophie, and become friends of their neighbors Jean and George Evans. However, eerie events happen in the house, inclusive the death of Sophie's cat. In Sophie's birthday party, a pipe leaks blood and they leave the place, disclosing a secret later.
translation:
William (Nicholas Ball) and Emma Peters (Rachel Davies) buy an old house that was brutally murdered years ago with the intention of restoring it. They move with their daughter Sophie (Emma RidleY) and become friends of their neighbors Jean (Patricia Maynard) and George Evans (Brian Croucher). However, there are some weird events in the house, including the death of Sophie's cat. In Sophie's birthday party, a pipe licks blood and they leave the place and reveal a secret later.

"The house that bleeds to death" is a sinister and one of the best episodes of the series "Hammer Haus des Grauens". The fantastic twist that reveals a secret and the tragic conclusion are really excellent. My voice is eight.

summary: Arthur is a happy drunk with no pretensions at any ambition. He is also the heir to a vast fortune which he is told will only be his if he marries Susan. He does not love Susan, but she will make something of him the family expects. Arthur proposes but then meets a girl with no money who he could easily fall in love with.
translation: As a drunk millionaire playboy Arthur Bach, Dudley Moore is perfectly captured as a grown man in childhood. As it turned out, the role of Moore was so perfect that she kept him captive as an actor. Many disappointments soon followed (including the pale episode of this film), but that does not diminish the charm or appeal of this image, which is cleverly written and directed. Some of Moore's drunken scenes are forced, parts of the film are shaky, but the cast plays with so much enjoyment that it's a difficult movie to resist. It has a very big heart and gives Academy Award winner John Gielgud a sly, dry amusing role as Arthur's servant, Hobson; his relationship with Arthur is delicious and they have a wondrous relationship. Liza Minnelli (as a lover of love) is naughty in a discreet and Moore is cheeky, but skillful and lively; He has never shaken off the shadow of Arthur, but at least we appreciate this document of a career climax. *** from ****

summary: Single father Dan Burns dedicates his life to his children, but one day he meets Marie at a bookstore. They get to know each other, but then Dan finds out that Marie is actually dating his brother, Mitch.
translation:
The most satisfying element about "Dan in Real Life" is that the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche) is meaningful and beautifully realistic. The cast of Oscar winner Juliette Binoche as Dan's love interest was an excellent choice; She is exceptionally talented, intelligent, naturally attractive and, thank God, aged accordingly! Had this movie been shot with Jessica Alba or Scarlett Johansson, that would have been a disaster.

Another wonderful aspect of "Dan in Real Life" is that it's a perfect movie for adults interested in a mature comedy that omits the three pillars of the "frat pack" formula: stupid girls, chauvinist types and greasy jokes. "Dan in Real Life" is funny and has fun, smart laughs everywhere. While other comedies are based on jokes or based almost exclusively on jokes that make the audience laugh, the jokes in "Dan in Real Life" are more natural and clever, and bring with them some reflection on the part of the audience.

My only problem with "Dan in Real Life" is that actress Brittany Robertson's rebellious middle-class daughter is too rude to play. It's hard to say if this was a personal decision or a decision of the director. However, her character is unrealistic and annoying. But that's just a small mistake in the movie and does not take the story as a whole.

All in all, "Dan in Real Life" is a great movie, a fantastic escape from the redundancy of insulting and stupid comedies. The quality of writing, governing, acting and (especially) cinematography is excellent. It's just a nice, carefree comedy.

summary: Abandoning artistic ambitions, sensitive and club-footed Philip Carey enrolls in medical school and falls in love with a waitress Mildred Rogers. She rejects him, runs off with a salesman and returns unmarried and pregnant. Philip gets her an apartment and they become engaged. Mildred runs off with another medical student. Philip takes her back again when she returns with her baby. She wrecks his apartment and burns the securities he needs to pay tuition. He gets a job as a salesman, has surgery on his foot, receives an inheritance, and returns to school where he learns Mildred is dying.
translation: This movie is about sexual obsession. Bette Davis plays Mildred. This is a woman to whom men are attracted. Not because she is a beautiful, beautiful girl, but because she is a sexual entity. Now the movie does not come out and says that but it's obvious. There is a scene in the movie where men are all about them. She works as a waitress in a cafe, she can not read and she is not really someone she can look at, but she is a flirt. It is obvious that the male customers in this cafe are there for her. One day, Phillip, a failed clump-footed medical student, comes to the store to say a good word for his friend, but he gets doted as soon as he sees her. He begins to buy her things, even pays for her apartment. In the meantime, she sees other people and she makes no secrets about it. He dreams of her as if she were an angel, but she is not an angel. He keeps thinking about her. His Med school grades are even failed. So what the Nookie is too good. He wants to marry her, but she rejects him because she marries another man. She always lets Phil know that she has no feelings of love for him all the time. He is broken, but he meets another woman. They seem to be good, but it's obvious he's still dreaming of the Bimbo. Mildred returns with a baby and unmarried. Phillip picks her up, but she leaves him with a friend, the light bulb comes a little and he kicks her out. She does what she knows works, so she tries to seduce him, well, it does not work and she continues to burn his tuition. Oh, we have a clubfoot he's having trouble with, even though a teenager on the street who has the same problem tells him to make fun of it. He meets another girl named Sally, we have a montage of March time that shows her aging as he continues her and is still waiting for Mildred. Well, he has no schooling, can not find a job. Eventually, Sally and her father pick him up. Not before another assembly in March of the time that shows him the descent. Soon his uncle, who raised him, dies and he gets money to become a doctor. Meanwhile, he finds that Mildred needs him again. She has TB. In the meantime, he still leads Sally the Primrose way over the marriage and he takes a job on a steamer. Eventually the bimbo dies and Phillip declares that he is now free and will marry Sally. I wish she had told him to stuff it. Now I know that my attitude to the characters will not bring me any points. But I think Phillip was the bad guy. Yes, Mildred is a trumpet BUT he knows and he always comes back. Mean, while he has two other girlfriends who love him, but he treats as appetizers. I think the sex was not so good. But in any case, he watches over those women who wait for Mildred. Not only that, the man who gets Mildred pregnant is already married, and when Philip asks him what he wants to do with baby (apparently the baby's name), he laughs, he has no intention of supporting her and baby and he is wealthy. Sally's father, who has 9 children, says some pretty bad things about women, but he's supposed to be an old traditionalist. Even Philip does not seem to disprove his feelings. Men use Mildred as a boy's toy, but the men in this movie get away with it. Yes, she was not a respectable woman, but far from a villain. For me it's Philip who had the real problem and it was his sexual obsession for Mildred.

summary: Anthony John is an actor whose life is strongly influenced by the characters he plays. When he's playing comedy, he's the most enjoyable person in the world, but when he's playing drama, it's terrible to be around him. That's the reason why his wife Brita divorced him; although she still loves him and works with him, she couldn't stand living with him anymore. So when Anthony accepts to play Othello, he devotes himself entirely to the part, but it soon overwhelms him and with each day his mind gets filled more and more with Othello's murderous jealousy.
translation: If an actor has to play the role of an actor, fictional or factual, the task becomes much more difficult than playing a role. In A Double Life, Ronald Coleman beat himself as Anthony John, the tortured double personality. He has put all his talent and sincerity into this character. The countenance, mannerisms, gait, and attitude spoke eloquently of what Anthony John was going through as he played Othello on stage. Coleman was also very good as a Shakespearean actor in the short scenes like Othello, which were part of this movie. Collisions of Coleman's face, when Othello was tormented by doubts about Desdemona's loyalty, were scenes worth considering. In addition, his off-stage character is desperate, and only someone with Coleman's depth can achieve the acting's perceptions. It was like I was Spenser Tracy as Dr. Watching Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, except that this dual role was much deeper and more moving. Shelly Winters looked so cute, vulnerable, and gorgeous, and added her talent to the movie. It is believed that Ronald Coleman liked his role in this film above all else he played and in 1947 won the Oscar for Best Actor. I would watch this movie repeatedly and never feel bored.

summary: The American writer of horror novels Cheryl is a woman tormented by nightmares since she was a child. She rents the Trifiri Villa in Italy with her husband Tom and they travel on vacation with their son Bobby. On the arrival, Chery befriends the local Ann that offers her younger sister Maria to babysit Bobby in order to allow Cheryl and Tom to have dinner with her. Cheryl is writing her latest novel about an ogre that horrifies her since her childhood and soon she finds that all her fears are coming true. Further the house is surrounded by orchids that attract the ogre and his victims. Now Cheryl has to convince her skeptical husband that they are in dangerous and must leave the place.
translation:
(aka: DEMONS III) Made for Italian TV, although filmed in English and never thought of as a continuation of earlier DEMONS films. It was supposed to be titled THE OGRE just as director Lamberto Bava had released it.

An American family rents an Italian villa for the summer. The woman (Virginia Bryant) has recurring dreams of herself as a little girl walking down the old wine cellar of this mansion, encountering this cocoon-like structure hanging from the ceiling. It glows and is covered with cobwebs and has something that looks like spider or insect legs hanging from it. It drips what looks like green paint.

Of course, the husband does not believe in it. The villa is just old and creaky and makes strange noises in the middle of the night and she should just ignore it.

But then the OGRE itself appears in something that looks like a kind of 16th Centaury costume with what looks like a wolf's head attached to it that attracts the scent of orchids.

The films are not really that bad and at least the dialogue is reasonably intelligent without the ridiculous embarrassing phrases that would bring the synchronization. There is no real blood, except that some skeletons rot in a basement pond that really looks like the bottom of a modern swimming pool. The OGRE itself just fades after being run over by the family's Jeep Cherokee.

The copy of the Shriek DVD that I saw was broken, and the picture went black for a few seconds, about half an hour after the movie, a mistake that I hope Shriek corrected him. Extras include a quick interview with Lamberto Bava explaining how this was not a sequel, etc..etc ... along with some trailers to other Shriek DVD releases. That's pretty normal stuff.

3 of 10

summary: Hunt Stevenson works for a large car manufacturer that has just been bought out by a Japanese firm. Suddenly finding himself having to justify his own job, he's forced to choose between redundancy or the seemingly inhuman Japanese work ethic that the new owners have brought with them.
translation: Gung Ho was a good idea, but it's too much to ask the Americans viewers to understand the dynamics of American jobs and foreign competition. In this film, the main character Hunt Stevenson (Michael Keaton) goes to Japan and convinces a Japanese car company to come to America and help his dying city of Pennsylvania. Two things come to you. First, why should a Japanese company come to America to build cars when they do that, and so good at it? Second, anyone can understand that American companies of all kinds are going to Third World countries to produce their products in ways that escape American labor costs. The film then assumes that the largest manufacturer of cars in the world would go to one of its "top competitors" (next to Germany) and would call a work there as unrealistic. Keaton was still in his comedy at the time. But he still gives a credible idea, because he could prove that he can go from comedy to drama in seconds, yet still does not have to embarrass, but director Ron Howard can not stop it from becoming a TV movie Anyway, they must put a happy ending to unlikely history and not endure the politics and problems of Japanese and American relations. Gung Ho has Happy Days and Laverne and Shirley the feeling, as the producers of both TV series have made the film and then have made the TV version of this film, which gives the film its light weight. The Japanese manager will love him American workers and he feels that he and other Japanese can learn from Americans. His husband No. 2, Saito, who supposedly does not like Americans so much, does not think so. I would have preferred that all Japanese characters were like Saito, as the soft fool characters who made them Japanese. That would have made the movie more interesting.

summary: From the heights of notoriety to the depths of depravity, John Forbes Nash, Jr. experienced it all. A mathematical genius, he made an astonishing discovery early in his career and stood on the brink of international acclaim. But the handsome and arrogant Nash soon found himself on a painful and harrowing journey of self-discovery. After many years of struggle, he eventually triumphed over his tragedy, and finally - late in life - received the Nobel Prize.
translation: I really do not get all the admiration this movie has received. It is shameful, unnecessarily manipulative, and evades many of the big issues - Nash's affairs and his love of sex with men in public places. The man just seems to slip around, clutching his briefcase and wearing a grungy hat, and somehow that seems to be a good spectacle? Anyone who has ever known a person with mental health problems will realize that Crowes performance is little caricature. It's also pretty offensive. And, dare I say, just on the right side to be really awful

summary: Darcy Wagner and her ten-and-a-half-year-old daughter Pamela "Pammy" are heading to the bed and breakfast of her boyfriend Peter Campbell in the River Bend Road in Northern California. Peter has quited his career of doctor and bought an old house to have a calmer life and write a book. Meanwhile Peter welcomes his first guest, the student Stephanie "Star" Roberts, while he works with his friend Bobby Boulet repairing the house. translation:
When I saw this movie cover, I thought at first that it was made for video. The second thing that came to mind was how similar this was to another dreadful movie "Darkness Falls," the story of that stupid witch who killed people in the dark. Unfortunately, Darkness Falls was pretty much the masterpiece compared to this dump, and this movie should not have been made.

The film begins with a little backstory for the witch, or more like a pointless idea of ‚Äã‚Äãtwo young children meeting the tooth fairy in the hope that she'll give them a shiny new bike for their tooth. The opening is badly filmed and like the rest of the movie it's certainly not scary. At the present time the film is about Peter (Lochlyn Munroe). Peter rents his house, and his ex-girlfriend Darcy (Chandra West) and her daughter Cole come to stay there. Cole meets a neighbor and they talk about the tooth fairy, and how you should not lose your tooth, otherwise it comes for you. Unfortunately, seconds later it looks like the tooth fairy is stealing her bike and knocking out her tooth (how ironic). If Cole survives the tooth fairy's anger, and her mother and Peter will be able to rescue her and reignite her romance ... it's a bad movie, you could probably find out.

One of the main problems with this idiotic movie is how indefinite the tooth fairy is. They say she kills you if you lose your tooth, but no. She's more like a serial killer killing indiscriminately, and if you lose your tooth, you'll definitely go. She steals a bike, so she seems to be a thief too. I said earlier that the idea for this movie was based on Darkness Falls, but where did they get the inspiration for the appearance of the Tooth Fairy? Just take a look. She looks like a burnt offering, and she used to walk around the neighborhood kidnapping children. Hmmm ... it's almost as if she's ripping off Freddy Krueger from the "Nightmare on Elm Street" movies. And that's not the worst part of this terrible mess that is the highlight. This movie could have the most ridiculous climax (not really ridiculous because I found it more disgusting than funny) that I've ever seen. Do not see that.

Just a few things. Lochlyn Munroe was in Scary Movie, and Jianna Ballard was in Scary Movie 3, and they were both in this, so obviously Scary Movie Stars are forced to end their career with evil scary films.

My rating: 1/2 from ****. 80 minutes R for violence.

summary: This is the story of a young resourceful heroine named Lisa Reisert who hates to fly, but the terror that awaits her on the night flight to Miami has nothing to do with a fear of flying! Upon boarding the plane, Lisa is trapped on a red-eye flight with a creepy villainous handsome and charming man by the name of Jackson Rippner, who's playing middle-man in the plot to assassinate a Homeland Security official. He's got her father pinned down by a would-be killer, using that advantage to coerce Lisa into phoning the luxury resort where she works and arranging to move the target into a pre-set position.
translation: Wes Craven, you laugh ... at our expense. The Red Eye plot is absurd ... We meet a man who seems to have been watching a girl for eight weeks, then appears behind her at an airport, flirting and chatting, somehow angling next to her a seat next to her a place for two people, not caught in the middle of a five-seat row (contacts at check-in?) and is pleasantly nice during a painful slooooow buildup. Then, once in the air, in a confined space, surrounded by strangers, he immediately starts to threaten the void, if super efficient, to Rachel McAdams and say, "We have you dad, do what I say, or Poppa gets it ". Or even - because these are the movies and we need some unreal twists - keep the stupid dad-in-distress thing intact, if you must, but dress up better, keeping it in a detrimental manner until that entangled plot was completed a feeling without the aircraft dulness? Alternatively, without wanting to sound like a truly thoughtful terrorist / assassin - the massive Bazooka rocket could not be used much easier, say, a car driving down the highway with the politician inside instead of the 50 story of a hotel on the Sea in Miami, seen from a fishing boat (mind you, security in Miami is loose, so will you be faster)? I know, I know, it's much more fun to watch a pretty girl for 8 weeks, break her father's house to steal his wallet (somehow - Star Trek Style - is immediately transported from Miami to Texas) - maybe - Get them to make a politician change the hotel room, and, and ... Well, a thousand things could go wrong here, each one destroys the Big Plan, so why not reduce the elements to a reasonable handful, like - 1. Bazooka. 2nd car. 3rd boom! My 50-minute drive home from the movie theater was spent highlighting the abundance of bugs and stupid cod-hitchcock phrases, which was unfortunately the biggest fun of the whole sad experience. And as for the security at Miami Airport ... We have a seemingly crazy and violent girl running from an airplane, being chased by police while the chase is drinking coffee and going elsewhere to read a magazine in a bar again like crazy up and down in the whole terminal ... now also pursued by the crazy Cillian Murphy (so no CCTV?) - I had dropped a few years ago at the airport of Miami for 10 seconds in the wrong place). So instead of talking to the cops - their ally - or talking directly to their father in a telephone booth to warn them that his life is in danger, McAdams prefers to transport a family carrier on the airport forecourt instead You damned security ...) and drive home to dad, mow the assassin with the vehicle in the front yard of the house, in a wealthy quarterwatch district, crushing the front porch - an act that is actually light awakens dad one minute from an afternoon slumber, but somehow does not interfere with neighbors who are not even slightly curious, and so spend 15 more minutes hide and seek around the huge Hollodeck house. .. Dohhh, it really hurts to think about all this - Cillian (safely renamed Silly 'un for this one?) Turns pervertly from the ice cream killer into a weirdly emaciated (and incompetent) lunatic killer in the end, this theoretically ruthless dispatcher of human life so that the father can live so that he can watch his daughter cooking. I better stop, because the stream of dirt I'm writing here has to sound as uncoordinated as the red-eye script.
