Oleg claims to work in President Putin's administration, supplying him with bottled water and his wife with liquor; Marina passes herself off as a marketing executive; and Volodya, the infamous lead singer of the rock group Leningrad, as a geneticist who clones twins (two times two makes four, again) in a laboratory that has been engaged in these experiments since the days of Stalin. After they separate, these fantasy realities, especially Volodya's, begin to dominate their everyday lives.
translation: I agree with the previous comment, the beginning of the film is pretty good, and you'll wander around, what's coming ....... That's nothing. All open storylines remain open; two characters who initially looked as if they were significant are completely ignored, except for 1 or 2 very short scenes. I wander, if Ilya did not do it better, just leave her out ... As for the one leftover character, nothing is done to her. She's just visiting a goddamn place and suddenly the movie is not about her anymore but about geriatric witches spending their days making dolls out of bread, drinking homemade vodka and flashing each other. Some may say the film is good at crumbling a society, like the judges of the IFFR, but for me it's just bad taste, bad camera work, a lousy script and a terribly bad direction. That's why I can not be as generous as my predecessor: 1!

summary: A young Hobbit known as Frodo has been thrown on an amazing adventure, when he is appointed the job of destroying the one ring which was created by the dark lord Sauron. He is assigned with three warriors including Gandelf, Aragorn and Boromir. But it's not going to be an easy journey for the Fellowship of the Ring, on the ultimate quest to rid the Middle-Earth of all evil!
translation:
I recently rented the animated version of The Lord of the Rings on video after watching the live action version of FANTASTIC 2001. The Peter Jackson-led live action trilogy "The Lord of the Rings" will undoubtedly be much better than the "Prequel" trilogy (Episode 1-3) by George Lucas will ever be the true fantasy film series of the 21st century! >
I remember seeing the animated version as a child and not fully understanding the depth of the film at the time. Now that I've read the books, I understand what the story is all about. However, some of the characters are pretty silly (Samwise Gangee is particularly annoying, much like Jar Jar Binks in Star Wars Episode One, (AWFUL!)), But I have to say that he follows the book fairly closely, and it goes into part from Book Two, The Two Towers. The good things are that the plot is a bit interesting and some of the animations are quite remarkable for the time being. The bad part is that it ends halfway between the Two Towers, without Frodo trying to destroy the one ring, and the animation looks pretty outdated compared to today's standards.

Overall, not as bad as many say. BUT, the live action version of 2001 is the new trademark of The Lord of the Rings! At least Ralph Bakshi took the script seriously! Peter Jackson said that the animated version inspired him to read the books, which in turn made him create one of the greatest fantasy series of all time, so at least we can thank Ralph Bakshi for that! I will take the animated version of Lord of the Rings on the live version of Harry Potter!

A 7 on a scale of 1-10, far less violent than the live version of 2001, but NEVER close so good! For die-hard fans of the books and movie versions of The Lord of the Rings.

summary: Adventures of Mystery, Inc. members Shaggy and Scooby-Doo as they solve various crimes around the world with the help of inherited cash and inventions from Shaggy's missing uncle.
translation:
The first episode of this new show was today and it was awful. Not only did Shaggy have a squeaky new voice that tormented listening to his lines, but she's so far from the original concept and animation style that she's barely recognizable as a "Scooby Doo" show.

Even in the dark days when Fred and Velma were gone and Scooby's nephew Scrappy was around, the team was still puzzle-solving. Instead, this new show shows Shaggy and Scooby fighting a James Bond-type supervisor and his henchmen while living in a mansion. There's not even a transporter called "The Mystery Machine" (and the teaser for the next episode that promised a transformer-type robotic car did not reassure me). How can someone take Scooby Doo and do THIS?

The show deserves two points for two scenes with the whole Scooby Doo gang, all of them speaking in the right voice, except Shaggy, and even then I'm way too generous.

summary: Great Britain has had an international agreement for the last 50 years with a small pacific island. It has been ignored until the death of their king brings it to the attention of the Foreign Office in Whitehall. They decide to send Cadogan de Vere Carlton-Browne to re-establish friendly relations.
translation: Another comedy about a brave little country struggling through the jungles of the modern (forties) global world, with only innate wit and twitching to guide them, is a nice introduction to the Ealing cannon. Terry-Thomas shines as always at the top, as a hapless minister stood on the edge of the abyss, as a nation he allegedly directs attracts the world's attention, making Ian Bannen a major romantic advantage over one of his calmer appearances than corrupt Politician and the presumptuous John Le Mesurier plays against type as a rough revolutionary leader. Everyone has a lot of fun, especially the spectator; Maybe not in the top of the Ealing classics, but pretty high.

summary: In Paris, the shy bureaucrat Trelkovsky rents an old apartment without bathroom where the previous tenant, the Egyptologist Simone Choule, committed suicide. The unfriendly concierge (Shelley Winters) and the tough landlord Mr. Zy establish stringent rules of behavior and Trelkovsky feels ridden by his neighbors. Meanwhile he visits Simone in the hospital and befriends her girlfriend Stella. After the death of Simone, Trelkovsky feels obsessed for her and believes his landlord and neighbors are plotting a scheme to force him to also commit suicide.
translation:
I'm a pretty old guy, old enough to remember the taste of Oreos and Coke, as they were 50-55 years ago, when every taste was fresh for a kid. I wish I had set something aside, then there is a magic wall cabinet so I can taste these things today. This magical locker may even have adapted the stuff of food to take into account how I physically and otherwise drove some sort of dynamic chemistry of anticipation. Over the course of half a century, they would have had to adapt quite a bit, because they would have known that I had set them aside. To eat now would be a celebration of self and past, and history and meaning that would make the intervening years almost an expected reward.

I did not have enough sense to do that with original Coke. And I would not have invented one of those magical psychic lockers. not then. But I did something almost as good. In the seventies I really understood Roman Polanski. He was a strange and exotic pleasure ?? You know, films smuggled out of the Soviet bloc. Films that are so sensitive to beauty that you cry for weeks. Films that make you live with Polish women and then decide that they are the last ones to get it.

I did the following. I took what I knew was my favorite Polanski movie and set it aside. I did not see it. I postponed until I thought I was big enough to earn it. Over the years, I would test myself, my ability to surround and describe beauty without occupying it. There are probably only a few Poles who have worked to earn Chopin. Working to earn femininity when I see it. Try to get the inners off the edges.

Lately, I've got the certainty that it was time to get this out. I already knew that I was out of time, as that would work optimally, because I had already seen and understood "9th Gate".

If you do not know this, it is a man who is innocent rents a room in which the previous tenant (of whom the story is called) jumped out of the window to die later after visiting this man (played by Polanski). What happens is that time is folding and he becomes this woman. We are tempted to believe that he is just crazy. But as we follow him, he is not. He has only lightning that the world is normal, and that the people around him are not part of a devil who is twisting his reality.

The story hardly matters. What counts is how Polanksi shapes this thing, both in the way he inhabits the eye, which only makes edges, and in the body, which consists only of tangled flesh. The two never meet. There is a dissonance that can haunt me for the next 30 years. It is the idea about and inside and an outside without edges at all? at all except a red-haired wig.

I do not know anyone who could do that, this sketch that remains a sketch, that horror that remains natural.

To understand the geniuses of this, you must know one of the greatest movies ever made; "Rear window." The genius of this film is the post-noir idea that the camera shapes the world; that the viewer creates the story. What makes Roman is to take this movie and turn it upside down. In Rear Window, the idea that the on-screen viewer (Jimmy Stewart) was the anchor and everything else was a fiction woven as we watched. Here is the movie dweller the filmmaker. We know that. We know that everything we see is true because he is the narrator. We know that it is true that bodies change identity, that times shift, that causality is plastic. We know that the narrator will kill us. We know that the narrator will leave us in an eternal terror, on the border he subordinates, but never shows us and introduces us.

Teds rating - 4 of 3: Every Cineliter should know this.

summary: The first interplanetary cruise ship malfunctions halfway to Jupiter, forcing most of the crew and passengers to abandon ship. A handful of people are trapped onboard.
translation:
Impressive. Something of a surprise. Although flawed, it is much better that I expected.

The brand new Arcturus Space Shuttle, with around 3,000 passengers, is on its final sixteen days journey to Jupiter. Without warning, the ship's Cerebral (Central Computer) issues a Disaster Alert and orders all to evacuate.

Soon there will be only a handful of people left, including an astronaut (Penny), the captain (Cary) and the shipping company director (Kenyon).

personal conflicts in order to survive.

The movie starts very well. The opening spot is a very nice gesture. There are clear parallels to 2001: Space Odyssey and the historic sinking of the Titanic. The movie sometimes slows down and has problems, but is usually well done and well executed.

summary: In the funeral of the famous British journalist Joe Strombel, his colleagues and friends recall how obstinate he was while seeking for a scoop. Meanwhile the deceased Joe discloses the identity of the tarot card serial killer of London. He cheats the Reaper and appears to the American student of journalism Sondra Pransky, who is on the stage in the middle of a magic show of the magician Sidney Waterman in London, and tells her that the murderer is the aristocrat Peter Lyman. Sondra drags Sid in her investigation, seeking for evidences that Peter is the killer. However, she falls in love with him and questions if Joe Strombel is right in his scoop.
translation:
They're not lamenting journalists Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell of "His Girl Friday" or witty detective William Powell and cheeky lady Myrna Loy of Thin Man, but Woody Allen and Scarlett Johansson are surprisingly charming as amateur snoopers in Scoop. Her republican screwball is postmodern rather than post-post-depressive, Allen's writings full of ironic self-irony and ordinary New York anxiety. Shades of the old joke are rare, as if he answers as Sid, the great Splendini magician, about his background: "I was born into the Hebrew belief, but when I got older, I converted to narcissism." Johansson, fresh from Allen's Match Point as a bad girl, is here a relatively good, sometimes thick journalism student, trapped in a murder mystery suitable for London: a serial killer. The storyline is a reworking of his recently released thriller Match Point in London, right up to the sins of the upper class and the accident with the "American Tragedy" / "Place in the Sun" boating. In fact, Allen is reviewing Manhattan Murder Mystery and Purple Rose of Cairo, to name just a few other examples. I do not care if he reworks; I would like the new material to be at least equal to the originals, and unfortunately it only reflects its younger size.

Allen as a director and actor can not hide his love for the actress, as he could not for Diane Keaton, and therefore takes a mediocre comedy to an appropriate location in the Allen canon, not big but amusing , sometimes brilliantly satirical: About the alleged upper-class murderer Sid (Allen) jokes "I would be very surprised if he had killed a person." This is Vintage Allen humor. Although there are hardly any literary allusions, as in most films, he smears Scoop with music by Grieg, Tchaikovsky and Strauss to tell us that the Woodman has not lost his class.

summary: 16 years of alcohol is about a skinhead named Frankie; his violent childhood, alcoholism and his love for Ska.
translation:
I feel like I, the fraud, did not fall for it. After reading glowing reviews (the director was a film critic with Sky for years, so many colleagues in the press must be ready to do him a favor by writing favorable reviews) I expected solid acting, atmosphere, excitement, strong characterization, a fascinating Action development and poetic moments. Sadly, "Sixteen Years of Alcohol," does not bring the critics promise, for the most part, sacrificing those qualities instead of cheesy low-budget special effects (what was the clich√© spiderweb scene for there?), Unrealistic fight choreography, and mindless ghost, the Narrative, clich√© edits and camera angles stunned.

"Sixteen Years of Alcohol" starts off interestingly with some nice location shots in Scotland, but it goes downhill from here. Instead of spending time creating atmosphere, creating characters that interest us or creating tension, the director decides to drive you away with self-absorbed, peppy chatter. The main characters are so disagreeable and so poorly played - the audience does not care what happens to them, desperate actors do desperate things ... like this movie! To make matters worse, the "Hommage's" (typical of a director trying to fulfill his obligations to former masters) is either absolutely cliched or unconvincing. The soundtrack is the only thing that picked me up and kept me in the movies, but even that failed to support the dramatic narrative that linked a period of time to the plot.

For some reason, the movie became increasingly flawed and quite frankly annoying. I still saw the whole damned thing!

I think I liked the dark realism in the movie, but even that was destroyed when they were often mixed up with weird and abstract, sometimes pointless scenes. You do not need a huge budget to make a really moving movie, so much was said about how little money they had to make this movie, half a million is not a bit of money ... SO NO EXCITATIONS! Sometimes I wonder what the actors ... or their agents think!

Pass on this turkey, unless you are masochistic or mindless anyway .... NOT MY THING

1.5 / 10

summary: A family driving through Nevada decides to take some snapshots at an out-of-the-way ghost town named Weaver, and horrible things start happening.
translation:
We had to go to an appointment, so we turned on the DVR to record the end. After it was over, I looked at my husband and said, "Do you have any idea?". He shook his head. I said, "So you made me see the end of this movie and I have no idea what just happened". He did not "make" me, but you know.

The film body itself was pretty good. There was a lot of tension. It woke you up. Then came the end. The end was ... well, it just ended. You were not informed about what happened or why. Until the credits, I always thought something would happen to explain it, but it never did. So I came here expecting someone to find out and I just would not pay attention. Nope. Here, four years later, I'm as clueless as Tom Sawyer.

I still have no idea what happened. I'm just glad I did not waste money to buy it because I was sure I was crazy.

OHHHHH! I get it! The end of the movie is gone! rofl

summary: A contract killer sees a chance to free himself from a tragic past.
translation:
This is such a great movie! Anyway, the low rating here. I really do not know where that comes from, they need to discuss another movie. Because I absolutely loved it and saw it as a little hidden treasure.

It's a story that is so original and charming. I really can not imagine anything bad. Maybe it has to be "your kind of thing," but I saw it with my sister and mother, and we were all taken with it.

Acting was also very good, and that's hard to do in a movie like this one. But I found all characters very fascinating and sympathetic.

I've always loved Dougray Scott and found his new "dark" role very interesting. It's really hard to make me look like a bad guy, but I had absolutely no problem with it. What's more, I loved him.

If you love a good thriller / drama that also has a good dose of love and tragedy, you should definitely watch this movie, no question! If you want to watch a movie with 80% bloodshed, you should rent something else. But I think the title is there again. This is a love story, not Saw 3.

I give this movie 4 out of 5 stars !!! Good work !!!

xxx Have fun!

summary: In the year 1984, rocket bombs and rats prey on the inhabitants of the crumbling metropolis of London. Far away on the Malabar Front, a seemingly interminable war rages against Eastasia. The Ministry of Truth broadcasts ceaselessly to the population via its inescapable network of telescreens. These devices, which pervade all aspects of peoples' lives, are also capable of monitoring their every word and action. They form part of an elaborate surveillance system used by the Ministry of Love, and its dreaded agents the Thought Police, to serve their singular goal: the elimination of 'thoughtcrime'. Winston Smith is a Party worker - part of the vast social caste known as the Outer Party, the rank and file of the sprawling apparatus of government. Winston works in the Records Department of the Ministry of Truth - the section charged with modifying historical news archives for consistency. When by chance Winston uncovers incontrovertible proof that the Party is lying, he embarks on a ...
translation:
Having heard of George Orwell's prophetic masterpiece in my entire life, I am now 37 years old, but I have never read the book, I am completely confused about what I have just seen.

I'm very familiar with the concepts covered in the novel, I am sure, but only by hearsay and quotes. Without this limited knowledge, this film would have been a complete mystery, and even so, I am still less educated in the 1984 story than before.

On the positive side. ..

The cinematography is amazing, Hurt & Burton perform well and the overall feel of the movie is wonderfully grim and bleak. The prostitute scene was a fantastically dark piece of film.

Now for the downside, and there are many ...

There is a war going on (at least as far as the propaganda is concerned), but why and with whom? Nothing is explained. There are a few names (Eurasia, etc.), but they do not mean anything without explanation.

Who is Winston? what does he do? Where does he comes from? where does he work? Why does he change messages? Why is not he on the front line? Why does not he eat the food in the canteen? What is the drink he drinks throughout the movie? Why is he so weak and sick? Why is not he brainwashed like everyone else? What's the deal with his mother and sister? What happened to his father? A little backstory would have been nice, no scrub, important for those like me who did not read the book. Without it, this is just a confusing and hard-to-follow art-house movie that keeps you guessing what's actually going on.

The soundtrack was dis-jointed and badly edited and the constant chatter of The Big Brother's screens swamped the dialogue in some places, making it even harder to figure out what's going on. I accept that this was an artistic decision, but it is still very annoying.

I also know that this has been mentioned, but why all the nudity? It just seemed superfluous and it felt like it had been thrown in to make up for the lack of any plot reporting.

I personally can not stand, as Hollywood believes, telling stories for word these days. We're not all brainwashing fools, but that's a few steps too far the other way. I can only imagine that it is entirely due to the fact that you have read the book, because if this film is really the "literal translation" that I have seen many, it would be difficult to understand why 1984 is celebrated like the classic it is.

It is undeniable that it was light years ahead of time and has pretty much predicted every change in our society so far (maybe that was some kind of Bible for the forces that are?), but many science fiction novelists have done the same without leaving any gaps in the story.

I think I have to do what I should have done from the beginning and buy a copy of the book if I make sense of it.

All in all, very disappointed with something I have been waiting for years to see.

summary: Dave, Sam and Jeff are about to graduate from Holden University with Honors in lying, cheating and scheming. The three roommates have proudly scammed their way through the last four years of college and now, during the final exams, these big-men-on-campus are about to be busted by the most unlikely dude in school.
translation: This movie has no plot and no focus. Yes, it should be a slap stick, stupid comedy, but the screen writers have no idea what the movie was about. Even the title does not fit the movie. It should have been called "Cool Ethan" or "Cheater Never Win" or something like that. The characters are not developed and nobody cares what happens to them! The roommate of the apartment (from That 70's Show) was the only person to see it. She was hilarious and stole every scene she was in. The others must make sure that their own college diplomas are in the works as they need a career other than acting.

summary: A political satire set in Turaqistan, a country occupied by an American private corporation run by a former US Vice President. In an effort to monopolize the opportunities the war-torn nation offers, the corporation's CEO hires a troubled hit man, to kill a Middle East oil minister. Now, struggling with his own growing demons, the assassin must pose as the corporation's Trade Show Producer in order to pull off this latest hit, while maintaining his cover by organizing the high-profile wedding of Yonica Babyyeah, an outrageous Middle Eastern pop star, and keeping a sexy left wing reporter in check.
translation:
That's a brilliant political satire. No wonder why it was largely ignored in the US: it exposes our murderous foreign policy for what it really is.

Another good movie from that time, Rendition, was also completely dismissed, simply because it showed that the US is a war machine designed to torture, murder and kill civilians mutilate, in search of total world domination.

A clever plot, good acting, some big stars (John Cusack, Ben Kingsley, Marisa Tomei anyone?) and some scenes of glee should have made this movie a hit. Unfortunately, Americans do not like to hear the truth about themselves, especially when they are involved in mass murder.

summary: A global war begins in 1940. This war drags out over many decades until most of the people still alive (mostly those born after the war started) do not even know who started it or why. Nothing is being manufactured at all any more and society has broken down into primitive localized communities. In 1966 a great plague wipes out most of what people are left but small numbers still survive. One day a strange aircraft lands at one of these communities and its pilot tells of an organization which is rebuilding civilization and slowly moving across the world re-civilizing these groups of survivors. Great reconstruction takes place over the next few decades and society is once again great and strong. The world's population is now living in underground cities. In the year 2035, on the eve of man's first flight to the moon, a popular uprising against progress (which some people claim has caused the wars of the past) gains support and becomes violent.
translation:
If scientists behaved in such a way that H. G. Wells was confident that this would be the case in the future, the story would not have gone down as it had done in "Things To Come". Nearly 80 years have passed since Wells wrote The Shape Of The Things To Come, on which this film is based, and closer to the world he describes than before, in some more distant directions.

Although well-known players like Raymond Massey, Ralph Richardson and Cedric Hardwicke are in the cast, they are more caricatures than real characters. It is the main weakness of the film, it is dedicated to Wells' philosophy of science, solves all the problems and the rest of us are backward fools.

Massey's characters, two generations of the same family, hold this extremely optimistic view. Cedric Hardwicke is a skeptic who feels that man is too far ahead. And Ralph Richardson is a warlord born of the destruction of another Thirty Years War fought with modern weapons. Incidentally, since the atomic bomb was not invented, poison gas was considered a weapon that almost destroys humanity.

According to Wells, science and conquest can never mix. Scientists as a group are way too far beyond the world of politics to engage in such things. During Wells's lifetime, the scientists fled from the far-right governments of Hitler and Mussolini. The same people, however, to defeat them, submitted to the Allies and formed the nuclear weapons that introduced the modern age. If they acted the way Wells would have liked, someone like Albert Einstein would have led a junta of scientists who would have created a new order after the Second World War.

Wells misunderstood it both in time and in development. He apparently never imagined the computer as well as nuclear power. Computer programmers are more likely to be our rulers in a brave new world than scientists at the moment. Still Things To Come, supported by the director William Cameron Menzies and the resulting sets offer an interesting insight into the mind of H. G. Wells, certainly a respected thinker of his time, although he did not quite get the shape of Things To Come.

summary: This movie follows the life of a young German woman, married to a soldier in the waning days of WWII. Fassbinder has tried to show the gritty life after the end of WWII and the turmoil of the people trapped in its wake.
translation:
Sensual and tough Maria Braun. (Hanna Schygula) marries a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends half a day and all night with him. That's how long their marriage takes until she loses him to war and then to jail. She goes on with her life, becoming a successful businesswoman, who is not only sensual, but also intelligent, ambitious and willing to use sex whenever and wherever: "I know nothing about the business, but I know what German women are You could even say that I'm an expert in it. " As she climbs on success, she always remembers her husband Hermann (her husband) and convinces herself, whatever she does ?? is for him, for her future happy life together. The style of "Maria Braun" is reminiscent of melodramas of Fassbinder's favorite Hollywood director Douglas Sirk and gives an insight into the loss and survival in post-war Germany. Hanna Schygula literally shines in every scene of the movie and she's awesome.

8.5 / 10

summary: The teenagers Isabella, Jamie, Melanie, Caroline and Stephanie are lost in a shortcut they took in their way back home. The inexperienced Bell is driving her mother's van and is worried about the late hour. The quintet decides to stop in an isolated store to ask for directions, and Bell accidentally bumps one headlight of a parked SUV. The girls decide to leave the place and drive in the dark and lonely road trying to reach the main road. They decide to make a u-turn and they are chased by the driver of the SUV along a night of terror.
translation:
Definitely, definitely the worst movie I've ever seen, no questions asked! Opponents of this opinion could argue that this title should not be judged on the same criteria as others, since it is an independent, low-budget movie, but come on? the dilettantism and the meager innovations are frightening.

I agree with everything that has been said about this movie, for example the mind numbing weak acting (if it's that bad, you take another try to turn the scene, damn it), The thing I found most annoying was the total lack of common sense in the script, provided that such a thing existed during production. There was an obvious absence of dialogue with respect for the viewers, the girls changed their personality several times and they did not seem to sing any rationality or even brains - five relatively fitting girls against a light female psychopath. Tail them, why do not you?

The only thing that can be considered as a kind of conquest for this title is that the camera never leaves the van and thus the viewer sees everything in it - which, like the rest of the movie A good idea is done exponentially terribly. Oh and by the way, this movie is nothing like The Blair Witch Project or Cloverfield or any other track filmed with a handheld camera? this is an effect and not a feature! Cleverly used, it can be breathtaking, but in this case it is an excuse for inadequate camera work.

summary: At 43, Luis is a confirmed bachelor, happy with one night stands, a success as a creator of perfumes. He has one problem: his mother and five sisters, who form an intimidating family council, want him married. Luis contrives to hire a woman to pose as a fianc√©e who will jilt him at the altar, leaving him disconsolate, with an excuse not to marry. He hires Emma, the sister of a colleague. She restores antique furniture and wants to adopt a child from Brazil. Things go too well: when Emma doesn't show up at the wedding, Luis's mother requires hospitalization; only Emma can bring her out of her swoon. It's time for a new plan that involves more tangled webs. And the child?
translation:
I have to be 100% honest with you, with other IMDb users. I just wanted to watch this movie for a long time because of the poster. Does not Charlotte Gainsbourg look very sexy and smile like that? I am in love with this woman! I got what I expected ... but only half. This film should have expectations for those who enjoy all kinds of romantic comedies or stories with intelligent humor and light dramatic situations.

I do not agree with another fellow IMDb user who says the movie is overrated; I must admit that "Pr√©te-moi ta main" has many mistakes.

My main problem with the movie is the lack of screen chemistry between the main characters. There is not a single scene before the climax that shows that the main characters share a moment of "romance" or even an indication that they are interested in each other.

In fact, only scene was both share a moment is tremendously embarrassing (if both are on the couch), and does not help understand the audience, a potential love interest. I did not buy the dinner sequence.

Nevertheless, the film delivers very funny moments and has strong dialogues that support such a naive premise. I mean naively, that these days it would be very hard to carry out such a farse from a 43-year-old man.

I understand that it's a movie and that's why I accept it as a funny situation. Plus, the humor is versatile. There are moments with S & M, funny lines with Chabat's best friend, some lesbian references, funny situations with the family women and more.

Charlotte Gaionbourg's performance is first class and she is by far the reason to watch the movie. She's funny, sexy, looks very thin and good and shows that it is a versatile and talented actress who can produce a comedic and dramatic performance in sheer brilliance.

Alain Chabat is a good actor and gives a very good decent performance. I think the supporting actors do what they can.

The score, art direction and other technical aspects are really good and give the movie a dynamic look.

Who enjoy this kind of cinema should be pleased after the credits. It's a good example of a good movie.

summary: This is the film of The Who's appearance at the third (and final) Isle of Wight festival in 1970. This is regarded as the band's finest performance.
translation: This movie was not made by Who fans. Most of the big moments, to which the fans will rejoice in the half-hour Tommy Medley are simply missing or covered up: At Christmas, they did not show Daltry's screams down the line, "Tommy does not know what day it is ..." they showed in Pinball Wizard almost * no * Townsend - guitar recordings, there was during the best moments of Go to the Mirror surplus Crowd - shots, and worst of all in the second half We're Nonna Taking it (Listening to You), robbed They give us almost every shot of Pete's flaming guitar chords. Huge parts of the film can be seen behind the band. It is a very frustrating movie that you can see and that does not deliver the goods. I do not know if director Murry Lerner simply is not a Who fan, or worse, at least for him if he * is a Who fan and these are all * eight * cameras that he can provide for him. In his favor, there are some rare numbers before Tommy, as well as some favorites that are well received, and sometimes the editing is brilliant. That might be enough to make some viewers happy, as long as you do not anticipate Tommy. The sound overall was mediocre in the transmission that I saw of DirecTV; It may be different on video or DVD.

summary: In a 1950's mining town called Coalwood, Homer Hickam is a kid with only one future in sight, to work in the local coal mine like his father. However in October 1957, everything changes when the first artificial satellite, Sputnik goes into orbit. With that event, Homer becomes inspired to learn how to build rockets. With his friends and the local nerd, Homer sets to do just that by trial and a lot of error. Unfortunately, most of the town and especially Homer's father thinks that they are wasting their time. Only one teacher in the high school understands their efforts and lets them know that they could become contenders in the national science fair with college scholarships being the prize. Now the gang must learn to perfect their craft and overcome the many problems facing them as they shoot for the stars.
translation:
I refused to see this movie, and I understand why he was not a big hit in theaters. "October Sky" feels and looks so familiar. And it is. All the storylines and emotions have been researched before in other films - and possibly even better. But despite his familiarity and resistance to all Hollywood formulas, this film is winning and sympathetic at every turn.

Sputnik is the inspiration for this journey of heart, mind and soul. Just as the characters in Steven Sondheim's musical MERRILY WE ROLL ALONG were standing on the roof of their home, hoping to start their new generation ("What do you call it? You call it a miracle."), Sputnik has a similar impact the boys rocket guys of this true story. While the truncated townspeople of the 1950s coal city reject the event, Homer sees Hickham as his ticket to life in the mines.

Masterly instructions and castings make the journey of rocket boys Homer and his buddies appear fresh and new. Particularly affected are subplots in relation to Homer's ailing young school teacher. Remarkable restraint is shown in the presentation of her delicate relationship. Also noteworthy is the father / son supplement that anchors the film. Played perfectly around. Even Homer's mother gets her moment without clich√© or intrusion. Her ultimatum to her husband is both dignified and heartbreaking. "Myrtle Beach" says it all.

A big video chain I despise has a sign next to this movie saying that you will love this movie or that you will refund your money. For once, I agree with them. You'll never see the October sky like this again.

summary: Top cover girl and fashion model, Jennifer Tree has it all - beauty, fame, money and power. Her face appears on covers of hundreds of magazines. At the top of her game, Jennifer is America's sweetheart. She is loved and adored and sought after. Everyone wants her. But someone out there has been watching and waiting. Someone wants her in the worst way. Out alone at a charity event in Soho, Jennifer is drugged and taken. Held captive in a cell, Jennifer is subjected to a series of terrifying, life-threatening tortures that could only be conceived by a twisted, sadistic mind. It follows the story of one woman who is abducted and tortured, held against her will in a place where days turn into weeks.
translation:
The only reason why I give him a 2 is that the filmography is so stylized these days that at least it has something to comment on.

This movie is amazing. It's like so many other chowder of the 21st century. The blood is free and simply repellent. I did not care about the characters, but it was important to me that a cretin complains about this crap: I would complain about the money I spent, but my date and I left wisely after 40 minutes and went in an adjoining theater Seeing the adventurous and entertaining "Live Free or Die Hard," which probably received a much higher rating from me, simply because I had to endure the total shuddering of "captivity" for 40 minutes.

summary: A young man finds out that his parents had been used in an atomic-weapons experiment shortly before he was born, and that the results have had some unexpected effects on him.
translation:
A man discovers that his parents were part of a nuclear experiment in the 1950s and that he now has the power to go up in flames!

I was really prepared for this movie, directed by the great Toby Hooper and the inflexible Savage Brad Dourif. Unfortunately, it did not rise above the average movie with individual violence. Spontaneous Combustion has an interesting premise, unfortunately it never seems to be full and prolongs its conspiracy too much. The special effects, however, are not bad and help to bring the film to the final.

The cast is not bad, Dourif is stealing the show.

All around, Not a classic, but it's not the worst of its kind.

** out of ****

summary: This series, the first since the character's overhaul revision in the comics by John Byrne, shows the adventures of the Man of Steel as he fights villains like the evil head of the mega-corporation Lexcorp, Lex Luthor. In addition, we see the adventures of Clark as a boy in Smallville and all the mischief he causes with his powers.
translation:
After the SuperFriends and Scooby Doo left the Saturday morning airwaves in the fall of 1986, I almost stopped listening to the cartoons on Saturday morning, as these were the only ones that voted me. And there neither the Real Ghostbusters nor the Flintstone Kids I was very promising for myself, I "retired" and fell asleep on Saturday morning. I only returned in 1988 for Saturday and Saturday only for a single animated show.

A new animated Superman show was something I would not miss. I was 17 at the time and in high school, but what's up? I loved this show. As far as I can remember, this series was a gift to the fans that I accepted on the occasion of Superman's 50th birthday this year. The theme music and style reminded of John Williams film music from the Superman films Richard Donner / Christopher Reeve. I really felt that Ruby Spears' animation style was reminiscent of the Super Powers Team: Galactic Guardians series by Hanna Barbera a few years ago. Unfortunately, Danny Dark did not return as Superman, but I felt that Beau Weaver did a very impressive job as the voice of Superman and his Clark Kent was nerdig like the Chris Reeve version. After his hearing as Reed Richards / Mr. Fantastic in the 90s Fantastic Four, I still could see this version of Superman in my mind. Ginny McSwain as Lois Lane. LOL! What a rhyme she was a dubbing director for Hanna Barbera and Ruby Spears, and I think she's committed to making Lois. Memories of the super friends remained in this series when it came to the voice over cast. Jimmy Olsen is Mark Taylor, who was on the SuperFriends formerly Firestorm. Perry White is none other than former Batman TV author Stanley Ralph Ross, who was on SuperFriends Gorilla Grodd and Brainiac in the Super Powers shows. And Lex Luthor, now a wise billionaire, is none other than SuperFriend's voice alum Michael Bell, whom I know best as Zan and the Riddler as well as many other characters from many other series.

I felt that this series was a combination of the movie Superman and John Byrne in Superman's postwar concept, living with Lex Luthor as a billionaire tycoon, Jonathan and Martha Kent, to Clark as Superman to see. The Bruce Timm series and Lois and Clark would do the same. Unfortunately we have never seen Brainiac, Bizarro, Toyman, Metallo or Darkseid. Except Luthor, we only saw the Prankster and saw General Zod. I especially liked this episode with Wonder Woman, voiced by BJ Ward, who also played her on the Super Powers team.

The episodes were overwhelming, and I also enjoyed Clark's growth and development stories from childhood through childhood to adolescent adulthood.

The only two things I did not like. It only lasted one season. And after Wonder Way's guest spot, I hoped that Batman would be voiced by Adam West (I still remember the Super Powers Team episodes). I also hoped that the Prankster episode saw baseball team Metropolis take on Gotham Goliaths.

Every popular superhero has a very rare comic series. For SpiderMan, I think it was the 1981 solo series that aired at the same time as Amazing Friends. For the Incredible Hulk it's the 1982 cartoon. For the Fantastic Four it's the 1978 series with HERBIE the Robot. For Batman it is the New Adventures of Batman 1977 by Filmation with BatMite. But for Superman this is the rarest series.

Superman books and documentaries never treat or mention them. This is another series that WB should consider for DVD release. All in all, this 1988 version of Superman is good .... Great !!

summary: Geronimo is the sheriff of a small Texas town. One night, 2 brothers from Palermo kill the sheriff's coworker and pal so he chases them. The chase takes him across the border down to Mexico where he kills one of the brothers and takes the other back to the States to stand trial. The surviving brother vows revenge on the sheriff. But the criminal is handed over to Italian police, and the sheriff's goes to Malta with the prisoner.
translation:
Two Qualifiers at the Top: I think Joe Don Baker can be good or even great with the right material and the right director (the remake "Cape Fear", a small role in "Goldeneye", "Walking Tall"). I even liked Baker in "Mitchell" because he played an anti-hero who was considered unlikely. Yes, MST3K's coverage was hilarious, but they made a lot of cheap recordings on Baker that he did not deserve to keep things alive and entertaining of the movie.

"Final Justice" seems more like the same, but despite the exotic locations and the theme of "Cowboy Frontier Justice," it's a bit weaker than "Mitchell." , And the main reason is that Baker's character, as written, is an idiot. The film has the notion that Baker, as Baker embodies Old Frontier Machismo, challenges its opponents to old-style Mano-a-Mano quick-draw contests. And because he is so tough and macho, he always wins, even if he is injured, wounded, inferior, and so on.

This is a fantasy with a lot of potential (it has worked for Gary Cooper), even if it is so condemns the movie to status "B". But Baker is so damn stupid and obsessed that he unnecessarily challenges three of the evil man's stooges to a showdown in a public market, with civilians everywhere. He just MAY have locked her up to the chief's headquarters (which is why he was following her at all) and they would never have noticed. Or he might have gotten the drop on her and forced her to surrender, and got one of the followers to take him to the top of the gun. But no, he has to be a Busch league hot dog and a macho fool, so he gets a kid taken hostage in the shootout!

This is a guy we should admire?

The whole movie is basically like this. Most of the supporting actors are somewhere between OK (the followers) and pretty good (the boss villain and his father, two well-known European actors) - they just go through the motions, but they are professionals and make it hard for them to be decent) , But through all of this, Baker's character draws stupid, unproductive stunts and mistakes that kill at least two relatively innocent people, plus a few baddies that may have been kept alive without the use of lethal force. > On a positive note, 90% of the film plays in Malta or the Mediterranean. Here you can see many beautiful landscapes and many exotic extras. And really, Baker himself is on the downside and a bit dyspeptic, but he's not that bad ... certainly not the weapon that these critics (including Mike and the bots in their hilarious coverage) seem to think.

In short, this movie is good for video wallpapers, but the viewer should not bother with it.

summary: This is the story of a young boy who moves to a small town after the divorce of his parents. At a local festival, he becomes an unlikely hero when he is chosen as the "Kirin Rider," a protector of all things good. And he must lead Japan's ancient Yokai spirits in their apocalyptic war against the evil bizarre-looking monsters.
translation: I just watched this movie and I have to say that I was so impressed. Everything was great. The acting of the characters, the story. A credible child who has become courageous and always ready to help others. His mother has to be proud. I could not take my eyes off this movie for fear of missing something. It's the fairy tale of the prefects with morals, cute and scary sprites and "monsters", yet heart-warming people. A child poked and bullied at school and became a hero. He was chosen to be a driver at the local village festival and travel to Goblin Mountain, where he discovers the Yokai, an amazing creation that Brian Froud could be proud of. And the evil Kato and his off sider, who definitely needed a hug. These evil people capture the yokai and throw them into a red pit along with unwanted objects such as motorcycles and other mechanical things that assemble into terribly violent robot monsters whose sole purpose is to kill. Takashi, a little boy, is the one who becomes her savior, along with a red man / dragon, a turtle man and a river princess, and a cute little creature that, if it had been America, would have made it a cuddly toy and sold it in all good toy shops. The lines are good, especially do not try to bring home children and other jewels that will bring a smile to your lips. Expose the faith and watch it with a child or alone and enjoy it! However, I have to admit that the end was a bit sad. And not necessarily like that. Prost Furdion

summary: Paris, 2054: a dark motion-captured world of shadows and right angles. Ilona Tasuiev, a brilliant young scientist, is kidnapped, and her employer, Avalon, a major health and beauty corporation, wants her found. Karas, a jaded police captain, is assigned to find her, fast. He seeks help from her sister, Bislane, and they are soon uncovering identify theft, missing files, and hints that something back in 2006 may explain what's going on. Ilona's mentor, Avalon's vice president, a Japanese researcher, an underworld boss, and Bislane's drug connection all figure in the mix. So does an attraction between Karas and Bislane. What's behind the kidnapping? Who's the victim?
translation: If the answer to this question is yes, you should enjoy this excellent movie. I just saw it here in Paris a couple of hours ago (where the action of the movie is taking place) and I can still feel the huge trauma I got in the back of my mind ... What a visual shock! I have never seen such a beautiful black and white photo and such a drastic change in the way of animated films. I firmly believe that before and after the "Renaissance" it will be similar to Pixar films or experiences with Akira and GhostInTheShell. This is a real breakthrough in the small world of animated films, and I hope that this French initiative (a small unknown French studio with some young people who had a dream called "Renaissance" ...) was the success and recognition who deserves it. Vive la France!

summary: In 2005, the only thing hurting Los Angeles Times columnist Steve Lopez more than his face from a recent bike accident was his pressing need for story ideas. That is when he discovers Nathaniel Ayers, a mentally ill, homeless street musician who possesses extraordinary talent, even through his half-broken instruments. Inspired by his story, Lopez writes an acclaimed series of articles about Ayers and attempts to do more to help both him and the rest of the underclass of LA have a better life. However, Lopez's good intentions run headlong in the hard realities of the strength of Ayers' personal demons and the larger social injustices facing the homeless. Regardless, Lopez and Ayers must find a way to conquer their deepest anxieties and frustrations to hope for a brighter future for both of them.
translation: What could have been an exciting and emotionally charged character study is completely undermined by the predictable factor. Fox is fine as Nathaniel Ayers, the Julliard-trained musician who dreams of playing with the Walt Disney Orchestra, until he takes to the streets with schizophrenia and finally drives him out into the streets. Reporter Steve Lopez is looking for a good story to improve his career. He gets to know him and tells his story. They use all the elements of the classic film "How we hit the skids", take the bonds of "A Beautiful Mind" very generously, take the fake "feel good" attitude of films like "Rocky" - you choose the sequence number - and whip up a lot of melodrama in the style of the 1930s All that's left on the screen is a burnt-out cover of a movie. It is trite, banal, absolutely predictable and too often plays on our feelings. I hate to say it, but this is the kind of movie that, when you say you hated it, people will make you look bad. I really wish I could say something positive about this movie, but I really can not. Acting triggers it a bit, but not enough to give more than one star. Strictly made for TV movie material. Not worth your time

summary: Howard W. Campbell, Jr., an American expatriate playwright, Nazi radio propagandist, and Allied spy, writes his memoirs during his pre-trial confinement in 1961 Haifa and learns that people are what they pretend to be.
translation:
I'm a big fan of Vonnegut's work and I love this movie a lot, but I would not say that this is a Mother Night movie I'm reading. When people say that Vonnegut is not able to film, I can think of two things. One is that many of his subjects are very close to the ankle or even taboo, despite the allegations sometimes made against him that he chooses relatively "easy" goals for his satire. This means less every day that goes by in terms of filmability. Directors seem to enjoy breaking taboos these days, and I have high hopes for the version of "Bluebeard" that is now in production. It's amazing to think that an innocent piece like Vonnegut's "Sirens of Titan" would probably have been the equivalent of "R" when it was filmed when it was released in the 1950s because of its violence, language and sexuality and thematic content, though it's a tragedy that no one has come up with a scriptable script yet. And in the current economic climate, I also hope that a director will look closely at "Jailbird", "Galapagos" and "Hocus Pocus".

The other thing is his narrative style, irony raises irony to irony, but still weird. It seems impossible to objectify, and that seems to be the biggest obstacle to making great films about his great novels, because the little comments that make up our reaction as readers are simply not possible in films, without too often awkward techniques Vonnegut said that the filmed versions of his work lacked a character who himself acted as author / narrator, and in his honor, "Breakfast of Champions" (the film) attempted to maintain the comedy, and came to grief a bit of a Cropper, just like another turkey from a Vonnegut novel "Slapstick" in an even more spectacular way.

Still, it's not a bad thing if a director gives us his subjective interpretation of Vonnegut, and "Mother Night" is an excellent example of how a good director, as another reviewer put it, adds a visual poetry to such a source But so much of the humor is lost that although it is the same plot, it does not really come from the novel I've read. If that had been so, I would probably have rolled in the hallways and laughed a few times when I saw it. For a reader of the novel, I think a giggle is even forgivable in the end. However, the end of the film is really poignant, and I think one of the film's successes is that you really can feel someone has seen someone between razor and greed switch between good and evil, and the jury is still out.

Alone and alone, a look is worthwhile. Technically, there are minor but blatant mistakes, especially in continuity, and it often looks shabby and theatrical, but mostly meets an acceptable rating and occasionally displays considerable imagination and ingenuity. The spectacle is usually of a high order, even though dialogue may be stilted a bit by today's standards.

It pretty much survives when you look back to back with "Slaughterhouse-5" and that is indeed the case Vonnegut shot some of the "good" out there, mostly versions of his short stories - "Harrison Bergeron, "" Who am I now? " and a few other things, like the misfiring, filmed version of his very funny, but disposable, Happy Birthday Wanda June game. There was also an interesting piece, if it still exists, in the 70s, "Between Time And Timbuktu", which Vonnegut did not seem to appreciate, even though he was involved in his production because he felt it was him misinterpreted in its generality. He said it reminded him of the bizarre surgical experiments that were done in the story of HG Wells's The Island of Dr. Moreau, but it was an excellent introduction to his work for many people.

But if the films do not let you go to the superior source material, they do not do their job.

As the man said, the big show is more or less in your head.

summary: After a wild night on the town, a dashing British airline pilot is attacked by thugs, and when he wakes in hospital he finds himself being cared for by a beautiful doctor, Emy Wong. He falls in love with her, but Emy gravely informs him that, in the ancient East Asian custom, she is betrothed to a man she has never met.
translation: The handsome British flight pilot George Taylor (a solid portrayal of Guiseppe Pambieri) is beaten up by thugs after a wild night in Hong Kong. George meets and falls in love with the sweet and virginal Dr. Emy Wong (a fine and charming performance by the enchanting Chai Lee). George recovers and goes back to work. When Emy no longer hears about George, she succumbs to despair and becomes a prostitute. While director / co-author Bitto Albertini does indeed deliver a satisfying amount of the expected delicious nudity and steamy softcore sex, this movie is anything but a routine that devours out of sheer mess. Instead, it is a surprisingly thoughtful, touching and tragic love story between two well-drawn and very responsive characters (Chai as Emy Wong is particularly radiant and lovable). The image starts bubbly and happy, but the sound changes radically into a grimmer and tougher mood around two-thirds of the passage. Emy's descent into vice, after falsely believing that George left her, is grim and disturbing; Likewise, the remarkably sad and heartbreaking surprise ending. Granted, the narrative is certainly melodramatic, but never too stupid or trashy. In addition, the sex scenes are very tasteful and even genuinely erotic. The notorious Italian pornstar Ilona Staller has a handsome, sizeable supporting role as George's jealous and uninhibited secretary Helen Miller. Guido Mancori's sophisticated cinematography offers many exciting shots of exotic locations. Nico Fidenco's funky, pulsating score hits the groovy spot. Worth a look for those who are looking for something different.

summary: Dr. Evil uses a device he calls a "Time Machine" to travel back to 1969 and remove Austin Powers' mojo. The sexually wounded swinger must travel back in time and, with the help of agent Felicity Shagwell, recover his vitality. Meanwhile, Dr. Evil's personal life runs amok as he discovers love, continues to shun his son and develops a close relationship with himself. Well, actually, a clone 1/8 his size whom he dubs "Mini-Me". The always time-baffled Dr. Evil begins his plan to put a gigantic cannon on the moon, thus turning it into a device called either "The Death Star" or "Alan Parson's Project," depending on which name is available.
translation: After enjoying Mike Myer's previous work (Waynes World and Saturday Night Live), my expectations of parodying the 60s bonds were quite high. After the first minute, it became clear that this was an exercise that was supposed to be as puerile and inglorious as possible. I left after ten minutes. I saw it a second time the other day to see if I had been unfair for the first time. I turned it off after ten minutes. I can hardly believe that even a twelve-year-old boy can find that funny. The dialogue is an irritation, Myers hurts, just like Heather Graham, and the succession of characters, including Fat Bastard, makes things even worse. In addition to the mild amusing title and the psychedelic stage design, this is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Personally, I recommend avoiding it like the plague, although some of my friends enjoyed it (maybe they were blindfolded at the time)

summary: An interweaving narrative chronicling the antics of such diverse characters as: a transsexual taxi driver, a family obsessed with hygiene and toads, a fiery reverend, a carnival owner who kidnaps women into marriage, and a xenophobic couple who run a local shop for local people.
translation:
That makes me proud to be a Brit. This is by far the funniest thing on TV. The league consists of Jeremy Dyson, Steve Pemberton, Mark Gatiss and the beautiful Reece Shearsmith. Totally underrated is this horror comedy perfection. The characters are iconic and the expressions bizarre "Hello Dave". It's a comedy that everyone just has to watch.

The best thing about the men's league is that it is always fresh and always pushing the limits. It does not have to rely on keywords (unlike the UK) for it to be funny. The fact that the League is ready to kill their most famous and famous characters shows us that they have steel balls.

summary: A team of renegade soldiers in World War II tries to stop the creation of the Fourth Reich in the Middle East.
translation:
Another piece of garbage made for the TV! This is an insult to a war movie (I use the word movie in its most relaxed form!) I thought Telly Savala's career had bottomed out as he discussed the Birmingham video screened on Tarrant on this visit on a regular basis, but then I had forgotten that he was involved! I tried to push it into my subconscious memory, but the cable television brought the memory in my wake and scream !!

I like that bit (laughs sarcastically!) in the movie, which claims to be a scene from Liverpool in the 1940s, but it's obviously a take on the Zagreb Cathedral in the late eighties. The steam train on which the commandos are training shows the logo of the JZ (Jugoslavia Zeleznice or Yugoslav State Railways) on the side of the locomotive quite clearly, although the manufacturers have tried to obscure it. Why not just film in the UK when most of the movie is playing there?

Cheap garbage and a waste of celluloid!

summary: Old Prof. Preobrazhensky and his young colleague Dr. Bormental inserted the human's hypophysis into a dog's brain. Couple of weeks later the dog became "human looking". The main question is "Is anybody who is looking like a man, A REAL MAN?"
translation:
This film (and yes, it's a movie - it was shot as a two-parter, but the two parts together make up more than two hours) - is one of the unsung masterpieces of world cinema. The film is a very good-natured and at the same time absolutely cruel denunciation of the Soviet regime and the kind of person who flourished under it. He is a faithful adaptation of the long-forbidden eponymous book by Mikhail Bulgakov. The sets are immaculate, and the director has made the brilliant decision to film in monochrome sepia, and feels authentically where a washed-up color incarnation of the late '80s almost ruined the film. I will not say much about the plot it deserves to be discovered by the viewer, but the performances are real Oscar material. Special mention goes to E. Evstigneev, who plays the old professor with such presence, gravitas and kind wisdom that in the end he barely steals every scene in which he finds himself with hardly a word or a gesture. The second, of course, is Creature / Sharikov V. Tolokonnikov's frightening perfection character is far scarier than Hannibal Lecter, for it does not exist only in real life - entire countries have been ruled throughout history by men like him, with everything, what happens.

Although this is a socio-political allegory, it is worth noting that the movie is also full of humor, albeit dark - there are many funny comedies that did not make me laugh like this movie. When you laugh about this movie, you not only feel funny, but also sympathetic and united, which is always a plus.

There is hardly a complaint I have with this film - the only one small flaw is the tone of intellectual / bourgeois snobbery that I sometimes catch from the "enlightened" characters. But that is a small mistake.

Unfortunately this movie seems to have been bypassed by Western licensed companies. It is a terrible shame that one of the best all-round films out there is unrestored and untranslated (which should not be incredibly hard) - although all cultural references and revolutionary terminology inevitably fade in translation, the main themes of the film should be accessible to all). While we wait with fingers for the Criterion edition, I'm thinking of creating English subtitles myself. Let's see how it works.

summary: What Is It? is a bewildering, unnerving, surreal, blackly comic film from the visionary mind of Crispin Glover that tells the inner and outer struggles of a young man facing villains and demons on multiple planes.
translation: This movie is very interesting. I've seen it twice, and it seems Glover has hit the nail on his head with what he claims. I can point out, on the one hand, the outrage that the filmmaker is clearly expressing in the face of the current, thoughtless business that is a rush in every media center, and the things we should not think about as a culture because of corporate media control. The outrage that Glover expresses through the "outrageous" elements in the films is beautiful in both his visceral aggressiveness and his poetic power. I'm glad I saw this movie, and it's even clearer that Glover is up to something interesting in the second part of the trilogy. It's okay! ALL IS WELL. See also that. People who dismiss this movie as "thoughtless" or "overbearing" really miss the boat. This is a smart movie. When you see it with his live show, which he's doing before with his books, it's also very angry. The way you get to his way of thinking is really something. You will have an experience!

summary: In WW1,German intelligence sends a team of saboteurs and a female spy to Scotland to kill Lord Kitchener.Also,German intelligence sends another team of spies to Allied headquarters in Belgium to steal the secret Allied defense plans.German female spy, known as Fraulein Doktor, is tasked with stealing the new mustard gas formula from its French female inventor.The German army plans to use the new French mustard gas on the battlefield during the upcoming German offensive against the Allied armies.
translation: This is an excellent but hard to find Trippy thriller from the First World War in the inimitable Italian style of the 60s. From the psychedelic graphics of the introductory credits and the great score by Ennio Morricone to the lesbian love scene with Capucine and the lavishly produced no-man's land battle scenes with poison gas and German cavalry in gas-tight "Storm Trooper" gear, this is a film not to be missed , It's a movie that captures the horrors and cruelties of war and the recklessness of players on and off the battlefield. Apart from the combat scenes, some of the production and special effects are crude, obviously because most of the budget for this film was saved for the fight scenes. For lovers of cinema in the 60s, this should not be a problem. I saw this movie on TV for the first time many years ago and had the foresight to record it on VHS. I still have the tape and look at it from time to time.

summary: nan
translation: The plot is rocky. The acting is somewhere south of a Jr. high school play. The camera is not bad, but it looks like it has been cut with a machete. I could not decide that this was a deliberately hokey strip or if people thought it would make a good movie. Think about Death Valley Days and Mayberry RFD. People walking around in a "lawless" modern city carrying 6 speedboat express trains. It has more than its fair share of Cutsey stuff. Imagine the good men driving up to an old farmhouse and parking the Ford Mustang right in front of a trailer hitch. Imagine the staff in a hotel looking at an obviously western (hemisphere) movie with a Japanese soundtrack but with English subtitles. It's all very strange, but could be improved if you watch it while attending a small peyote. It's a real curiosity with modern parallels to any Western clich√© you can imagine. There is even a modern version of the good-natured dance hall girl AND a twisted Jew's harp in the soundtrack. Really! If someone brings this to your home for a Saturday night movie session, tell them that your DVD player has died.

summary: "Baptists at Our Barbecue" is the comedic story of the small town of Longwinded, USA, a divided, feuding town of 262 Mormons and 262 Baptists. It's also a love story, about one man who will try anything to end the ridiculous feud, bring the town together, and keep the peace-loving girl of his dreams from leaving town.
translation:
"Baptists at Our Barbecue" is the best movie ever made. Now that I have caught your attention with this dreadfully inaccurate statement that should be a hanging offense in the case of a conversation, let me start with my brief overview of this sticky, offensive, overbearing and boring scrap product. First of all, this stinker's low budget is completely obvious, based on the very bad and inexperienced direction of Christian Vuissa and the cheesy, all-preaching, winy and stilted screenplay by F. Mathew Smith. I really despise the fact that this sends out a very pro-Mormon and a kind of anti-any other religious message. Yes, the story is about a small town half full of Mormons and half full of Baptists. It shows that all the main and role model characters are Mormons and are so kind and perfect, yet they are taken up by the evil, engaging and very valuable Baptists. It shows how beautiful Mormons are and how cold-hearted and ignorant Baptists, instead of showing a little solidarity, would be appropriate and realistic. I'm not part of a religion (I'm actually an atheist), but that offended me along with a myriad of Baptists, most likely. It shows that for the Mormons, the Baptists are very unopened and unwelcoming, and that the Mormons are very acceptable, though in reality there is again a mutual dislike / dislike between them. I'm sorry, I did not want to go on a whim.

Another aspect of 'Baptists at Our Barbecue' that I did not particularly care about was acting. The performances are very amateurish and unnatural, especially by the female lead Heather Beers. Miss Beers stumbles through her role with no passion or emotion for her role, and Dan Merkley, who is the main character in this lackluster movie, did not particularly impress me, but I have to say he is much more talented or shows more talent in this film than Heather Beers. Who played the sheriff of the city, was also terrible. Although there may be a tiny laugh in the movie, it's full of stereotypes. For example, the protagonist Tartan (Merkley) finds solace in a Native American woman who always gives him the best advice on how a tribe lives - how clich√© is that? To make the situation even miserable, Tartan buys a puppy dog ‚Äã‚Äãto the poor, lonely pagan. Ugghhh!

If you want my advice, stay as far away as possible from 'Baptists at Our Barbecue'. I saw it on the shelf and thought it was a sweet and interesting little indie about religion. All I got was a piece of crap. Note: D-

my rating help - A + (absolutely flawless); A (a masterpiece, almost perfect); A- (excellent); B + (great); B (very good); B- (good); C + (a mixed bag); C (average); C- (disappointing); D + (bad); D (very bad); D- (absolutely horrible); F (not a single quality effect in this piece of Hollywood feces).

summary: When two sisters inherit their family castle, a string of murders committed by a mysterious dark haired woman in a red cloak decimates their circle of friends. Is the killer their ancestor, the "Red Queen" whom legend says claims seven lives every hundred years?
translation:
There are some films that every horror fanatic owes himself, and Emilio Miraglias "La Dama Rossa Uccide Sette Volte". "The Red Queen Kills Seven Times" (1972) is definitely one of them. Since Gialli and Gothic Tales were my two favorite subgenres in horror, I was really looking forward to seeing this movie for a while, and though my expectations were high, this masterpiece exceeded my highest hopes. Miraglio's earlier Giallo, "The Night That Evelyn Arised" (1971), was already a scary and highly atmospheric film that successfully blended Giallo with Gothic horror, but was unlike this personal personal favorite. "The Red Queen Kills Seven Times" is undoubtedly one of the most unique and overwhelming Italian horror films ever made, and no lover of the genre could consider missing it. An incredibly fascinating giallo with strong gothic elements. "The Red Queen" offers everything one can expect in both genres: an imaginative and incredibly captivating storyline, creepy suspense, an eerily sinister setting and a truly eerie atmosphere colors, stylish murders, a brilliant score and last but not least a gorgeous female cast Led by breathtakingly beautiful Barbara Bouchet, this film is simply one of the most outstanding combinations of elegant beauty and sheer terror.

The movie begins incredibly in a beautiful gothic castle in Germany. Kitty Wildenbr√ºck and her sister Evelyn fought as little girls when her grandfather tells the story behind an incredibly sinister painting: Legend has it that a devilish red lady should return to the castle every hundred years and kill seven people. Fourteen years later, Kitty (Barbara Bouchet) has become a successful fashion photographer. Suddenly people are being murdered ... Director Miraglia's "Evelyn's Night Out" has demonstrated his incredible talent for style, atmosphere and colorful scary, and he uses these elements in this gem much more effectively. "The Red Queen Kills Seven Times" is indeed a feast for the eyes and one of the most overwhelming Italian horror films, both visually and in terms of plot. Only the haunting painting in the grandfather's castle can give the viewer the goose bumps. The Red Lady (or Red Queen, as she's known in the English title) is probably the meanest figure in a giallo, and the scary laughter that accompanies the murders alone would be frightening.

A sexy female cast is always appreciated, especially in a giallo, and this is a prime example of it. The gorgeous Barbara Bouchet (one of my favorite actresses) has to be one of the most beautiful women ever seen on screen, and she's also a great actress. Bouchet's presence has recorded many Italian films, including playing in three of the greatest cult masterpieces of Italian cinema in the 1970s: Fernando Di Leo's "Milano Calibro 9", Lucio Fulci's Giallo highlight "Don" Tortures She is a duckling and this unforgettable jewel Apart from the wonderful Miss Bouchet, the beautiful female cast of the film includes young, sexy Sybil Danning, Marina Malfatti ("The Night Evelyn came out of the grave") and other beauties Do not be afraid to wear it for the camera.

Like the rest of the film, the murders are stylish and extremely elegant, but scary and macabre at the same time, and some of them are pretty bloody - Bruno Nicolai's captivating film music so memorable that the eerie atmosphere of the film becomes even more insistent, the plot is sophisticated and full of red herrings, the tension increases every minute. "The Red Que en ... "starts scary and remains breathtaking until the last second. Overall, this is one of the films for which I can not find enough praise. "The Red Queen Kills Seven Times" is an absolute masterpiece that is easily one of the best gialli ever made, and top priority for any horror and / or Italian horror fan. 10/10

summary: When a powerful developer named Mr. Scheck wants to knock down all the stores and houses in Arnold's neighborhood to build a huge "mall-plex", it looks likes the neighborhood is doomed to disappear. But with the help of a superhero and a mysterious deep-voiced stranger, Arnold and Gerald will need to recover a crucial document in order to save their beloved neighborhood.
translation: I like animated shows. I enjoy the Nick fare, including Hey, Arnold. However, moving a TV show to the big screen is not easy and just does not feel big enough. It was more like a long episode of the show and it just did not progress so well. Judging by the behavior of the children we had with them, it did not fare as well with them.

summary: During the Spanish Civil War, a republican courier travels to England to try and buy coal. He meets with an amount of local hostility, while his life is at risk from those on the fascist side. Support comes from an unlikely if attractive quarter.
translation: Good old black and white Graham Greene lived in dangerous times with heroic and mysterious things. Hardly a shot or a stroke, and a hundred times more interesting than the blow that shapes Hollywood today. Of course Bacall lights up the screen and Boyer is absolutely captivating. They do not make movies anymore.

summary: A young anthropomorphic cat goes on a psychedelic journey with his sister in order to save her soul.
translation:
Best animated movie ever. This film explores not only the vast world of modern animation with absolutely fluctuating effects, but also the branches of the human mind, soul and philosophy. The story reveals a cat family where the younger brother sees this in the big sister and saves her body, but when she awakes, she remains without a soul. So the two sibling cats are looking to find them. I have linked this journey with many things. The world history, the Bible, the life cycle and every time I look at it, I discover more and more hidden topics and metaphors. If you do not like the physiological aspect, you will still love it. The animation is superb and the creative scenes will attach you to the screen. For example, the ocean freezes in time, God eats soup out of the earth, a strange and slightly SNM retelling of Hansel and Gretel. Finally, Cat Soup is an absolute treat for everyone.

PS- Not for kids, including violence.

summary: Leila and Charli Hunter are in Rome to participate in a Summer Intern Program. After they begin their jobs, they are immediately fired due to careless mishaps. But Derek Hammond, who owns the company, decides to re-instate Leila and Charli. But while in Rome, Leila and Charli find true romance that will take them joyriding to see the sights throughout the city of Rome.
translation: This movie really has no beginning and no end. And it's really incredible. Mary-K and Ashley are to be interns at an Italian fashion company in a post office. But for some reason they are housed in a 5-star hotel (conveniently located opposite the Colosseum), and all the other interns they work with look just as unusual as models. One thing that I obviously found in this movie is the way one of the twins does NOT end up with the guy. I think they tried to twist their usual action a bit. Nice try.

summary: In a POW camp, the Nazis have placed the huts far from the boundary so that any escape tunnel would have to be a long one. One British officer has the idea of starting a daily gynmastics routine using a vaulting horse: they can place it near the boundary and start a tunnel from under it. He and two others do escape the camp by this means and plan to make for neutral Sweden. To do that, they'll not only have to move around without arousing any suspicions, but also find a stranger from a neutral or occupied country who'll be willing and able to help them.
translation: Excellent P.O.W. Adventure, by Eric Williams from his own book (a paperback that incorporates my father's library) inspired by true events; It is perhaps the first movie of its kind and therefore has a lot to answer? not just similar stiff upper lip examples like ALBERT, R.N. (1953, which I will just look at), THE COLDITZ STORY (1955) and DANGER WITHIN (1959), but higher-level publications from the other side of the Atlantic, namely STALAG 17 (1953) and THE GREAT ESCAPE (1963). Thus, the base is quite solid: British soldiers who are interned in a German camp, devise a brilliant escape plan and borrow a page of the Greek legend. Digging under a vaulting horse used in physical exertion and under full view of the kidnappers! Actually, the film is divided into two halves: the first is about the slow excavation of the tunnel to the flight itself, while the last stages represent their assets outside the camp, while trying to reach the neutral Sweden. Typical for these British films, the cast features several well-established (Leo Genn), current (Anthony Steel) and up-and-coming (Peter Finch, David Tomlinson and Bill Travers) stars, not to mention countless reliable character actors (Anthony Dawson), Bryan Forbes, Michael Goodliffe and Walter Gotell). The three tracks / escapes are Genn, Steel and Tomlinson: while the first two hold together, are the latter going their own way? Just to bump into the others when they're safe. As you might expect, the narrative contains much excitement and excitement; as with most male-centered P.O.W. Even the saying of women is kept to a minimum.
