How could they have gone so far? Did not you see that they made the biggest mistakes in parts 2 and 5? But they do that? It's all about the money, DO NOT SEE THESE SAD CITIZENS FOR A NACHTMARSCHEN SERIES.

I HAVE AN ALBTRAUM ON ELM STREET SIX (6) 3 out of 10.

GOOD POINTS OF FILM: Had potential with action.

BAD POINTS OF THE FILM: Awful acting / lack of dead / Too funny to be classified as horror / very confusing.

summary: Gary Reich, the man who started the hidden-camera careers of Sacha Baron Cohen (Da Ali G Show) and Dom Joly (Trigger Happy TV), has found three women to take to the streets and carry the genre just that little bit further. Nothing is sacred and no-one is safe.
translation: Imagine the scene where a couple of scriptwriters sit at a table and one says, "Have a black woman in the street speak to an unsuspecting member of the public (including black) and ask him if he's black, then go You away. " The other authors laugh hysterically until they are told to repeat them in each episode. More laughter. If you now think that the premise is funny and the show contains many such situations, you will enjoy this show. For the rest, use your zapper and find something more entertaining like looking at the color. Those who have written glowing accounts of this show should either come out more or be forced to watch television comedies that are really funny. Another example of humor in the series is a girl trying to get by at a supermarket cashier by trying to hypnotize the cashier. Marginal funny the first time, but why do you repeat it again and again in different shows with different cashiers? I could give other examples, but these could only be treated as spoilers and reveal why this comedy is just not funny.

summary: A woman moves from NYC to LA after a murder, in which she is implicated. She is followed by what is apparently her evil alter- ego. She moves into a room for rent by a writer, and he begins having an affair with her, but after some strange things happen, he's not so sure if the affair is with her or her doppelganger.
translation:
Drew Barrymore sees her alter ego over and over again in the city and it's starting to get a pain in her butt.

After Dee hires an apartment from a hacker, her encounters with "the other Drew" become more frequent. Writer Buddy feels it is his responsibility to rip "the real Drew" out of her daze, so he does what he can to help seduce her as soon as he has some spare time. Not very interesting and even less scary, but Drew is sexy as always, especially when she gives a finger to a group of rude construction workers ... yeah Drew, that's hot!

Perhaps the best scene is where Drew stabs her real mother, Jaid, with a big kitchen knife ... hmmm ... and how was your day?

summary: The Herlihys are a working class family from Chicago whose three children take wildly divergent paths: Brian joins the Marines right out of High School and goes to Vietnam, Michael becomes involved in the civil rights movement and after campaigning for Bobby Kennedy and Eugene McCarthy becomes involved in radical politics, and Katie gets pregnant, moves to San Francisco and joins a hippie commune. Meanwhile, the Taylors are an African-American family living in the deep South. When Willie Taylor, a minister and civil rights organizer, is shot to death, his son Emmet moves to the city and eventually joins the Black Panthers, serving as a bodyguard for Fred Hampton.
translation: The 60s are an occasionally entertaining movie, most of which are about laughter about the movie. It is extremely uneven and contains many disturbing elements. Take, for example, the change between black and white and color. If done right, this could be quite effective, but because it was done badly, it became a nuisance and only detrimental to the already bad experience; Much of the film had a strange feeling. The drama was not bad for a mixed movie, but on the other hand it was downright embarrassing at other times. Many of the events were incoherent and confusing in the end. How did it happen that this family was in many of the big events in the 60s? The end was far too cheesy for my taste; because it was hollywoodized, everything had to go out in the end. I would advise you not to waste your time in the sixties and do something different with your time. I'm glad I saw it in class, not at my own time. I think I can say for sure that the best part of the movie was the recording of Bob Dylan's music. These are just my extravagant thoughts about the movie. I hope you take my advice and stay away from it.

summary: The Muppets graduate from college and decide to take their senior revue on the road. They hit the streets of Manhattan trying to sell their show to producers, finally finding one young and idealistic enough to take their show. After several mishaps and much confusion, things begin to come together for them.
translation: The third Muppet movie is perhaps the most relaxed and enjoyable, with the gang filling its modest college musical with the bright (but volatile) lights of Broadway with typically naive optimism. Of course, their first attempt fails and Kermit (leader of the group and author of the show) blows his top; So the others all go their separate ways so that he does not feel responsible for them. Kermit herself makes friends with a young wannabe fashion designer who makes ends meet by serving food in her dad's restaurant (the old man then has a snake in particularly tortuous non-reservations!). We get the usual cameo appearances from a variety of stars: Art Carney (as producer), James Coco (as overzealous dog owner), Dabney Coleman (as con artist), Elliott Gould (who also starred in THE MUPPET MOVIE [1979]), Gregory Hines, Liza Minnelli (as she herself replaces her portrait in a classic restaurant with Kermit, with a fake mustache, as a supposedly celebrated entrepreneur in a ruse to promote the Muppets show), Brooke Shields, and even director John Landis (Perhaps the funniest scene in the movie as a Broadway producer, before which Kermit behaves like an actor who behaves like a street musician and merrily rides around sunglasses and an afro wig!). The other Muppets go through more or less their typical steps, but this time Gonzo has (unfortunately) less space; while Miss Piggy is something of an acquired taste with me, the scenes in which the latter spies on what she takes to be Kermit's romance with the waitress? and above all, her violent reaction to it? are undeniably funny. summary: An evil ruler uses witchcraft and evil spirits to keep his subjects in line, but the his reign of terror prompts the people to revolt.
translation: I tend to love everything the great late Paul Naschy (R.I.P.) has ever done. Although not all films are great with Naschy, they all have a special charm that can not be found anywhere else than in Naschy movies, and they are always entertaining. However, there is no exception without exception, such as "El Mariscal del Infierno" aka. "The Devil's Possessed" (1974) proves. While the film has the specific Naschy-Flick charm, unfortunately it draws way too much and gets really, really boring in between. Naschy plays the evil baron Gilles De Lancr√©, who oppresses people and uses black magic and bloody rituals to stay in power. As Gaston de Malebranche (Guillermo Bredeston), who fought side by side with Gilles De Lancr√© against the British, learns of the bad behavior of the Baron, he decides to turn against his former comrades in arms and to liberate the people from the satanic baron rule. Directed by Le√≥n Klimovsky, who is best known for directing Naschy's "La Noche De Walpurgis" (1971), the screenplay is by Naschy himself. Naschy often wrote his own films, and one I have to say that most of the time he did a better, more original job than is the case here. "El Mariscal del Infierno" is more of a historical adventure than a horror movie, and in the middle it gets pretty boring. It often resembles the Sword and Sandal films of the 50s, except that this film plays in the Middle Ages. The satanic part was probably added only because the name of the great Paul Naschy is associated with the horror genre. The film has its good sides: Paul Naschy makes strange speeches, Paul Naschy looks weird, Paul Naschy makes satanic stuff, Paul Naschy tortures innocent victims, etc. But unfortunately most of the film focuses on the boring hero and the good guys, and These moments are boring. The female actors are nice to look at, but unlike most Naschy films, they have no nudity and no veil. While there is some blood, it usually looks clumsy and is not as fun as most other Naschy films do. Overall, "El Mariscal Del Infierno" is worth a look only for my Naschy enthusiasts. There are dozens of films with the Spanish horror deity to be seen before this, such as "El Jorobado De La Morgue" (1973), "La Orgia De Los Muertos" ("The Hanging Woman", 1973) , "El Espanto Surge De La Tumba" (1973), "Latidos De Panico" ("Panic Beats", 1983), "Rojo Sangre" (2004) or another of the "Waldemar Daninsky" Werewolf films. REST IN PEACE. Paul Nashy. Legends never die!

summary: When her sister is kidnapped by white slavers, only Grandpa knows what to do. He puts in a call to a fictional hero, Jake Speed. She is amazed to find that he actually exists, and that as flesh and blood, is much less formidable than his reputation.
translation: Do not be fooled by the name of this movie; in fact, Jake Speed's character may be the laziest action hero you can ever film. When Jake Speed ‚Äã‚Äãdoes not rescue virgin girls from the bad madman, which he often is not, he relaxes seriously. Maybe that adds to his charm, but in my opinion, an action hero should not "chill" when he has the chance. Besides, unlike other brave heroes who usually have an impressive list of talents, this man has no, unless of course, you sleep a talent to sleep. Anyway, this movie is basically worthless, the writing is below average and the plot, if any, is very lame. (The machine guns on the Jeep were not bad, but that's it) So, if you're in the mood to see a movie that's a cure for insomnia, then this piece is perfect for you - it has a hero, he not only sleeps, but also his audience.

summary: Based on the famous novel by Emile Zola. The vivacious and beautiful Nana seeks fame on the stages of Paris in the shows at the Th√©√¢tre des Vari√©t√©s. (which will look familiar to lovers of "Children of Paradise"). When she bombs as an actress, Nana becomes a courtesan, using her allure and charisma more directly to entice and pleasure men. She is kept in a sumptuous fashion by a wealthy count, and several prominent and wealthy men find themselves unable to withstand her charms. In the novel, the theater manager describe Nana: "Nana has something else, dammit, and something that takes the place of everything else. I scented it out, and it smells damnably strong in her, or else I lost my sense of smell." But there's a pain and a pathos at the heart of Nana's situation, and it slowly makes its poisonous way into the lives of all in Nana's orbit.
translation:
When Jean Renoir's first movie "Whirlpool of Fate" takes us into the world of the countryside, the rivers, the peasantry, which he will continue to explore, it seems only fitting that his second film be largely with the rich and privileged, the upper ones Classes and those who want to fight their way up. Put the characters from the first two films together and you have the seeds of his great "Grand Illusion" and "Rules of the Game". This is beautifully filmed, with the restless camera taking full advantage of the amazingly large apartments and backstage areas that dominate the interior of the movie, and the often-outdated drama also offers some great moments, especially from Werner Krauss's Muffat. But the glamorous and sultry Ms. Hessling, who seems to be giving Louise Brooks a run for her money in vampire-seeking, never goes beyond a monotonous, selfish whoredom. Maybe this is partly a problem with the script, which mostly causes highlights and indignant emotions; If I did not read the novel, I'm not really sure if the decisions were good or not.

Nevertheless, the differences between the candidates of Nanas have been good, and I especially liked the relationship between Muffat and Jean Angelos Vandeuvres - the tragic understanding that everyone seems to have of his last fate and sympathy, especially in the scene at the foot of the huge staircase where Vandeuvres warns Muffat and we wonder if violence will break out - these and other glimpses of the lazy rich ridiculous help to give the movie the depth it has.

Far from his greatest achievement, and for me probably just the shy overall of "Whirlpool of Destiny," this is still worth seeing for Renoir fans or anyone else interested in silent film.

summary: Sandy and Phil, both Overseas Workers in Dubai, are busy preparing for their wedding. Upon reaching her home, Sandy learns from her mother, Daisy, what happened to her friend, Helen. A short time after Helen's father died, Helen proceeded with her wedding. A few weeks after the wedding, Helen's husband dies in a plane crash. As Helen goes to the crash site, she dies in a bus accident. A few weeks later, Helen's mother suddenly disappears inside her house. Their bodies have never been recovered. Sandy proceeds with her own wedding. During the ceremony, she suffers from nosebleed and starts seeing glimpses of a ghostly flower girl. It turns out that she is not the only one who saw it. Maja, a psychic and the daughter of her husband's cousin, also saw the flower girl. Hours later, Sandy and Phil learn that the van carrying some of the secondary sponsors met an accident. When they get to the site, the bodies of the victims could not be found. Instead, they see a bridal cord. Sandy's ...
translation:
I would have given this movie a 1 out of 10 if it had not been for MS. Claudine Barretto's performance. and I will take this time to overlook that Kris Aquino is here. and ... end.

I really HID to see Pinoy horror movies because stories lacks originality and I really think that (some) writers do not pay enough attention to the characters (and their progression) in their stories (superfluous?). It was as if they were pushing the film if their storytelling stank. and my goodness, creative exhaustion has made her rip off other films. Why?? Why did this movie get a good rating? I would not deserve it that much. The movie was scary to KIND OF, but the movie seemed a little wackier as it has to do with Filipino folklore ... it's in my "most likely" category list. I just wish they spent more time improving the storylines and repairing those flashback sequences, no matter if the lighting leaked, it would not matter much if the content was going to blow you away. SAYANG.

summary: While taking a shower, Kate Miller, a middle-aged, sexually frustrated New York City housewife, has a rape fantasy while her husband stands at the sink shaving. Later that day, after complaining to her psychiatrist Dr. Robert Elliott about her husband's pathetic performance in bed, she meets a strange man at a museum and returns to his apartment where they continue an adulterous encounter that began in the taxicab. Before she leaves his apartment, she finds papers which certify that the man has a venereal disease. Panicked, Kate rushes into the elevator, but has to return to his apartment when she realizes she's forgotten her wedding ring. When the elevator doors open, she's brutally slashed to death by a tall blonde woman wearing dark sunglasses. Liz Blake, a high-class call girl, is the only witness to the murder and she becomes the prime suspect and the murderess's next target. Liz is rescued from being killed by Kate's son Peter, who enlists the help of Liz to catch his mother's ...
translation:
Typical De Palma movie with a lot of style and some scenes that bring you to the limits of your place.

Certainly, what makes this movie better as an average thriller is the style. It has some brilliantly edited scenes and some scenes that are really nerve-wracking that will take you to the edge of your place. The best scene is from the movie; The museum scene and the elevator murder. There are some mild erotic scenes and the speed of the movie may not be fast enough to show this movie to the casual viewer. So maybe this movie is not for everyone.

The story itself is pretty good too, but it's really the style that makes the movie work! It could only be for the fans, but occasional viewers should also appreciate the well-developed tension in the film.

There are some nice characters represented by a good cast. Michael Caine is an interesting casting choice and Angie Dickinson looks just as good as she looks (not bad for a 49 year old!).

The music of Pino Donaggio is also typical De Palma likes and fits the movie very well, as well as his score for the other De Palma movie "Body Double".

Brilliant Nerv Wrecking Thriller. I love De Palma!

10/10

summary: A documentary-style drama which questions the existence of a monster in an Arkansas swamp. It is really more of a glimpse at lower-class swamp culture from the seventies, though, than a monster flick.
translation: This gritty movie has cult status and one of the word of mouth features you've just seen. Perhaps hard to believe, but there is a rural community in southwest Arkansas, Fouke, who knows that the legend is true. This story is told in a documentary style and narrated by Vern Stierman. The legend changes with storytelling, but in the late '60s and most of the' 70s, the area around Fouke was visited by a Bigfoot-like creature traveling along Boggy Creek. Long-legged with three toes and over 7 feet high, this hairy creature periodically caused damage and scared the "bejeebers" of most communities. Personally, I crossed the small Boggy Creek Bridge in 1974, and yes, the hair on my neck has risen. Of course it was around 1 o'clock in the morning in the rain. When I arrived in Shreveport, I laughed.

summary: A GI in Vietnam saves his buddy's life, but in the process is shot in the head. The injury results in brain damage to the point where he basically has a child's brain in a (very large) man's body. When they get out of the army the two open up a bar together, but some local gangsters make things tough for them after they refuse to take part in brutal "cage" matches where fighters battle to the point of serious injury and/or death.
translation: I hired this movie to see what a dumb non-stop action movie might be, and got this over-the-top, low-budget action drama, which makes kickboxing like Die Hard. Lou and Reb are in Vietnam and Lou saves Reb from sight, he is shot in the head, which is probably one of the worst effects of all time. The Vietnam scenes are shot in a backyard, I swear! Lou is brain damaged now and Reb and he live together and own a bar. Super homoerotic. Lou is convinced to fight for money in a cage and Reb goes on a rampage to get him back. There are no good fighting scenes, the strokes are two inches from a person. Characters Personalities change in seconds. One guy is bad and in the next scene he is good. The acting is awful and the music is an overly sentimental Frank Stallone sounding song that would make you sick. I hated this movie.

summary: In 1896, Jeff Webster sees the start of the Klondike gold rush as a golden opportunity to make a fortune in beef, and woe betide anyone standing in his way. He drives a cattle herd from Wyoming to Seattle, by ship to Skagway, and (after a delay caused by larcenous town boss Gannon) through the mountains to Dawson. There, he and his partner Ben Tatum get into the gold business themselves. Two lovely women fall for misanthropic Jeff, but he believes in every-man-for-himself, turning his back on growing lawlessness, until it finally strikes home.
translation:
The penultimate collaboration between director Anthony Mann and star James Stewart (apart from the few days that Mann worked on Night Passage before parting with the star under less than friendly circumstances) refutes the Far Country's mainstream look Showing another portrait of a bitter man. Reluctant to his own salvation, they fight every step of the way. This time around, he's a drover whose response to work-related problems - provoking annoying cowherd men to a shoot-out at the end of the road - leads to his cattle being confiscated by John McIntire's predatory Judge of the Roy Bean School of Law and Order. They steal her back and take her across the Canadian border, he soon reluctantly finds himself in the growing conflict between miners and the judge as he cheats or kills her from her claims ...

While not A big surprise is how Stewart turns in the end, he is a surprisingly callous creature along the way, even with his desire to simply be left alone so as not to warn a group of prospectors of an impending avalanche when he dies Chance has, because it is not his problem. For most of the movie, there's only a hair's breadth between him and McIntire, something that the judge instantly recognizes and indulges in the company of a like mind, though he prefers to lynch him. In many ways, the citizens who have trusted him probably also recognize it - despite their appeals to his deceased, better nature, there is an unspoken recognition that the only person who can resist the judge is almost as bad as he is ,

As usual with Mann, there is an exceptional use of Highland locations, though for once the final showdown takes place on level ground, and the film is almost perfectly staffed with strong support from Walter Brennan, Harry Morgan and Ruth Roman (although Corinne Calvert's young romantic interest is aimed at the irritant). Unfortunately, the great Cinematography of the Canadian Rockies is favored by a significantly average DVD transfer, only the movie trailer as an extra.

summary: Set in the late 1920s, The Luzhin Defence tells the story of a shambling, unworldly chess Grand Master who arrives in the Italian Lakes to play the match of his life and unexpectedly finds the love of his life. Discovering his prodigious talent in boyhood overshadowed by his parents' failing marriage, Luzhin's lyrical passion for chess has become his refuge and rendered the real world a phantom. Already matched up by her family to the very suitable Comte de Stassard, when Natalia meets Luzhin, she is drawn to the erratic genius and offers him a glimpse outside of his chess obsession. But it is a world he is not equipped to deal with and his two worlds collide to tragic effect.
translation: The storyline was pretty interesting, but the characters were rather shallow and sometimes too extreme in their thoughts / behaviors. More extreme than necessary. I also think something went wrong with the casting. John Turtorro does not really satisfy me when I play a semi-autistic chess player so as not to speak of the Italian player. Motives were also not very outlined.

summary: The morbid Catholic writer Gerard Reve who is bisexual, alcoholic and has frequent visions of death is invited to give a lecture in the literature club of Vlissingen. While in the railway station in Amsterdam, he feels attracted to a handsome man who embarks on another train. Gerard is introduced to the treasurer of the club and beautician Christine Halsslag, a wealthy widow who owns the Spider beauty shop, and they engage in a one night stand. On the next morning, Gerard sees the picture of Christine's boyfriend Herman and recognizes him as the man he saw in the train station. He urges her to bring Herman to her house to spend a couple of days together, but with the secret intention of seducing the man. Christine travels to K√∂ln to bring her boyfriend and Gerard stays alone in her house. He drinks whiskey and snoops through her safe, finding three film reels with names of men; he decides to watch the footage and discovers that Christine had married each; all of whom died in tragic ...
translation: When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and erotic thrillers, most people think of "Basic Instinct" and some of "Showgirls." But Verhoeven has done his best erotic thriller years before these two films: "De Vierde Man". This movie is mesmerizing and overwhelming - and most of all, the story is absolutely plausible, which makes the whole experience even more intense. The performances of Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are extraordinary, and Verhoeven does the rest. "De Vierde Man" makes even "Basic Instinct" look pretty tame ... It could not be better, a true classic of erotic nightmare cinema. 10 out of 10, at least ...

summary: Vampires fighting zombies.
translation:
Vampires Vs. Zombies was not the original title. It was actually ...

Nasty Lesbian Semi-Vampires and Two Zombies Getting hit by cars: Special guest appearances by Bob the Lesbian Gypsie-Witch and her dog, Random Woman with special powers and the Catholic school girl - short rock zombie choir.

Also on the box: Warning: No plot - only the writer and the director understand the end or something else in this movie.

Seriously, I love bad movies. I love vampires. I love zombies. Hell, I even enjoy the lesbians. This film combined all three with a vague and confusing (or nonexistent) plot, horrendous (I mean REALLY BAD) dialogues, and random STUFF and PEOPLE who have nothing to do with anything (or have them ... I do not know what in the world is going on). Oh, and I can not forget the green oatmeal "zombies" in latex gloves (yes, the filmmakers were so cheap that they could not even cover their zombie hands in oatmeal and color). Anyway, the result was this torturously bad movie, if you could call it that.

Should the end make no sense? The vampire was really a nurse and the other girl was really a mental patient? Where were the Vampires Vs. Zombies? Hell, where were the vampires anyway ... you really could not call girls vampires. What ever.

Do not rent or buy this movie. If you are really curious ... okay, I'll understand. Seriously, even lovers of BAD movies will not stand it. It should be number 1 on the bottom 100.

summary: After a terrible day, two good friends and housemates find the outside world converted into a featureless and empty white void.
translation:
I saw the trailer on the DVD after watching the movie, and I think anyone who saw it before watching the movie would be very surprised and possibly disappointed. It made a big deal of the film being "by the director of Cube" and making it look like a horror movie, though it's actually an absurd comedy (IMDB's spell checker does not seem to think that Absurdist is a word, but it does) Rosencrantz and Guildernstern are Dead.

I love the way the story builds up slowly, then gradually escalates. I also enjoy the fact that no explanation is given what happens in the movie. That and the fact that the story mainly plays in just one movement are the only aspects in which this movie resembles Cube. I recommend it.

summary: A series of dances inspired by composer Isaac Alb√©niz's "Iberia" suite.
translation: I've never danced flamenco before, but somehow I feel like this movie was perfect. The colors, how blunt the dances were, the gypsies and rivals all together made a movie that seemed to end too soon. I have seen other Carlos Saura films and agree that this film could be his best production. I feel that the best qualities of his earlier films have been put together and aligned to make Iberia. I appreciate the use of mirrors to reveal the activities behind the cameras. As I watched this movie, I felt like I was sitting in a small restaurant in Madrid, watching the dancers leisurely pop into a wooden plank over a delicious fruit cocktail. For me, this film fits like a glove. I do not know how I'll get a copy of this movie in the US in the next few years. I recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in the livelihood of other cultures. It's safe to say that this movie is certainly on my favorites list.

summary: A jilted husband takes his revenge by filming his wife and her lover and showing the result at the local cinema. This was one of Starewicz' first animated films, and stars very realistic animated beetles.
translation: Ladislas Starewicz's curiosity about insects and cinema culminates in a short film about a love triangle between Mr. Beetle, a synthetic grasshopper, and Mrs. Beetle. The rather simple story of an adulterous beetle pair seeking both stimulation outside of their marriage is similar to a biographer or vitagraph short in time. Starewicz's story revolves around the use of embalmed beetles with wires that stretch legs in a single-frame animation. The story begins when Mr. Beetle is unknowingly caught in front of the camera by a jealous locust with a dragonfly from the local nightclub. When Mr. Beetle comes home to find his wife in the arms of her artistic friend, he chases her around angrily, but finally forgives her and takes her to watch a movie. However, Mrs. Beetle soon finds out about her husband's unfaithfulness as the movie they see is the jealous grasshopper of Mr. Beetle and the dragonfly. Mrs. Beetle hits Mr. Beetle with her umbrella, Mr. Beetle jumps through the screen, and they both end up in jail after the projector they've captured goes up in flames. The insects are placed in humanized environments such as a house or a nightclub and receive human characteristics such as jealousy, anger, lust and revenge. The insect figures carry briefcases, drive cars and even wear shoes, but they also twitch their antennae and open and close their jaws like real insects. The novelty of the story is not exhausted, even after several considerations, but as fluid as the movements are, the film moves slowly. Action happens with complicated details, but speed and a faster speed of filming is lost. Despite its speed, the film is a prime example of Starewicz's early puppetry and is highly recommended.

summary: Haunted by nightmares. Plagued by a past that won't go away. When Maddy goes to a party with her new boyfriend, Shawn, she only wants to meet his friends and have a good time. They tell her about their 'Murder Club' and invite her to join. Confused but intrigued, Maddy really wants to be part of the group. Before she can join, though, the 'Murder Club' members are being killed off, one by one. Who can be trusted? Can the killer be stopped? Or will they all bleed?
translation:
Unfortunately, more downs than ups. The plot was pretty decent. I mean, nothing extraordinary, but it had a story, unlike the other modern horror movies. The other good thing was the cast. I'm not saying the drama was good because it was not, but every actor / actress was hot and attractive.

One of the lows is that the movie will only get exciting after the first 40 minutes or so. The rest was pretty boring. Another downside (or you could use it as an up if you want to) is the excessive nudity. All 4 girls were topless for a few minutes and all the guys showed their butts for a long time. It's not that I'm against nudity, but that was a horror movie, not 'The Dreamers'.

Unless you are very desperate to see a guy take off his swimsuit and walk around naked for a few minutes, or watch a girl go nude for no reason, or you're a die-hard fan of Debbie Rochon, as this is the movie for you. But if you're looking for a good horror movie, stay away.

summary: "The Wedding Date" centers around Kat Ellis (Messing), who returns to her parents' London home for her sister's wedding. Afraid of confronting her ex-fianc√©, who dumped her two years before, she hires a top-drawer male escort (Mulroney) to pose as her new boyfriend.
translation:
Too much of something borrowed Class B -

Super Bowl Sunday is one of the slowest days in cinemas every year. For this reason, movie studios tend to avoid larger budget movies on the weekend. Every few years, a studio publishes an opposite women's movie (2001: "The Wedding Planner") to compete with the big game. Entitled "The Wedding Date," this Super Bowl weekend will seek to succeed and attract viewers who are not watching the game.

Sick of people who feel sorry for her, single-woman, Kat-Ellis (Debra Messing, TV "Will and Grace") hires male escort Nick (Dermot Mulrony, "About Schmidt"), to ask her as her friend for her sister's wedding in London. Her family has made it difficult for her not to be married, and her ex-boyfriend of seven, who has left her for no reason, is the best man. To make him jealous Kat cat catapults her ex so he sees what he misses. But in the end, Nick Kat helps to realize that she can open up and someone loves her.

The movie borrows too much from similar wedding movies. It is almost a 1999 punch "Picture Perfect" and mixes in scenes similar to "The Wedding Planner" and "My Best Friends Wedding". The film also has a reverse "Pretty Women" theme, and since it knows its audience, the director makes clever references to this and other films.

"The Wedding Date" has all the clich√©d elements of a typical wedding movie is the stereotypical dominant mother (Holland Taylor, "Legally Blonde") and practically plagiarized wedding speeches of the family and friends at the wedding and rehearsal dinner. The turn at the end was made before, but it was something that was not fully expected. The real reason why Kat was dumped is surprising and changes the direction of the movie for the last half hour.

Although "The Wedding Date" is predictable, it can be alone. Debra Messing, in her first lead, proves that she can be charming and funny. Dermot Mulrony has a great chemistry with Debra Messing, but most of his dialogues were too bleak and unrealistic. He is able to make the most of what he has been given and to be able to save the character.

The use of many clever puns (often sexual) makes the movie funny. Although it's mostly a chick-flick, the movie has components that everyone can enjoy. The good mood story and humor make it the best date movie released in a long time.

summary: Iago convinces Othello, The Moor of Venice that his wife, Desdemona has been unfaithful. Iago is an evil, manipulative character with his own agenda. A plot of jealousy and rage transpires in this classic Shakespearean tale.
translation:
I've always enjoyed Kenneth Branagh's versions of the Shakespearean classics, as he's always doing a very good job, but in this movie, the one who stars in the movie is nothing but "the always-great-actor" Laurence Fishburne. Surely he's made some bad decisions in movies, even though he's a wonderful actor, but in this we really have the real Othello: the passion, the intensity of jealousy, as she gets stronger along with Fishburn's well-portrayed paranoia and besides, we finally have a black Othello!

I do not think they could have chosen a better Othello. Who else could have given him that mixture of sympathy / antipathy, love / hate and, not to forget, those fiery eyes ...? Branagh is good as always, but not at his peak, Ir√©ne Jacobs Desdemona is pretty good, but a bit bleak, while Laurence Fishburne really lifts her and makes it a very interesting and entertaining movie. Look at it.

summary: At the end of the 1950s, in a more innocent America, the brutal, meaningless slaying of a Midwestern family horrified the nation. This film is based on Truman Capote's hauntingly detailed, psychologically penetrating nonfiction novel. While in prison, Dick Hickock, 28, hears a cell-mate's story about $10,000 in cash kept in a home safe by a prosperous rancher. When he's paroled, Dick persuades ex-con Perry Smith, 31, to join him in going after the stash. On a November night in 1959, Dick and Perry break into the Holcomb, Kansas, house of Herb Clutter. Enraged at finding no safe, they wake the sleeping family and brutally kill them all. The bodies are found by two friends who come by before Sunday church. The murders shock the small Great Plains town, where doors are routinely left unlocked. Detective Alvin Dewey of the Kansas Bureau of Investigation heads the case, but there are no clues, no apparent motive and no suspects...
translation: I'm from Sweden and I have just watched this movie and the thing is that I thought it was alright. I've seen a lot of bad comments about it, but you have to remember that many people who see this two-part miniseries are around the world, not just in the US. Remember too, that not everyone has ever heard of the movie that was made in the 1960's and maybe not in the events (murders). And even more ... that it's hard to find the original movie and if so, then there are always people who do not like black and white movies. This one feels fresh and in color and will find its publicity. It is now 12 years old, but I saw it for the first time. I will try to find the first one if I compare them, but I have not seen them anywhere in Sweden. Ofcorse is internet but not for anyone in the world. The thing here is that this is largely part of an American crime story and in the 50-60: s was just great in just USA, but in the rest of the world it just over by, I think. Well, it has been told for some time, but 40 years later it will disappear in Europe, for example, as time goes by. We had our own problems and crimes. So, if someone makes the remake of the movie and puts it back into the light, that's not a bad idea. A new generation can take part in this terrible story and even the movie about Capote, which was released a few years ago, was also a pretty good movie, I think. It will boost interest in the events that took place about 50 years ago and perhaps prevent it from falling asleep. It started me and now I'm looking for the Robert Blake version, so it was not that bad ... huh? These are my opinions. Of course, some people will not agree, but hey ... it's okay. Sometimes it will be good to do remakes on old films. It's not every time that the old ones are so good. The techniques of filmmaking have evolved a lot and scenes can become more realistic if they want it today. It's always a question of money, of course. There were so many films made in the "good old days," but they also lacked money, bad directors, etc., and they're redoing them today (fifty years later) and suddenly they're alright. My friend got this box of old classic horror movies and s / f and I can not say that I was impressed by the so-called good old days. Most of them are placed in the dustbin in the bin. They were so bad that we just sat there like zombies ... could not move ... like brain dead. I can not recommend it to anyone. Some of them I have seen remakes of and I remember liking them ... but not the originals. They were just painfully horrible. That's like in the old story, who was the best Bond ... Moore or Connery ... I think if you first see Roger Moore, then you might find the one you trust or like ... Thanks for me and I'm sorry my english, that's not so good. / Lars from Sweden

summary: A group of hobgoblins, who allow you to live out your fantasies but kill you in the process, escape from a studio vault, and a security guard and his friends must stop them before dawn.
translation: Even for the 80s cocaine, that's pathetic. I do not understand why someone wants to waste celluloid, time, performance, money and audience brain cells to do this. If you want to do a comedy, make fun of it. If you want to film garbage like that, keep it to yourself. If you want to publish it as a joke: NOT !!! I mean, it was a joke, right? Someone tell me, that was a joke. You're welcome.

summary: Sort of a low-budget Short Cuts (1993), set in the Flemish port city of Antwerp on a warm day in June. Natalie, her brother Chouki, her boyfriend Walter and his ex Lara, the gallery keeper Firmin, unhappily married French language teacher Paul Garcin, a couple of party-loving studs from Ghent (another Flemish city) and the enigmatic Windman, independently go about their lives, which have little in common, yet all end up on the same place for a grand party that evening.
translation:
Barman just wanted to make a movie because he wanted. Just as easy and successful. Not only in his goal, but also in making a wonderful movie, especially visually. He knows how to use pans, slow-motion sequences, camera shots, crane shots, etc. in a nice, smooth way. This gives the movie a very relaxing feeling.

The story is about the lives of 8 very different characters who have nothing in common except one thing: a party they all visit, which is also the turning point of this movie. The beauty of this image is not the question of how the characters interact (compared to a similar, of course, better movie like Magnolia). I just do not think that was Barman's idea. The beauty lies in the various details of the experiences that people go through making or breaking their lives. Barman is very successful in telling these little stories that describe small experiences. He knows people ... and Antwerp.

The soundtrack of the film is also excellent, but no surprise, because we know that Barman is also a very successful songwriter and musician with his band dEUS. The music is sometimes hot and relaxing at the same time, which contributes to the film's sunny, soft feel. Other times we hear funky pop / rock tunes that give some scenes the strength they need.

There is only one mistake and that is the last half hour. Was it the runtime that broke me? Or were the last scenes not as fresh and exactly as the scenes until then? I can not find it out ...

All in all a beautiful sunny movie that lifts the Belgian cinema.

8 out of 10!

summary: Set in the 30s, Helen and Adelle are two women whose sons commit a gruesome murder. After their conviction, they move to Hollywood change their names and open a dance school for girls. Adelle is looking for a good life and when one of the parents of her students who is wealthy takes a liking to her she thinks she's got it made. Helen thinks that someone who blames them for what their sons did is stalking them. But Adelle thinks it's all in her mind.
translation:
The 1930s. The posh, elegant Adele (wonderfully played by Debbie Reynolds with dignified determination) and the beefy, stale Helen (the magnificent Shelley Winters, who runs at full speed with her usual histrionic talent) are the mothers of two killers. Leaving behind their cheesy midwestern past, they move to Hollywood to start their own dance school for aspiring children's starlets. Adele begins to date brisk millionaire Lincoln Palmer (the always-fine Dennis Weaver). On the other hand, the religious fanatic Helen soon falls into despair and madness.

Director Curtis ("Night Tide", "Ruby") Harrington, works for a clever script by Henry Farrell (who wrote the book) "Whatever Happed to Baby Jane?" Based on the script for "Hush ... Hush, Sweet Charlotte" and co-writing a complex and compelling psychological horror thriller about guilt, fear, oppression and religious zeal amok. The super cast has a ball with its colorful roles: Michael MacLiammoir as a pompous speech teacher, Agnes Moorehead as a serious fire-and-sulfur radio speaker, Yvette Vickers as a snide, overbearing mother of a bright-eyed wannabe kid star, Logan Ramsey as a sneaky detective, and Timothy Carey as a scary bum. An ingenious talent recital set piece featuring Pamelyn Ferdin (the voice of Lucy in the "Peanuts" TV cartoon specials) serves as a showman and original "Friday the 13th." Victim Robbi Morgan makes a wickedly indecent dead Mae West impression qualifies as a specific marker. David Raskin's scary score, a fantastic scene with Reynolds performing an incredible tango in a posh restaurant, the imaginative time of depression, Lucien Ballard's pretty cinematography, and above all, the macabre ending, are all excellent and effective. MGM presents this grandiose gem on a chic DVD double sheet featuring "Who Aunt Roo?" Both images are presented along with their cinema trailers in razor-sharp widescreen broadcasts.

summary: In the near future, Japan is ruled once more by a monarchy. But, rebels opposed to this rule seek to overthrow the government. The House of Takemikazuchi, a band of assassins is hired by the government to suppress the rebels. As a conspiracy from within signals the shadowy organization's impending demise, Yuki, the last of the Takemikazuchi bloodline befriends one of the rebels and seeks revenge against the group's leader.
translation:
In the recent move to bring Asian films to America, this is THE LAST movie to be released here. Because I'm a big fan of Asian films from all genres, I spotted the Internet and came across this problem to be re-released on the US market. That's why I decided to check it out in advance and rent it in a video store Trust me ... the action scenes are unbelievably disappointing, Crouching Tiger and Iron Monkey have completely blown this movie out of the water. Jet Li would fall asleep watching the combat sequences. If you're looking for martial arts entertainment, your time with a Jackie Chan movie would be better.

Also ... think you'll see a martial art with about one girl in revenge for her parents' death BUT SURPRISE !!! A good hour of this film in the middle is filled with dialogues, a lack of action, the lack of developing a tangent plot that is pretty much NOTHING about the premise that we're exposed to. It has more to do with the relationship between her and the boy, as well as with the boy with his conspiracy group, where the producer / director did not have time to do the Elba work, and yet devoted a part of the film to the topic. It would have been much better if they had just cut this whole hour and had developed the story in themselves through another film and had focused on the martial arts aspect. Speaking of which, I really do not believe in the choreographer of Iron Monkey who has the action sequence in Princess Blade. I was utterly offended by the frequent use of slow motion and fast camera shots to illustrate the physical speed of the assassins. I just did not buy it.

Please ... I warn you please PLEASE do not waste your time / money with this movie. The premise is intriguing, and the trailer might even seduce you, but I'm convinced that this movie is NOT for the public (maybe in Japan, but not in the States) and will be the worst movie from the Asian movie in the states is brought industry.

summary: A film about struggling to deal with paralysis. Author Joel Garcia breaks his neck while hiking, and finds himself in a rehabilitation centre with Raymond, an exaggerating ladies' man, and Bloss, a racist biker. Considerable tension builds as each character tries to deal with his new found handicap and the problems that go with it, especially Joel, whose lover Anna is having as difficult a time as he is. As Raymond reveals a dream about dancing on the surface of a lake to stay afloat, it becomes apparent that each of them must find his own Waterdance to survive his tragedy.
translation:
I know, that's not what you expect from a movie with this kind of descent - it's a direct descendant of the best years of our lives.

and the men ... movies about men who live in the Hospital are.

Handling tragic circumstances. But this movie is full of wonderful

surprises and performances. It features outstanding performances by Eric Stoltz and Helen Hunt (including a rather risky nude scene) and Wesley Snipes and William Forsythe. As Emanuel Levy wrote

in his book Cinema of Outsiders (about the Independent Film

Movement), "The Waterdance is coherent, attentive to details and

unsentimental with a wicked, down to earth humor - it's suddenly

funny and sad, and the whole cast is impressive. I was very moved by this movie, it's hard to beat, yes, but has also very tender moments and laugh loud moments, a rare gem.

summary: Chaos unfolds as Tom is roped into being a pallbearer (and delivering the eulogy!) by the mother of a recently deceased "friend" from high school that he just can't remember. In the meantime, an unrequited love from high school (NOT the dead guy's girlfriend) reappears in his life.
translation: This movie is being promoted as a smart love comedy. It's neither smart nor romantic and it's definitely not an effective comedy. The fortunes of well-meaning but pathetic character "Tom" oscillate from one extremely embarrassing catastrophe to the next. The only redeeming graces are the competent performance of Toni Collete and the frequency with which we see Paltrow's pleasant face. To avoid altogether!

summary: A young man with a talent for music has begun a career with much promise. He meets an aspiring singer, Apollonia, and finds that talent alone isn't all that he needs. A complicated tale of his repeating his father's self destructive behavior, losing Apollonia to another singer (Morris Day), and his coming to grips with his own connection to other people ensues.
translation: I will begin by telling my first encounter with Prince's music. It was in a bar on my 39th birthday and a girl danced naked breasted to "1999" played on the speakers. I asked people, who is this singer? I was told that it was Prince. It was so good that it distracted me from a beautiful, topless dancer. Later, I started listening to other Prince songs and really "digging". When Purple Rain came out, I knew very little about this guy, Minnesotan. The movie blew me away. I immediately became Prince No. 1 fan of the "War Baby" generation. Later I found out that one of my cousins ‚Äã‚Äãwas his secretary, and she put me and my nephew in a V.I.P. Prince concert where we sat next to his mother ... how cool is that! Returning to the subject, I agree with Siskel & Ebert, who calls Purple Rain an instant classic. I have seen it over 17 times and absolutely love it. I thought Prince's acting was okay, Apollonia fought a bit, but all in all, the acting was fine. John Gielgud was not available to play "The Kid," so Prince took over the role. The film is visually stunning, brilliantly in tact (he never gets slow) and is incredibly purposeful. I count it among the best film musicals of all time. The last time I saw it was after about 7 years break and it still delivered. I'm so proud of my Minnesotan Prince Rogers Nelson and would love to tell him in person. He ran right in front of me during the concert mentioned above and said "Hi" to my nephew but not to me. He talked to his mother. I was a bit depressed, but he is still No. 1 with me.

summary: Oh no! It appears as if Satan isn't going to fill his soul quota this month! So of course, he turns himself into a tour guide and takes a bus-load of unsuspecting tourists on a ride down the highway to hell.
translation: Do you know how sometimes you can watch a crappy movie with friends and laugh about all the shortcomings of the movie? Well, that was beyond. I bought the DVD from Tower Records because it was like $ 3.00 and I had heard that this was a movie to laugh about. It's nothing short of pathetic. After an hour, we compromised to advance to the end, so we could see how the conflict was resolved (and because we had been watching Matt Walsh all the time). Seriously, do not look at this movie. It is beyond painful.

summary: Kim Ji-Hoon and Choi Su-Wan are both 21, born 3/1982. Su-Wan is a Year 2 University student while Ji-Hoon is only a high school student (Repeating 3rd year). Su-Wan's father lose his job, and her mother works in family business, killing chickens and sell them like Kentucky fried chicken, like that kind of shop but it's family business. The salary of this tutorial pays Su-Wan her entire semester, half of the school term. Ji-Hoon is a school fighter, loves fighting, and always attract girls, draws attention. Except studying, Ji-Hoon is really a all-rounder. Ji-Hoon was being sent to USA to study abroad when young. His relation with parents is bad due to they sent him to USA when he was young. translation: After that, I watched the movies ... I thought, "Why the hell was this movie in the Korean Box Office such a big hit?" Even if the film had a clever / unusual scenario, the acting was not so good and the characters were not very interesting. For a Korean movie ... I liked the fight scenes. If you want to watch a movie without thinking, this is the movie for you. But I have to admit ... the movie was kinda childish ... 6/10

Meanwhile, the revolutionary, pedophile, and mad killer Anna Planeta makes candy in her boat while sailing through the canals of a city that seems to be Amsterdam. translation: Virgin is chosen to marry a rich man. Rich guy urinated. Woman on the boat likes sailor. Sailor urinated. Virgin participates in a rough-out dinner. You urinate on the table. Boatwoman striptease for little boys. The man pretending to be a baby urinated. There is an underlying topic here. Makavejev tries to say that he is off in the world. To say that this is a bizarre movie is an understatement. To justify the title, there's a scene where Laure, who barely spends ten lines in the movie, bathes in chocolate syrup. It is indeed a sweet scene, but the rest of the film leaves a bad taste in the mouth, unless one shares the fetishes of the director.

summary: Dave and Rob, fresh from the Police Academy, enrage their captain because they want to do more than controlling the traffic. As penalty they are sent to Brooklyn. However they don't give up, but develop their own methods to fight against dealers, criminals and corrupt colleagues.
translation:
Gordon Parks, the prolific black life magazine photographer, has made a real ticking time bomb out of a movie here - one that does not fumble! Based on the true story of two New York policemen - later called Batman and Robin - who single-handedly applied radical tactics to cleanse their neighborhood of drugs, this is a cop-buddy movie before that term becomes a repeating formula has been. Lightning fast, there is no unimportant throwaway scene here.

Man, early 70s NYC must have been a terrible place to be a cop, from the looks of such movies and "Serpico". These two cops start out as Safety Division rookies robbing plainclothes civilians at leisure. Instead of receiving applause from the city police, they receive nothing but resistance and antagonism from their peers. They must single-handedly cross a minefield of police and legal corruption, bony jobs to keep them from working on the streets, reckless drug kings and a nasty ghetto neighborhood.

Both David Selby and Ron Leibman are fantastic in the leads; part of the conversation is to watch Leibman's eyes wander madly in every scene in a pristine, weird comedy, and Selby's acting is cautious and crooked. These two make all the comedic aspects of the story work - showing a noticeable frustration mixed with courageous determination. Director Parks, who was already known for his coverage of controversial issues in his photography, is not afraid of the glaring of the story. Rather, the film is uncompromising in portraying the harshness of the world of police and street criminals who inhabit these two men. Adding to this realism is that the real Hantz and Greenberg acted as technical advisers to the film and even appear in surreal cameo roles as two colleagues ridiculing the protagonists. It is a true tribute to the effectiveness of Parks' direction that he has managed to perfectly balance this depressing Mileu with perfect comedy.

Why has MGM / UA been on the shelf for 30 years? is it a home video or DVD release in the US? It is a small masterpiece from the 1970s.

summary: In the first sequel to Tarzan, the Ape Man, Harry Holt returns to Africa to head up a large ivory expedition. This time he brings his womanizing friend Marlin Arlington. Holt also harbors ideas about convincing Jane to return to London. When Holt and Arlington show Jane some of the modern clothes and perfumes they brought from civilization, she is impressed but not enough to return. Tarzan wrestles every wild animal imaginable to protect Jane but when he disallows the expedition from plundering ivory from the elephant burial grounds, it is he who takes a bullet from Arlington's gun. Jane eventually believes that Tarzan is dead but he is nursed back to health by the apes. As Jane and the returning expedition are attacked by violent natives, we wonder if Tarzan can rescue them yet again.
translation: This grand-directional fantasy is the second in the popular flawed Tarzan series issued by MGM. It's a first-class adventure for many reasons, I suggest - fine photography, strong imaginative qualities, a delightful cast, good simulated jungle locations, and a very exciting story. Johnny Weissmuller plays Tarzan, a monosyllabic, untyped variety, unlike Edgar Rice Burroughs' creation; but he is honest, loyal, courageous and very brave, and he must be during this narration. As Jane Parker, his wife, who had been Jane Porter in the novels, Maureen O'Sullivan is very attractive and lively, as well as athletic, where the script demands this quality. The effect of the lighting, the spacious and clever sets is quite unusual. This is an outdoor adventure filmed on the MGM Back-Lot that really works. The fabulous Mutir Escarpment is a secluded place that allows Tarzan and Jane to live undisturbed. but in their idyll come people looking for them, emissaries of a civilization that Jane left behind and into which Tarzan could not really settle in comfortably. One is Harry Holt, still in love with her, who seduces her with his friend to return to civilization with him; she is interested in the dress and the scents, but she refuses to leave Tarzan. Tarzan must protect her from several wild animals in scenes that look like a humanized king king. The group claims to want to hunt animals, and Tarzan agrees to a bit of big game trapping for Jane's sake; But at some point, the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãivory and the acquisition of a fortune will upset the heads of the expeditionary heads. Tarzan is shot, left dead; and the group forces Jane to accompany them on an expedition as they follow a dying elephant to the fabulous "Elephant Cemetery." But they find the area guarded by a wild tribe and are attacked by lions. Tarzan rides an elephant, whom he brought back to life in time; In a spectacular elephant scene, he rescues Jane and what's left of the expedition, who returns a little richer, but much wiser, while Jane continues her wild idyll with her new husband. The film was designed by set-design wizard Cedric Gibbons, and also very pretty. His work and lighting are the outstanding achievements of this entertaining and exciting film, which, despite all the shortcomings of Hollywood, is real from start to finish. Neil Hamilton is a very good Harry, Paul Cavanagh is even better before and after he turns out to be absolutely bad. Forrester Harvey and Nathan Curry complete a small cast very professionally. An unusual and well-realized fantasy film with interesting situations and strong dialogue confrontations. Recommended.

summary: Two losers from Milwaukee, Coop & Remer, invent a new game playing basketball, using baseball rules. When the game becomes a huge success, they, along with a billionaire's help, form the Professional Baseketball League where everyone gets the same pay and no team can change cities. Coop & Remer's team, the Milwaukee Beers is the only team standing in the way of major rule changes that the owner of the Dallas Felons wants to institute.
translation: I found this movie very funny, I loved it, as it was made from the politics of modern sport. This movie is not as fun as South Park, but it's pretty funny. And because I'm a sports fan, I loved how they made fun of the most ridiculous things in sport. This movie is also suitable for non-athletes, probably even better for them, since they have to go through life wondering why people follow the sport when there are so many crazy rules and subtleties in the sport and that it means absolutely nothing. I also found that the actual game was interesting, it's like a horse with bases and psyche-outs (for the person who shoots). Overall, I recommend you to watch this movie and to believe that you will love this movie. But if this style of comedy is not your favorite, you probably will not like it. (but that's with every comedy)

summary: The story of menstruation begins, as the motherly narrator informs us, with the pituitary gland - a gland at the base of the brain that sends hormones throughout the bloodstream that order growth. When a girl reaches an age somewhere between 11 and 17 - the average is 13 - the pituitary gland sends maturing orders to the ovaries, which in turn order the uterus to create a thickened lining, filled with watery fluids and blood. If an egg is fertilized it will remain within that thickened lining for nourishment. But if the egg is not fertilized, the body has no use for the extra nourishment, and it passes out of the body - which is the process called menstruation. The narrator proceeds to disprove taboos against bathing or exercise during menstruation. She advises that girls should keep a calendar that keeps track of the number days between periods. And she notes how good posture, healthy foods and positive attitudes can affect the menstruation cycle.
translation:
If you've never heard of this movie from Walt Disney Pictures, do not worry. It would be classed with Disney's other films intended for educational purposes such as "family planning".

It was coproduced with Kotex to teach preschool girls about menstruation, presumably. It is only raised on a superficial level, so it does not go into detail for the animated "Ram's Head" / Reproductive System sequence.

The film features "The Wonderful World of Disney" elements such as turning the page and using animation to tell the story.

This movie is impossible to find, so if you find the movie, good luck and enjoy it.

summary: The seven American lawyers hired by Australian media magnate Jack Doulan, whose company rivals Albert Teal's Digicron for preponderance on the world market of telecommunications, are suddenly struck during a video conference in Seattle by an incredibly fast-working virus which wipes out everyone on their floor. Dr. Nick Baldwin, a brilliant virologist who works as an 'insubordinate' ambulance technician after being fired for failing to observe procedure, is first on the site and points out to US Army disease specialist Dr. Samantha Carter, who told him there were deaths in several other cases but never a trace of the virus, his ambulance has taken a survivor to his hospital; her therapeutic incompetence gets the patient killed, him assigned as temporary consultant to her army research unit- even there computer model operator Darren is killed by the virus, which also strikes at other sites in and around Seattle, notably at places where Digicron's 500 TV channels setup box is being ...
translation:
Despite his clich√©s, virtually "no-name" cast and an apparently low budget, I thought this movie was alright; much better than I expected. I was skeptical at first - the idea of ‚Äã‚Äãa computer virus that can infect people seemed a bit ridiculous. But in the end, I thought the movie worked well with the concept (though some scenes were a bit clich√©d). The cast was pretty good and the two leads seemed to take their roles very seriously. I do not think Janine Turner looks a bit like a Geena Davis. Maybe it's just her face or the make-up, the hair, and the clothes she had in this movie, but it's always in the back of her mind.

Although it's not a must have Fatal Error is an entertaining movie that will keep you watching until the end.

summary: An intended rape victim manages to escape from her attacker but leaves her purse behind. Worried that he may visit her house and finish what he has started, she contacts the police but they are unable to help, saying that she has no proof. "If he calls, let us know and we'll send a man round!" A fat load of good that would be. Her worst fears are realised when, alone one day in the house, her attacker visits and attempts again to rape her. Circumstances allow her not only to resist the attack but to turn the tables and lock him away. And that is where her dilemma really starts. Does she release him and risk another attack? Does she go to the police and risk being called a liar? Or does she kill him - and become as low as him?
translation: Farrah Fawcett gives the best performance of an actress on film in this gritty real life trying Rapeseed Thriller, where she turns the tables and gives James Russo a taste of his own medicine. A must for every movie fan.

summary: Sissy Hankshaw is born with enormous thumbs that help her hitchhiking through the U.S. from a young age. She becomes a model in advertising, and her New York agent, "the Countess", sends her to his ranch in California to shoot a commercial, set against the background of mating whooping cranes. There, she befriends Bonanza Jellybean, one of the cowgirls at the beauty ranch. The cowgirls take command of the ranch from the Countess, and drug the cranes with peyote. The police besiege the ranch.
translation:
That was an excellent movie. I do not understand why so many people do not like it. There was so much to connect, so many beautiful pictures and so much compassion in things that were not said. I was thoroughly entertained and had a sense of joyous exuberance, just as I am when I finish the Tom Robbins story. Now I have not read this book by Robbins, so I do not know how it fits together, but I can not imagine that this movie could be a very bad interpretation. The movie has left a lot of room for you to define yourself, which is the best part of Tom Robbins novel that came up with the details.

To all who said this was the worst movie ever, I regret what's left of the faint light in your heart. Far from the worst, this movie was glorious. Long live the screaming crane.

summary: Charleston, South Carolina. The Odoms have lived a life of the traditions of the American south in their longtime, large family beach front home. That tradition is turned upside down when younger daughter, bright high school senior Lucille Odom, arrives home to find a note from her mother, Helen Odom, that note which states that she has left for good. This move has been a long time coming for Helen, although the actual act was somewhat spontaneous based on evidence around the family home. The family patriarch, retired Warren Odom, believes his wife will eventually return. To help with the situation, Warren and Lucille request the return of Warren's eldest daughter/Lucille's older sister, Rae Odom. However, Rae has her own issues as she arrives with her new Yankee husband, Billy McQueen, and news that they got married because she's pregnant, about which she doesn't seem too happy. These goings-on affect impressionable Lucille the most, she who is trying to find her own way in life and ...
translation:
I've enjoyed Law and Order's Criminal Intent series for a long time. Kathryn Erbe, Det. Alexandra Eames, the detective, is pretty tough and seems a bit bitter in the Criminal Intent series. See her other side in this movie.

This movie shows the wonderful soft side of these talented actresses and if you're a crime intent fan, this movie is a joy in their acting and you'll be damned good yarn of family trouble in the south.

I did not like Albert Finney's role in this movie because he did such a compelling performing work of the older Southern fellow, who is harsh and intolerant and does not accept changes. He reminds me of so many men of my youth and the depiction is divine, but you will probably like him hard in this movie.

Katryn Erbe is easy to like in this movie and why I recommend it is a 10 star hotel for criminals, law and order fans.

summary: Made for television version of the Charles Dickens classic of the same name. Ebenezer Scrooge is a hard-nosed, single-minded businessman in Victorian London. He has no friends, has disowned his only living relative - his nephew Fred Holywell - and generally treats everyone he meets with extreme contempt. He hates Christmas, only cares about making money and only gives his clerk, Bob Cratchit, the day off. However, he is taught the true meaning and spirit of Christmas by three ghosts who show him his own past and present. He is also shown what the future holds for him after his death if he doesn't change his behavior for the better.
translation:
I know that many people have a special liking for the Alistair Sim version of Dickens' story, but for me, this 1984 version is the one to beat. My wife and I own a copy of this movie on VHS, and we meet each Christmas Eve. I often realize that we can see it on Halloween too, because it is a very scary ghost story. Scott - typographical like Scrooge - is shuddering mean and mean, making his transformation all the more wonderful and moving. I think it's up there with his performance in Patton. The spirits are all effective, each more gruesome than the last. Watching the dark, hovering, skeletal shape of the Christmas spirit that comes to me every year makes me shudder every year. And what a supporting role! In particular, David Warner is in top form as Bob Cratchit, as is Susannah York as his wife.

I think I remember that this version of the original story is closer than most others - but I could be wrong, since it's been several years since I read it. Anyway, that's a great Christmas classic.

summary: Poor lonely Casper the friendly ghost keeps scaring away prospective friends. Then a little fox cub who doesn't know better befriends him, and all is fine until a hunter comes along...
translation: I remember seeing this cartoon when I was 6 or 7. My grandfather recorded the video for free at the mall. I remember that it really sucked. The plot made no sense. I hated the fox who became Casper's friend. He was so stupid! Casper cried his head when he could not find a friend. So what? Get over it! The only good part and I do not want to sound mean when the fox was shot and died in the end. I laughed at the payback because this cartoon sucked so much. The bad news is that the fox is resurrected and becomes the ghost. I wish he had died. I think I even gave the video to someone because I hated it. No wonder they offered it for free in the mall. If you have a child, do not let it look at you. You'll probably agree that it's shit.

translation:
