summary: A mysterious creature from another planet, resembling a giant blob of jelly, lands on earth. The people of a nearby small town refuse to listen to some teenagers who have witnessed the blob's destructive power. In the meantime, the blob just keeps on getting bigger.
translation:
THE BLOB is a great horror movie, not only because of the vivid images of its almost unstoppable, carnivorous title character, but because it contains a true social message. It's a "feel-good horror movie" in many ways. The clever story is immensely helped by solid performances of the entire cast. The two romantic leads Steve McQueen and Aneta Corsaut bring surprising depth and sentimentality into the action. They are misunderstood, but very well meaning young people, and it is very easy to root for them.

This is a pro-society movie, and its youthful delinquent characters cause boredom, not some kind of malicious character flaw. Steve McQueen's drag racing rival seems almost an enemy at the beginning of the game, but quickly joins McQueen's campaign to save the city from the seeping intruder as soon as he sees McQueen's seriousness. In this way, a character situation that initially appears cartoon-like suddenly develops depth and human realism.

The authorities' initial skepticism about the wild claims of children proves to be wrong - and once the threat is recognized by all, all conflicts within society disappear. This unification of purpose and affirmation of the "troublemakers" becomes official when Aneta Corsaut's father breaks into the school to obtain the fire extinguishers needed to freeze the blob. On any other day, breaking into the school is considered vandalism typical of a juvenile delinquent - on this day it is a necessary action performed by an adult authority figure. At this turning point it is clear that there are no dividing lines between young and old.

This is an unusual film that recognizes the perception of a "generational gap," but suggests it is more imaginary than real, and given a real crisis, people will naturally band together to restore order , "The Blob" is a perfect tonic for the kind of depression that usually accompanies a consideration of "Night of the Living Dead" (1968).

Much of the cheap but innovative movie has been made (and effectively!) visual effects. You are undeniably smart. A lot of the gravity-tricking tricks we see performing the blob were achieved with miniature sets designed to be turned. The camera was usually attached very tightly to the sets (the lights had to be similarly mounted so that the lighting remained stable as the room was rotated in this and that way). These scenes were often photographed one picture at a time as the room was slowly turned - the silicon drop trickled very slowly and his action had to be accelerated. In a way, this was similar to stop-motion photography, but using a dab of silicone instead of a dumbbell. To date, the effects are surprising and bizarre.

A very good movie with an exploitative title, THE BLOB is a must.

summary: The Green Arrow sends out for reinforcements and Bart Allen, a.k.a. Impulse, Arthur Curry (Aquaman) and Victor Stone (Cyborg) return to Smallville to help him take down LuthorCorp's secret lab called 'Project 33.1'. During a break-in at the LuthorCorp facility, Bart is captured and tortured by Lex for information to who hired him. Clark sets off to rescue him but is felled by kryptonite. An alarmed Chloe goes to Oliver for help, and the newly formed "justice league" springs into action to rescue Clark and Bart. Meanwhile, Oliver painfully decides to break up with Lois, feeling that his dedicating to justice is more important, but he leaves out that information from her.

The Maysles brothers pay visits to Edith Bouvier Beale, nearing 80, and her daughter Edie. Reclusive, the pair live with cats and raccoons in Grey Gardens, a crumbling mansion in East Hampton. Edith is dry and quick-witted - a singer, married but later separated, a member of high society. Edie is voluble, dresses - as she puts it - for combat in tight ensembles that include scarves wrapped around her head. There are hints that Edie came home 24 years before to be cared for rather than to care for her mother. The women address the camera, talking over each other, moving from the present to events years before. They're odd, with flinty affection for each other.
translation:
Hey, well, you, TheatreX, thought so while I was scouring videos at the flea market in near-new condition, and when I read the back of the box, I saw that it was a "cult hit," so of course came home me.

What a strange movie. Aunt and cousin of former First Lady Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis lives in this dilapidated 28-room house on Long Island (Suffolk Co.) and shares the house with raccoons, cats, fleas (eyow!) And who knows what else. Suffolk Co. was at a point above them because they lived in filth, and old Jackie herself came by to fix things. Anyway, this is a weird couple, Big Edie and Little Edie ... Edie (the daughter) always wears something over her head and dances, sings and gives the camera little things that rarely make much sense. Big Edie (the 79-year-old mother) seems to like walking around naked, and while we're getting clues as to what that might look like, fortunately, that has been made so tasty (?) That it's mercifully spared us. These women talk and talk and talk mainly about the past, and it does not make much sense except to them. They live in absolute filth, cats do their business everywhere ("Look, this cat is going to the bathroom behind my portrait!"), And a bedroom seems to be their work center. Closing my eyes and hearing Big Edie's voice reminds me a lot of my own deceased aunt, who came from that part of the country and had that Lawn Guyland accent. In one scene, Little Edie put on flea repellent, nice, you can see the cats scratching all the time, so the place has to be infested. The box refers to these two women as "eccentric," and I would say, in this case, it's just a euphemism for "being thrown out of their pumpkins," but this movie is not without moments where you really feel something. This is equally scary, sad and disgusting, but I could not stop looking when I started. This is not my "normal" type of strip, but I found it a bit intriguing. It will not be for everyone, guaranteed.

summary: An innovative look at the life of fictional Mafia Capo Tony Soprano, this serial is presented largely first person, but additional perspective is conveyed by the intimate conversations Tony has with his psychotherapist. We see Tony at work, at home, and in therapy. Moments of black comedy intersperse this aggressive, adult drama, with adult language, and extreme violence.
translation: Now I have read some negative reviews for this show on this website and frankly I am appalled. For anyone who thinks the sopranos are not television, I'm afraid I do not know what the world has come to. Let me tell you something. I started seeing many TV shows like Lost, Prison Break, Dexter, Deadwood and even Invasion. But all those shows have lost their character after the first season, especially Lost and Prison Break, which I do not want to see because the companies took two brilliant ideas and slaughtered them by doing more than one season. Then we have the sopranos. I can honestly say that this is the only television series I have ever seen where I was thrilled in all its season and especially in all episodes. There is no department where this show is not unique. Acting - Nothing less than great. James Gandolfini is one of my favorite actors and I think his acting is absolutely stunning in every episode. After hearing that HBO wanted Ray Liotta to play Tony, I felt that it would have been a better choice after watching the first episodes, I knew that HBO had done a great job of throwing James as Tony. The raw emotion he shows is outstanding. Then we have everyone else, Edie Falco, Michael Imperioli, Lorraine Bracco, Dominic Chianese (whom I remember as Johnny Ola in Godfather Part 2) and my personal favorite characters Tony Sirico and Steve Van Zandt Paulie Walnut Gualtieri and Silvio Dante. All these perform the best quality and perform excellently in each episode. Then we have the story, never before was I so sucked into a TV show. The story is nothing less than excellent. Every episode is great and the score of this show is just fantastic. I think that The Sopranos is a show that I can see again and again and that I'm never bored with. It has everything from hilarious humor to brutal violence, but nonetheless it is and always will be the best thing that sets the television apart, and I challenge everyone to find a real flaw in the show. I mean, it's a mafia show at the end of the day, I do not think the characters will be very honest or loyal to God. I implore everyone to watch this show because believe me, you will be addicted from the first episode, I was and I even got some friends who at first refused to see the show, addicted to it. Trust me when I say that this show is a godsend compared to the crap that comes on TV. After watching the first season, you'll inevitably agree with me when I say again that this show dominates television and no TV show present or future will surprise the wonder that the sopranos are.

summary: Lewis and Clark were famous comedians during the vaudeville era. Off-stage, though, they couldn't stand each other, and haven't spoken in over twenty years. Ben, Willy Clark's nephew, is the producer of a variety show that wants to feature a reunion of the classic duo. How will Ben convince the crotchety old comedians to put aside their differences before the big show?
translation:
Walter Matthau and George Burns were a famous variety comedy, Lewis and Clark, who have not spoken for over 10 years. Burns retired and Matthau took it personally and has since expressed a grudge. This is the premise of this fun Neil Simon play that was made into a movie. What makes it so good of course is Matthau and Burns in their prime, and the material is funnier than anything you can find today. Richard Benjamin appears as Matthaus nephew and agent. There are even old clips from current stars of the Golden Age to get you into the groove of the movie, and character-actor Fritz Feld starts everything with a "pop." Rosetta LaNoire, who went to the theater with Orson Welles in the thirties and later became a grandmother on "Family Matters", is great in a small role.

The only problem I had with it (and maybe I'm too picky and / or serious) is the way Matthau treats Burns when they first meet. Granted, he's been in a lot of trouble all these years, but some of the things he does would be considered rude or simply bad manners taken out of context. Besides, I'm used to Matthau's behavior in other films, but not with George Burns. And Matthau's roar tends to get a bit old.

All in all, if you need a thoroughly funny movie to help and forget about your problems, put in "The Sunshine Boys". They will lift your spirits and make you think of a simpler time and way of life.

Benjamin: "You have to push it."

Matthau: "Wait, wait, I think you have to push it."

summary: A musical drawing room farce set in Paris in October, 1925. Gilberte, in middle-age, flirts with men but loves her husband Georges, wishing he were more demonstrative. He's negotiating a deal with an American, Eric Thomson, who turns out to be Gilberte's first husband from an annulled and secret stateside marriage. Along with her sister Arlette, Gilberte begs Eric not to tell Georges about the marriage. Meanwhile, a young artist, Charly, pursues Gilberte while Arlette tries to match him with the young Huguette, who loves him. Will Eric play along or try to re-win Gilberte's affection? Can Gilberte play one off against another? And who will manage to kiss whom on the lips?
translation:
Resnais, wow! The genius brought to us by Hiroshima Mon Amour takes on the challenge of making a French musical of the 1930s in vibrant colors. The introduction with old, embellished inter-titles was a nice touch. Then the camera opening (like the old crank handles) opens on a black and white poster. The camera steps back (or rather, up) and suddenly shows us the surprisingly brilliant colors of an elegant table set for a tea party. That's all in the first 60 seconds.

Then the music starts. A rather banal and forgetful Diddy with an unconvincing chorus of three girls blabbering some nonsense that's not relevant to the movie (and yes, I speak French, so I can not blame the subtitles). These characters whiz out the door and are replaced by more people breaking into an even more forgotten song. Then they go, and finally Audrey Tautou appears and we hear our first noteworthy dialogue 15 minutes after the movie.

I am not sure what Resnais has intended with such a yawning waste of time and musicality cacophony. The effect on the viewer, however, is that you want to throw Skittles on the screen and storm out. I could stand it.

It did not get much better. I will tell you why. There is absolutely no familiarity with any characters. We do not even see their faces half the time (because Resnais is too eager to show the expensive landscape to take care of the people in front of the camera). People are pacing up and down like moths around a lamp, and we viewers are unable to focus on a particular person or action. It's like taking every episode of Brady Bunch and stuffing it into a two-hour movie. With bad songs.

The only thing that kept me watching (1 hour) was that I looked at the camera techniques, the lighting and the scenery, all of which, admittedly, were excellent. But is that enough to keep your attention for 2 hours? Not me. Maybe tomorrow I will try to watch the end. Oh, who am I doing? I have more important things to do. I'm sure you do too. Skip this.

summary: In 19th century New Orleans a new class of colored people has arisen. They are creoles, a result of relations between African-Americans and wealthy European people. Children are born, there is love, but marriage is out of the question. Colored people are still not considered equal. Henriette Delille is a very religious creole. The time she has she spends on educating, care and helping out in church. On the day her father Jean-Baptiste leaves her mother Pouponne to marry a white woman, Henriette is supposed to meet her arranged future 'caretaker' Paul Cartier. But she refuses him, defying every tradition and so bringing her mother to madness. She becomes friends with the French doctor Gerard Gaultier. He is in love with her and wants her to move to France, so they can be legally married. Henriette is torn apart by her feelings for Gerard and her devotion to the church. She must choose, but neither choice is going to be an easy one as there are people who greatly disapprove of ...
translation:
When I see this movie, it's interesting to see how much he marginalizes black men. The film spends its time showing how powerless the most visible black in it is (except for a heroic moment). For much of the film, the other black men (and dark-skinned black women) in the film are far in the background, barely visible.

Vanessa Williams's character was strong and sympathetic. The viewer can easily identify them and sympathize with them. There are also some pretty visible and three-dimensional supportive figures that are fair-skinned, and some white characters of some warmth and dignity. But 99% of the black men in this movie are nothing but invisible men. Voiceless shadows in the background, without meaning. Such a terrible mistake, but anything but unusual in the mainstream media.

Unfortunately, their admittedly colorful gimmicks can not cover up the weaknesses of this updated storyline, and the acting is sadly overripe. Dillman, under pressure to remember the events of the night in question, goes through an actor's seminar of tics, stuttering, noses and crazy half-laughter as he spits out dialogues like "Dream ... a dream ... drugs ... yes "Drugs ... SOUND ... Bells ... help!" A rogue colleague with a smile on his grin, Pat Hingle almost dumbles Dillman in the Grand Thespian department by calling everyone in baby talk like a middle-aged peacock strutting around and turning his mouth in pain. Hope Lange's scholarly interest in love is briefly scolded, but not before she indifferently screams - Lover Dillman: "What do I have to do, Ape Man talk? I want you!" When I saw the end where the two main characters rushed into the room and mercilessly killed people, they commit Suicide and I had to hold on to my stomach. I was shaking, so strong is this movie.

The movie is amazing. It's too incredible not to get a perfect ten. It is sad that so few people understand the true beauty of this film. It's not a budget that makes a movie good, it's the amount of feeling the creators put in it that makes it good.

Almost true to the original - with some small deviations and omissions, z. the absence of Scylla & Charybdis and the fact that Eumaeus recognizes the swineherd Odysseus disguised in his hut - realistic acting and authentic scenery and costumes all contribute to this being a truly memorable masterpiece, not some Hollywood sword and sword. Sandal-B stripes. At least that's what I did, and that inspired me to learn Italian to better appreciate the movie.

Very disappointing - avoid it.

Cassidy addresses the band, and specifically Neal, before revealing four tarot death cards. The band returns to the recording studio where Rex and Madison are working on a recording of their own. During a session break, Cassidy's spirit takes over Dora's body. One by one, Dora isolates and murders each member. When Dora is finally killed, Cassidy's spirit is exorcized from the body. summary: After a spot of therapy Cruella De Vil is released from prison a changed woman. Devoted to dogs and good causes, she is delighted that Chloe, her parole officer, has a dalmatian family and connections with a dog charity. But the sound of Big Ben can reverse the treatment so it is only a matter of time before Ms De Vil is back to her incredibly ghastly ways, using her new-found connections with Chloe and friends.
translation:
Huge fun for adults and kids, this movie works on many levels: everything from car accidents and face cakes to some very good (but fine) adult jokes.

Glenn Close is with her sublime evil best as Cruella ("call me Ella") De Ville.

After three years in dr. Pavlov's Behavior Modification Clinic is she cured of her cravings for fur? even the fur of the puppy skin she had so much wanted. She has even put all her fur coats in the dungeon of the extraordinary castle that inhabits her.

But it would not be a Dalmatian movie without the excuses and machinations of Cruella and you know that will change her behavioral change. And now she needs an extra puppy (hence 102 Dalmatians) to complete this nefarious project.

Ioan Gruffudd is immediately more appealing than the hero of the film who runs the Second Chance School. Although he was in "Titanic" and in the TV version of last year (as Pip) of "Great Expectations", I did not recognize him; Well, he was "Fifth Officer Lowe" in "Titanic" and I did not see "Great Expectations", so I'm not too surprised.

Gerard Depardieu is having a good time as a furrier farmer from Cruella. He prances and poses in the most sophisticated fur clothes you've ever seen? and do it well. His "Wicked Witch of the West" tribute is hilarious.

Tim McInnerny is outstanding Cruella is not that evil stooge? he was also "Alonzo", "Cruella's Butler", in "101 Dalmatians" and you can also recognize him from all "Black Adder" Brit-Coms. He plays his usual awkward, good-natured, somewhat stupid character with great effect.

Oscars for costuming are generally given for the entirety of costuming in a movie. This is unfortunate, because the clothes of Glenn Close is amazing? it is incredibly detailed (note her handcuffs when she is released from the Behavior Modification Clinic) and deserves such exaggerated character. Her clothes alone deserve at least one Oscar nomination.

Animation has a special place in my heart? but comparing this movie to the original animated movie is like comparing apples to orangutans: it's not possible. Suffice to say that "102 Dalmatians" is even better than the movie version of "101 Dalmatians", which came out in 1996. There is a lot to see here: from the gags, the dialogue and the costumes to the casting - it's a good movie for the whole family.

summary: When a promised job for Texan Michael fails to materialise in Wyoming, Mike is mistaken by Wayne to be the hitman he hired to kill his unfaithful wife, Suzanne. Mike takes full advantage of the situation, collects the money and runs. During his getaway, things go wrong, and soon get worse when he runs into the real hitman, Lyle.
translation:
"Red Rock West" was by far one of the best thrillers of the 90s with a great script (by John and Rick Dahl), with the most of the film could sit on the edge through and through. It was brilliantly staged by John Dahl and featured a wonderful cast featuring Nicolas Cage, Dennis Hopper, Lara Flynn Boyle and, most notably, J. T. Walsh (in a memorable performance), making it a captivating and compelling thriller not to be missed. The film never had much publicity when it came out (in fact, I first caught it on TV) and is therefore one of those special little gems to visit, but this unique film is slowly gaining cult status.

Nicolas Cage is Michael Williams who is bankrupt and unemployed while in the small town of Red Rock. Failing a contract killer named Lyle from Dallas, he is shocked to be offered $ 10,000 for killing wife of barkeeper Wayne Brown (the award-winning J. T. Walsh). He plays with the plan and decides that he should warn Brown's wife Suzanne (Lara Flynn Boyle), but then the action thickens and there are so many twists, turns and surprises - and doubled business - that Cage from one crisis to the next is thrown and finds himself in a terrible situation, from which he can not tear himself out! Then, just to complicate matters further, the real Lyle turns up to execute the hitman (played by everyone's favorite, Dennis Hopper). When Hopper discovers what happened, he goes to Cage, but no one could predict the surprising events that follow.

Some favorite parts of the movie:

Nicolas Cage (to Lara Flynn Boyle): "I hate to see an innocent woman get hurt, but it's a lot Money."

J. T. Walsh (to Cage): "Michael Williams Well, Michael, you'll spend some time with us until we get to the bottom of it."

Boyle (to Cage): "You are not a murderer?". Cage: "That's right, no, but the guy I expected to have just ridden into town to get you out of here."

Boyle (to Cage): "OK, the way you are. I'll explain that I'm disguising a paid murderer and taking $ 10,000 from my husband?"

An extraordinarily entertaining little thriller (only 98 minutes) with a story that never fades and looks powerful. Each film with J. T. Walsh is O.K. in my book and "Red Rock West" was one of his best. How sad it was that this exceptional actor's career was tragically shortened in 1998 by a heart attack. The most productive time for "Film Noir" was undoubtedly the 1940s, but "Red Rock West" is a good modern example of the genre and has gone straight to my "Top Ten" list of all favorite movies. I'm looking forward to more from director John Dahl. 10/10. Clive Roberts.

summary: The Jews of Poland (invaded by Germany in 1939) are depicted as filthy, evil, corrupt, and intent on world domination. Street scenes are shown prejudicially, along with clips from Jewish cinema of the day and photos of Jewish celebrities, while the narrator "explains" the Jewish problem. The climax and resolution of the film is Hitler's 1939 announcement that the Jewish race will meet its "annihilation" (Vernichtung).
translation: After seeing "Triumph of the Will," all I can say is that this movie is horrible, even against the historically low "standards" of the time. Of course it's all totally fabricated and harmful. That is what one would expect from German propaganda of 1930. Unfortunately, the quality of the presentation itself is trite and cheap. It is also so ridiculously so ridiculous that even contemporary Germans must have left the theater with their noses. In a genre that is known for its fundamental appeal, lack of originality, and unreflected falseness, this film is not even considered "bad." It would have to be significantly improved to achieve this status!

summary: International terrorists are terrified when their hijacked cargo turns out to be genetically engineered dinosaurs. Now... the army commando team attempting recovery of this secret cargo is about to make the same deadly discovery!

Even the humor in C3 is funny because it's bad. Definitely a highlight in the genre "So Bad It's Good". If you enjoy the worst of the worst, this is for you.

summary: A man wanders into the woods in search of his cat and witnesses a murder.

Soft For Digging follows the old man's attempts to convince the police that what he saw was not an invention of his imagination. However, there is a problem every time the old man leads the police to the place where the murder occurs, that no body can be found. Soft For Digging has a small dialogue that reflects the majority of the film's scenes, an old man living alone in a house. During the movie, I realized that I was scared twice when the murdered child suddenly appeared in front of the old man. Alone in the woods at night, insecure in your own mind, can lead to sinister situations, children are always scary like ghosts, see Dark Water.

summary: An atomic explosion awakens Gammera--a giant, fire-breathing turtle monster--from his millions of years of hibernation. Enraged at being roused from such a sound sleep, he takes it out on Tokyo.
translation: This movie was in a Science Fiction 50 pack, a friend of mine got me for Christmas. It's very similar to the first Gozilla movie and, like this movie, has scenes with American actors inserted for no real reason. An interesting thing about the scenes inserted is that there is a tension between the Cold War and America portrayed between America and Russia. As in Godzilla, Gamera is awakened by an atomic explosion and rampages all over the world, paying close attention to Tokyo, as no big monster movie is complete unless Tokyo bites him. All in all, that's a good movie. Some of the scenes with Gamera, especially the scenes in Toly, are quite spectacular and have special effects that were pretty decent at the time. If you like Japanese giant monster movies, you'll really get a kick. I give it a 4 out of 10 points. If this were the unedited Japanese version I saw, it would probably have got a 5.

summary: Alexandre, a TV reporter, is working for a few days in a border town, where a lot of refugees from Albania, Turkey and Kurdistan are packed in. Among them, he notices an old man and thinks he is an important Greek politician who disappeared mysteriously a few years ago. Back in Athens, he asks this politician's former wife to come and identify him. A slow and dry meditation about inhumanity of borders.
translation:
A highly recommended masterpiece, not only for the underlying themes of the story, but also for the incomparably brilliant and ingenious image work of Angelopoulos, not to mention the acting of the giants Mastroianni and Moreau and the remarkable character play of Iliad's Logothethis. Gregory Karr's appearance may seem overshadowed by his "tough" partners at first glance, but in fact he plays his character perfectly, as shown in his very last scene with the girl (Khrysikou) and the man (Mastroianni), though hinted at earlier. (Hence the spoiler.)

Get your expectations! It is an "art film" in whatever meaning this sentence has to offer and requires attention. Not to spend free time, but to look at a work of art with the necessary concentration, such as reading a book or attending a concert. Due to the general photographic style, a large-screen view is recommended.

Dialogues are used sparingly. But the film contains - in addition to the usual Greek and English speaking - fragments spoken in Albanian, Kurdish and Turkish, which will be attractive to those charmed by the beauty in listening to different languages.

summary: As with Almereyda's previous films, this one deals with a gothic subject in a modern context. Lushly filmed it concerns an alcoholic womans return to her Irish roots, only to turn into a film about a woman whose soul is desired by a 1000 year old witch.

Dooohhh! My bwainn hurrrts! Well, after this endurance test of a film. How on earth did I manage to keep going without hitting the Forward Lord, just know.

summary: Despite its nearly four-hour running time, this is a uniquely personal look at movies from one of the late 20th century's great directors and film historians. The film consists of head & shoulder shots of Scorsese speaking into the camera for a minute or two, followed by 10-15 minutes of film clips with Scorsese voice-over. Scorsese approaches the films in terms of how they affected him as a director foremost and as a storyteller/film fan second. Segments include "The Director as Smuggler," "The Director as Iconoclast", and so on. The Journey begins with silent masters like D.W. Griffith and ends in 1969 - when Scorsese began to make films; as he says in closing, "I wouldn't feel right commenting on myself or my contemporaries."
translation: I never thought that I would almost cry if I cut a minute out of a 1920's black-and-white movie without a cut-out. Thanks to Martin Scorsese (the film is by F. Borzage). You will start to understand (if it is not already), which makes a good movie.

translation:
Great script and some of the best actors the world has ever produced. Montand gives the concept of the police detective "Lone Wolf" a whole new dimension of intensity and above all credibility.

When a typical Hollywood cop loses his family, friends and pets, he is usually given his minute of mourning. But when the sixty seconds are over, he pulls himself together, grabs his weapon and maliciously goes to his enemies.

Montands Marc Ferrot, however, is really devastated - by his girlfriends murder, of course, but also by finding out that she had another lover. In his confusion and anger, he seeks no revenge, but must go on to find the true culprit of a crime where his fingerprints are all over the scene. So all his actions inevitably become logical. This is the main reason why this film sticks to our seats, but definitely not the only one.

summary: Brian Kessler, a journalist researching serial killers, and his photographer girlfriend Carrie set out on a cross-country tour of the sites of the killings. Sharing the ride and their expenses are Early Grayce, a paroled white trash criminal, and his girlfriend Adele. As the trip progresses, Early begins to appear more and more unstable, and Brian and Carrie begin to fear that they may have a real-life killer in the back seat of their car.
translation:
**** = A masterpiece that is recorded in the books and never forgotten.

*** 1/2 = A classic in time; just a must

*** = A solid, valuable, very entertaining piece

** 1/2 = A good movie, but there are some uneven elements or noticeable flaws

** = Can still be considered good in areas, but this work either has serious problems or is constrained by unavoidable elements that are considered inevitable (eg genre).

* 1/2 = Mostly a bunch of nothing triggered by mild, rewarding moments

BOMB = No visible quality

- California = ***

- Unrated (for heavily violent material, considerable sexuality and language)

I have rented this movie in anticipation of a Brad Bitt summer blockbuster Quality celebration of Brad Pitts face, but was happy surprised and disappointed. This is really more of a drama, and very grim in this ... I remember some emotionally intense Duchovny voice-overs.

Pitt is playing his possibly most un-sexiest movie ever with amazing talent. Who started out as a hopeless but harmless "White Trash" husband became a violent, disturbing alcoholic with a confused mind. During some of the later stages of the film, I found it hard to keep watching - unpredictable and sinister. This proves very good writing and acting.

The whole movie is filled with bizarre, sensational scenes that make me breathe no less than once, and I do not mean action scenes. I mean dialogue scenes that are so brilliantly designed that I actually flinched and gasped for what I saw. It was like watching a rhino and a lion in a cage and watching each other gnaw each other to death. I am again very impressed by the screenwriters; whoever they are has made the impossible possible: mixed oil and water.

I really enjoyed Juliette Lewis's performance. It is so rare that this talented young actress is performing nowadays, when she does, it is such a pleasure. Some of her moments in this movie brought tears to my eyes. I mean, that. The emotions this girl can get in your head are unbelievable, and I clearly remember that on some occasions I got blurry eyes.

I almost feel like cheating the quality of the filmmaker's artistry just to give "KALIFORNIA" a *** rating. But the dark emotions that move it are too powerful and depressing to increase it. I think everyone should see this movie. I really do.

summary: Two years before his famous encounter with Montezuma, Cortes is sent on a scouting mission to shores south of Mexico where he and his band of Conquistadores discover a small tribe of Aztecs who sacrifice their own people to satisfy the hunger of the "Thunder Lizard" living in the jungle.
translation:
It was 1 o'clock in the morning and I had nothing else to do. Do not judge me ... please.

We are back in time during the Spanish settlements. A group has come to an island. It does not take long for them to encounter a big "reptile" devouring their horse. Soon they will be captured by the natives and in order to gain freedom they will have to kill the "reptile gods". The CG sucks; It reminds me of the CG of early console video games. The encounters were lame. The only positive thing I could say was that the hottie natives were running around in a tight outfit. Otherwise, it's just a mediocre effort.

summary: Bobby is a Los Angeles teenager who buys a customized Dodge van to pick up girls and spruce up his dull life, all while trying to win money racing other vans in order to pay for his own.
translation:
The Cult of Personality has elevated the status of Roger Corman, Sam Arkoff, Lloyd Kaufman, etc. as kings of B. Because people at Crown International were so important, they were not raised to the status they deserve. A movie like THE VAN may now seem like a one-way drive-in esoterium, but it was a big hit when it was released (not to mention later re-releases as a double feature with other Crown hits).

THE VAN was a perfect example of Crown's strategy to use the moviegoers' mood when releasing a movie. Here it was sex, drugs, rock'n'roll and the short "custom van" -fad. As others have noted, it is ironic that the "hit" song in the movie refers to a Chevy when the title vehicle is a Dodge in the movie itself. I had a town called Selecman, where I even stated at the time that these vans were "sin caves on wheels"! A perfect ad line for the movie!

There is the usual selection of "good" and "bad" girls, muscle heads and low-brows (including a support bit by Danny DeVito). In many ways, that's not much different from the old 60s beach party movies, but now spiced up with nudity and drug use. Obviously, on a limited budget and on a limited schedule, the movie is pleasant enough with a breezy charm that balances some, by today's standards, safe, un-PC views of women.

The classic touch is a toaster for Bobby's sin cave on wheels. Yes, a toaster! Hey, you have to have something hot for these munchies!

Grindhouse Fest.

summary: After total humiliation at her thirteenth birthday party, Jenna Rink wants to just hide until she's thirty. Thanks to some wishing dust, Jenna's prayer has been answered. With a knockout body, a dream apartment, a fabulous wardrobe, an athlete boyfriend, a dream job, and superstar friends, this can't be a better life. Unfortunately, Jenna realizes that this is not what she wanted. The only one that she needs is her childhood best friend, Matt, a boy that she thought destroyed her party. But when she finds him, he's a grown up, and not the same person that she knew.
translation:
This movie is awful. Everything in it has been done before. There is nothing original. I can not stand it if the authors do not have their own plans.

A girl wishes for a wish on her thirteenth birthday and wakes up as an adult. Hmm, sounds a lot like a movie in the 80s, called Big. What's even more annoying is Jennifer Garner's acting. She does not behave like she is, she just acts like she's stupid.

From then on you can guess the whole story. She gets a good job and it just happens that a friend she had at 13 works with her. Wow, how great! But, no ... her friend is angry and goes to her, trying to get her job. But of course she wins in the end, if she has a "great" idea.

There's also a dance scene in the movie that I've seen a thousand times. >
I hate this movie.

summary: Willful young Jennifer Cassi travels to South America to claim the inheritance of her recently deceased twin sister Johanna's house. While there Jennifer must contend with her eccentric grandmother Mary Ellen Cassi, who has damned the family with an ancient curse. Jennifer immediately starts to suffer from scary visions of a sinister raven every time she goes to sleep.
translation: The only reason I rented this was the article in Fangoria Magazine. The article has made this movie interesting. Well, it is not. It was a very boring, amateurishly written and staged film. All the actors in this movie are terrible except Faye Dunaway, who is always a pleasure to see. But too much time was focused on Gina Phillips and her ridiculous encounters with Ravens and Duilio Marzio. Marzio has such a strong Argentine accent, you can only understand every word he says. Also present is Nicholas Pauls, who gives Gina Phillips the ultra-casual love interest. The bottom line: This movie is not scary. There is only one good scene and these are the last five to ten minutes of the movie. I would have given this one star, but I gave it three just because I like Faye Dunaway so much. But even she was not so great at it.

summary: Time travellers from the 23rd century return to 1992 to warn Japan that Godzilla will cause a catastrophic nuclear incident in the 21st century and suggest a way to rid the world of him forever. They intend to go back to 1944, to Ragos Island, where a dinosaur was exposed to radiation from the Bikini H-Bomb test and became Godzilla. Upon completion of this task, King Ghidrah appears in 1992 and the visitors' true plan is discovered. They wish to destroy Japan so it will not become the dominant economic force. Luckily for the Japanese, Godzilla was still created and will now fight Ghidrah.
translation:
When you talk about Japanese cinema today, most people do not talk about Rashomon or the Seven Ronin or Ran. For the masses, Japanese cinema means all the monsters we love to destroy these Japanese cities over and over again, often in battles with each other. The first and greatest of them is Godzilla, who comes back a dozen times or more and in some movies faced the three-headed hydra-like space monster, Ghidrah. Strange enough in tune with the times, the special effects got a little better. But part of the charm of these old movies was to see these paper mache city sets destroyed, they looked so fake, maybe three steps above Ed Wood.

Some visitors from the future have traveled to Japan to urge that Godzilla has been destroyed since its discovery. In fact, he was discovered as a surviving dinosaur during World War II when he protected the Japanese garrison on a Pacific island from these American troops. But later, with nuclear tests on bikini, Godzilla, the friendly dinosaur, and Barney became the common machine we met in the movies.

Of course you are eliminating Godzilla when you give Ghidrah a free field to ruin Japan so that it did not become an economic colossus when it appeared in 1991 when the movie came out. I will not say more, but we all know that Japan is doing pretty well in 2010.

Like all other Japanese monster movies, just sit back and enjoy the chaos.

summary: When Holly (Amanda Bynes) is 16, her father takes a job in Japan and she moves in with her strait-laced sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) in New York City. Val finally has both a great career and a great boyfriend in a carefully organized life on the Upper West Side when Holly moves in and tries to become a part of her sister's fabulous life.
translation:
What I hate about this show is how bad the leads are written. These women have no self-esteem or dignity. The whole plot is that they throw on guys. Amanda Biene's talent is completely wasted. She was brilliant in "All That" and her own show. Why would you write them and Jenny Garth as stupid, Airhead, desperate, chasing men, "old maid" wannabes is about me.

Your actions and dialogues remind me of "The Simpons," says Homer Whenever his cartoon character Poochie is not on the screen, "Everyone should ask, where is Poochie?". The whole conversation focuses on whining about some guy and then whining to a guy. Sometimes they change it and the guy whines instead. Then they come together again or break up in the end. The 2 women are either superficial, stupid or addicted to sex. The only word I can think of is "sucks".

summary: Young Tommy Hudler decides to become a security systems salesman, and is an instant success. Everything seems to be going great until he discovers there's more to this business and his boss Heinrich than he previously suspected.
translation:
What starts out to be a pretty shrewd farce about a somewhat dodgy security surveillance company almost immediately turns into an uninteresting and totally unacceptable murder mystery. David Arquette and the great Stanley Tucci are trying hard to make this train wreck handsome, but some things just are not humanly possible.

What, for example, causes Gale to suddenly change from a sweet maternal figure to a drunken shrew at Tommy's childhood home? Why should Henry, though admittedly a sleeping bag, destroy the business to which he dedicates his life by robbing and perhaps murdering his customers? Why does the seemingly reasonable Tommy believe that Henry could be a murderer (almost entirely based on a dream), and even if that were credible, why not go to the police? And why did not Gale sound the alarm when she got home, especially after telling Howie she was off? Of course, all these events are necessary for the plot to unfold (and I use the term very, very loosely). And it could be forgivable if it led to the slightest comedy. But everything from Howie's description of his date rape, to the false identification of the medical examiner with Gale, to the last "joke" about Gale and Howie, who is still dead, is tastier and more pathetic than anything.

I ticked the box and pointed out that my comments contained "spoilers", but there's nothing I or anyone else could do to spoil this thing that already stinks to the sky ,

summary: Mary Giordano is a bright, intelligent student who goes to a catholic school. She also has an addiction to mystery novels and detective magazines (hence the title of the movie), which inspire her to do her own detective work. When she starts snooping around on the case of a murderer of teenage girls, it gets her in hot water with her mentor Detective Jerry Gunn. But it also starts a team up with police cadet Tony Campbell. The two work together to find the murderer. But the closer Mary gets to solving the murder, the more danger she puts herself in of being the next victim.
translation:
That's a nice piece of work. Very sexy and rousing enough to keep my interest. The main drawback is that it looks like it was made for TV: full screen, and although there were several sex scenes, there was absolutely no nudity (but boy it was close!). Strange too, since Netflix shows that it was rated R. Nonetheless, very exciting, and I wish Alicia Silverstone had made more films like that.

A Netflix reviewer said that it was part of a series, but I could not figure out which series it was. I would like to find out, because this movie was so good.

Walt D in LV. 23.08.2005

summary: Shohei Sugiyama has attained all that he has wanted in life. But he is still depressed and unhappy. One day, he gathers up the courage to sign up for dancing lessons. He hopes they will rid his depression and help him get his life back together.
translation:
This film is about a man who has been overtaken by the accepted convention of success, trying to be always mobile, working hard to be proud of having his own home. He assumes that's all there is to it, until he accidentally starts dancing just because he wants to take a closer look at a beautiful girl he sees every day in the dance studio while he's on the subway.

He was first blinded to her, went to the dance class just to idolize her, but he finally let himself go and got into a dance. It finally becomes clear to him that there is more to life than to work yourself to death. There are a number of comic characters who also learn in the studio, giving the movie a lot of laughter and a sense of connectedness between the downtrodden.

There are also revelations about various characters, including the girl he initially admired, giving them some depth by showing their unclean past and their struggle to overcome them.

The dancing was also engaging, with the big competition in the end, but it's not the usual story where our underdog comes to the top by winning them. Instead, there are falls, revelations, and redemption.

All this makes it a moving and entertaining movie.

summary: Professor Wassermann (John Stacy) is asked by industry magnate Morgan Hunnicut (Eddie Faye) to lead an expedition to study the giant Yeti creature found frozen in a large ice block on Newfoundland's coast. The professor does not know that Hunnicut intends to use the prehistoric creature as a trademark of its multinational industrial group. A very big mistake.
translation:
I was at 7 when I first saw this movie. It was not that special, but a few years later I saw it again and it was a lot of fun, a lot :)

I think the best parts of the movie are: Yeti's body language and the "special effects" too ,

If you want to watch this movie, do not wait for a blockbuster made in Hollywood, also this movie was made out of about 1000 bucks :)

I have a copy of it.Film - and video version (but I do not think it was ever shown in cinemas)

Watch it, enjoy it !!! Yeti forever !!!

summary: Set before the events of the previous films. As group of strangers awaken with no memory to find they have been involuntarily placed in a maze containing deadly traps, a young man whose job is to watch over the Cube endeavors to rescue a woman trapped within.
translation:
I did not really like the first "Cube" movie. It was a good idea, but the annoying acting and the characters always kept me from liking it too much. I did not really feel the need to see its sequel, but when I heard that they were making a third film that would rather be a pre-history of the original. I was intrigued, thinking that maybe they would fix some of the original's problems and give us a memorable cast of characters. Well, I thought wrong.

"Cube Zero" starts well enough by introducing us to the two characters who are responsible for observing and preserving the endless maze of traps that plague people in the cube. The filmmakers manage to give the establishment of the everyday life of the two men a mysterious feeling. This raises several questions, the reason why people are sent there and the true nature of those who lead the entire operation. All of these are completely up to the viewer. Acting was a bit weak, but overall, the first half of the film moved relatively well.

As the story progresses, one of the two "watchers" begins to doubt seriously what he is doing. And later decides to help a group of people in the trap. Everything quickly dissolves into boring cheese.

Sent by the people who run the Cube program, we are introduced to the character "Jax". Together with his two subordinates play a major reason why this movie has failed. At the beginning of "Jax" he looks and speaks more like a third-rate villain straight out of a James Bond movie complete with the ever-popular "Glass Eye" that alone ruins any atmosphere created by the relatively nice tempo of the first half. What's more, it feels more like a comedy rather than a serious movie. With some unbelievably cheesy lines, the scriptwriter might get bored and he did not care. The action itself continues to deteriorate when the former "observer" hits the group in the dice. The entire interaction is painful to watch, as well as everything else that follows.

Once again, it's a waste of time for all those looking for a good horror movie.

summary: After a bitter breakup with his girlfriend, a photojournalist takes an assignment to an area in the Pyrenees Mountains in northern Spain. On his way, he meets a beautiful freelance writer, whom he convinces to join him. They stop at an ancient hotel and hear rumors that the nearby mountain is haunted by a coven of dangerous witches, but proceed there anyway.
translation:
This captivating (which should not be) inferior Spanish exploitation (rather tame, I would add) looks good, but not true? Let me express that again, huh? Actually the word "huh?" you would think pretty much. Nothing makes sense, nor does it try. I just do not know if it's complicated cryptic or just a nested confusion, but there's no denying how laconically uneventful, funny, and wordy it feels. Disjointed sequences (like this nasty opening with a little girl), dead cat, and fire) turn into a sparse story with photographer Mario (played by a puffing John Caffari, the mustache is a dead wrestler for Nintendos iconic Mario. What's the odds?), who digs his girlfriend's home and meets a young lady (a gorgeous fixing Patty Shepard), whom he asks to come with him on a photography assignment, where she disguised some in this remote mountain retreat Meet witches.

Look past the dried-up plot and wallow in what is simply a moody piece of atmospheric mechanisms and growing unrest. Ra√∫l Artigot draws only a few unusual images and scary passages, but for the most part he appears sporadically non-existent and unfocused as his writing. Ramon Semperes impressive cinematography characterizes the graceful, rich scenery, while we enjoy the picturesque views and pass the time leisurely. However, there are certain areas where it is too dark to see what is going on. Fernando Garc√≠a Morcillo's creepy, bombastic and overblown score combines with a compulsively dense atmosphere. The leads are capable, but there is also a robust group (the Pick V√≠ctor Israel) of secondary benefits.

Slowly with little interest, but this dreamy setup (that seems to go on and on) manages to watch you through to the end.

summary: Sexual satire about a young farmer who has had many bad experiences with women. He showers love and affection upon his pet pig, Amanda, saying she alone is worthy to be his wife. His "marriage" to Amanda causes a scandal in the community, almost mass hysteria.
translation:
FUTZ is the only show that was received in New York in the 1960s from the experimental theatrical movement (the origins of Off Off Broadway). While it's not for everyone, it's a really brilliant, grim, funny, even more deeply disturbing story of love, sex, personal freedom and revenge, a serious morality even more relevant at a time when Congress wants to ban gay marriage by destroying our constitution. History, however, is not about being gay - it's about love and sex that does not conform to social norms and therefore needs to be eradicated through violence and hatred. On the surface, it tells the story of a man who falls in love with a pig, but like any big fable, it's not really about animals, it's about something bigger - suffocating conformity in America.

The stage version gained international recognition in its original production, toured the US and Europe, and influenced almost every other drama that followed. Fortunately, we kept the show as well as originally planned, with the original cast and original director Tom O'Horgan (who also staged HAIR and Jesus Christ Superstar on Broadway).

This is not a mainstream, easy-to-take studio drama - this is an aggressive, disturbing, calm, deeply emotional, wildly imaginative piece of storytelling that you'll never forget. And it could just change the way you see the world ...

summary: A semiserious, often rollicking, multigenerational insider's look at the origins of surfing, the colorful and subversive birth of surf culture, and the mythology and lure of the big wave. This passionate and fluid film is without question the first authentic history of surfing from its humble Hawaiian beginnings to the big business it became to the still-rebellious universe it inhabits today. Riding Giants is a study in individuality and freedom, the pursuit and techniques of pure kinetic pleasure, and the risk taking and attitudes that characterize its leading figures. For some viewers, this is perhaps more than they ever wanted to know. But Peralta's detailed knowledge of the surfing lifestyle, its icons and locations, its boom and exploitation by the media, and the fascination it has held for young men for more than five decades is unparalleled and fuels this expedition for the expert and initiate alike. Closely chronicling the sometimes-life-and-death drama that big-wave riding ...
translation:
Impressive! Stacy Peralta has been following Dogtown and Z-Boys with an equally impressive documentary about the history of big-wave surf culture in America. Along with insider footage and interviews from surfing legends, we are immersed in the daring and free-spirited life of the early pioneers whose passion for sports has spawned an industry that touches the lives of millions today.

It gets to know these symbols and their stories that give the film its warmth. You can feel the respect that Peralta feels for this group as we hear reports from Greg Noll walking by a group of awesome surf surfers on the beach to challenge the 50-foot waves off Hawaii's north coast. Or Jeff Clark, who spent fifteen years surfing the outrageously dangerous Maverick off the coast of California, before he was discovered and became a surf destination in California. And the story of Laird Hamilton, the surf icon of today. Greg Greg Noll is reverently called Hamilton as the best surfer ever sent will cool my spine.

(Apart from that, Noll, Clark, and others were at Sundance screenings.) Noll described himself humbly as an old, Over the Mountain surfer .He was deeply touched by the spectator's reception of him and the movie and Clark were personally as personable as in the movie.

Riding Giants pays tribute to these exceptional athletes while giving us a glimpse into the scale and scary power of the waves they are trying to conquer greedy vertical drops needed to get into them, and the almost unfathomable combination of adrenaline and fear surfers experience every time they tackle a monster wave.

All that, and the movie has more. For those of us who did not live in California in the 1960s, we get a glimpse into the impact of surfing on American pop culture (and, to my surprise, the impact of the film Gidget on the Surfing!) Peralta also interweaves some technical aspects of the sport and the history of innovation in equipment. I'm not a surfer, but like the rest of the Sundance audience, I was absolutely mesmerized by this movie. Peralta sets his claim as the Big Kahuna of American documentary films.

summary: Baba (Rajini) an atheist, by a twist of fate, acquires magical powers from a divine source and takes on crooked politicians.
translation: Not the best movie of the actors. The director has focused on the star of the projected actor instead of giving a good entertainer. May be hero, his family and his sincere fans can enjoy it. But definitely not worth it for a neutral audience. The combat sequences are a total comedy. The dance moves in the song sequences are pathetic. The music is average. This movie was the biggest flop for the actor. Despite the hype about the movie, the movie failed miserably. Do not even think about watching this movement, even if you want to kill time. You can watch a few cartoons instead. A good movie fan can not digest this crap for 2 1/2 hours.

summary: In 1896, Jeff Webster sees the start of the Klondike gold rush as a golden opportunity to make a fortune in beef, and woe betide anyone standing in his way. He drives a cattle herd from Wyoming to Seattle, by ship to Skagway, and (after a delay caused by larcenous town boss Gannon) through the mountains to Dawson. There, he and his partner Ben Tatum get into the gold business themselves. Two lovely women fall for misanthropic Jeff, but he believes in every-man-for-himself, turning his back on growing lawlessness, until it finally strikes home.
translation: After losing his cattle herd to a dishonest law enforcement officer, a trail boss lands in the Yukon goldfields with a bad reputation and low chances of returning to the States. While there his luck turns for the best, until a pitch specter comes from the past. Good western with many old favorite faces in the lineup.

summary: This movie is the fictional story of computer programming genius Milo Hoffman after graduating from Stanford and getting out into the competitive world of computer software. In his contemplation of where to begin his career, he is contacted by Gary Winston whose character is loosely based on Bill Gates. Winston is the CEO of a company called NURV, and they are on the brink of completing the global communication's system, Synapse. They need Hoffman to help them meet their launch date, so after much thought and with the full support of his girlfriend Alice, he accepts the job. Tragedy soon after strikes and Milo becomes suspicious of the company he has been wrapped up in. He learns that trusting anyone could be a mistake, and that nothing is as it seems.
translation: Five minutes after this movie you realize that you've seen everything before. It is a KESSELZIMMER. It is THE COMPANY. And it's THE DEVIL ADVOCATE. And there are NO new elements here. Except for the all-encompassing Bill Gates allegory. Conspiracies are always good things for filmmaking, but why must it be so extreme? Kesselraum is a good movie because it seems - at least for a while - realistic. Everything is wrong in antitrust law. How realistic is it, for example, that your boss pays a scammer to be your girlfriend so you can work harder and control yourself? I would give it 1, but the soundtrack is OK, so 2/10.

summary: Feature-length version of the documentary TV series Πλανήτης Γη (2006), following the migration paths of four animal families.
translation:
The release date is 2009, not 2007 for this full-length documentary. It should more correctly be called "Earth, 2009". Secondly, allow me to respond to the complaints of some reviewers who have seen the 2006 television series "Planet Earth".

I have not seen this TV series, but here learned that this movie is full length version of this 2006 television series. I judge each film, on its own merit, not by its source. I judge the results for myself and the results of "Earth, 2009" are indeed outstanding. I reject this trivial complaint of some reviewers: that it is simply an enhanced version of the TV series "Planet Earth" from 2006. So what? It is not really important.

As a film fan and one who has seen dozens of nature documentaries in my life, I was amazed and very impressed with "Earth, 2009". This is the debut feature of Disney's new Disney Disney section, following in the footsteps of Walt Disney's seminal and Oscar-winning nature documentary films of the 1950s and 1960s.

Cinematography, film editing, music score, sound and narration are all excellent. There have been several other nature documentaries that have also been awarded in these categories. What truly distinguishes "Earth, 2009" is its scope. It literally covers the entire planet and covers all seven continents.

After my first look, it was obvious that this documentary required a tremendous amount of effort and time and talent.

Three production companies were needed for this great documentary.

"Earth, 2009" convincingly recounts the stories of four species on their long hikes spanning over a year The seasons start in January and end in December, from the North Pole to the South Pole.

Two special new high-tech cameras were used for this film: One camera has a 360-degree computer-controlled motorized rotating lens and the other is an HD camera with an amazing 1,000 frames per second. This film technique gave some scenes of "Earth, 2009" drama and beauty, especially the cheetah hunt and big white sharks that jumped out of the water to catch sea lions, and an aerial shot over the edge of the highest waterfall in the world. There are many breathtaking shots in this documentary.

Via cinematography, music score and narrative there is drama, sadness, humor and great beauty in this documentary. With a great musical score performed by the world-famous Berlin Philharmonic, excellent creative and technical cinematography, and James Earl Jones narrative, I consider "Earth, 2009" to be the largest documentary documentary on nature films of all time.

Five years of hard work, patience, talent and dedication have paid off very well here. This movie should be seen in all schools in the world. Among other things, I say an Oscar for the best documentary. Really, a stunning, amazing, exhilarating and great documentary.

Highly recommended

summary: Conrad and Sally Walden (Spencer Breslin and Dakota Fanning) are home alone with their pet fish. It is raining outside, and there is nothing to do. Until The Cat in the Hat ('Mike Myers') walks in the front door. He introduces them to their imagination, and at first it's all fun and games, until things get out of hand, and The Cat must go, go, go, before their parents get back.
translation:
Audrey, I know that you really appreciate the memory of your husband Ted, but PLEASE do his old justice and pay attention to his wishes. Dr. Seuss refused to license his characters during his lifetime for good reason. We ask that you please stop redeeming his stories, images, fantasies and characters. They are gutted by the powers of Hollywood and Broadway. The children of tomorrow will cling to these histrionic and grotesque interpretations that will forever pollute the loving warmth and innocence of his books.

It is indeed your property to do with it as you wish. I only wish you would listen to the advice of others for a while. Save what Dr. Seuss is left. Many Thanks.

summary: John's struggle to get out of a locked room with a sinister secret inside.
translation:
I am a big fan of David Lynch. However, this movie was a pretty disappointing experience. Apart from the background music? What really sets the mood of the movie? Almost all the qualities I associate with Lynch's work are missing. The visuals are boring, to say the least, and the dialogue is too vague and monotonous to be of interest.

This feels more like a film student awkwardly trying to do an artistic dogma film than the work of an experienced director. I've seen a lot of amateur films with far superior camera work, scenery, sound and script. This film lacks almost all artistic qualities. I feel like watching one of the Davids home videos produced during a weekend trip with some friends.

summary: Clifford Skridlow teaches at a small Chicago college run by his father. Conned into managing four prostitutes by their pimp, who skips town to escape the mob boss known as Mom, Clifford draws on his course in medieval literature in his quest to save the women from Mom.
translation: This is without doubt the worst movie I have ever seen. It's not funny. It is not interesting and should not have been done.

summary: Four sisters in New Zealand fall for four U.S. soldiers en route to the Pacific theater in WWII
translation:
Unusual? Yes!

Unusual backdrop for an American war movie, New Zealand.

Unusual theme, four sisters and their relationships with American soldiers, from one who is the illegitimate child of the dead son of a senator, to another who lives with seven marines (one after another) before he is murdered by her returning prisoner of war New Zealander husband.

Unusually, Paul Newman delivers such a poor performance so soon after his unforgettable role as Rocky Graziano in the ingenious "Somebody Up There loves me".

Unusual for two fine "stars" Joan Fontaine and Jean Simmons, leaving so little of themselves in a movie /> Unusual that I could try a review on such a Write a bad movie, give him a miss!

summary: Dr. Feinstone has everything, a beautiful wife and a successful career in dentistry, but, when he discovers his wife in an affair, he realizes that behind every clean, white surface lies the stench of decay. Having gone insane, he enacts cruel dental torture on his patients.
translation:
Not many films have really taken advantage of the fear of going to the dentist. Those in this profession have really intimidating-looking tools. Show screenwriters Dennis Paoli, Stuart Gordon, and Charles Finch that they have received a maximum shock-in-the-seat-shock-value from their premise.

Corbin Bernsen, in a nuanced presentation, is Alan Feinstone, dedicated dentist whose train jumps off the rails early. As an unbalanced obsessive-compulsive disorder, he begins to think of ideas of decay, even imagining them where there are none, and equates decay with the corruption of society in general. After seeing his unfaithful wife Brooke (Linda Hoffman) carry on with her pool boy, he decides to punish her. At the same time he is under pressure from a smarmy I.R.S. Agent (Earl Boen, known as Dr. Silberman of the "Terminator" franchise) to do a favor that the agent is silent about Feinstone's financial affairs. Feinstone begins to perceive everyone around him as being forfeit in one way or another, and he goes on a series of murders as police detective Gibbs (the ever-welcome Ken Foree) picks up his trail.

Director Brian Yuzna has great fun with the script. It allows some really nasty and remarkably entertaining gothic scenes that do just as well to create sympathy for the victims that thrill the audience. The script gives the Feinstone character some fine dialogues and is altogether pretty crafty and amusing, with big cans of jet-black humor (like Feinstone ordering a victim to "get his tongue out of the way!"). Brooke and I.R.S. Agent figure in particularly effective torture scenes. The makeup effects are pretty good for the most part. And the film does a good job of maintaining its forward momentum as Feinstone, with his relentless pursuit of perfection, moves from a respected pro to a killer in record time.

Foree, always cool and funny, is pretty much wasted in a standard detective role, but it's fun to watch Boen play his slimball part. Hoffman and Christa Sauls offer very attractive eye candy. And a pre-fame Mark Ruffalo can be seen in a minor supporting role. But that's all very much Bernsen's show as he sinks his teeth (excuse me for that phrase) into his plum-bearing role with full conviction.

"The Dentist" is one of the most original and interesting horror movies of the 1990s.

8/10

summary: A drunken, down-on-his-luck adventurer is hired by a wealthy man and his beautiful wife to take them on a hunting expedition in the jungle. After a while, though, the guide begins to suspect that there's more to the expedition than just hunting.
translation:
Although this is usually a cheesy jungle adventure movie, it does have some highlights - the settings are pretty nice and the pace of the adventure is good. You will not see it boring.

Keith is as airy as possible and plays the eponymous lead role, a rude drunk jungle guide who accompanies the rich boy Van Hoffman and his gorgeous wife Shower on a hunt expedition in cannibal land. He never takes things seriously. The shower is there as a decoration and Keith uses it extensively - she does not really have to do much. She is not the only woman to flaunt her body, and the lascivious aspects of the film make it about halfway to a T / A image.

There is nothing in this movie that would draw attention to or away from it. Produced to be shlock, it succeeds without fuss. A good 2 AM cable programmer.

summary: The first spaceship to Mars, presumed lost, is found in space and brought back to Earth by remote control. Only two from an initial crew of four are still alive, but one is unconscious due to an attached alien growth, while the other is traumatized, blocking out all memory of what happened. In hopes to save the unconscious crewman, the amnesiac is interrogated back into remembering. Those in charge thereby learn of the terrible dangers awaiting anyone venturing into the spooky, ruddy stillness of the very alien Martian ecosystem.
translation: Certainly no TV children's show on Saturday morning was so bad. After all, these producers had to count on the audience coming back. Well, in this horrible offer, they could at least count the money they had saved on sets. The script could have been a rejection of a long-forgotten space opera, with a few dingy lines added to cool guy Gerald Mohr to mumble to Naura Hayden. No director could have done anything decent with such a crazy story, so the action just tramples boringly. The spacecraft props are absurd - a Bulova wall clock and a portable typewriter, for example - but the planetary gear sets must be among the worst in the history of the movie. Most are rough drawings and everything is dipped in an often misaligned red light. Even Mohr's bare hairy chest serves as a support. And it's a bad one - as thin as the plot. Any viewer who can make it to the end of this movie will hear a message from the Martians - and will probably agree completely!

summary: A television show centered around a macho everyman, his loving wife, and their three precocious children.
translation: I love the episode where Jim becomes a Greenman. It is great! When Jim throws that little person through the window, the expression on his face is priceless. Then, when he starts addressing the priest in the name of his wife, only to find out she has become the Pee-Woman? Great writing and good casting together with great acting make this a must. I'm trying to find a particular photo from this episode. I would like to use it as my avatar on a message board because I think the Greenman is hilarious. Does anyone know where I can download a photo of Jim as Greenman? Can someone point me in the right direction to find such a photo?

summary: Trash is a coming of age drama set amongst the poverty stricken trailer parks of the deep South. In a spiraling tale of hatred, love and loyalty, two teenage friends realize that the only way for each of them to escape their miserable futures is by forever sacrificing the other.
translation: You need to give this action sketch to any would-be filmmakers arriving at the bus station in Hollywood. Then they fill in the gaps and put their story in the city or ghetto they just came from. You know exactly what this film is about, from the opening shot, four young guys playing in grainy slow motion, accompanied by voice-over narrations. Next stop after the bus station must be to buy stock footage of four boys playing in grainy slow motion. Once they grow up, it's easy to spot the author / director among the four. He is the calm, thoughtful, long-haired one who is never seen in his pants without his composition book. This means his outstanding writing talent will be his ticket from Hickville to Hollywood. Only here there is no literary talent. And if you still can not figure out who he is, here's a clue: the author and his character have the same middle name. It took more than an hour to find out that those twenties were still in school. What looked like a prison was apparently a high school, the director was the director. Once again, the poor, misunderstood rebel can throw anyone in the movie on the sidewalk, murder and plunder, but is powerless against his alcoholic father. How about striking back, boy, how are you all the others? Numerous fistfighting scenes for no apparent reason. Howling bad dialogue. Many scenes are out of focus. Cartoon characters appear again and again as little players and extras and draw unintentional laughter from the premiere audience. Exaggerated in extreme cases. And if you do not fully understand the self-important speeches or the slow-motion scenes, just listen to the arrogant music. It will recognize you and what you should feel. Poor Marisa Ryan has to earn many frequent flyer miles as she travels across the country, working in these amateur regional films. The biggest sin is that the public should feel sympathy for children slaughtering old women, running, robbing and stealing puppies chained to a tree while complaining about their sad, sad life. But if we could just get out of this city and go to college. Yes, that's the ticket. Why does every twenty-year-old filmmaker believe that his life so far is so important and so interesting that the world can not wait to see it on screen? If this film is as autobiographical as it seems, then the author should better look over his shoulder for policemen who carry cursory arrest warrants.

summary: Ancient codes hidden within the Torah reveal the secrets of global events, past (i.e., Hitler, the Kennedy assassination, the Gulf War), present, and future. One man (York) is after the Code, seeking the power to change the world as we know it... for the worse. Another (Van Dien) seeks the truth, risking his life and everything he stands for in order to stop him.
translation:
Yes, I admit, I cried in this movie. It was so incredibly disappointing that I could not help crying. TBN (Trinity Broadcasting Network) has done it again. First with the Million Dollar Man (ex-professional wrestler) on their program, and now that.

The Omega Code follows a stream of sketchy religious-oriented films. It was quite amusing, but at the same time annoying to find it so biblically inaccurate. The film follows what is known as "the Bible code" instead of following the biblical scriptures. This movie is extremely poorly made; from his writing to his directing to his hilarious horrible acting. It's depressing that people really get involved in this movie. It seemed more like a late-night movie that someone would watch on the US channel or a direct home video instead of a theatrical release movie.

I recommend you not to watch this movie, even if your life depended on it.

summary: After being wrongfully convicted of her father's murder and subsequently spending six years in prison, Bianca Foster (Williams) returns home to a new set of family problems. Determined to help, she takes a job at a resort, only to become romantically involved with business's engaged heir (Hutchinson).
translation:
No, not the administration of GWB, the Decider / Strutter / Smirker - but the mini series "Monarch Cove". Lifetime must have realized what a dog it was because the series was burned out in two episodes at once, most of them broadcast between 11:00 pm. Friday evening and 1 clock Saturday morning. Why I've watched the whole thing, I can only argue for weekly sudden convulsive attacks of masochism.

Most of the performers are unknowns who probably remain unknown. The only two identifiable names are Shirley Jones and Rachel Ward, who make the only proper appearances (Jones can not make it through the entire series - Happy Woman). By the way, Ward has become very old since her "Thorn Birds" days.

The only common thread in the plot - who murdered the heroine's father, who was wrongly convicted of murdering Dad - is released after six years in jail - stretched out so long and so hastily locked up that it does not matter to you who it is. There is a lot of "steamy" sex, multiple murders and any kind of rude behavior - of which hardly anything is interesting or credible. Most performers are not very attractive and definitely not talented. The writing and the direction is on par with the cast.

If you stay until the end, the postcard is a (very small) cry.

Consider being warned!

summary: Kimball Kinnison, a young man from the agricultural planet Mquie and his Valerian companinon, Buscirk find a dying man with a legendary crystal lens embedded in his hand. As the man was dying, he mysteriously passed on the Lens to Kim. With more companions to come by, Kim must find out the purpose of the Lens before the Boskone dynasty does.
translation:
"Secret of the Lens" may be a foolhardy all-time favorite of mine. The best and funniest of Kajawari Yoshiaki, known for splatter anime and sleazy hentai-ecchi anime. I wish he had more campiness like this.

My favorite scenes are the psychedelic CG sequence, the parts in which Lord Helumis blows up his failing henchmen, the party riots Bill causes (one of the funniest scenes). and whenever my favorite character, Worsle, appears.

Look at this.

ATTENTION: This is not for serious sophisticated anime fans!

summary: A night out on the town turns into a nightmare as six young college students find themselves hunted by a killer.
translation: No? Did not think so! Well, in that case, you just have to stay a long way from "Want to know a secret," since it's just the tenth pointless post-"scream" slander that has absolutely no redeemable value. The plot is extremely ridiculous; the characters are unbearably stupid, the gore factor is negligible and the whole thing is just boring! As you can already deduce from the title, this film is mainly inspired by "I still remember what you did last summer," as events take place in a similar environment and the murderer's motivations are equally stupid. Why someone wants to steal ideas from the trash like "IKWYDLS" is a mystery to me anyway. At the very least, this film could fall back on the precious shelf of Jennifer Love Hewitt, while the girls in this junk, besides being brainless, are also terribly unattractive. One year after her friend's unresolved murder, Beth Morgan, her new adulterous lover, and four other foolish college students go to Florida to spend her Spring Break vacation in a chic beach house. The killer has not made a move all year, but now he follows the gang to Florida and starts slaughtering them while leaving the titular message as a kind of business card. You really do not have to be a horror expert to quickly figure out which face hides behind the unspeakably ridiculous mask, and the authors' attempts to get you on the wrong track are downright embarrassing. Since the plot is so thin, most of the film is purely irrelevant, including the subplots relating to the incompetent Florida police force and the "mysterious" FBI inspector, who seems to have a personal touch. The murder happens inexplicably outside the screen (do not you hate it when that happens?), There's not even a free T & A to enjoy it, and you'd better not bring me into the quality of the dialogues.
